DOC.HEAD: Kidnapper of Freed U.S. Miner Arrested in Ecuador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Heimdal's comments, details, DELETES outdated material. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: One of the abductors of Scott Heimdal, the American gold miner who was kidnapped in Ecuador's jungle on April 28 and freed after 61 days in captivity, has been arrested, police said Wednesday. They identified him as a member of a Colombian guerrilla group who lived in neighboring Ecuador and said he was tied in with a Colombian drug trafficker who was freed from prison by a guerrilla attack. The police communique said, ``According to our investigations, the kidnappers of Scott Heimdal are Roberto Andres Moreno (and) his brother Ruben Dario, who are members of the People's Liberation Army, and Luis Pablo Tobar, a drug trafficker freed from the prison of Tena.'' In his hometown of Peoria, Ill., Heimdal said he had no way of knowing if those arrested were responsible for his kidnapping, and questioned whether they would ever be found. ``Those names mean nothing to me,'' Heimdal said in a telephone interview Wednesday night. ``I suppose it's possible, but not very. The jungle's a very, very big place. The only way I would know if it were them is if I saw a photograph.'' Heimdal said the name of the group that kidnapped him is the Popular Liberation Army, not the People's Liberation Army named in the police report. The police report said the brothers are from Ecuador and that Tobar is Colombian. Only Roberto Andres Moreno has been arrested, the report said. It gave his brother's name only as Ruben Dario. The People's Liberation Army operates along the Colombia-Ecuador border on the western edge of the Amazon rain forest. The communique gave no details of the arrest. It said, however, that Roberto Moreno had kept in contact with Tobar when Tobar was imprisoned in Tena, a village in Ecuador's eastern jungle. Colombian guerrillas attacked the prison in August 1988 and freed Tobar and other four Colombian drug traffickers, according to officials reports. Two police officers were killed. Heimdal's captors asked for ransom money to press their fight against the Colombian government. Heimdal, 28, was released June 29 after his family paid a ransom of $60,000. Most of the money came from donations from his hometown. Heimdal's parents came to Ecuador to secure his release following secret negotiations. They all left Quito for Peoria on July 2. Last April 28, a band of men wearing camouflage uniforms and carrying assault rifles seized Heimdal when he was in a canoe Heimdal was traveling on the Bermeja River. The kidnapping took place in the jungle about five miles from the Colombian border and 100 miles northeast of Quito. Heimdal had been working with IMINCO, a gold mining company, since October. He operated electronic equipment to locate gold deposits on the river bottom, and also oversaw construction of a large dredge.

DOC.HEAD: Departing Red Army Soldiers Selling Arms, Police Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet armed forces may be leaving Hungary but it seems some of their weapons are staying behind. There have been persistent reports of illegal traffic in firearms from a district of the capital that is home to a Russian base, the Magyar Hirlap newspaper reported Tuesday. It said it had learned that a heavy machine gun that can be mounted on an armored vehicle sells for $1,500 and a machine gun can be had for between $50 and $410. Bullets usually cost just over a penny apiece. The newspaper, quoting police sources, said that in one incident a Red Army soldier reported having been approached last month by a Hungarian man and a woman who said they wanted to buy his AK-47 assault rifle. Soviet military authorities alerted Hungarian police, who found out that the would-be buyers were a Hungarian bricklayer and a prostitute. The two were detained and then released since they could not be charged with any crime, the newspaper said. The paper quoted local precinct police chief Capt. Arpad Szabadi as saying two Hungarian soldiers were caught recently with duffel bags filled with automatic pistol parts that they said they bought from Soviet soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: News Agency Says More Than 43,000 Germans Died in Soviet Camps After War
DOC.TEXT: More than 43,000 Germans died in Soviet internment camps that were set up in what is now East Germany after World War II, the East Germany news agency ADN says. Nearly all of them died of illnesses such as tuberculosis, the agency said in a report Tuesday. The news agency said its report was based on information obtained by East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel during a visit to Soviet Union. More than 122,000 Germans were interned by the Soviets from 1945 to 1950, the agency said, and of those, 42,889 died of sickness and 756 were condemned to death by a military court. Another 12,770 were deported to the Soviet Union, and 6,680 were transferred to prisoner of war camps, ADN said, without elaborating. The others were released or escaped, the news agency added. Georgi Kynin, deputy head of the division for diplomatic history in Moscow's Foreign Ministry, was quoted as saying the camps were necessary to remove fascism and militarist elements from German society. He said the number of prisoners executed accounted for less than 1 percent of those interned. He said 4 million Soviet soldiers had died in Nazi concentration camps.

DOC.HEAD: Police Reportedly Detain ANC Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with ANC spokesman reporting detention of ANC leader, edits to trim. No pickup. ^By LAURINDA KEYS
DOC.TEXT:
An African National Congress leader who returned from exile under a government grant of immunity has reportedly been detained by police for questioning in an investigation of guerrilla activities, an ANC spokesman said Thursday. Chief ANC spokesman Ahmed Kathrada said he received information from a reliable source Wednesday night about the detention of Mac Maharaj, a fellow member of the ANC's 35-person National Executive Committee. Maharaj, who is affiliated with the South African Communist Party, was among the first of the exiled ANC leaders to return to South Africa this spring after the white-minority government legalized the black nationalist movement. He had worked at the ANC's exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. President F.W. de Klerk granted temporary immunity from prosecution to members of the ANC's executive committee to allow them to return to the country for negotiations. The immunity covered past offenses, but not activities considered illegal since the exiles' return. Kathrada would not reveal the source for his information about Maharaj's detention, but described it as reliable. Dozens of ANC guerrillas who recently infiltrated the country have been arrested, according to South African press reports. Police say they have seized weapons including grenade launchers, mines and combat rifles. Many of those arrested are being held under the Internal Security Act, which allows indefinite detention without trial. Kathrada said the ANC will discuss the recent wave of arrests with the government and reiterated his organization's objections to the Internal Security Act. Police spokesmen were unable early Thursday to confirm the report of Maharaj's arrest. They have not named any of the others detained for questioning in the investigation of ANC guerrilla activities. The ANC's internal chairman Walter Sisulu has said that 150 ANC members have been arrested recently and that the detentions go against the spirit of the talks held between the ANC and the government in May. The ANC has confirmed that its guerrillas continue to infiltrate South Africa, but denies police and media reports of an ANC plot to seize power if political negotiations fail.
The ANC supports a guerrilla campaign against the white-led government, but it has not carried out any major attacks this year.
The ANC, the country's leading black opposition group, says it will not suspend or call off its ineffective armed struggle until a formal treaty is negotiated with the government.
De Klerk has rejected demands by conservative whites that he break off talks with the ANC because of the reported guerrilla activities. De Klerk says he will meet Aug. 6 with Nelson Mandela and other top ANC leaders to try and clear the way for negotiations on sharing political power with the black majority.
The ANC says that before formal constitutional negotiations can begin the government must allow 20,000 ANC exiles to return without fear of arrest and release some 3,000 people convicted of politically motivated crimes. On Wednesday night, Mandela praised thousands of armed men and boys for defending their neighborhoods in a township where at least 21 people died this week in fighting between black factions. ``You have the support of the ANC in everything that you do,'' the leader of the African National Congress told the crowd of 2,000, who waved spears, axes, sticks and chairlegs and chanted ``ANC!'' in the township of Sebokeng. Mandela pleaded for Sebokeng to return to normal after three days of fighting, arson, street blockades, work and school boycotts. Residents and police say at least 21 people died Sunday after members of the Zulu-based Inkatha party headed by Mangosuthu Buthelezi staged a rally in Sebokeng, south of Johannesburg. Armed Inkatha members left the rally and clashed with township residents, who were warned for days by ANC leaders that Inkatha planned to attack them. Fighting continued sporadically Tuesday night and spread to neighboring Evaton. Mandela, deputy president of the ANC, said Sebokeng was an ANC stronghold, and blamed the violence on Inkatha. ``We are happy to note that you made a stand against the thugs and killers who came from outside in order to kill our people,'' he told the angry crowd of young blacks. The Inkatha vs. ANC violence has killed 5,000 people in Natal province the past five years. The Sebokeng battle was the worst outbreak of the feud outside Natal. Both the ANC and Inkatha oppose apartheid, but differ on ways to fight racial segregation in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Arthur Strengthens in Caribbean
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to UPDATE with storm's position at 10 p.m.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Arthur, with heavy rains and wind up to 70 mph, strengthened Wednesday and forecasters warned that it could turn into a hurricane threatening parts of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic. The Dominican Republic issued a tropical storm watch for the south coast of the island after Arthur pushed across the Windward Islands and into the Caribbean Sea. A similar watch was in effect for the south coast of Puerto Rico. Forecasters said a hurricane watch could be issued for parts of those areas late Wednesday. Arthur was expected to ``remain very near to hurricane intensity'' through early Thursday without reaching sustained winds of 74 mph that would classify it as a hurricane, said Mark Zimmer, hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``We think that there is more than a 50-50 percent chance that it won't become a hurricane,'' he said. ``But there is certainly the chance that in the next 12 to 18 hours it could go ahead and reach hurricane intensity.'' At 10 p.m. EDT, Arthur was centered near latitude 14.2 north and longitude 65.5 west, or about 420 miles southeast of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. It was moving northwest at about 15 mph and was expected to continue that motion through the next day or two, said Bob Sheets, director of the hurricane center. Arthur, the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season's first named storm, grew from a tropical depression, the second of the 1990 season, that formed Sunday in the open Atlantic. The hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: North, South Korea Sign Agreement on Prime Ministers' Meetings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 7th `Meanwhile, five' to UPDATE with five North Koreans arriving at border, but crossing in question; pickup 8th graf pvs, `The North...'
DOC.TEXT: The two Koreas signed a historic agreement Thursday setting up the first meetings between prime ministers of the hostile states since the Korean peninsula was divided more than 40 years ago. The 19-point agreement calls for meetings in Seoul from Sept. 4-7 to discuss the easing of political and military confrontations, multilateral exchanges and cooperation on the divided peninsula. A second meeting is to be held in the Communist North Korean capital of Pyongyang from Oct. 16-19. ``This precious fruit will open a decisive chapter in a road to ending national division and achieving peaceful unification,'' said Song Han-ho, the chief South Korean delegate. ``We can no longer shun the changing international situation,'' he said. ``We should rather actively respond to this and use it as an opportunity to pursue national prosperity and forging a new history.'' Representatives of both countries signed the agreement in the truce village of Panmunjom inside the 2{-mile-wide Demilitarized Zone separating the two Koreas. Later Thursday, five North Koreans arrived on the northern side of the border, presumably in preparation to cross into South Korea. A delay in their arrival, however, was first blamed on bad weather and later on last-minute meetings. South Korean officials finally said there were indications the crossing might be called off, but they did not elaborate. The North Koreans would be the first to cross the border with the approval of both governments since 1985, when dozens of separated family members were allowed brief reunions. The North Koreans were scheduled to take part in a two-day conference with South Korean opposition activists to discuss plans for an unprecedented joint rally calling for unification of their divided peninsula. Both nations desire unification but on their own terms. Three South Korean dissidents were allowed into the border security area to wait for the North Koreans, while dozens of others prepared to welcome them a few miles away. ``Let's become one nation!'' and ``Tear down the iron wall of division'' read placards at the welcome site. About 100 radical students sang solidarity songs while awaiting the North Koreans. Twelve riot police buses were parked in the area, but police remained out of sight. South Korean dissidents said the unification rally was expected to be held in Panmunjom on Aug. 15 _ a sentimental holiday on both sides of the border celebrating the 1945 liberation of Korea after 35 years of Japanese colonial rule. The rally would mark the first contact between civilian organizations of the two Koreas. In the past, South Korean authorities have blocked such contacts out of fear they could turn into radical anti-government protests. The planned prime ministers' meetings and the unification rally could serve as indicators of the future course of relations between Communist North Korea and pro-Western South Korea _ bitter enemies for more than four decades. The Korean peninsula was divided after World War II, and two separate governments were formed in 1948. North and South Korea fought a three-year war that ended in 1953. No peace treaty has been signed and they are still technically at war. By signing the accord for a prime ministers meeting, North Korea grants tacit recognition to the legitimacy of the Seoul government, a recognition denied since 1948. Prime Ministers Kang Young-hoon of South Korea and Yon Hyung Muk of North Korea are considered figureheads in their respective governments with limited policy-making roles. But their meeting is symbolically significant because it would be the highest-level contacts ever between the two rival states. The most powerful figures in the two countries are President Roh Tae-woo of South Korea and Kim Il Sung, the North Korean president and Communist leader. Despite sporadic talks on exchanges and easing tension, there has been little real progress in improving relations between the Koreas. The Korean border is one of the most heavily fortified in the world. More than 1.5 million troops are deployed on both sides. There is no mail, travel or other communication between the two sides. Last week, Roh proposed that the border be opened for five days in mid-August on a trial basis, allowing people on both sides free travel. North Korea rejected Roh's proposal, but has said it is willing to open the border on a limited basis on Aug. 15 to Koreans desiring unification. The North also demanded that Seoul scrap its anti-Communist national security laws and release prisoners jailed for promoting unification.

DOC.HEAD: Spider Expert Accuses Hollywood of Spinning Web of Deceit
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The new summertime movie thriller, ``Arachnophobia,'' is bugging Dr. Michael H. Robinson, a spider expert who accuses Hollywood of spinning a web of deceit about his favorite creepy-crawly. ``It's a pity to give spiders a bad name,'' says Robinson, director of the National Zoo and former director of the American Arachnological Society. ``It's very sad that we should be so irrational about them and see movies that reinforce all those ancient, primitive fears about spiders.'' Robinson, an English-born biologist, spent 20 years studying spiders in Panama, Papua New Guinea and more than a dozen other tropical countries. He was outraged when he saw a newspaper advertisement for the Steven Spielberg-Frank Marshall movie about a monstrous vampire spider that terrorizes a California family. ``Eight legs, two fangs and an attitude,'' the ad reads. It's ``Jaws with legs,'' warns one film critic. ``Arachnophobia,'' which means ``fear of spiders,'' is about a huge Venezuelan spider that hitchhikes in a coffin to a small town in California. Besides breeding an army of deadly offspring, it leaps to sink its fangs into human victims, paralyzing them in seconds with a lethal neurotoxin and sucking their bodies dry. Robinson immediately summoned a reporter to issue a protest. ``This bloody movie is making horrific allegations about spiders, and they are so important to the ecology of the world and so incredibly beneficial to mankind that I decided they need some good press,'' he said. Robinson hailed spiders as nature's pest exterminator, ridding the Earth of billions and billions of houseflies, roaches, mosquitoes and other insects every year. Without spiders, he said, human beings would be overwhelmed by winged creatures that would destroy crops and threaten to leave the planet virtually uninhabitable. ``Ordinary spiders are perfectly harmless and they are marvelous friends to have around the house,'' Robinson said. If they give you a severe case of the shudders, he said, simply cover them with a water glass, slide a sheet of paper underneath and carry them safely outside the house. Don't stomp on them or flush them down the toilet, he pleaded. Not only are spiders great for gobbling pests, Robinson said, but they are wonderful objects of scientific study. ``The sex life of spiders is absolutely bizarre,'' he said. A lot of the details can't be published in a family newspaper, but Robinson speaks in awed tones of the antenna-like things on a male spider's forehead that suck up sperm deposits like old-fashioned fountain pens. In his elaborate courtship ritual, he said, the male spins a silk ``mating thread'' and serenades his female friend by strumming it like a guitar. And during their nuptial embrace, he said, ``every hair stands on end _ it's quite exciting to see.'' Of the thousands of spider species in the world, Robinson said, only three are poisonous to humans _ the black widow, the brown recluse and the dreaded Australian funnel web spider, or Atrax robustus, which is ``very aggressive'' and whose repeated bites will kill a person within a few hours. The tarantulas used in filming ``Arachnophobia'' actually are pretty innocuous, Robinson said. Their main weapon is not their venom, which is no more dangerous than a bee sting, but their ability to launch clouds of barbed hairs that produce an irritating skin rash. The American Association of Poison Control Centers says it has reports of only two human fatalities from spider bites in the United States in a recent three-year period. Both involved elderly people with medical complications, a spokeswoman said. Even Little Miss Muffett had nothing to fear from spiders. Robinson said the nursery rhyme heroine was a real-life little girl named Patience Muffett, who not only shared her seat with spiders but apparently ate them, too. Her father was Dr. Thomas Muffett, a 16th century English physician who frequently prescribed pills containing spiders to treat his patients, including Patience.

DOC.HEAD: He's Serious and Studious, Popular and Funny, But Somewhat of a Mystery
DOC.TEXT: David Souter's start in upholding the law came at Concord High School, where classmates pegged the popular member of the hall traffic squad as destined for bigger and better things. Their prediction has proven true _ Souter is a Senate confirmation away from one of the nation's highest honors, a seat on the Supreme Court. Yet it appears his meteoric rise in the legal community has done little to change the man whom classmate John Prowse remembers from his traffic squad days. ``I guess that was the first enforcement duty that he had and let me tell you, he was good at it,'' Prowse said in an interview Tuesday. ``Soutie,'' as Souter's classmates called him, still lives in the same house he grew up in, a modest clapboard and shingled building tucked away on a tiny dirt road in Weare, a town of 4,500 people a dozen miles from Concord. And judging from the praise being heaped on him from fellow lawyers and judges, he is viewed no differently now than 33 years ago, when Concord's Class of '57 voted him most sophisticated, most literary and most likely to succeed. The life of the 50-year-old bachelor now is most likely to be dissected, as the Senate prepares for confirmation hearings and interest groups involved in the abortion debate and other contentious issues scour Souter's record for hints of how he might vote as a Supreme Court justice. Friends and associates say people will find that Souter the man is much like Souter the boy _ modest, considerate, frugal, studious, humorous and anything but controversial. He has a small circle of friends, choosing instead to spent much of his time alone, studying and interpreting the law. His breaks for recreation are spent hiking the hills and mountains of New Hampshire, his home since age 11. ``I'm very happy to go off alone,'' Souter once said. Prowse remembers his boyhood friend ``as one of the rare people who transcended all the cliques in high school _ we called them the jocks and the brains back then. Everyone thought very highly of him.'' He was an honor student, student council member and yearbook staffer, beginning his lifelong hobbies of collecting books and stamps while gaining a reputation as an intellectual. Friends say Souter balances his bookwormish image with a biting sense of humor. On one of his few not-so-good days at high school, a teacher returned a paper to Souter with the admonition it was so bad ``he should take it home and wrap the garbage with it,'' Prowse says. ``I'm not in the habit of wrapping my garbage in bond paper,'' was Souter's quick retort, according to Prowse, who said his friend meant no disrespect but often used his dry wit to break up school monotony. Prowse laughs today at a yearbook reference that Souter enjoyed ``giving and attending scandalous parties.'' ``This was the 1950s, when scandalous meant that the parents weren't home,'' Prowse said. ``Pot then was something you put on the stove and grass was something that you mowed. And most of us didn't have our first beer until we were in the military or sophomores in college.'' Friends now say Souter rarely stays long at social functions, generally saying he needs to go home to work. That's where the White House found him Sunday, tucked away in the house that could easily be mistaken for vacant, its mailbox listing to the left, its paint chipping and a doghouse out back all but overrun with high grass. His love of the outdoors is easily understandable. The roads leading to the house offer a stunning view of the state's rolling hills; the nighttime sky is breathtaking. Souter's dedication to his work, friends say, can be traced to his youth, when he often lingered so long at New Hampshire Historical Society exhibits that he had to be asked to leave. He exhibited similar commitment during stints as an overseer of Dartmouth Medical School and as a board member and president of Concord Hospital, colleagues say. ``I never worked so hard in my life than when he was here,'' said the hospital's current president, Richard Warner. But while serving as master of ceremonies for a retirement party, Souter ``displayed the most fantastic, dry sense of humor that you can imagine.'' Souter lived with his mother most of his life but she now resides in nearby Concord in a retirement home. Now 82, she takes his confirmation for granted and says she will miss his frequent visits. The nomination has brought a gush of pride to New Hampshire. At Cinder's Country store, a few miles from Souter's home, an outdoor sign promoting the pizza was rearranged Tuesday so a new message could be added in the middle: ``Good Luck David Souter!''

DOC.HEAD: Poacher, Smuggler And Alleged Cop Killer is India's Robin Hood ^An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: He haunts the forbidding jungles of south India with his band of thieves, slaughtering elephants for their ivory and smuggling tons of fragrant sandalwood. Police want him for the murders of 20 policemen and forest officers. Residents in this poor village of iron-red earth worship him as a Robin Hood and priest. He's built them temples, stocked a reservoir with fish and attends wedding ceremonies incognito, presenting newlyweds with gifts. He appears to have friends in high places and once escaped police custody, reportedly by paying a $17,000 bribe. His only name is Veerappan. The 38-year-old outlaw is India's most wanted man, and he's managed to elude a dragnet of hundreds of officers. In April, after the killings of four police officers, two southern states of Karnataka and Tamil Nadu formed a task force of more than 800 officers to catch him. The manhunt, Operation Snap, is the biggest in India's 43 years as an independent country. The investigation in Karnataka is led by K.U. Shetty, a 51-year-old inspector general of police who has vowed to capture the outlaw alive. In addition to hundreds of officers, Shetty is using two helicopters, night vision devices, jeeps, automatic weapons and high-tech communications equipment. The operation recently took over Veerappan's hometown of Gopinatham, turning the local elementary school into its headquarters. In Tamil Nadu, Superintendent of Police Krishnaswami Gopalakrishnan wants Veerappan dead. Gopalakrishnan, a 36-year-old former karate instructor with a penchant for gold chains, has formed a band of 14 highly trained men _ dubbed ``The Liquidators'' _ for the task. ``I don't need all that fancy stuff like helicopters,'' he said in an interview several days after emerging from a three-week hunt in the jungle. ``We're just going to blow him away.'' Gopalakrishnan's men recently gave him a brass statue of Sir Lancelot, the legendary British knight, ``to motivate me to slay this dragon,'' he said with a loud laugh. So far, Veerappan remains on the lam in the forests, often sleeping in two places during the night. Known for his thick black mustache and protruding adam's apple, Veerappan had a jungle wedding in January to a shepherd's teen-age daughter. Soon afterward, Veerappan allegedly killed again in his hometown. While more than 250 officers slept in barracks 50 feet away, someone crept into the house of an alleged police informant at 3:15 a.m. and shot him as he slept. Police call Veerappan a one-man ecological disaster. In his two decades in the jungle, they say he has killed 500 elephants for their tusks and smuggled out thousands of tons of sandalwood, which is used for oils, soap and furniture. It is sent mostly to the Middle East. The main problem in catching Veerappan is that few villagers are willing to help, police say. When they do, horrible things happen. In January 1989, Veerappan invited five men whom he suspected were police informers to a village feast. As they washed their hands before the meal, police say Veerappan stood behind them with an elephant gun and fired. His men later chopped the bodies into pieces and floated them down the nearby Cauvery River in gunny sacks. ``I will say nothing about Veerappan except that he's a good man and pays well,'' said Kumar Gounder, an elderly villager in Gopinatham who cuts sandalwood for the fugitive. ``When my child was sick he gave me medicine.'' Numerous news reports say Veerappan and his smuggling ring are linked to officials in Karnataka state who profit from his schemes. In November 1986, a forest service officer captured Veerappan while he was shopping for weapons in a gun store in Bangalore, Karnataka's capital. He turned Veerappan over to police. A few days later Veerappan escaped. Police at the time said he oiled his hands and slipped off his handcuffs. Subsequent news reports said Veerappan paid thousands of dollars to gain his freedom. Veerappan started his career as an apprentice to a legendary elephant poacher, who abandoned crime 10 years ago after his son became a judge. Veerappan's parents were farmers, tilling the poor earth around the Kollegal Forest. Just a few generations earlier, his people lived in the jungle as members of the nomadic Padiachi Gounder tribe. A lack of opportunity in Gopinatham turned Veerappan and his two brothers to crime. Police have already jailed his brothers on murder and robbery charges. Only when authorities linked Veerappan and his men to the deaths of police officers did the manhunt begin in earnest. But there has been criticism of the operation to hunt down Veerappan. Karnataka's state assembly recently debated a proposal to disband the task force because it was making little progress. Gopalakrishnan also has voiced concern that his colleagues on the other side of the state border are not aggressive enough. ``What do you mean, they arrested them?'' he said after learning of the recent capture of two alleged gang members. ``The job is to liquidate them.''

DOC.HEAD: Castro Sees Merit in Higher Pay for Some Workers
LaserPhoto HAV6
DOC.TEXT: Cuba may tout itself as a bastion of Communism in the Western hemisphere, but there's evidence of creeping capitalism: Fidel Castro is an enthusiastic advocate of bigger paychecks for workers in key areas of the economy. The Cuban president and revolutionary leader, faced with cuts in Soviet aid that will force his country to sink or swim, has come a long way from the view that workers could be induced by moral suasion to increase their output. In a recent speech, Castro railed against what he called technocrats who had the ``crazy idea'' that farm workers would exert themselves while earning 80 pesos a month, less than $70. He expressed admiration for the way in which the most developed capitalist countries, such as Japan, have been able to maintain high production by subsidizing farm income. He said farmers should be paid whatever is required for them to produce more. In the past, Castro has resisted using increased pay to boost production, arguing that other alternatives must be explored. Cuba also is experimenting with a new system under which workers in key sectors such as tourist hotel construction can earn more than doctors and other professionals. Cuban officials now believe the surest path out of the current economic crisis is through increased tourism from countries with convertible currencies _ Canada, West Germany, Spain and Italy. To speed construction at some tourism projects, workers get not only premium pay but also easier access to prized appliances such as color televisions. They are not asked to perform off-hours ``volunteer'' work, a common practice in Cuba, and they get to live in quarters far more comfortable than the average Cuban, officials say. The work is arduous, the laborers live away from their families but the material rewards are substantial. A Cuban journalist said the perquisites offered to these workers are such that there have been angry clashes with less privileged workers. But Castro apparently feels that a bit of class warfare is a small price to pay if it means that Cuba will be able to reverse its steady economic decline. The need for dollars has become more acute now that Cuba, because of uncertainty over future economic dealings with the Soviet Union, may need hard cash to meet its oil needs. Under an economic cooperation agreement, the Soviets provide Cuba with about 90 million barrels of oil annually. Even in inflated dollars, the tourism income is only a fraction of what it was during the last year before Castro came to power, 1958. The government is hoping for an increase of almost five-fold in the number of tourists between now and 1995. Castro's reforms could boost production but they also carry the risk of bringing to Cuba some of the ills of capitalist society. For example, laggard workers on some priority projects are subject to dismissal, a penalty once unheard of. There also is a campaign to make companies self-financing and to put an end to inflated payrolls _ an ailment that Castro says has afflicted Cuba for all 31 years of the revolution. Reform of this type has meant an increase in unemployment. The government has long since dropped the claim that every Cuban in the labor force has a job. Throngs of people can be seen each day at the government-run employment office. An added element in the reform campaign is that people are being encouraged as never before to speak their minds about the revolution's shortcomings. While constructive criticism is welcome nowadays, there is a low tolerance threshold for Cubans who cross the line of criticism into opposition. For these Cubans, the price often is imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Souter Nomination Temporarily Defuses Abortion Fight
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's first appointment to the Supreme Court _ and the speed of the announcement _ are helping him score points with conservatives and moderates while temporarily defusing the emotional abortion argument. Moderates generally seem comfortable with the fact that David H. Souter, although billed as a conservative, has left no paper trail yet as a federal appeals court judge, particularly on the abortion issue. And conservatives seem to be rejoicing in the mere fact that Souter came with a strong recommendation from White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. Since Sununu is the Republican right wing's unofficial liaison with the White House, his seal of approval must mean that Souter's conservative credentials are impeccable, the reasoning goes. And while Bush has sought to minimize Sununu's role in Souter's selection, senior White House officials suggest privately that the former New Hampshire governor's role was one of direct advocacy for the man he placed on his state Supreme Court in 1983. Bush's quick naming of Souter caught abortion rights activists and opponents off guard, cutting off any efforts on their part to mount massive pre-nomination lobbying campaigns. But at the same time, some White House officials privately have voiced concern that the president's rapid naming of Souter _ mainly with only Sununu vouching for him _ has short-circuited the system of elaborate background checks. Although his background was routinely checked when he was nominated earlier this year to the federal appeals court in Boston, he as yet has not received the degree of scrutiny to which other high-level appointees have been subject. And, while Souter's lifestyle seems spartan and his judicial views seem strict constructionist, some administration conservatives suggest there is a high potential for surprise once Souter is on the bench. Bush for the time being seems to be having it both ways with the appointment _ not alienating either conservatives or moderates. And it isn't the first time his administration has been able to gloss over a controversial subject and appease rival wings of the party at the same time. For instance, Vice President Dan Quayle often seem at odds with Bush on issues involving relations with the Soviet Union, taking a harder-line stand. When that happens, spokesmen for both Bush and Quayle quickly insist the two leaders are on the same wavelength _ when, in fact, Quayle's words have been mainly designed for conservative audiences. Sununu has been known to practice the same verbal sleight-of-hand. For instance, shortly after Bush entered budget negotiations pledging there were ``no preconditions,'' Sununu was putting out the word that the president likely would reject any tax proposal made by Democrats. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater disavowed Sununu's comments, saying they didn't reflect the views of the president. But was Sununu in the doghouse? Not on your life. His words were designed to provide a reassuring signal to conservatives that the president wasn't about to abandon his opposition to new taxes. Of course, that was before Bush specifically revoked his ``no new taxes'' pledge. On the abortion issue, Bush has managed to soften some of the edges of his position even as he asserts that he's strongly anti-abortion. Bush says he opposes government funding for any abortions other than those to save the life of the mother. But he also says that if there isn't government money involved supports a woman's right to abortion in cases of rape or incest. Earlier in his career, Bush voiced support for the Roe Vs. Wade Supreme Court ruling that he now says he would like to see overturned. There has always been a perception among some women's groups that first lady Barbara Bush does not share her president's anti-abortion views. She declines to address the issue; but her silence only reinforces that perception and further blurs the edges of Bush's stance. This may have helped Bush escape some of the vitriol that pro-choice activists have directed at other political leaders, including former President Reagan, who oppose abortion rights. In the same way, Sununu's role in the selection of Souter for the Supreme Court is enabling Bush to escape criticism from anti-abortion activists who would have preferred a candidate with a proven judicial anti-abortion record. Meanwhile, Bush has said his position has not changed on abortion _ at least since the last time he changed it. But his record for standing by a position no longer has much credibility _ even with Republican audiences _ since his about-face on no new taxes. A GOP audience in Philadelphia laughed on Tuesday when he said he was going to leave before the broccoli was served; but it howled and applauded when he added: ``I'm going to stay with my position. You know, I never change my position on anything.''
