DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: New Energy Taxes Would Hurt Farmers, Rural Residents, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: A move to impose energy taxes as a way of trimming the federal budget deficit would severely hurt farmers and small-town people, says the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association. Rural electric systems operate at cost and are owned by their customers, said Bob Bergland, executive vice president of the association. Any price increase caused by energy taxes would be paid by consumers. ``Rural consumers can't escape,'' Bergland said Tuesday. ``They are the equity owners of the electric systems which provide electricity to them.'' Bergland, who was secretary of agriculture in the Carter administration, joined natural gas and electric utility leaders to protest any move by the Bush administration to raise money by imposing new energy taxes. One type of tax that has been suggested would base the tax on the amount of carbon in the fuel. Coal, petroleum and natural gas would be taxed, but nuclear, hydroelectric and solar energy would not because they contain no carbon, an air pollutant. Still another plan would base the tax on the amount of energy, measured in British thermal units, or BTUs, that a fuel contains. The BTU tax would apply to all fuels. Bergland, whose member co-ops serve more than 25 million people, said the rural economy has ``taken severe shocks'' the last decade through droughts, floods, falling commodity prices, plummeting land price and a sharp decline in federal funding for rural areas. ``Energy taxes will unfairly penalize rural areas which already have higher electricity rates, either by driving up the price of fuel used to generate electricity or by taxing the selling price of electricity,'' he said. A joint statement protesting the use of energy taxes was signed by Bergland; George Lawrence, president of the American Gas Association; Tom Kuhn, president of the Edison Electric Institute; and Larry Hobart, executive director of the American Public Power Association. ``The burden of broad-based energy taxes will fall unevenly across consumers and income classes, among industries and across regions of the country,'' the statement said. ``This is unfair and inequitable taxation.'' BTU and carbon-content taxes were described as ``inherently regressive.'' Such taxes were said capable of raising at least $14 billion a year. ``Heating, lighting, cooking and water heating are not luxuries but essentials,'' the statement said. ``Lower-income families already pay three to four times more of their income for energy than the average American family.''

The Agriculture Department is looking for a better scarecrow and is ready to hire a top scientist to help design one. That's not the exact reason, but it's close. The project is one of six new post-doctoral research jobs USDA has created for studies in plant and animal science. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the six scientists selected will be able to work for two to four years. He said the salaries range from $24,705 to $42,601 per year. Glosser said the objective is to obtain needed research in support of the agency's regulatory programs. Another goal is to attract first-rate scientific talent to the field of plant and animal health. ``Contact with participants will continue to benefit us long after the post-doctoral projects have been completed,'' he said. The bird-scaring project is located at the Monell Chemical Senses Center at the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia. As the APHIS report explained, the project ``will study the psychology, neurobiology, chemical ecology and analytical chemistry involved in motivating birds to fly away and not come back.'' Birds have become major pests on many farms, damaging enterprises as diverse as fish farms, fruit orchards and grain fields, the agency said. Existing devices don't do the job effectively. More information and applications for the post-doctoral positions are available from: USDA, APHIS, Recruitment and Development, 236 Federal Building, Hyattsville, Md. 20782, or call 1-800-762-2738.

Kiwifruit is a native of New Zealand and is named after the country's national bird, the flightless kiwi. But a trade report by the Agriculture Department says Italy is expected to become the world's leading producer of kiwifruit. Italian production was 210,000 metric tons in 1989, up 75 percent in just one year, said the report by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service. That has caused a significant decline in prices, despite rising domestic consumption. Exports have increased sharply, too, the report said. Other European Community countries are major buyers, led by West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Douglas, Richard Stoltzman Soloists at Mostly Mozart
DOC.TEXT: It was a night of anomaly at the Mostly Mozart Festival. A Cambridge-educated musician conducted Haydn's ``Oxford'' Symphony. A Mozart piano concerto was played with cadenzas nearly 200 years older than it. A clarinetist of remarkable talent showed himself to be his own worst enemy. The concert Tuesday also raised an important issue: how a performer's interpretation can cross the border into arrogance. The conductor was Mark Elder, and he was joined by Belfast-born pianist Barry Douglas in the Piano Concerto No. 22 in E-flat, K. 482, and Richard Stoltzman in Mozart's A major Clarinet Concerto, K. 622. Stoltzman, 48, a fixture at Mostly Mozart for more than a decade, has joined that rare species: a wind-playing superstar, like Jean-Pierre Rampal, Heinz Holliger or James Galway, in demand with concert-bookers and a guaranteed sell-out. He is unquestionably one of the great clarinet players, known for his ability to play incredibly softly, his smooth articulation, his technique. But many clarinetists dislike him intensely, whether it be jealousy, distaste at his crossover into jazz, wide vibrato (which is unusual for a clarinetist), or highly personal interpretations. In the Mozart concerto Tuesday, his little additions of ornament were reasonably tasteful. The large size of Avery Fisher Hall smoothed over his vibrato. His excessive tonguing of fast notes was acceptable, though sometimes distracting. But Stoltzman's taffy-chewing distortion of rhythm in an attempt to be expressive was so severe that the music lost shape. Lines didn't unfurl, they jerked back and forth, obscured by the soloist's shadow. Mozart lost. Even the orchestra seemed tentative at times. But another anomaly: Stoltzman played the slow movement, one of Mozart's greatest, with surpassing serenity. He was simple, to the point, and communicated directly with the audience. But Stoltzman, again trying to be different, broke the spell with an ungainly, inappropriate sounding cadenza instead of the one Mozart wrote for his clarinet quintet _ also in A major _ which is traditionally played here. Cadenzas also figured prominently in the piano concerto. They were by Benjamin Britten and had elements of Rachmaninoff and Debussy. Despite the clash of periods, they are wonderful and somehow fitting, and the 29-year-old Douglas seemed to play them with particular affinity. Douglas arrived after winning the 1986 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow as the first non-Russian since Van Cliburn and also is given to unusual interpretations. He played the concerto with a good deal of romance, inflecting phrases in a personal but not excessive way. The conductor kept the orchestra in extremely close ensemble with soloist. Elder, director of the English National Opera, appropriately let the winds sing out, a good course in a concerto, which is really chamber music for piano, strings and winds. Unlike Stoltzman, Douglas seemed weaker in the soulful slow movement, his melodies having a too-dreamy, almost formless quality. There was some particularly fine interplay with the orchestra in the final Rondo. Douglas seemed really to be listening. In all, it was a high-level, if not superlative, performance. In the succeeding Symphony No. 92 in G major, nicknamed the ``Oxford,'' Elder brought out a larger range of colors than is usually heard in Haydn, and better balanced the orchestra's sections.

DOC.HEAD: Many Crosses Atlantic In Ultralight Plane
DOC.TEXT: He just flew across the Atlantic Ocean and boy, are his arms tired. Dutch aviator Eppo Harbrink Numan isn't kidding when he says it. Numan, 49, claims to be the first person to cross the Atlantic in an ultralight aircraft. ``My arms were getting tired in the end,'' he said Tuesday at an airport in suburban St. Hubert, where he landed Sunday from northern Quebec. Unlike a conventional airplane, the motorized ultralight is maneuvered using a horizontal bar, like a hang glider. Numan said he began his journey 11 weeks ago, leaving the Netherlands for northern Scotland, then skipping to Iceland and Greenland before arriving on Baffin Island Thursday. The aviator said the trip was to call attention to the environment. He has campaigned for five years to get the United Nations to establish international legislation to restore and protect the environment. In March, he sold his cafe to help pay the $30,000 (U.S.) cost to make the flight. Numan said bad weather kept him on the ground repeatedly. The seven-hour flight over Greenland was the most spectacular part of his flight, Numan said, and the toughest occurred in Quebec. Numan says the 4{-hour trip from Kuujjuaq, in Arctic Quebec, to Schefferville, Quebec, included the worst turbulence of his journey.

DOC.HEAD: Miners The Scrappy Heroes Of Rescue Effort
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Miner John Dilla takes a swig of cheap local gin, chews on betel nut, then covers his mouth with a thin surgical mask before burrowing into a crevice in the rubble of the once swank Hyatt Hotel. Dilla is among 200 volunteer gold miners still searching for bodies, and possibly survivors, buried beneath twisted steel and tons of concrete after the July 16 earthquake devastated nearly 30 buildings in this mountain resort. ``The miners are the real heroes of this operation,'' said Dave Kemp, a member of the British International Rescue Corps. ``The job they have done is simply excellent and very professional.'' Kemp, a fireman from Norfolk, England, said Filipino miners had done about 70 percent of the work of finding people beneath the ruins in this city 130 miles north of Manila. Most foreign rescuers left last weekend after deciding there were probably no more survivors in the ruins. Now, the miners, along with a few daring civilians and Philippine Military Academy cadets, are left with the job. ``They have committed to continue the search to the last body,'' said Rogelio Singson, a spokesman of presidential relief coordination center for Baguio. Dilla said the miners need the gin to numb their sense of smell as the stench of death grows stronger in the remains. Betel nuts satisfy hunger pangs. He said the linen masks did little to lessen the stench of decaying bodies. But he and others wear them all the same because they are the only facial covering available. ``You will need a gas mask with an oxygen supply before you can really work inside those tunnels. Otherwise, you will pass out before you can reach deep inside,'' Dilla said. ``But since we lack the equipment, we're using the best available resources.'' Fellow miner Orlando Bay-os said they came to Baguio after hearing reports about damage in the once swank resort. The miners volunteered although their own camp at the Philex Mining Corp. was also damaged. Twenty-one of their fellow miners and their families were killed there. ``We proceeded to Baguio as soon as we heard the news that we did not even have the time to check the condition of our families,'' Bay-os said. ``There was a greater need for us in Baguio.'' Bay-os said most of the volunteer miners walked from their camp, about 20 miles, to reach Baguio. Most have stayed since and have been working for stretches of up to 48 hours to find people trapped in the debris. Working side by side with the miners are the 1,000 cadets of the Philippine Military Academy, whose campus is in Baguio. Eight cadet companies formed the first organized search and rescue group in the resort. ``We knew there was a lot of damage and there was nobody on deck but us,'' said Cadet 3rd Class Keith Cardones. ``We had to decide fast.'' ``We were not prepared for a disaster but with just guts and our bare hands we started the rescue attempt,'' Cadet 2nd Class Jun de Vela said. ``We only realized the dangers of what were were doing after experiencing being inside tunnels during the aftershocks.'' Singson said he had received reports of how cadets took turns entering a 12-inch-high space between a collapsed floor of the Hotel Nevada to talk to a woman who was pinned down by a concrete beam. He said that when an aftershock lowered the void even more, the thinner cadets who could still enter the space took over. The woman was saved. In another incident, the cadets joined several drinking straws in a makeshift tube to allow another survivor to take in liquids from a bottle several yards away, Singson said. But de Vela also spoke of the frustrations of not being able to save people they knew were still alive for hours after the earthquake. He said many cadets worked overtime after hearing the cries of 5-year-old Michelle Reyes, who was trapped on the fourth floor of the Hyatt. He said that for two days the cadets were trying to talk with the girl, who was crying from beneath the rubble. But after several aftershocks, the crying stopped. Reyes's body was recovered days later. ``It really hurt but we did the best we could,'' said de Vela.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Refuses to Intervene in Rushdie Film Controversy
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has refused to intervene in the row over a decision to ban a film that portrays the death of author Salman Rushdie. The independent British Board of Film Classification has banned the Pakistani film, ``International Guerrillas,'' on the grounds it is criminally libelous of Rushdie. British Moslem groups have denounced the ban on the film and accused the board of hypocrisy because Rushdie's book, ``The Satanic Verses,'' which they say blasphemes Islam, was not banned. ``The Board is an entirely independent body,'' Mrs. Thatcher said Tuesday. ``If the distributors ... wish to appeal against the decision of the Board, they may make application to the Video Appeals Committee in the usual way.'' The prime minister was responding in the House of Commons to an opposition lawmaker who accused her of ``double standards.'' The distributor of the Punjabi-Urdu language film, Mohammed Fayyaz of London, made an appeal to the Video Appeals Committee on Monday to allow the film to be distributed. Rushdie, born to a Moslem family in India and now a British citizen, has been in hiding since Feb. 1989 when the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran called for the author's death for blaspheming Islam in ``The Satanic Verses.'' The author said through his defense committee on Monday that he would not initiate a libel action against the film and supports the right of the film to be shown. The 3{-hour film depicts Rushdie as the agent of an international conspiracy against Islam and shows him torturing and killing Moslems until he himself is killed by a bolt of lightning.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chief: Bank Won't `Fritter Away' Gains in Inflation Fight
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, seeking to reassure jittery financial markets, says the central bank won't ``fritter away'' the gains made in the last few years in the fight against inflation. Greenspan told lawmakers Tuesday that the Fed has not abandoned its inflation battle as part of some deal with the Bush administration to trim the federal budget deficit. He insisted that any move to lower interest rates to ward off the adverse impacts of budget cuts and tax increases needed to reduce the deficit would be made only ``in the context of not inducing inflationary pressures.'' Private economists saw Greenspan's comments as an effort to calm fears in financial markets that the Fed is buckling to election-year pressures by the administration to abandon its inflation battle. Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said Greenspan's comments should help to ease market anxieties. ``It took away from any negatives he created when he seemed to be wavering'' last week, Platt said. Those fears were raised when Greenspan said the Fed stood ready to lower interest rates to support a credible deficit reduction package if such assistance was needed to keep the country out of a recession. At a hearing Tuesday by the House Banking subcommittee on domestic monetary policy, Rep. Stephen Neal, D-N.C., told Greenspan that he believed Monday's steep drop in the stock market was caused by general worries that the Fed was wavering in its inflation-fighting resolve. The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 56.44 points on Monday, after a topsy-turvy day that saw the indicator down by more than 100 points in early trading. On Tuesday, stocks rebounded with the Dow industrials finishing up by 17.82 points. In his testimony, Greenspan repeated his support for legislation sponsored by Neal that would commit the Fed to pursuing policies to achieve ``zero inflation.'' He said he believed such a goal was within reach because of policies over the past three years that have slowed the growth of the nation's money supply. The Fed's goal is to provide enough money to the banking system to keep the economy growing while guarding against supplying so much that it results in renewed inflation. Over the past three years, the money supply has grown at a slow pace not seen in three decades, Greenspan said. ``If we don't fritter away the benefits of the last 2{ to three years, and I can assure you we don't intend to do that, then I see no reason to expect other than the achievement of general price stability over the next several years,'' Greenspan told Neal. Greenspan said the actual response of the Fed to any deficit-cutting agreement would depend very much on how financial markets viewed the package. He predicted that a ``credible and enforceable'' budget deficit agreement would spark a significant drop in interest rates on financial markets. And he said the Fed would not act to accelerate the move to lower rates unless such action could be taken without risking the central bank's overriding goal of reducing inflation. Greenspan testified that the recent report showing that consumer prices jumped 0.5 percent in June had added a ``note of caution'' to the inflation outlook. But he said the June increase and other bad inflation figures reflected past history and not recent gains the Fed has made by slowing the growth of the money supply.

DOC.HEAD: American Forces in Gulf Conducting `Short-Notice' Maneuvers
DOC.TEXT: U.S. warships and aircraft are conducting a joint exercise in the Persian Gulf with forces of the United Arab Emirates amid rising tensions between Kuwait and Iraq over oil production and pricing. The Pentagon announced Tuesday that six U.S. warships and three aircraft were participating in a ``short-notice'' exercise with UAE forces, but the administration gave conflicting signals on the alert status of the U.S. forces. The UAE has been an implicit target of Iraq's recent complaints that some of its Arab neighbors have been undercutting oil prices by exceeding their oil-production quotas as established by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Concern for Kuwait's security has grown since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last Friday accused his tiny neighbor of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from Iraqi wells and of trying to wreck the Iraqi economy by conspiring to push down world oil prices. Baghdad renewed its verbal assault on Kuwait on Tuesday. The Iraqi government newspaper Al-Joumhouriya accused Kuwait of coordinating its moves with the United States to ``clear the way for foreign powers to intervene in the area.'' Meanwhile, Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III said in congressional testimony that American ships were put on alert in the gulf on Monday, but he offered no details. Later, Pete Williams, spokesman for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, said he could not confirm that the ships were on alert. Williams told reporters that two U.S. vessels had left early from their port in Bahrain, midway in the gulf, to join the exercise with UAE forces. He said that did not mean they were on alert. Williams said the exercise, code-named ``Ivory Justice,'' began Monday. He said it was mainly an air-refueling mission with UAE aircraft. Participating in the exercise were two U.S. Air Force KC-135 refueling tanker planes and one U.S. C-141 cargo plane, plus six American warships already patrolling in the gulf. The U.S. aircraft flew to the gulf from an air base in West Germany, Williams said. Williams said he could not comment on whether the joint exercise in the gulf was in response to the Iraq-Kuwait tensions. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said both Iraq and Kuwait had built up their forces and U.S. officials were ``very concerned.'' ``Iraq and others know there is no place for coercion in a civilized world,'' she said. ``All disputes should be handled through peaceful means.'' When asked whether the United States would come to Kuwait's defense if attacked by Iraq, Williams said he could not comment beyond restating U.S. policy on the gulf. ``Our continuing efforts there are not directed against any single country but are to ensure that we have an adequate capability, together with our friends, should the need arise,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Known as Tough Prosecutor, Judge
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Denis is cq in 12th graf
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When a judge began releasing demonstrators who had trespassed at the Seabrook nuclear power plant in 1977, then-Attorney General David Souter jumped into his car, sped to the court and insisted the protesters be jailed. When state workers struck illegally in 1983, then-Superior Court Judge Souter agreed to a midnight hearing and issued a pre-dawn ruling threatening stiff fines if the workers didn't end their sickout. When a lawyer stole money from a client, Judge Souter wanted him to go to jail, not just repay the money. Throughout his career as prosecutor and judge in New Hampshire, Souter, 50, has taken his role seriously and dealt firmly with those who didn't hold the law in as high a regard as he. The opinions he authored as a state Supreme Court justice reveal a writer who sticks to the facts and avoids rhetorical flourishes. There are no broad pronouncements on issues such as abortion or affirmative action that he certainly would confront if he wins confirmation to the U.S. Supreme Court. Souter was attorney general when the state police arrested 1,414 demonstrators who defied authorities, marched onto the Seabrook nuclear plant construction site and camped overnight. The protesters were locked in National Guard armories for two weeks. When a local judge released a demonstrator on a suspended sentence and small fine, Souter was incensed. ``He played a very significant role,'' said Seabrook foe Robert Cushing, one of those arrested in the May 1977 protest. Cushing said that when Souter found out about the suspended sentence, ``he left from Concord, drove down to district court, and argued that there should be a jail sentence imposed.'' The judge resentenced the demonstrator, Cushing said. The State Employees' Association felt Souter's sting during a sickout in June 1983. At midnight, then-Gov. John Sununu called Souter and asked him to hold a hearing, which he did. At 3:45 a.m., Souter ordered everyone back to work and threatened to fine the union $5,000 a day and its leadership $500 a day. ``He came down heavy,'' said the union director, Denis Parker. ``There's no question about it.'' Manchester lawyer Jack Middleton remembers a case in which a lawyer had stolen money from a client. Both sides had decided to drop the matter if the lawyer repaid the money, he said, but Souter wouldn't buy it. ``That just sounded like a bank transaction to him,'' Middleton said, and ``he didn't view that as a loan.'' In addition to showing that Souter was tough, Middleton said the episode showed that Souter ``was going to take a hard look at the facts and make up his own mind ... and not just take the word of the prosecution or the defense lawyer.'' Souter served seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court. In a 1988 decision criticized by women's rights groups, Souter ordered a new trial for a man who was convicted of sexual assault. The defendant said his lawyers improperly were prevented from offering evidence the woman publicly flirted with other men on the day of the alleged attack. Souter said such evidence was essential to the man's defense that the woman had consented to having sex with him. Souter often sides with positions advanced by state government officials, especially in criminal cases. But there have been notable exceptions. In 1988, Souter led the state court in declaring unconstitutional a state law that barred a non-profit group from providing legal services to some disabled people. As state attorney general, it fell to Souter to defend the state's prosecution of a couple who, for religious purposes, taped over the ``Live Free or Die'' motto on their automobile license. The Supreme Court ruled that the prosecution violated the couple's religious freedom. As a judge, Souter participated in just one known case dealing with abortion, siding with the majority in a 1986 ruling that said physicians have a responsibility to test unborn children for birth defects and in the event defects are detected to counsel the pregnant woman about options _ including abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Pays Courtesy Call on Capitol Hill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Recasts first 2 grafs; raises reference to advice to 5th graf; Souder-Dole meeting expected around noon EDT
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter, the reserved New Hampshire judge picked by President Bush for the Supreme Court, is armed with White House advice as he sets out to press the flesh with the politicians who are key to his confirmation. Souter was attending get-acquainted meeting with Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon. The committee will conduct Souter's confirmation hearing, expected to begin in September. The president said he hopes the full Senate will confirm Souter before the high court's next term begins Oct. 1. Souter was paying a similar courtesy call on Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and possibly other Democrats later in the day. Fred McClure, the White House's liaison with Congress, and Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., an old friend, are Souter's guides at the Capitol. And the nominee has been told by Bush aides to expect a strong spotlight to be shined on his personal and professional life. Souter, appearing more relaxed than he did when his intended nomination was announced by Bush on Monday, told reporters Tuesday he was getting used to his new celebrity. ``The blood is circulating a little bit better than it was yesterday afternoon at five o'clock,'' he said. ``I didn't think it was going to happen. I was astonished.'' Many senators and special interest groups were surprised as well, and the divisive rhetoric that immediately accompanied President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork in 1987 has not resurfaced. Bush lavished praise on Souter at fund-raising events Tuesday in Philadelphia and New York. ``I look forward to the Senate hearings of David Souter; I am sure they will find him to be tough but fair,'' the president said. ``He's a first-rate appellate judge, an outstanding jurist and a great legal mind.'' ``In my nomination of Judge David Souter for Senate confirmation ... there was no single issue, no litmus test or standard dominating my decision,'' Bush said. ``And I will add there should be no litmus test in the process of confirmation.'' Conservative and liberal activists alike were taking a wait-and-see attitude, acknowledging that the president's swift action in choosing Souter had caught them a little off guard. Little is known about Souter's views on the vexing social issues _ abortion, civil rights and church-state relations _ he would confront if confirmed to replace Justice William J. Brennan, who retired Friday because of poor health. The Union Leader in Manchester, N.H., reported today that in a 1976 college commencement speech, Souter, then state attorney general, attacked rigid federal affirmative action guidelines as ``affirmative discrimination'' and added, ``There are some things government cannot do.'' Souter is ``clearly not like Bork,'' said Elliot Mincberg of People for the American Way, a liberal group. ``He doesn't have much of a track record.'' The United Conservatives of America gave Souter ``a cautious thumbs-up.'' Richard A. Viguerie, the group's chairman, said, ``Most conservatives today have nervous smiles.'' Souter brushed aside reporters' questions Tuesday about his views on abortion, one of the sure focal points of the confirmation hearings. Several senators said it would be inappropriate for the Judiciary Committee to obtain from Souter his opinion on specific issues before the court, but one committee member _ Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. _ suggested that general topics could be broached. ``I think there is a desire to have full and complete hearings _ fair,'' Kennedy said. Souter spent several hours Tuesday in the White House, where presidential aides told him that his personal and professional life would come under exceedingly close scrutiny. One participant, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Souter listened to the advice and indicated there was nothing in his past to cause him discomfort. It appears that in 22 years of public service, Souter has rarely given a speech or written a law review article, and never publicly criticized a Supreme Court ruling. The only paper trail on him comes from his seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court, and it indicates he is a clear, dispassionate writer of legal opinions. A review of many of the nearly 200 opinions Souter authored reveals he is most assuredly a judicial conservative _ a judge who believes in sticking to the case at hand and shies away from making sweeping statements about the law. He often sides with positions advanced by state government officials, especially in criminal cases. But there have been notable exceptions. In a 1988 decision, Souter led the state court in declaring unconstitutional a state law that barred a non-profit group from providing legal services to some disabled people.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-KBG Official Critical Of Agency Comes Under Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A fired KGB official who's been waging a public relations campaign against his former employer is being investigated by government prosecutors looking for evidence he illegally leaked official secrets. The government is investigating former counterintelligence chief Oleg D. Kalugin under a law against divulging classified information, the government newspaper Izvestia reported Tuesday. Kalugin, who worked as an operative in the United States from 1958 to 1970, in recent weeks has in recent weeks been speaking out against the KGB at demonstrations and in interviews with Western and Soviet reporters. He has said the KGB still taps telephones, infiltrates Soviet life, including the Russian Orthodox church and labor organizations and engages in dirty tricks. In a recent article, he said about 20 agents who have defected to the West in the past decade have caused the ``total collapse'' of many of Soviet spy rings. Izvestia did not indicate which of Kalugin's remarks constitute state secrets. ``In June and July 1990,'' the newspaper wrote, ``mass media in the Soviet Union and other countries disseminated confidential information, constituting state secrets, citing former major-general Oleg Kalugin of the state security force or on his behalf.'' Izvestia said the prosecutor's office began criminal proceedings July 17. It did not explain why the action was not reported for a week. Kalugin has embraced the reform policies of the radical Democratic Platform, alleging his superiors drummed him out of the agency because of his politics. Since he began speaking out, he has been dismissed from the KGB and stripped of his rank as major general. KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov has criticized Kalugin, who was nominated as a candidate to the Russian republic's parliament from Krasnodar. In a newspaper article earlier this month, Kalugin denied allegations by his former superiors that he himself was responsible for leaks of information. ``Since 1960 until 1980, three KGB agents defected to the West,'' Kalugin wrote in Komsomolskaya Pravda. ``And since 1980, about 20 have already betrayed the motherland. ``Thus we can boldly speak not of an information leak but about a majority of Soviet intelligence's secrets sold to the West, about the total collapse of a great number of intelligence networks,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,701.27, down 1.19 points, or 0.004 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill at Least 40 Militiamen In Jungle Battle
DOC.TEXT: In a surprise attack on a small jungle village, Shining Path rebels killed at least 40 poorly armed peasant militiamen and wounded about 10, authorities say. A band of more than 50 rebels swept into the town of Vista Alegre early Tuesday and overwhelmed the militiamen, a spokesman for the government of Junin province said by telephone from the provincial capital of Huancaya. Vista Alegre is located near Satipo, a jungle city 160 miles northeast of Lima. Huancayo is 120 miles east of Lima. There were no reports of rebel casualties, the spokesman said. The Maoist-inspired rebels were armed with assault rifles and machine guns, while the peasant militiamen were armed with carbines, machetes, arrows and spears, the spokesman said. The army has established hundreds of peasant militia groups to allow isolated villages and towns to defend themselves from rebel attacks. The number of people killed in rebel violence has increased since the militia program began. The government says at least 19,000 people have been killed in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Fears Linger A Year After Girl Was Stabbed at Street Fair
LaserPhoto HF2
DOC.TEXT: Fears linger over the slaying a year ago of a 9-year-old girl stabbed 34 times by a mental patient at a street fair, but city officials say this year's festival Friday will be safe. ``I'll be looking around and I'll probably be holding on to my kids very tightly, not that I think it would have made any difference last year,'' Cindy Morehouse said as she strolled downtown Tuesday with her two young sons. Jessica Short's mother and several other people watched helplessly as the girl was killed on July 28 by David Peterson, a patient at Connecticut Valley Hospital. Peterson left the minimum-security state mental hospital without permission, took a bus three miles to downtown, bought a hunting knife and pounced on Jessica as she walked out of a Woolworth's store. Horrified witnesses and police pulled him off the girl in less than a minute, after she was stabbed 34 times. George Russell, manager of the Woolworth's store and a witness to the attack, said the slaying sharply curtailed business for months. Now, business has rebounded, but Russell said the attack took a personal toll. ``I still relive the incident. Time is not a factor. I have a picture in my head and I still get flashbacks. It's hard to deal with,'' he said. Officials in this city of 45,000 held a news conference Tuesday to assure that the annual one-day festival will be safe. ``Middletown can't blame itself as a city for what happened. Things like this could have happened anywhere,'' said Mike Blais, the festival chairman. As a measure of security, a mobile crisis team of Connecticut Valley workers will attend the festival, Mayor Paul Gionfriddo said. But he predicted the fair will be as uneventful as this year's Memorial Day parade and July 4 celebration. A booth will be set up at the festival to raise funds for two charities established in Jessica's name. Peterson, 37 when Jessica was stabbed, is a chronic paranoid schizophrenic with a history of mental illness and violence. He has spent more than 15 years in mental institutions. In 1971 and 1988, he was found innocent by reason of insanity in stabbing attacks. In March, he also was found innocent by reason of insanity in Jessica's slaying and ordered confined for 70 years and placed in Connecticut's only maximum-security psychiatric hospital, Whiting Forensic Institute in Middletown. At Peterson's arraignment, an angry crowd yelled, ``Kill him, kill him.'' Some Middletown residents are afraid other David Petersons are waiting to strike. Connecticut Valley patients with passes make regular trips downtown from the 468-bed hospital, and ex-patients live in halfway houses in the area. Many customers call The Baby's Shoppe on Main Street before coming to the store so they can be met at their cars, said Laurel Rosner, a co-owner. She accompanies customers to their cars when they leave. Even merchants who say the effect of the stabbing on the community psyche has been overblown acknowledge it is still on the minds of many. ``Occasionally we'll still hear, `Is it OK to bring my daughter downtown?' '' said Vincent Amato, who owns a toy and hobby shop. Gionfriddo said Connecticut Valley has tightened restrictions since the stabbing. The hospital can't take day passes away from patients entitled to them, but it plans its own activities Friday to encourage patients with passes to remain on hospital grounds, Gionfriddo said. Jessica's father, Ronald Short, may attend the festival, but her mother, Catherine, will not. ``This is a very difficult time for me emotionally,'' she said. ``I don't feel there is any need for me to go.''

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes 5 Percent Budget Increase for Arts Endowment
DOC.TEXT: A $180 million budget approved for the National Endowment for the Arts by a House Appropriations subcommittee includes a $900,000 increase in federal funds for state arts agencies. The bill was sent to the full House Appropriations Committee by voice vote Tuesday without action on any anti-obscenity amendments that would restrict the kinds of art eligible for tax-paid endowment grants. Debate on separate legislation to extend the NEA's life for five years has been postponed until after the August recess because of the large number of amendments to be considered. Republicans are drafting proposals for a drastic overhaul of the endowment as a result of past financial support for art that some have denounced as obscene or sacrilegious. The appropriations bill approved by the subcommittee Tuesday would provide a 5 percent increase in the NEA budget, from $171.3 million to $180 million in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. At the urging of Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., the subcommittee chairman and a staunch arts advocate, the panel approved boosting endowment funds for states arts councils from $26.1 million to $27 million.
DOC.HEAD: No Increase in Disciplinary Action Against Physicians in 1988
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group says the same number of physicians were disciplined by state medical boards in 1988 as the year before, reversing a trend toward more sanctions. Public Citizen Health Research Group said Tuesday it arrived at the number of 1,489 from an analysis of the most recent data compiled by the Federation of State Medical Boards. It counted license revocations or suspensions and probations. In 1984, serious actions were taken against 745 physicians, Public Citizen said. That increased to 1,089 in 1985 and 1,277 in 1986. The group said none of the rates were high enough. ``A physician could still operate drunk, commit a gross act of negligence, or sexually assault a patient and receive a mere slap on the wrist from his or her state's medical board in most states,'' the group said.
DOC.HEAD: UPS Negotiations Could Force Mail Changes
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service may limit the number of packages it accept at one time to avoid being overloaded in case there is a strike at rival United Parcel Service. ``If there is a (work) stoppage next week there is no way (the Postal Service) can absorb the operations of UPS overnight into our system,'' Deputy Postmaster General Michael S. Coughlin said Tuesday. However, he said any restrictions would affect only to volume shippers. Individuals sending four or fewer parcels at one time would not be impacted. Individuals or organizations needing to send five or more packages will be required to contact the postal service by telephone to make a reservation to bring their parcels to a postal handling center in the region of the intended delivery, he said. For example, if a company in Chicago wanted to send truck loads of parcels to customers in Atlanta, it would make a reservation to deliver the parcels to the postal facility in Atlanta. The company sending the packages would be responsible for getting them from Chicago to Atlanta, and the Postal Service would then complete the delivery to homes.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Called Important Step for Alzheimer's Victims
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of a genetic defect that may cause most cases of Alzheimer's disease could someday lead to a treatment, researchers say. ``We're anxiously following this, and if it's true it would be quite significant,'' said Creighton Phelps, vice president of medical and scientific affairs at the National Alzheimer's Association in Chicago. On Tuesday, Dr. Allen Roses of the Duke University medical school in Durham, N.C., said he found a genetic abnormality that may cause the most common form of Alzheimer's disease, which afflicts about 4 million Americans. The finding surprised most researchers studying the disease's genetics. They have been busily investigating a different abnormality. ``We're betting the output of our laboratory'' that the new abnormality is the cause of all but a rare form of Alzheimer's, Roses said. In a presentation at the Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Roses said that based on his study of 32 families in which Alzheimer's is prevalent, the disease appears to be linked to an abnormality on chromosome 19, one of the 23 pairs of human chromosomes. Previous studies found a defect on chromosome 21 linked to an early-onset form of Alzheimer's in which memory loss and other symptoms begin to appear around age 40. That form of the disease has been found in only 10 or 20 families in the world, Roses said. It could turn out that the early-onset form of Alzheimer's is a different disease. Roses used his genetic samples to search for a defect on chromosome 21 in late-onset Alzheimer's disease and couldn't find it. The idea that chromosome 21 is linked to the disease was so powerful that Roses said he has had difficulty persuading others that chromosome 21 may not be the culprit in most cases. He said he has been frustrated in efforts to publish his findings in a scientific journal. Other researchers are now rapidly trying to determine whether their genetic samples from Alzheimer's victims also reveal an abnormality on chromosome 19, said Dr. Peter St. George-Hyslop of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He is one of the discoverers of the defect on chromosome 21. ``The follow-up studies need to be done,'' St. George-Hyslop said. ``This area of genetics of late-onset neurological disease is extremely difficult to do.'' Finding the genetic defect is a crucial first step toward figuring out precisely what goes wrong in Alzheimer's disease and perhaps how to fix it. No cause or cure is known for the progressive neurological disorder. One of the problems with doing research on Alzheimer's is that the disease normally appears in people in their 60s, 70s or 80s. Many people who carry a genetic predisposition for the disease die of something else before they develop it, Roses said. ``There are a lot of people in the field who have doubts about whether late-onset Alzheimer's can even be approached by genetic techniques,'' Roses said. Researchers differ in their view of the disease. Roses believes that virtually all people would develop Alzheimer's if they lived long enough. Some people merely have an abnormality that makes the disease show up in their 60s; others might not get it unless they lived to be 120, he said. In fact, the condition normally thought of as senility in very old people is indistinguishable from Alzheimer's, Roses said. The genetic research could ultimately lead to a way to delay the appearance of the disease, if not cure it outright, Roses said. ``If we can delay it from the age of 80 to 105, I think people would be satisfied,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Van Gogh Suffered Maddening Ear Infection, Not Madness
DOC.TEXT: Vincent van Gogh cut off his ear and later killed himself because of a painful but undiagnosed inner-ear infection, not madness, a report published today suggests. The artist, who committed suicide 100 years ago Sunday at age 37, suffered from Meniere's disease, an often misdiagnosed infection, Dr. I. Kaufman Arenberg said in the Journal of the American Medical Association. The disease, which afflicts about 7 million Americans, is brought on by excess fluid and pressure in the ear and can cause severe bouts of vertigo and hallucinations. Van Gogh, who sold just one painting during his life but whose work now commands record prices, described those symptoms in letters to family members, Arenberg and colleagues reported. ``His voluminous correspondence should forever banish the notion that he was an epileptic or `mad,''' their report said. Other symptoms include vomiting, painful pressure and persistent noise in the ear, along with possible hearing loss. Attacks may last from several hours to several days and are often marked by long periods of no symptoms, conditions described by van Gogh. ``The tragedy is that this disease was discovered about 30 years before van Gogh's death but (information about it) was slow to disseminate,'' Arenberg said. It is unlikely van Gogh's doctors knew of Meniere's disease, named after the French doctor who identified it in 1861, Arenberg said. He added that no treatment for the malady was available at the time. Researchers have guessed for decades about van Gogh's mental problems. One doctor theorized that van Gogh had a personality disorder stemming from epilepsy. Another scientist suggested he was addicted to absinthe. Arenberg and colleagues at the Swedish Medical Center in Englewood, Colo., studied 796 letters that van Gogh wrote to family and friends from 1884 to 1890, and those of the doctor who treated the artist. After years of deterioriating health, the Dutch-born artist checked into a mental asylum in France, where a Dr. Peyron wrote: ``It is my opinion that Mr. van Gogh is subject to epileptic fits at very infrequent intervals.'' In a letter dated Sept. 10, 1889 to his brother, Theo, the artist recounted his gloomy prognosis. ``I must say that M. Peyron does not give me much hope for the future and I think this right, he makes me realize that everything is doubtful that one can be sure of nothing beforehand,'' he wrote. Peyron wrote that van Gogh probably cut off his left ear in a fit of madness or instability in December 1888. But Arenberg said the artist might have done so as a crude way of relieving the pain or intense buzzing or ringing. Doctors now treat Meniere's disease with drugs, by removing the inner ear or by shunting blocked fluids from the area under pressure, Arenberg said. Treatment is effective in about 80 percent of all patients. ``The biggest impact the disease had on him was fear,'' Arenberg said. ``He had a tremendous fear that (epilepsy) would come and leave him incapacitated from painting permanently. That's probably why he painted so much in the years before his death.'' Van Gogh's work is among the most prized in the art world. In May, his ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' drew the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting _ $82.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: John Mellencamp's sleepy hometown has become the site for his first movie. Most of the work on ``Souvenirs'' is being done after midnight so production doesn't interfere with merchants and residents, Cindy Livinghouse, deputy director of the Indiana Tourism and Film Development Commission, said Tuesday. Filming began Monday in this southern Indiana town of 13,600 and was expected to last about seven weeks, said Harry Sandler, the singer's manager. Mariel Hemingway and Claude Akins appear in the film with Mellencamp. Few details about the movie have been released, which is how Mellencamp wants it, Sandler said. Mellencamp, known for his Midwestern rock and work in organizing Farm Aid concerts, was born and raised in Seymour and lives near Bloomington.

Celebrity attorney Melvin Belli says he went into law to help people, not to make money. ``If you're going into law to make money you're going to have a very miserable old age,'' Belli, who turns 83 on Sunday, said while in San Diego recently for a seminar. ``But if you're going into it to help people, what a life it is. I can't think of anything more rewarding.'' Belli's clients have included Jack Ruby, who killed John F. Kennedy assassin Lee Harvey Oswald, and Jim and Tammy Bakker. Belli has written 62 books and dabbles in acting. He will soon appear in an episode of television's ``Murder, She Wrote'' and has made an ice cream commercial.

Marla Maples still dreams of a future with Donald Trump. Asked if she'd consider marrying the flamboyant real estate mogul with whom she has been romantically linked for eight months, Maples said, ``Of course I would think about it, of course,'' Tuesday's Daily News reported. ``This could be a story with a very beautiful ending,'' she said. Maples is fighting a subpoena to testify about Trump's prenuptial agreement with Ivana Trump, said Chuck Jones, a spokesman for Maples. A hearing on the prenuptial agreement is scheduled for Aug. 20. The News said Maples described Mrs. Trump as a ``cold'' woman who is neglecting her children. Mrs. Trump, through her spokeswoman, Lisa Calandra, denied the allegations.

Fastball _ not the farm bill _ was on the minds of the more athletic members of the House, who split along party lines for their annual confrontation on the baseball field. The Republicans beat the Democrats 9-6 on Tuesday. Rep. Joe Barton, R-Texas, handcuffed Democratic batters with a fastball and drove in the winning run. ``It was a great game. It just goes to demonstrate that when Republicans and Democrats meet on equal terms, the Republicans will always win,'' said Rep. Jack Fields, another Texas Republican. ``We made the Democrats realize what a deficit really is.''

DOC.HEAD: Archeologists in Israel Find `Golden Calf'
DOC.TEXT: Archeologists in Israel have discovered an ancient ``golden calf'' figurine, a pagan idol frequently mentioned in the Bible, it was reported today. The hand-sized, mixed-metal figurine, about 3,500 years old, is the first of its kind to be unearthed, The New York Times reported. Harvard University archeologists excavating Canaanite ruins near the ancient port city of Ashkelon found the figurine on June 26, the Times said. The earliest legends of Judaism feature warnings against worshiping golden calves, revered by Canaanites because their gods were believed to ride the sacred beasts. ``It was a totally unexpected find,'' said Lawrence E. Stager, the Harvard professor who heads the Israeli dig. ``We were just cleaning down the side of the stone ramparts, and the last thing we thought we would find was this temple. We haven't found any precedents for this.'' The figurine was found in the rubble of a temple destroyed by Egyptian conquerers in about 1550 B.C., during the Bronze Age. The figurine dates from midway through the second millennium B.C., Stager said. The calf is about 4\ inches tall and 4{ inches long and weighs just less than 1 pound. It was cast in parts and pieced together. The body is made of bronze and markings show it likely was burnished to look golden. The legs, head and genitals are made of an as-yet untested metal that appears to be silver. One surviving horn and the tail were made from copper wire and the figure is filled with a heavy metal, believed to be lead. It was found near a small pottery shrine that had an opening with doors. ``We believe it was displayed looking out, emerging from this cowshed, which was a shrine to the milk goddess,'' Stager said. The largely intact figurine suffered mild corrosion, giving the bronze and copper pieces a green tint and making the silver look gray. In the Bible, golden calves are mentioned in the story of Aaron, the Exodus, tales of ancient Jerusalem's rivalry with the calf-worshiping Hebrew king Jeroboam, and in other Old Testament accounts. The find is expected to help scientists study religious developments in the region that gave birth to Judaism, Christianity and Islam. When testing and research is completed, the calf likely will be turned over to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem. Ashkelon, one of the largest cities in the region during its heyday, was about 2,000 years old when Egypt invaded and had a population of 15,000 to 20,000 people. The dig site is located about 30 miles south of Tel Aviv.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up In Tokyo; Stocks Unchanged
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange were almost unchanged. The dollar closed at 149.13 yen, up 0.43 yen from Tuesday's finish of 148.70 yen. It opened at 148.98 yen and ranged between 148.89 yen and 149.32 yen. The dollar has gained 1.88 yen in five trading days after it shed 0.95 yen to a 147.25-yen close on Friday. Trading was active, with spot transactions totaling $11.130 billion, up from Tuesday's $8.833 billion. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost a marginal 1.19 points, or 0.004 percent, closing at 31,701.27. The index had shed 192.33 points on Tuesday. The widely watched index has lost 1,354.35 points in four trading days. Volume on the first section was estimated at a meager 350 million shares, down from Tuesday's 355 million shares. The benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was quoted at 86.00 points as of 4:00 p.m., up from Tuesday's close of 85.84 points. The yield was 7.415 percent, down from 7.450 percent. Currency dealers said tension between Kuwait and Iraq and moderate recovery of the New York stock prices prompted dollar buying. Kouhei Kuroda of Fuji Bank said there was a strong demand for the dollar, but selling resistance limited the dollar's ascent. The dollar usually is bought in Tokyo as a safe haven in times of international tension. On the stock market, share prices softened after opening higher following the recovery on Wall Street. ``A lingering uncertain outlook for (Japan's) interest rates was the main factor,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a dealer with Daiwa Securities. Japan's long-term credit banks are considering raising the long-term prime rate by 0.3 percent to 7.9 percent later this week, according to bank officials. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's stock market less attractive to investors.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Militants Kill Five Hindu Devotees
DOC.TEXT: Bursting into a Hindu temple during evening prayers, Sikh militants opened fire with automatic rifles, killing five worshipers and wounding at least 14, police said today. At least 40 people were in the temple and its gates were unguarded when the attack occurred Tuesday in the Punjab town of Bhatinda, said police Superintendent Rajinder Singh. Four militants entered the building, spread out and fired at the congregation, then escaped, he said. Also Tuesday, a Sikh couple and their two children were killed in their sleep when militants broke into their home and shot them, police said. At least three militants were involved in the attack on the outskirts of Amritsar, the Sikh holy city, Superintendent Sanjiv Gupta said. The United News of India news agency reported at least four other killings by Sikh extremists in other parts of the state on Tuesday. Sikh militants have mainly targeted Hindus in their 8-year quest for an independent nation in the Sikh-majority state of Punjab. But they have also killed moderate Sikhs whom they accuse of being police informers. Sikhs, easily identifiable by their long hair, colorful turbans and untrimmed beards, make up only 2 percent of India's 880 million population but comprise 55 percent of Punjab's 17.6 million people. They accuse the Hindus, who comprise 82 percent of the country's people, of discriminating against Sikhs in language and and job opportunities. Tuesday's deaths raise to 1,485 the number of people killed by militants in Punjab this year. Most of the deaths have occurred in the district of Amritsar, the center of the insurgency. Bhatinda, in the heart of the state's cotton belt, is 110 miles south of Amritsar.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Show is No.1 in U.S.
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian import won the latest ratings battle among U.S. networks. Part two of the four-hour Canadian Broadcasting Co. docudrama ``Love & Hate: A Marriage Made in Hell,'' broadcast on NBC, was the No. 1 program on American television for the week ending July 21, the A.C. Nielsen Co. reported Tuesday. Part one of ``Love & Hate,'' a Canadian Broadcasting Co. production starring Kenneth Welsh and Kate Nelligan, ranked sixth in the Nielsens a week ago. The program was Canada's top-rated mini-series last year. It was pitched to NBC programming guru Brandon Tartikoff by producer Ivan Fecan, a former NBC employee who now is Tartikoff's counterpart at CBC. NBC also scored in the latest Nielsens with the debut of ``Real Life with Jane Pauley,'' on Tuesday at 10 p.m. The magazine-style show starring the former `Today'' co-host tied for fifth place with a repeat of NBC's ``Empty Nest.'' NBC won the overall ratings with a 10.2 average, followed by CBS with 8.7 and ABC with 8.4. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Love & Hate: A Marriage Made in Hell,'' Part 2, NBC, 16.3; a ``Cheers'' rerun, NBC, 15.5; a ``Roseanne'' rerun ABC, 13.8; the ``20-20'' prime-time news show, ABC, 13.4; ``Empty Nest'' and ``Real Life with Jane Pauley,'' (tie) NBC, 13.3; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC, 13.0; ``The Simpsons,'' Fox, 13.0; ``Married...With Children,'' Fox, (tie) 13.0; ``Miss Teen USA'' pageant, CBS, 12.8. The network news battle was won again by ABC with an 8.9 average. CBS was second with an 8 and NBC finished last with 7.4.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Capture Two Towns, Establish Link to Rebel Stronghold
DOC.TEXT: Government troops have captured two towns just south of the rebel-held Jaffna peninsula, opening a major road into the Tamil militants' stronghold, military officials said today. At least 96 of the separatist rebels and 13 soldiers were killed in the three-day operation that gave the government control over Paranthan and Kilinochchi by dusk Tuesday, said the officials. Kilinochchi, 3 miles south of Paranthan, is linked by a national highway to the town of Jaffna, headquarters of the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. The government troops also control the highway north of Paranthan up to the town of Elephant Pass, located just inside the peninsula, officials said. Government paratroopers took Paranthan on Monday after fierce fighting. The troops then moved to Kilinochchi, establishing control of the highway, said the officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. ``Having secured Paranthan, troops established a link between Kilinochchi, Paranthan and Elephant Pass,'' said a senior military official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The report could not be independently confirmed and there was no immediate comment from the rebels. Elephant Pass is 30 miles southeast of Jaffna and 185 miles north of the capital, Colombo. It is at the northern end of the Elephant Pass causeway across the Jaffna lagoon, which links the mainland with the peninsula. The rebels blew up the causeway last week, but military officials said it was repaired over the weekend. The causeway is the only viable route for large-scale crossing onto the peninsula, which hangs like a scorpion's tail from the northern end of the island. Elephant Pass has been under the tenuous control of government troops since fighting started June 11. The rebels now are pushed north of the town. The rebels control most of the peninsula and some pockets in the east. About 2,900 combatants have been killed in the fighting in the two predominantly-Tamil districts, where the rebels seek to establish a separate homeland. On Tuesday, the militants raided a small Sinhalese colony in the northeastern district of Polonnaruwa and killed eight Sinhalese as they slept, military officials said. The victims, four men, two women and two children, were hacked and shot, they said. Also Tuesday, the rebels raided a mosque and killed two Moslems in the eastern town of Sammanturai, accusing them of being military informers, said the officials. Tamil militants have been fighting for an independent homeland since 1983, saying they are victims of discrimination in jobs and education by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The Sinhalese, who control the government and the military, comprise 75 percent. The latest round of fighting ended a 13-month cease-fire called by both sides in May 1989 to help push peace talks. At least 13,900 people have been killed in the 7-year-old Tamil insurrection.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Researcher Finds New Moon Around Saturn
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A NASA researcher analyzing 30,000 images taken a decade ago by the Voyager II space probe discovered a hidden moon in Saturn's outermost ring. ``It was actually in the first image I looked at,'' said Mark Showalter, a scientist at NASA's Ames Research Center in Mountain View. ``It was exactly where I expected it to be.'' Showalter on July 2 found a bright, 12-mile-diameter orb undetected by Earth-based telescopes. ``I remember I was so excited I worked through July Fourth,'' he said Tuesday after the space agency announced the discovery of Saturn's 18th moon. In 1986, National Aeronautics and Space Administration researchers first theorized a moon was hidden within what is known as the Encke's gap around Saturn, but Showalter said he wasn't able to search for it until recently. ``The honest truth is we just didn't work on this for a few years,'' Showalter said. ``When you drop a research project, it's very hard to pick it back up.'' His find confirmed what scientists had believed for several years _ that undiscovered moons could be hidden among Saturn's three major icy rings, making them undulate and causing gaps in several minor rings. ``Theory has predicted this new moon for years,'' said David Morrison, chief of Ames' space science division. ``It's very gratifying to find that the theory was correct. It's almost a textbook example of the scientific process.'' Showalter, 32, found the moon by using a computer program he designed to sort through the 30,000 Saturn images sent back to Earth by Voyager in 1980 and 1981. The moon, Saturn's smallest, orbits in Encke's gap within the planet's outermost major ring. Showalter and Ames' planetary ring expert Jeff Cuzzi theorized that a small moon was creating a 200-mile wide gap with its orbit and was leaving a ``moonlet wake'' pattern similar to boat wakes. The computer program was based on that hypothesis. ``The trick was writing the computer program to tell me which images to look at,'' Showalter said. ``After that it was actually a day's work to find it.'' During the next several days he found 11 images of the moon. Pete Waller, manager of public information for NASA, said the moon is orbiting about 73,600 kilometers from Saturn's cloud tops and weighs about 1 trillion tons. It's tentatively known as 1981S13. The discovery was reported last week in a publication by the International Astronomical Union, which now must certify the find and approve a name. That could a year. Showalter has suggested Pan, the Greek god of shepherds, because the moon creates a so-called ``shepherding effect'' by pushing material away from its orbit to cause the ring gap. Showalter said he doesn't expect any more hidden moons to be found within that gap, but scientists have theorized that undiscovered moons might be spotted in another major gap around Saturn known as the Cassini Division.

DOC.HEAD: Patients Face Minimal Risk of Getting AIDS From Surgeons, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Physicians with AIDS are unlikely to transmit the deadly virus to patients during surgery, according to a study of 2,160 people operated on by a Tennessee doctor who had the disease. None of the patients whom Dr. Harold Dennison operated on between 1982 and his 1989 death are believed to have contracted AIDS during surgery, a report in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association said. Only one patient, an intravenous drug user who frequented prostitutes, tested positive for the AIDS virus. But the authors concluded that the patient had contracted AIDS through his high-risk activities and not from surgical contact with Dennison, who removed a lymph node from the man in 1984. ``The results of this investigation support the concept that risks to patients operated on by (surgeons infected with the AIDS virus) are most likely quite low,'' wrote the authors, led by Dr. Ban Mishu of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. An accompanying editorial by Dr. Frank Rhame, a University of Minnesota AIDS expert, estimates that hundreds of AIDS-infected surgeons are practicing in the United States. The CDC has no figures on the number of U.S. surgeons and physicians infected with AIDS, said spokeswoman Gayle Lloyd. But of the 139,765 AIDS cases reported in the United States since 1981, more than 5,000 involved health-care workers, including doctors, nurses, lab technicians and other medical workers, she said. But Rhame said there are no known surgeon-to-patient transmissions of the disease. He estimated the risk of patients being infected by their surgeons at between one in 100,000 and one in 1 million operations. Dennison, 56, died Jan. 30, 1989, just weeks after he tested positive for AIDS. Dennison believed he contracted AIDS while operating on a patient with the disease, but he didn't know when he had been infected, co-author Dr. William Schaffner of Vanderbilt University's School of Medicine said in a telephone interview Tuesday. It was estimated that Dennison had been infected no earlier than 1982, so with the help from Baptist Hospital, HCA West Side Hospital and HCA Park View Hospital _ the Nashville facilities where he worked _ the authors learned the names and addresses of the 2,160 patients he had operated on since then. None of them had been reported to Tennessee's AIDS registry, and 264 had died. None of the deaths were AIDS-related. The authors mailed letters to the 1,896 remaining patients, seeking to have them tested for AIDS. Letters to 244 patients were returned marked ``address unknown.'' Of the 1,652 who were contacted, 615 were tested for AIDS. Although 1,037 patients chose not to submit to tests, those who were tested had undergone the most invasive operations or had been operated on most recently _ when Dennison was the most contagious _ and thus faced the greatest risk of contracting the virus, Schaffner said. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, cripples victims' ability to fight infections. It is passed through blood and other body fluids.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Insurgents Blast U.S. For Planned Funding Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Rebels fighting the Soviet-backed Afghan government reacted angrily today to a U.S. move to slash their military aid as part of efforts with Moscow to work out a cease-fire plan. The mujahedeen, or Moslem holy warriors, have been bankrolled by the United States for more than a decade. ``It will damage the good will between the mujahedeen and the United States, said Suleiman Shah, spokesman for a provisional rebel government. ``Even now many people in the resistance are skeptical of the true dependability of the United States.'' On Tuesday a U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee voted to slash aid to the mujahedeen, claiming Washington had achieved its purpose in Afghanistan when Soviet troops withdrew in February 1989, said Sen. Frank Murkowski, R.-Alaska, a panel member. Shah claimed Moscow still funds its Kabul allies to the tune of about $300 million a month. Washington had been giving the guerrillas between $300 million and $500 million annually. A U.S. congressional source, speaking on condition of anonymity in Washington, said about $100 million would be cut from covert aid to Afghan rebels in 1991. ``The Russians despite economic problems inside the Red empire and (internal) political upheaval have done nothing to stop aid to their puppets in Kabul,'' said Shah. ``It's true that lots of signs of change have taken place inside and outside the Russian empire, but nothing has changed in Afghanistan,'' he said. The U.S. Embassy in Islamabad refused to comment on the proposed cuts. Rebel supporters in Washington are hoping money would be restored at higher levels before the entire Senate finishes work on the bill, which includes 1991 money for covert action around the world. Washington and Moscow have been trying to work out a political end to the 12-year-old war that has claimed more than 1 million lives. Three million Afghans live in squalid refugee camps throughout Pakistan's rugged border provinces. Two million live in Iran. Most fled their homeland after 1979 when the Soviet Union sent about 115,000 soldiers into Afghanistan to help crush a burgeoning insurgency and install a friendly communist government in Kabul. A U.N.-brokered accord provided for the Soviet troop withdrawal. The United Nations has been trying to initiate a political settlement along with the two superpowers, who claim to be close to an agreement. Next week in Irkutsk, Siberia, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze are to discuss a timetable for Afghan President Najibullah to step down, said U.S. officials in Washington who spoke on condition of anonymity Tuesday. The stumbling block among the rebels has been Najibullah's role in a post-war Afghanistan. Washington has agreed Najibullah could remain as president during elections, but only if he gives up control of the military, media and state-run secret police. Earlier this month Najibullah seemed ready to go along with the plan, but Western diplomats feared he was not prepared to turn the power over to a neutral body. There has been no reported progress on who would assume control of the key ministries during an election. A Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said ``we're just waiting for the Soviets to return with a reply. We've gone as far as we can go and still get the mujahedeen to sign on.'' The United States earlier refused to even accept Najibullah's presence in Kabul before or after elections. But Washington revised its bargaining position after guerrilla fighters, who had been expected to overrun Kabul shortly after the Soviet troop withdrawal, fought to a stalemate on the battlefield and were defeated in successive political battles. ``The United States doesn't care about the people of Afghanistan. ... It was just looking for its own benefit in Afghanistan,'' said Abdul Haidi, a spokesman for the vociferously anti-Western Hezb-e-Islami (Party of Islam) rebel group, led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. Hekmatyar's party has been linked to the narcotics trade, which some senators cited as part of the rationale for reducing assistance. Hekmatyar has repeatedly denied the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Landslide Victory In UMW Vote
DOC.TEXT: Workers at one of Kentucky's largest coal companies voted overwhelmingly to join the United Mine Workers, culminating a bitter organizing drive. Tuesday's 540-149 vote at South East Coal Co. was ``the largest victory the United Mine Workers has had, that I'm aware of, in the last 15 years,'' said Don Barnett, the union's assistant regional director for the South. ``I think this is a direct result of the victory at Pittston,'' Barnett said. The union settled a 10-month strike against Pittston Coal Group on Feb. 19 when 1,700 workers in Kentucky, West Virginia and Virginia approved a new contract. Miners and union organizers celebrated loudly at a motel in this small eastern Kentucky town, slapping backs and showering each other with champagne. Officials at South East declined to comment. In a newspaper advertisement before the vote, the company had warned of ``possible strikes, work stoppages and violence'' if the union prevailed. South East, one of the state's largest coal companies, operates four underground mines and a large coal processing plant in Irvine. Last year the company mined 2 million tons of coal. Workers were angry the company didn't offer a retirement plan, had cut health benefits and hadn't raised salaries since 1981. Top scale for South East's 738 hourly workers is $11.75 per hour; under the union's 1988 national contract, top pay is $17.38 per hour. ``It just proves that everybody was fed up,'' said Greg Horn, 29, a laborer from Whitesburg. UMW President Richard Trumka telephoned his congratulations to the new union members. Trumka, who turned 41 Tuesday, called the union vote ``the best birthday present he could have had,'' Barnett said. The UMW and other unions nationally have suffered membership losses and organizing defeats in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The blood is circulating a little bit better than it was yesterday afternoon at five o'clock. ... I didn't think it was going to happen. I was astonished.'' _ David H. Souter a day after President Bush nominated him to replace Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr.

``If we don't apply, we'll lose out and become poor like all communists. ... I'm doing this for my son.'' _ John Lam, a 41-year-old office manager, as he waited at the Immigration Department in Hong Kong for permission to move to Britain before Chinese communist's take over in 1997.

``Ordinary spiders are perfectly harmless and they are marvelous friends to have around the house.'' _ Dr. Michael H. Robinson, director of Washington's National Zoo, trying to ease fear of spiders prompted by the movie ``Arachnophobia.''

DOC.HEAD: No Official Bottle for New York
DOC.TEXT: New York has an official fruit and an official muffin, but it won't have a state bottle so long as Gov. Mario Cuomo can help it. Cuomo vetoed a bill Tuesday that would have designated the collectible container for Empire Spring Mineral Water as the state's official bottle. He said the naming of official state objects has gotten out of hand. ``We have walked the line a number of times in recent years with these `memorializations,' '' Cuomo said. ``This bill crosses it.'' Cuomo also said he didn't want to give a collectible an advantage in the marketplace. The pint-sized emerald-colored bottles now fetch $4 or $5 apiece. Lawmakers pushing for official designation had hoped to draw tourists to the National Bottle Museum in Ballston Spa, a northeastern New York town. With the veto, the bottle fails to join other state symbols that include the official fruit (apple), tree (sugar maple), insect (lady bug) and muffin (apple).

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Parts of Northeast, West.
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell along the New England coastline and was scattered in the West early today. Early morning temperatures were mostly mild across the nation. Rain also fell today in central Wyoming and just west of the Cascades in Washington state. In the Midwest, there was rain at Minneapolis and St. Paul, Minn., and thundershowers in western and eastern Nebraska. In New England, there were thunderstorms in Boston and light rain along the coast in Maine. Mostly dry weather prevailed early today in much of the remainder of the nation. Today's forecast called for pleasant and dry weather from the central Appalachians to the Great Lakes region. Along the Gulf coast, occasional thunderstorms were expected later in the day. Flooding was possible. Thunderstorms were expected today to pound the Cascades and northern Rockies with rain, hail and strong winds. Thunderstorms also were likely in the central and northern Plains and the desert Southwest. The nation's high on Tuesday was 110 degrees at Bullhead City, Ariz.
