DOC.HEAD: Garlic Rustlers Have Mac McDonald to Contend With
DOC.TEXT: Garlic rustlers beware: Mac McDonald is on your trail. Garlic, a major crop in the Gilroy area, is disappearing from fields and farm bins. That's why McDonald, a deputy sheriff, patrols southern Santa Clara County with garlic snatchers in mind. ``He doesn't fool around. He's saved us I don't know how much money,'' said Mike Martelli, vice president of field production at Christopher Ranch, Gilroy's largest garlic grower. Garlic is the most popular haul among the region's crop thieves, McDonald says. Most of 70 people he has arrested during the last three months for crop rustling have been for garlic. ``Basically, I think there isn't anything that somebody won't take for free,'' McDonald said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Office Moving to Shopping Mall
DOC.TEXT: Village Hall is moving to the mall. Mayor Joel Rosenthal says government outgrew the old hall and will have twice the space at the Valley Plaza Shopping Mall. The village's board of trustees approved the switch Monday. Government agencies could move into its 27,500 square feet at the mall as early as next spring. A developer that owns the mall will take over the government's old home. The mall space will cost the village $1.4 million, or $600,000 above the hall's $800,000 pricetag, Rosenthal said. He said the village will make up $500,000 of the difference by selling another municipal building. The move is aimed at revitalizing the shopping center and providing more space for government, the mayor said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against other major currencies in light early European trading today. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said the dollar was boosted by a modest recovery on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday after Monday's sharp decline. Traders said markets were quiet ahead of Friday's release of second-quarter U.S. gross national product figures. ``There isn't really any news that could move the dollar either way right now,'' said a trader at a large U.S. bank in Frankfurt. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.43 yen to a closing 149.13 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 149.17 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6240 West German marks, up from 1.6185 _1.3840 Swiss francs, up from 1.3750 _5.4463 French francs, up from 5.4275 _1.8303 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8230 _1,189.25 Italian lire, up from 1,184.75 _1.1567 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1557 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8085, compared with $1.8250 late Tuesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $367.40 a troy ounce this morning, down from $368.25 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $367.40, down from $368.35 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $1.42 to close at a bid $367.83. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.86 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.85.

DOC.HEAD: Bail for Marlon Brando's Son in Murder Trial Set at $10 Million
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's son was ordered to stand trial for murder in the fatal shooting of his half-sister's boyfriend at the family estate, and bail was set at $10 million. The rulings by Muncipal Court Judge Larry Fidler on Tuesday came after a two-day preliminary hearing in which Christian Brando was quoted as saying he accidentally killed Dag Drollet, 26, in a fight over a gun. Brando, 32, said a scuffle broke out because the victim was abusing his pregnant half-sister, Cheyenne Brando. ``Death is too good for the guy,'' Brando was quoted as telling police shortly after the killing at his father's Hollywood Hills mansion. Drollet's body was found on a couch, still holding a cigarette lighter and a television remote control, and prosecutors say there was no sign of a struggle. The judge decided that Brando should stand trial for murder, not the lesser charge of manslaughter his lawyer had wanted. ``There has been a killing and the defendant pulled the trigger,'' Fidler said. Prosecutors argued that Brando should be held without bail because his father's fortune could meet any bail amount and allow him to flee the country. ``If the court sets bail in this case, Christian Brando will make it even if it's $20 million,'' said Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop. To support his argument, Barshop cited Miss Brando's recent departure for Tahiti, where she remains. She is not expected to return for the trial. Defense attorney Robert Shapiro said Christian would not jump bail because he would never betray his father, known for his starring roles in such films as ``On the Waterfront'' and ``The Godfather.'' ``This is a young man who has great and tremendous respect for his father,'' Shapiro said as the bulky, white-haired actor listened from a front row courtroom seat. After the judge's decision, the elder Brando was hurriedly led out a back door of the courtroom. Later, Shapiro said bail would be posted but declined to say when Brando's release from jail was expected. District Attorney spokeswoman Sandi Gibbons said the $10 million bail is likely the highest ever set by a judge in Los Angeles County. Brando also will be tried on a weapons charge for allegedly possessing a machine gun. If convicted, he could face 25 years to life in prison. Arraignment in Superior Court arraignment was scheduled for Aug. 7. During arguments, the prosecutor quoted spontaneous comments Brando made to the first police officer on the scene. ``I did it because he hurt my sister. My sister is pregnant. ... He was laying on the couch. He was fighting with my sister. I said, `You leave my sister alone,''' the policeman quoted Brando as saying. Later in the statement, Brando conceded that he did not like Drollet and declared, ``Man, death is too good for the guy.''

DOC.HEAD: Nick, The 37-year-old Gorilla, Dies at National Zoo
DOC.TEXT: One of the oldest gorillas in the United States has died at the National Zoo. Nikumba, a lowland gorilla who sired one of the first gorillas born in captivity, died Monday of natural causes, the zoo said. He had been at the zoo since 1955. Nikumba, a popular attraction known as ``Nick,'' was believed to be 37, the zoo said. His death leaves six gorillas at the zoo, including his mate, Haloko. Nikumba had four offspring, including Tamoka, who was born at the National Zoo in 1961 and was then only the third gorilla in the world to have been born in captivity, according to the zoo.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco Says It Will Appeal Judge's Order to Pay $155 Million
DOC.TEXT: Amoco Corp. said it will appeal a federal court order to pay $155 million in damages and interest from a massive oil spill by the tanker Cadiz off northern France in 1978. ``We feel the claims were exaggerated,'' Amoco spokesman Mike Thompson said Tuesday after the penalty was announced. Amoco's decision to appeal the order issued by U.S. District Judge Charles Norgle promised to prolong the case, a prospect lamented by plaintiffs. ``We, Amoco's victims in Brittany, pray that this great American company, in its concern for justice and the environment, will finally pay for the damage that it has caused us,'' said Jean-Baptiste Henry, spokesman for the local governments and businesses who sued Amoco. ``After 12 years and two judges, we fail to see what Amoco hopes to gain with an appeal,'' Henry said. About 100 French towns have argued the spill adversely affected their commerce. Amoco was held liable for Europe's largest spill, which fouled 100 miles of France's coastline. Norgle on Tuesday formally endorsed an order he spelled out in June. That order was based on damage recommendations from former U.S. District Judge Frank McGarr, appointed the case's special master after retiring from the bench in January 1988. The order was finalized after lawyers for Amoco and the French parties suing the Chicago-based company agreed upon interest payments on the damages. Norgle ordered Amoco to pay about 690 million francs, or about $120 million split equally in damages and interest, to the French government, local governments and businesses. Amoco also was ordered to pay damages in British pounds to the Shell oil company, owner of the spilled oil, in the rough equivalent of $35 million. Amoco Tuedsay also said it will sue the ship's builder, Astilleros Espanoles, S.A., of Spain, to recover damages. The Spanish shipbuilder has refused to participate in the U.S. District Court, contending it lacks jurisdiction. In a statement, however, it said the court found that Amoco's ``extensive negligence'' was the cause of the grounding and oil spill. The tanker ran aground March 16, 1978, two miles off the Brittany coast, and spilled 68 million gallons of light fuel oil _ the world's worst spill until a spill in the Gulf of Mexico in 1979. The Exxon Valdez last year spilled nearly 11 million gallons. The Amoco Cadiz was under tow through the English Channel when the towlines snapped in hurricane-force winds and heavy seas, impaling it on rocks.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Could Face Criminal Charges; Fellow Indians Rally To Their Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: MOVES up reference to pro-Mohawk march. fixes ``native'' to ``Indian.'' No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk Indians locked in an armed impasse over a plot of land are running low on food and could face criminal charges. But other Indians from across the nation are rallying to their support. The Assembly of First Nations said Tuesday it was organizing a ``peace and justice caravan'' that is expected in Oka on Sunday. Ovide Mercredi, Manitoba regional chief of the Indian assembly, said as many as 10,000 Indians and non-Indians from across Canada would take part. He said they would try to take food and essential supplies to the Oka Mohawks but do not plan to challenge police barricades. Police have opened several hundred criminal investigations which could lead to charges from Quebec's justice minister against the Mohawks, provincial police Constable Andre Blanchette said Tuesday. The investigations began after the death of Cpl. Marcel Lemay during a police assault on the Mohawk barricades at the Kanesatake reservation near Oka, about 20 miles west of Montreal. Two of the investigations concern possible charges of murder and conspiracy to murder the 31-year-old police officer, though it has not yet been determined whether he was shot by an Indian or a fellow officer. Other charges include possession of prohibited firearms, discharging firearms, theft of police vehicles, blocking roads, threatening to blow up a bridge, firing submachine-guns, evicting tenants and misdemeanors. The reservation, home to 6,000 people, has been closed by police and Indian blockades since July 11, when police tried to storm the Mohawk barricade. Provincial police are only letting limited supplies through. The police raid brought to a head a four-month barricade by the Mohawks, who want to stop expansion of a municipal golf course onto land in Oka they claim is ancestral Mohawk territory. The Mohawks have rejected government demands that they put down their arms and remove the barricades before negotiations for a solution take place. They want the police to withdraw before they disarm and are demanding shipments of food, clothing, medical supplies. They also want observers from either the United Nations or Amnesty International to be brought in. On Tuesday, the Quebec Human Rights Commission called on the police to respect the provincial Charter of Rights and to allow the free movement of people, food and medicine into the reservation. The commission wants Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa to intervene personally. Spokesman Jacques Lachapelle told a Montreal news conference the commission is considering suing the police for blocking the flow of food into the settlement. Residents are allowed to cross police lines with one bag of groceries, and some food is brought in on back roads and across the Ottawa River. But Ellen Gabriel, a Mohawk representative, said children behind the barricades aren't getting a balanced diet. A Red Cross team got through the police blockade on Tuesday and distributed food and supplies to the Mohawks. Linda Gauthier, a Red Cross official, said the agency hopes to check on the situation every two or three days. She said the Red Cross distributed enough food for 80 people for three days. The Kanasetake Mohawks have drawn support from other Indians across Canada, including roadblocks in British Columbia and a blockade by other Mohawks of the Mercier Bridge into Montreal, 18 miles from Oka. The Mercier Bridge blockade has forced thousands of people to find other ways to get into the city from the south shore of Montreal island.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Leader Leaves Church After Scandal, Plans Political Career
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Allan Boesak, a prominent anti-apartheid campaigner, said today he is resigning his church posts to seek a political career after a scandal over an extramarital affair. Boesak, saying he wants to play a role in South African politics, reaffirmed a decision to step down as a Protestant minister despite pleas from other religious leaders and friends not to leave the church. ``I have ... decided to offer my services to the people of this country to bring about a united, non-racial and democratic South Africa. I am prepared to play any role which I may be called upon to play in this regard,'' he said in a statement released by his lawyer. Church officials had asked Boesak to reconsider when he announced earlier this month that he was resigning. But he said today he could not alter his decision to step down as a minister of the Sendingkerk Church and as president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, an international council of Protestant churches. The mixed-race leader also said he would continue his relationship with television journalist Elna Botha. Press revelations about Boesak's relationship with Ms. Botha led him to announce he was resigning. Boesak said he and his wife, Dorothy, would divorce. He said he was not ashamed of his relationship with Ms. Botha and hoped the press would ignore his private life. ``The breakdown of my marriage was a fact long before I met Elna and what exists between us is a personal matter and nothing which I can be ashamed of. I have, therefore, no valid reason to discontinue such contact,'' the statement said. Ms. Botha, in a separate statement, said she would continue to see Boesak. She said her marriage to television journalist Colin Fluxman had broken down before she began a relationship with Boesak earlier this year. Ms. Botha works for the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp. Boesak has played a major role in the opposition to apartheid, leading demonstrations and touring the world to denounce South Africa's racial segregation. Boesak, who was long thought to be interested in a political career, models himself after the late Martin Luther King Jr. The revelations about Boesak and Ms. Botha were seen as a moral scandal in South Africa since both were married and Boesak was an ordained minister. Boesak came under fire in the mid-1980s following news reports of his involvement with a female church worker. A church inquiry later cleared him of any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Seeks Agreement to End Civil War in Afghanistan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lead to reflect Baker departure; single name Najibullah in 2nd graf correct
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will try to clear the last roadblocks to a cease-fire in Afghanistan during a four-nation trip to Asia that began today. U.S. officials said Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will discuss a timetable for President Najibullah to step down during their meeting next week in Irkutsk, Soviet Siberia. ``The Soviets hinted at a deal; they haven't fleshed it out,'' an administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday. ``The thread of the deal is going to be pursued in Irkutsk by Baker.'' Members of Congress also have been pushing for a settlement in the 12-year-old civil war. Earlier this month, members of the Senate Intelligence Committee voted to cut aid to the Afghan rebels. Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, a member of the committee, said he did not attend the meeting where the vote was taken, but the rationale was that the rebels had achieved their purpose. A congressional source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he understood the panel reduced funding for the rebels by about $100 million. Last fall, Congress reportedly appropriated about $300 million for the rebels. Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the intelligence committee, would not talk about the action on Afghanistan. In the past, however, he has called for a reassessment of aid to the rebels. A State Department official said Congress appropriates less than 10 percent of what the Soviets give their allies in Afghanistan. Moscow reportedly spends about $300 million a month to maintain the Najibullah government. For weeks the Bush administration has hoped for a breakthrough to end the war between Afghan government forces armed by the Soviet Union and a guerrilla coalition fighting with American-supplied weapons funneled through Pakistan. The administration official disputed a report from Moscow by ABC News on Tuesday that Shevardnadze and Baker already had cut a deal to end the civil war. Baker is scheduled to meet Shevardnadze on Aug. 1. The Soviets have not yet conveyed to the United States how Najibullah might be removed from power in Kabul, said the administration official. The Soviet Union installed the Najibullah government in 1979, but the government in Kabul has been unable to impose its will on the countryside. The Soviets withdrew their troops last year but continued to supply arms. The Soviets canceled plans this month to send a delegation to Washington for talks on when Najibullah should yield power. Both sides already have reached a tacit agreement that Najibullah would play no role in the new government and would step down at some point before his successor take over. Administration officials did not criticize Moscow for not sending the delegation. They said they thought the Kremlin was simply preoccupied with the 28th Communist Party Congress at the time. On his Asia trip, Baker also will attend a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Indonesia, and will hold talks in Singapore and visit Outer Mongolia.

DOC.HEAD: Stradivarius Stolen from Violinist at Airport
DOC.TEXT: A musician's Stradivarius violin, worth about half a million dollars, was snatched from an airport baggage cart, police said. Erich Gruenberg, 65, was carrying the violin, crafted in 1731, as he checked through customs after arriving from London at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday afternoon, said city police Sgt. Dave Nichols. The musician reported the violin disappeared from the baggage cart as he was leaving the airport, Nichols said. The instrument was insured for about $500,000. Also stolen were a violin worth $8,000 and two bows worth $3,500. There were no arrests by early today, Nichols said. Thefts at the airport are a common occurrence, but the thief may not have realized what it was he was plucking from the cart, Nichols said. ``If he reads the paper he will, so I guess it won't take him too long to figure it out,'' he said. Scholars estimate that Antonio Stradivari made nearly 1,120 of the prized violins bearing his name before his death in 1737. Less than a few hundred are believed to exist. Gruenberg's whereabouts were not known. Nichols said he believed that Gruenberg came to Los Angeles on vacation and was staying with friends. The Austrian-born performer and music teacher makes his home in England and has played with the London Symphony Orchestra. He now appears as a soloist with leading orchestras in Britain and abroad. He was made an honorary member of the Royal Academy of Music in London on July 4.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez Skipper Faces New Fight to Keep License
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing begins at noon EDT, lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Capt. Joseph Hazelwood will try to hold on to his license as a ship's master at a Coast Guard hearing to determine if he was guilty of negligence in the nation's worst oil spill. Today's administrative law hearing comes just four months after the skipper of the Exxon Valdez was acquitted in Alaska on similar charges. The judge, Harry J. Gardner, could elect to dismiss all charges, revoke Hazelwood's license or place him on probation, according to the Coast Guard and Hazelwood's lawyers. No fine or prison term can be levied. Hazelwood was accused of breaking a Coast Guard rule by drinking alcohol within four hours of assuming command of his ship and leaving the ship's bridge while the vessel was traveling through Prince William Sound. He also was accused of leaving a crewman who did not have a required license in control of the bridge. Hazelwood's attorney, Michael Chalos, contended in a telephone interview Tuesday that any drinking within four hours of sailing was unintentional because the ship left port an hour earlier than scheduled. He argued the Coast Guard had waived its requirement that the person in control of the bridge have a pilotage license for Prince William Sound and said the Coast Guard did not adequately monitor the Exxon Valdez via radar. The Exxon Valdez was en route from the Alaskan port of Valdez to Long Beach on March 24, 1989, when it struck a charted reef. Gashed by jagged rocks, the 987-foot tanker spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil. Hazelwood was acquitted of being drunk and reckless, but was convicted of one misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. He was ordered to pay $50,000 restitution and spend 1,000 hours cleaning beaches at Prince William Sound. He is appealing the verdict.

DOC.HEAD: Leak Detected During Third Testing of Atlantis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with leak detected, prospects of upcoming shuttle flights. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Atlantis' leak ...'.
DOC.TEXT: NASA detected a hydrogen leak during testing today of Atlantis' fuel tank, which could mean a trip back to the hangar for the shuttle and further reduction of NASA's 1990 flight plans. This morning's test was the third filling of Atlantis' external fuel tank in hopes of pinpointing the leak's source. The shuttle had been scheduled to blast off on a classified Pentagon flight in mid-July. There was no immediate indication how much fuel escaped during today's testing, but it appeared to exceed allowed amounts. ``It is currently unclear where the leaks were originating from,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. ``We are analyzing the situation.'' Space agency workers had tightened bolts in Atlantis' porous fuel line, but officials doubted that would be enough to correct the problem. The space shuttle Columbia also is crippled by a hydrogen leak and is being fixed. If no leaks had occurred in Atlantis today, NASA would have tried to launch it in mid-August and Columbia in September. The possibility of launching both shuttles in the next two months was uncertain after the leak reappeared. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today also planned to launch an Atlas rocket bearing a government satellite designed to illuminate the Earth's usually invisible magnetic fields with brightly colored gas cloud displays. Atlantis' leak was believed to be in a flange in a pipe that carries liquid hydrogen from the tank to the main engines. Plastic bags to isolate leaking gas and about 20 sensors were placed over the flange and elsewhere in the fuel line to help find the source of the leak. Atlantis' leak was discovered during the first so-called tanking test, on June 29. That prompted NASA to temporarily ground its three-shuttle fleet. The leak also appeared during a more elaborate test two weeks later. Columbia's leak, believed to be larger and in a different place, was detected during fueling for a May 30 launch attempt. The leaky plumbing has been replaced with components from the new shuttle Endeavour, under construction in California. If Atlantis goes back to the hangar, NASA could attach a new external tank and roll the shuttle back to the launch pad for a September liftoff, or move Columbia out to the pad for a September flight with the Astro observatory. NASA officials want to get at least one of the shuttles up before Discovery's October mission with the sun-probing Ulysses satellite. Discovery must lift off between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23 or the mission will be delayed 13 months, when Earth is in proper alignment again with the sun and Jupiter.

DOC.HEAD: East German Prime Minister Tries to Keep Government From Unraveling
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere convened his Cabinet today, but there were two empty chairs because one party pulled out of the government in a clash over united German elections. The departure of the centrist Liberal Party, and a threat by the left-leaning Social Democrats to follow suit, has jeopardized the broad coalition chosen to steer the nation to unity with West Germany. The Social Democrats, the nation's second-biggest party, have said they will leave the government by Friday unless their demands are met. Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, president of the Parliament and a Christian Democrat, pleaded for unity and told the Liberals that they can return to the government. ``The door to the coalition is not entirely shut,'' she said of the dispute, which could delay reunification if it worsens. The Social Democrats and the Liberals want East Germany to dissolve itself on Dec. 1 and for single elections across German lands to be held on Dec. 2. Parties would need at least 5 percent of the vote from the entire combined electorate to be represented in a new united Parliament. De Maiziere and several smaller parties, including the former Communists ousted last year, want East Germany to wait until just after the Dec. 2 elections before it ceases to be a nation. The elections would be held separately in both German states. How a party did in its own country would determine its representation in Parliament. Under that scenario, a party would have a far better chance of winning 5 percent of the vote in East Germany than if the electorates were combined. That proposal would increase the likelihood that smaller East German political parties would get seats in a new Parliament. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, like de Maiziere a Christian Democrat, wants smaller East German conservative parties to win seats so they can bolster a Christian Democrat coalition. The Social Democrats believe they will be hurt by the separate elections because it would split the left-leaning vote among smaller leftist parties. Political analysts say the outcome of the feud could help determine whether Kohl, or the Social Democrats, govern a united Germany. The Liberals resigned from the government late Tuesday and the two Liberals in the Cabinet _ Regional Affairs Minister Manfred Preiss and Construction Minister Axel Viehwege _ stayed away from a Cabinet meeting this morning. The Liberals hold 21 of the 400 seats in Parliament and two of the 26 ministries. If the Social Democrats also leave the government, de Maiziere could lose control of Parliament, where a two-thirds majority is needed to enact unification. However, all major parties are committed to unification. The strife, if not settled, would more likely slow the process rather than derail it. In an interview with the West German newspaper Bild today, de Maiziere was quoted as saying the Liberals' departure ``would not hinder my government'' and that the process of unifying Germany would be completed. De Maiziere later flew to Vienna for a meeting with Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky. The two were to discuss economic ties. The East German leader also had reportedly planned to consult with Kohl, who is vacationing in Austria, on the government crisis. But a de Maiziere spokesman said no meeting was planned.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says ANC Will Halt Violence Once Reforms Are Made
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said today the African National Congress will halt its armed struggle as soon as the government meets its demands for political reforms, and possibly sooner. Mandela indicated the ANC might accept a government commitment to change, rather than insisting on the reforms being implemented before armed action ceases. ``The government must remove all the obstacles. Then we will suspend the armed struggle,'' Mandela said, adding that the timing of the cease-fire was negotiable. But Mandela also said, ``As long as apartheid is the case, the armed struggle will go on.'' The ANC, of which Mandela is deputy president, is demanding the government allow thousands of exiles to return home without fear of arrest; free prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes; stop trials for politically motivated acts; repeal laws restricting political freedom; and lift the state of emergency in Natal province. Until these changes are made, the ANC has said it will not participate in formal negotiations with the government on ending apartheid to give the black majority a say in national affairs. The government wants the ANC to formally end its military activities before negotiations begin. Mandela told a news conference the ANC leadership was confident progress would be made on clearing away the obstacles at an Aug. 6 meeting with government officials. The ANC National Executive Committee decided at a two-day meeting that it will definitely suspend all armed activites once the obstacles have been removed, he said. He added that ANC guerrillas have not killed anyone since talks with the government began in May. He acknowledged that the ANC leadership was having difficulty getting word to members of its guerrilla wing _ Spear of the Nation _ about the plan to suspend armed activity. ``The men ... who have been deployed in the country are still operating according to the old instructions and we have been trying to reach all of them,'' Mandela said. The government and ANC agreed to commit themselves to a peaceful resolution of the country's problems during talks in May, two months after President F.W. de Klerk freed Mandela from prison and legalized the ANC after a 30-year ban. The government has granted amnesty to certain ANC leaders and allowed them to enter the country to begin reforming the organization. However, it is still illegal for ANC guerrillas to infiltrate and store weapons. In addition, de Klerk has not lifted the state of emergency in Natal province, the site of black factional fighting. Mandela said no infiltrations of guerrillas had occurred since the May 2-4 peace talks. He also denied local news reports of an alleged plot by Communist members of the ANC military wing to mount an insurrection. ``I don't need to repudiate anybody because there is no such plot,'' he said. His comment about ANC members not having killed anyone since May seemed to refer specifically to planned and directed activities by its armed wing. In fighting between ANC supporters and rival black groups, hundreds of people have died in the past few months, and ANC opponents say guerrilla wing members have participated in the violence. The fighting has pitted ANC affiliates against the Zulu-based Inkatha political party in Natal province.

DOC.HEAD: Composer Morty Nevins of `Three Suns' Dead At 73
DOC.TEXT: Morty Nevins, the accordion-playing member of The Three Suns group of the 1940s and '50s, has died. He was 73. Nevins, the last surviving member of the original group, died of cancer Friday at his Beverly Hills home, his daughter, Ferielle Faine said Tuesday. The Three Suns sold several million records over a 20-year span, including ``Peg o' My Heart'' and the trio's signature tune, ``Twilight Time.'' Nevins' brother, Al, played guitar while his cousin, Artie Dunn, sang and played the organ. The Three Suns performed for radio, played club and hotel dates across the nation and were regulars on singer Kate Smith's television show in the early 1950s. The original members disbanded when Al's health began to deteriorate, but Dunn recruited other musicians for several years. Nevins continued to compose music, producing such hit tunes as ``These Things I Offer You for a Lifetime,'' ``Lovers' Gold,'' ``You Are My Destiny'' and ``Midnight for Two.'' Al Nevins died in 1965, and Dunn in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Chopper Crashes During Training, Two Killed, Three Injured
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter crashed during a training exercise at an Army base, killing two soldiers and injuring three others, officials said. Soldiers from the 7th Battalion, 101st Aviation Regiment, were training with the CH-47D Chinook medium-lift helicopter when it crashed Tuesday night at the Fort Campbell Army Base in western Kentucky, said spokesman Bill Harralson. The Chinook is used to carry items such as artillery and fighting vehicles to battle areas. The soldiers were engaged in training with a load slung beneath the copter when it crashed, said Sgt. Steve Sanderson, another post spokesman. Further details were not immediately available. The names of the victims were being withheld pending notification of relatives, Harralson said. Officials from the Army Safety Center at Fort Rucker, Ala., arrived today to begin an investigation.

DOC.HEAD: After Successful Launch, Arianespace To Get a New Leader
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Arianespace rocket launching consortium is leaving for a new job now that the Ariane program is back in business following a liftoff explosion in February. An Ariane rocket successfully lifted a double payload of French and German TV satellites into orbit Tuesday night, five months after a similar rocket exploded. French Transport Minister Paul Quiles, in attendance at the Ariane launch center in French Guiana, announced that Frederic d'Allest, president of Arianespace since its creation in 1980, would be leaving shortly to become second-in-command at the French aerospace company Matra. D'Allest, 50, said he had planned the move for several months but did not want to leave until Arianespace overcame the February failure with a successful mission. He is expected to be replaced by Arianespace's director general, Charles Bigot. Tuesday's flight put the five-channel French television satellite TDF 2 and the 11-channel DFS Kopernikus 2, for West Germany's Deutsche Bundespost Telekom, into geostationary orbit, always staying above the same spot on the Earth's surface at an altitude of 22,328 miles. Ariane Flight 37 was the first launch of a European rocket since an Ariane carrying two Japanese communications satellites blew up less than two minutes after takeoff Feb. 22. Launches were suspended after the accident. February's failure was the fifth in the Ariane series and was particularly costly because Arianespace had lobbied hard for the Japanese contracts. Bigot, who was present for Tuesday's launch, said the flight was doubly important. ``It is putting into orbit two satellites of the countries who have given the most support to Ariane politically, technologically and industrially. It is also the flight in which we pick up after the failure of Flight 36,'' he said. Ariane rockets dominate the private aerospace industry, carrying about half the world's commercial payloads into space. Arianespace, the commercial partner of the European Space Agency, has contracts worth $2.8 billion to launch 37 more satellites. The next mission is scheduled for Aug. 30, putting into orbit a telecommunications satellite for Eutelsat and a British military satellite, Skynet-4C. Arianespace is a consortium made up of aerospace, electronics and banking companies from 11 countries _ Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland, Sweden and West Germany. Its rockets have sent into space 45 commercial satellites from Canada, France, West Germany, Britain, India, Italy, Spain and the United States, as well as international organizations such as Intelsat and Eutelsat. Ariane is facing increased competition, however, from American private-sector rockets including the Titan-4 made by Martin Marietta Corp., General Dynamics' Atlas-Centaur and the Delta built by McDonnell Douglas.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Jumping Off S&L Bandwagon
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to clarify source of contributions
DOC.TEXT: One of Rep. Doug Barnard's Republican opponents announced his candidacy under a billboard showing a giant check for $20,000. ``Give the money back, Congressman Barnard,'' the text demands. The pressure is on, and so is the race by many politicians to get rid of campaign contributions linked to the savings and loan industry. Rising public outrage over the multibillion-dollar thrift mess is making the return of S&L money an increasingly popular means of declaring independence from the troubled industry. While Barnard, D-Ga., a senior member of the House Banking Committee, deliberates over what to do with his S&L contributions, some lawmakers are marking checks ``return to sender.'' Others are mailing the money to the U.S. Treasury, often earmarking their checks for deficit reduction or the fight against S&L fraud. One signed a $98,950 check on Monday and dispatched it to his home state. ``I didn't want to have it go to build MX missiles,'' said Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., explaining Tuesday why he sent the money to the Colorado treasury. Wirth, a Banking Committee member who does not face re-election until 1992, said many of his colleagues are cornering him to ask questions about what he did. ``There's a tremendous feeling of liberation,'' he said. ``I think you're going to see a lot of people doing it, including leadership people.'' Aides to Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas are poring over a decade of records to find contributors associated with troubled thrifts. Dole says he's ``prepared to return'' tainted contributions to the Treasury. Here's what some others are doing: _Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said he was sending the Treasury $120,000 _ all the money he has received from thrift interests and kept since 1983. In 1988, Riegle returned $78,250 he had received from Charles Keating, operator of the failed Lincoln S&L of Irvine, Calif. _Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., running for re-election this year, plans to send the Treasury contributions he's received from people or organizations that are under investigation for wrongdoing in connection with a thrift failure. The money will be earmarked for the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency cleaning up the S&L mess. _Rep. Hank Brown, R-Colo., a Senate candidate, is sending the RTC a check for $9,000 _ all the money he has gotten from S&L interests since he first ran for Congress in 1979. Earlier this year he returned two contributions from board members of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan, a failed Denver thrift. _Rep. Dan Schaefer, R-Colo., is searching for S&L-linked contributions dating from 1983, when he joined Congress. The total _ expected to be nearly $7,000 _ will be sent to the Treasury's public fund for debt reduction. _Rep. Lindsay Thomas, D-Ga., returned $1,100 to a political action committee affiliated with Great Southern Federal Savings & Loan in Savannah to ``avoid any possibility of criticism or misunderstanding.'' His letter was dated June 27, five days after the S&L had been taken over by a Georgia bank in a federally supervised proceeding. The Democratic National Committee recently returned a $5,000 contribution from someone linked to the S&L scandal, but it refused to identify the contributor. DNC Chairman Ron Brown said last week that the party would return contributions ``that are determined to be illegal or where the circumstances surrounding the contribution suggest illegality.'' A Colorado Senate candidate, Democrat Carlos Lucero, has demanded that the Republican National Committee give the Treasury a $100,000 contribution that came from Ken Good after he had declared bankruptcy and defaulted on loans from Silverado. RNC spokeswoman Leslie Goodman said the party is reviewing its contribution records and ``will consider giving back money,'' but she said it would be premature to discuss contributions from specific people or organizations. ``We have to define our terms _ what is taint, how do you define it,'' Ms. Goodman said. ``We're certainly not going to slur anybody's reputation with the implication of guilt and we're not going to act capriciously.'' Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the House Republican campaign committee, has recommended that candidates ship their S&L contributions to the Treasury. But the chairman of the committee, Rep. Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, says he'll do no such thing. Deciding what constitutes tainted money and sifting through reams of records to find it can be a complicated business. Some lawmakers have simplified matters by making a clean sweep of all S&L contributions. ``We couldn't make a distinction between good S&Ls and bad S&Ls,'' Wirth said. The result was his renunciation of nearly $100,000. ``I was just crushed when I found out how much money it was,'' Wirth said, only half-joking. ``But it was probably the best money decision I ever made in a campaign.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed, 12 Wounded in Renewed Clashes For Disputed Town
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Syrian militiamen fought sporadic gunbattles with Iranian-backed rival Shiite Moslems in a strategic hilltop village, leaving at least five combatants dead and 12 wounded, police said today. The fighting came a day after the two sides battled house-to-house in an inconclusive showdown for control of the village of Jarjou. The new casualties raised the overall death toll to 144 killed and 439 wounded since the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, captured Jarjou from the more secular Amal militia in a surprise attack on July 16. Hezbollah's seizure of the village was aimed at expanding its area of control as far as the Mediterranean coast to open a badly needed supply line to Iran. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting intermittently for more than three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Almost 2,000 people have been killed and over 4,000 wounded in that struggle. Tens of thousands of people continue to flee the current fighting in the region of Iqlim al-Tufah, or Apple Province, where Jarjou is located. Police said 50,000 of the province's 75,000 people have left the area. The independent An-Nahar newspaper said Tuesday that only five of Jarjou's original 5,000 inhabitants remain in the town. ``There is no more life in Jarjou,'' said Khadijeh Mukalled, a 56-year-old refugee who fled. ``Every morning when I woke up I didn't believe I was still alive,'' she told reporters in the southern port city of Sidon. ``My house was set ablaze by shellfire. I tried to put off the fire but I couldn't.'' ``At last I decided to escape the hell of Jarjou,'' she said. Police said no new attacks were mounted today and that the only fighting was sporadic exchanges of machine gun and rocket-propelled grenade fire around Jarjou and the surrounding towns. On Tuesday, about 1,500 fighters of the pro-Syrian Amal militia launched a pre-dawn attack on Jarjou behind a rain of mortar shells and rockets. They were backed by about 500 pro-Syrian Lebanese Baath Party militiamen. Police said they captured new positions around the village and appeared to be resting for a new assault. The Baathist intervention on Amal's side suggests that Syrian President Hafez Assad wants to curb Iran's growing influence in Lebanon. Assad is leader of the Syrian Baath party. Syria maintains an estimated 40,000 troops in northern, eastern and central Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the Arab League and regards Lebanon as its own backyard. Ayoub Homayed, second-in-command to Amal chieftain Nabih Berri, called Hezbollah's occupation of Jarjou an Iranian invasion. He said in a statement published by An-Nahar that Amal planned to lodge a complaint to the U.N. Security Council against ``the Iranian invasion of the south which is a very dangerous move that threatens the future of our land and people.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Plane Crashes in South China Sea, Two Crewmen Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with identification of crew members, ADDS background on aircraft. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Navy attack bomber crashed in the South China Sea on a routine night mission, a spokesman of the Navy's 7th Fleet said today. The pilot and navigator were reported missing. Lt. Lee Saunders said the Grumman A-6E Intruder crashed about 8:30 p.m. Tuesday almost 400 miles southwest of the Subic Bay naval base. Subic is about 50 miles west of Manila. Saunders said the plane left the aircraft carrier USS Independence on night flying operations but failed to return. The names of the pilot and the navigator were being witheld pending notification of next of kin, he added. However, Howard Thomas, a spokesman for the Whidbey Island Naval Air Station in Washington, where the plane was based, identified the missing pilot as Lt. Cmdr. Jeffrey Mines, 35, of North Bend, Neb., and the navigator as Lt. Cmdr. Arthur Braun, 37, of Georgetown, Texas. An extensive search for the two missing crewmen was under way, Saunders said. He added that the cause of the accident is under investigation. The Grumman-built A-6E is an all-weather carrier bomber.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Drops All But One Pornography Count Against Former Day-Care Owner
DOC.TEXT: A judge has dropped all but one charge of possessing child pornography against a former day-care center owner who allegedly had hundreds of photographs of nude children. Police had charged John Shaver, 56, with 29 counts of possessing child pornography after police said they found the photographs at his home across from his now-closed Rainbow Learning Center. Shaver faced up to seven years in prison if convicted on all counts. One count would be punishable by up to 22 months. Broward Circuit Judge Robert Tyson Jr. dropped the charges Tuesday after defense attorney J. David Bogenschutz cited a recent state appellate court ruling that defendants can only be charged with one count of pornography possession no matter how many photographs they own. ``It's boiled down to a case of some alleged dirty pictures,'' Bogenschutz said about a police investigation that had widened into whether children at the day-care center had been abused. ``And these pictures aren't even of any children in the day-care.'' Bogenschutz said the state's case, expected to go to trial in September, has fallen apart. But prosecutor Brian Trehy disagreed. ``Nobody ever said this was more than a case of child pornography,'' Trehy said. ``Somehow people got the impression that this was a case of sexual abuse and there was never any evidence of that.'' Trehy said police had interviewed children who attended the day-care center and their parents because it was ``prudent in light of the situation to at least inquire whether there had been any abuse.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Investigating Whether FBI Agent Avoided Drunken Driving Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Lanier denied ...' to remove extraneous matter.
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors are investigating allegations that South Carolina's top FBI agent avoided a drunken driving arrest with the help of the state's chief highway patrolman, sources said. Justice Department officials were expected to arrive here today to begin the investigation of Fred Verinder, the FBI's special agent-in-charge for the state, government sources told The Associated Press, speaking on condition of anonymity. Verinder was taken home March 23 rather than to jail by Col. J.H. ``Red'' Lanier, the state highway department's director of law enforcement, the source said. The FBI agent was stopped north of Columbia after state trooper John Osborne saw a government car weaving and running off the road, sources said. Verinder failing a field sobriety test, according to sources who saw an affidavit from the trooper. The failure included his inability to recite the alphabet. The agent then scuffled with Osborne, who handcuffed him and put him in the patrol car, where Verinder convinced the trooper to phone Lanier, who came to the scene and took him home. Verinder was cited for alleged speeding, but never was given a breath test for alcohol nor charged with drunken driving. An official at the FBI's Columbia office who refused to give his name said he had been told to say Verinder refused to comment on the incident. The official would not connect a reporter with Verinder. Lanier denied he did anything wrong, saying the trooper never told him Verinder failed the field sobriety test. ``He had been drinking, (Verinder) told me that, but he wasn't drunk,'' Lanier said. ``(Verinder) told me he'd had several drinks.'' Lanier denied his actions had anything to do with a federal investigation of the highway department, which oversees construction as well as law enforcement. The FBI is one of several agencies investigating allegations that highway department employees took money from contractors. ``That's ridiculous,'' Lanier said. ``He can't control an investigation that the State Law Enforcement Division, the IRS and the FBI, that three agencies are doing.'' Sources said Gov. Carroll Campbell was notified of the incident about a month later. The governor told the AP Tuesday night that he ordered the case brought to the attention of U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel and top state prosecutors. ``The fact that the statement had been made verbally that the head of the FBI (in South Carolina) had been assisted by the head of the highway patrol could have compromised the investigation,'' Campbell said. The governor met with Highway Department chief Joseph G. Rideoutte and Highway Commission chairman Charles E. Dalton Tuesday about the allegations. Campbell refused to discuss Lanier's future. Rideoutte said he was investigating the incident, but wasn't considering firing Lanier.

DOC.HEAD: A New Research Industry is Born
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after pvs 2nd graf, In law, to indicate increase in databank searches.
DOC.TEXT: Maybe, in the great expanse beyond the Washington Beltway, there was some other topic of conversation. Maybe somewhere people talked about the weather or George Steinbrenner, or the Dow. In Washington, the subject was David Souter. In law offices, at the National Organization for Women, in the rooms at the National Right to Life Committee, at the Washington Legal Foundation, in the offices of newspapers, wire services, television networks, in Senate offices, at the Justice Department, in the FBI and around the water coolers in dozens of offices around the city the great search was on for the life and times, the opinions and ideological bent of David Souter. Mead Data Central, which supplies legal information with its computerized Lexis service and news and business information with Nexis, said searches of files containing information about Souter jumped 10 percent from Monday to Tuesday. The increase, from 4,500 to 5,000 searches, was in cases of the new Hampshire Supreme Court, of the attorney general's office when Souter was there, and of the 1st Circuit of the United States Court of Appeals. Souter, as in suitor. An overnight celebrity, the man of the hour, President Bush's mystery nominee to be associate justice of the Supreme Court. In an instant, a research industry was born. ``I had heard the name Souter before yesterday,'' said Richard Samp, chief counsel of the Washington Legal Foundation. ``He had vaguely been mentioned in connection with the (Anthony) Kennedy nomination years ago.'' That's as far as the knowledge about Souter went when President Bush presented him late Monday in the White House press room. Even the president did not seem to know much about Souter's opinions. ``In my view it would have been inappropriate to ask him his views on specific issues,'' said Bush. ``More important are the broad concepts of excellence, is the man qualified, does he share a broad view that what he ought to do on the bench is interpret the Constitution and not legislate. And so that's all I need.'' Samp, along with others trying to get a handle on Souter, turned to the great computerized legal data banks for information. The nominee has been a federal appeals judge only since April and, said Samp, ``he has had absolutely zero written opinions to date.'' But Souter also was on the New Hampshire Supreme Court for seven years and an associate justice of the state superior court for five years before that _ a 12-year paper trail. The handy thing about judging judges: part of their job is explaining their decisions. ``We have gotten a printout of all his decisions, we are talking about 700-800 if we include every opinion of the New Hampshire Supreme Court issued during the time he was on the bench,'' said Samp. ``If we are looking at the ones he authored, there will be 100-150.'' Five noted conservatives held a news conference Tuesday afternoon to say how they stood on the nomination. Four stood on yes and one on no. All five said they didn't know much about Souter. ``There remain too many unanswered questions about who he is and how this nomination came about,'' said Peter Flaherty, chairman of the Conservative Campaign Fund, former chairman of Citizens for Reagan, and the one who said no. ``This man has been on the planet for 50 years, never given a speech, written an article.'' Robert Grant, president of the American Freedom Coalition, said all he knows about Souter is what he read in the paper. ``There's a dearth of real information,'' he said. ``A pig in a poke. The big question is what do we have in this 50-year-old man who lives alone on a farm in the mountains of New Hampshire.'' Richard Viguerie, chairman of United Conservatives of America, said most conservatives are cautious supporters who approve with nervous smiles. As for Souter, the subject of all this, his first full day as a nominee was spent in the White House where presidential aides told him what he could expect at the Senate confirmation hearings. They told him everything he had ever written could be picked on, that his personal life would be scrutinized. According to reports, the man who has the answers to all the questions didn't seem too concerned about the prospect.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Raid Turns Up Illegal Sea Turtles and Coral
DOC.TEXT: A search for drugs on a Korean tanker revealed stuffed sea turtles belonging to an endangered species and about five tons of coral from protected Philippine reefs. ``This is unique. We've never seen this amount of coral before,'' said Rick Ellison, chief of U.S. Customs inspectors for the San Francisco waterfront. Importation of the items violates federal and international laws prohibiting transporting and possessing endangered or protected wildlife. Eight stuffed green sea turtles, one over 3 feet long, and 1,100 blooms of coral were seized last week from the ship, the Bum Dong, which has since left for Korea. No charges were filed. Crew members said the items were destined for Korea, authorities said. There is an active market in endangered wildlife items in South Korea because it is not party to an international treaty regulating trade in such species, said Ginette Hemley with the World Wildlife Fund in Washington, D.C. The eight turtles were valued at between $3,000 and $5,000, with the coral estimated to be worth $30,000, said Scott Pearson of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Customs had been tipped that the ship, hauling coconut oil, might be carrying drugs, said Ellison. He said no drugs were found, but the coral and turtles were found in the living areas of the 444-foot ship. .61\ 2.63 +.01} Tue.'s sales 98,000. Tue.'s open int n.a.

Jury Selection Begin For Contra Mercenary Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The 1986 Contra supply plane crash that led to revelations of U.S. involvement in the Iran-Contra affair is at the center of a civil lawsuit that opened today against Richard Secord and a CIA-linked airline. Eugene Hasenfus, the sole survivor when Sandinista forces shot down his C-132 in Nicaragua during a supply run, has accused Secord and Southern Air Transport of misleading him and using planes that were ``wholly inadequate and dilapidated.'' Hasenfus, who was captured by the government troops and held for three months, is joined in the lawsuit by the family of Wallace Sawyer Jr., the co-pilot who died in the October 1986 crash. Jury selection began today with Hasenfus expected to take the stand later in the day as the first witness. Secord also was present. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to lying to congressional investigators when he said he wasn't aware of any money that went to Oliver North's benefit from the maze of companies he had used in the Iran-Contra affair. Secord on Jan. 24 was sentenced to two years probation. When the suit was filed in 1988, attorneys had estimated damages at $135 million, but on Tuesday the judge asked for more specific figures. Following the crash, the Reagan administration, faced with evidence found in the plane, acknowledged money was diverted from Iran arms sales to the Contra supply operation. The suit says Hasenfus was recruited in 1986 through the Pennsylvania airline Corporate Air Services and William Cooper, a Southern Air pilot. Cooper, who also died in the crash, led Hasenfus to believe ``the Contra resupply operation was being run `right out of the back door of the White House' '' by North, Secord and Southern Air, the suit said. Hasenfus and the Sawyer family claim Secord misrepresented the nature of the flights and failed to take routine safety precautions such as providing parachutes. Southern Air, once owned by the CIA, has denied any association with the Hasenfus flight, even though the plane was registered to Corporate Air, which had the same office address as Southern Air.

DOC.HEAD: Government Reports Sharp Decline in Durable Goods Orders
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 5-6 to UPDATE with home sales report; picks up 5th graf pvs, Durable goods...
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for ``big ticket'' manufactured goods plunged 3.2 percent in June, the government said today. The Commerce Department said that demand for durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, suffered a May-to-June decline of $4.14 billion to a seasonally adjusted $124.69 billion last month. The report caught analysts by surprise. They had been expecting a healthy increase following on the heels of a 4.2 percent rise in May. The decline, the third in the past six months, served to emphasize the problems besetting the U.S. manufacturing sector. In another economic report today, a real estate trade group reported that sales of existing homes in June posted their first increase since last September. The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes, bolstered by falling mortgage rates, rose a modest 1.2 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million units. Durable goods orders are considered a key signpost for the future since a drop in orders normally triggers cutbacks in production plans and job layoffs. The 3.2 percent June decline was the weakest performance since a 4.1 percent drop in April. Orders had fallen 10.5 percent in January, the biggest drop on record. For the first six months of the year, orders totaled $744.7 billion, 1.5 percent below the same period in 1989, indicating how sluggish demand has been this year. In fact, the monthly level of $124.69 billion in orders was 5.6 percent below the record level of orders reached more than two years ago. The June weakness was widespread across all industry groups. About half of the decline was attributed to a 20.7 percent drop in orders for military hardware, the biggest setback in the defense category since a 33.6 percent drop in January. The military sector tends to be extremely volatile, depending on the timing of government contracts. But even without the big defense decrease, durable goods orders would have been down 1.7 percent. Orders in the key category of non-defense capital goods, considered a good barometer of businesses plans to expand and modernize, were up a small 0.3 percent after declines of 1.4 percent in May and 10.6 percent in April. The largest industry decline came in transportation, down 4.8 percent to $33.8 billion. Most of this decline came in aircraft orders. Electrical machinery was down 3.9 percent to $19.9 billion with electronic components accounting for most of the decrease. The machinery category, which includes computers, fell 3.2 percent to $21.7 billion. Orders for primary metals such as steel fell 4.9 percent to $11.3 billion. Shipments of durable goods increased slightly in June, up a modest 0.5 percent to $127.3 billion. For the first half of 1990, shipments totaled $740.9 billion, 1.1 percent above the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Two Questioned in Attack That Killed Nun, Three Policemen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with comment from IRA's political wing, nun's order, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police said today two men were being questioned about an IRA bombing that killed three police officers and the first nun to die in Northern Ireland's sectarian conflict. The IRA's political wing said it regretted the deaths but blamed British policy in Northern Ireland. The three officiers of the Royal Ulster Constabulary police _ the force of the Protestant-dominated British province _ died instantly when an estimated half-ton of explosives was detonated beneath their car on a rural highway just after 2 p.m. Tuesday, police said. The nun, Sister Catherine Dunne, who was in an oncoming car, died at a hospital shortly after the blast. A 25-year-old social worker who was a passenger in the nun's car, Cathy McCann, was injured. She was reported in satisfactory condition this morning. Sinn Fein, the IRA's political wing, said in a statement it ``deeply regrets all deaths which occur as a result of this conflict, whether they be those of active participants in the conflict or innocent victims, like Sister Catherine Dunne.'' But the statement issued by the Republican Press Center in Belfast said the conflict continues because of Britain's ``insistence on placing obstacles in the way of a genuine peace process.'' Police said two men were arrested at their homes not far from the scene of the explosion on the outskirts of Armagh. They were being questioned about ``serious terrorist crimes'' in the Armagh area, including the latest bombing, said a police spokesman, who under standing rules was not identified. The explosion blasted a crater nearly 10 feet deep, crushed the policemen's car and flipped it over, and knocked the nun's small car off the road. An anonymous caller claimed responsibility on behalf of the mainly Catholic IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Protestant and Catholic leaders joined in vigorous condemnation of the attack. Catholic Bishop Cahal Daly said the death of Sister Catherine added ``a new dimension of poignancy and horror,'' but he said there were ``no legitimate targets _ all four people murdered were innocent victims of a senseless and evil campaign.'' Two of the three police officers were married, and they had a total of six young children. Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey called the slayings ``utterly futile,'' and Ireland's Anglican primate, the Most Rev. Robin Eames, expressed his ``absolute disgust at the brutal attack on policemen and civilians.'' The Irish News, a Belfast daily which serves the Catholic community, said in today's editions that an anonymous caller claimed responsibility on behalf of the IRA. ``The second battalion, North Armagh Brigade, claims responsibility for the military action at Armagh today,'' the caller said. He did not give a recognized code word, which often accompanies IRA statements, the newspaper said. Nor was there any apology, such as the one the IRA offered after killing two Australian tourists in the Netherlands on May 28 or the 6-month-old daughter of a British soldier in West Germany on Oct. 26. Police said the latest bomb apparently was triggered from a nearby bungalow while the occupants, including young children, were held hostage. The three officers killed were identified as Constable William James Hanson, 37, of Armagh, and reserve officers Joshua Cyril Willis, 35, of Caledon, and David Sterritt, 34, from Markethill. The IRA killed four soldiers with a similar bomb beneath a road on April 9. Attacks against police officers and soldiers are a trademark of the IRA and smaller groups fighting British rule. The IRA wants to unite the province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Sister Catherine, a native of Dublin and a member of the Sisters of St. Louis, was deputy director of St. Joseph's Training School, a training center for young offenders, in Middletown, 10 miles outside Armagh. At the Middletown Convent, where Sister Catherine lived with 15 other nuns, she was remembered as ``a lovely young woman full of life and joy'' by Sister Fiona Fullam, regional superior of the St. Louis Sisters. She said the nun's funeral would be held Friday at the convent. The Irish News said she was the first nun among the nearly 2,800 deaths attributed to sectarian and political violence since 1969. Two priests were killed in the early 1970s, it said. The 21-year death toll includes 273 police officers and reservists. Armagh is the ecclesiastical capital of all Ireland, and the cathedrals of the Catholic and Anglican primates dominate its skyline. According to tradition, the city owes its prominence to St. Patrick, who chose it as his seat.

DOC.HEAD: Fiji Adopts Constitution Ensuring Dominance of Ethnic Fijians
DOC.TEXT: Fiji adopted a constitution today that guarantees native Fijians a majority in both houses of a new Parliament. The constitution calls for the native Fijians to be allocated 37 of the 70 seats in a House of Representatives and 24 of the 34 Senate seats. The guaranteed majority has been a demand of the military, which overthrew a coalition dominated by ethnic Indians in 1987. The military said the coup was necessary to protect the rights of indigenous Fijians. Native Fijians and ethnic Indians each comprise slightly less than half of the 720,000 people in Fiji, an island nation in the South Pacific. Indians were a majority before the coup, which was followed by a second military takeover in 1987, but emigration has since depleted their numbers. President Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau, a native Fijian, promulgated the document following Cabinet approval, calling it ``an historic and solemn duty'' and asking for national reconciliation. He said in a nationally broadcast radio speech that the constitution would ``immediately take effect as the supreme law of the land.'' He added that he hoped elections would be held next year. Indian leaders have branded the constitution as ``racist, feudalistic and undemocratic'' and said they would boycott the planned elections. The constitution has not yet been released publicly. Ganilau said the coups were the result of a growing sense of insecurity among native Fijians because Indians dominated commerce, finance and industry. ``It seems only fair and just that the Fijian position should be strengthened in some areas to compensate for its weaknesses in others.'' He called on Indians, who were brought to Fiji by the British as indentured sugar-plantation workers, to set aside that memory, along with ``their sense of grievance about the past.'' ``Join with the Fijians in sharing the nation's resources and participating fully in national life,'' Ganilau said. The proclamation comes 2{ years after the country was declared a republic. The 1970 post-independence constitution was revoked following the second coup. In late May, New Delhi said it would launch an international campaign against Fiji over the new constitution. Fiji ordered the Indian Embassy closed and expelled its diplomats in retaliation. New Zealand Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer recently criticized the constitution, saying it would not improve strained bilateral relations.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MEXICO CITY
Cuban Dissidents Leave Swiss Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with confirmation from Swiss, details about departure. ADDS byline. Pickup 13th graf pvs, `While Cuba...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Castro's Reform
DOC.TEXT: Three Cubans who had sought refuge in the Swiss Embassy in Havana have voluntarily left, Swiss officials said today. The asylum-seekers, who managed to penetrate tight Cuban security, had entered the Swiss compound on Sunday. They told diplomats they wanted to leave the country because of restrictions on free speech. The departures, reported by Swiss officials in Havana and Bern, left 18 Cubans in the Spanish Embassy and four in the home of the Italian ambassador. The wave of asylum-seeking at embassies in Havana began two weeks ago, not long after similar incidents were occurring at embassies in Albania. Albania, like Cuba, is a hard-line Communist state that has refused to follow the lead of other Eastern European countries in adopting democratic reforms. Cuba has contended the asylum-seekers are part of a U.S.-inspired Western plot to destabilize its Communist government, a charge the United States and European countries have denied. In Bern, the Swiss Foreign Ministry said the departure of the three came after assurances by Cuban authorities that there would be no reprisals against them. Ministry spokesman Michel Pache said the Swiss ambassador to Cuba, Markus Kaiser, planned to stay in contact with the men and monitor their situation. The men had told Swiss diplomats they were being followed by police, although they gave no individual examples of persecution, Pache said. Although Switzerland had granted the men temporary refuge in the embassy, it did not recognize them as political refugees, according to the Foreign Ministry. Pache said embassy staff drove two of the Cubans to undisclosed locations on Tuesday. The third agreed to leave the embassy this morning. Nine of the Cubans in the Spanish Embassy are threatening a hunger strike to protest what they say is poor food. The Spanish and Italians have refused to turn over the asylum-seekers, which has strained both countries' ties with Cuba. Today's departures came one day after a senior Cuban official demanded the ``unconditional and voluntary'' departure of the Cubans now being sheltered at foreign embassies. Cuba's vice foreign minister, Jose R. Viera, said it is ``not admissible'' for a Cuban wishing to emigrate to circumvent normal procedures by forcing his way into an embassy. Viera sought to portray the incidents at the embassies as unrepresentative of the overall situation in Cuba. There has been a substantial increase in security around many diplomatic missions of NATO countries. The vice foreign minister said the annual carnival celebration this week has been proceeding normally. The highlight of the carnival celebration is a speech Thursday by President Fidel Castro commemorating the 37th anniversary of his debut as a rebel fighter. Castro took power in Cuba in 1959. While Cuba has called the asylum-seekers ``scum'' and habitual vagrants and said it will never allow them to leave the island, Spain has said it will not expel the Cubans and will try instead to negotiate their departure. Last week, reflecting escalating tensions between the two countries, Spain suspended a $2.5 million aid program to Cuba, recalled its ambassador and sent four guards to bolster security at its embassy in Havana. Spain's foreign minister, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, had said Castro is afraid his hard-line Communist government will fall like those in Eastern Europe if he allows Cubans to leave. Fernandez Ordonez also urged a transition to democracy in Cuba.
