DOC.HEAD: Credit Cards Used For First Time In Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Tourists can now use credit cards for the first time in Vietnam. The official Vietnam News Agency said Visa International credit cards have been accepted in Ho Chi Minh City since July 17 under an agreement between the Vietnam Foreign Trade Bank and the French Bank of External Commerce. The report, dated Tuesday, was seen in Bangkok Wednesday. It said card holders can make payments in dollar equivalents at 12 places including major hotels, restaurants, shops and tourist centers. The report said steps were being taken to permit the card's use in the capital, Hanoi, and in other cities. It appears, however, that Americans will not be able to use their credit cards in Vietnam. The U.S. government clamped a trade embargo on that nation following the Vietnam war, which ended in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Burger King Opening France's First Highway Fast-Food Restaurant
DOC.TEXT: Travelers on France's superhighways will soon be able to dine on hamburgers at roadside fast-food restaurants. Burger King, in cooperation with the French restaurant and hotel company Elitair, announced plans Wednesday to open the first two fast-food restaurants at rest stops along the national highway network. One will be near Evry, southeast of Paris, on the A-6 highway. The other, a drive-through restaurant, will be near Bordeaux on the A-10 highway. Burger King also said the first fast-food hamburger restaurant at a French airport will open next month in a shopping area at Charles de Gaulle airport outside Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly `Mercy Killer' to be Moved to More Comfortable Prison
DOC.TEXT: An 81-year-old man convicted of murdering his ailing wife in what he said was a mercy killing may be transferred to a more comfortable prison under a state review of a crackdown on prison security. Roswell Gilbert, who suffers from heart and lung diseases, was moved from a medium-security to a top-security prison earlier this month after Gov. Bob Martinez ordered all prisoners serving minimum mandatory sentences for violent offenses be taken out of less-secure prisons. That order came after Donald Dillbeck, serving a mandatory life sentence in the murder of a policeman, walked away from a work-release program last month and was charged with killing a shopper outside a mall. Bob Macmaster, a spokesman for the state Department of Corrections, said Wednesday that the cases of Gilbert and 46 other elderly, ill and disabled inmates serving sentences for violent crimes will be reviewed by Monday for possible transfer to less secure prisons where they would have more privileges. Fifty other inmates whose medical conditions are less serious also are likely candidates for transfers, said Paula Tully, a corrections department spokeswoman. Gilbert's attorney, Brad Stark, praised the decision to reconsider the move. ``The bottom line is that (Gilbert) finds being in a maximum-security facility a big strain, emotionally and physically,'' Stark said. Gilbert's 73-year-old wife, Emily, was suffering from Alzheimer's disease when he shot and killed her on March 4, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Killed While Robbing Seven Undercover Police Officers
DOC.TEXT: An armed robber was shot to death after he burst into a motel room unaware that seven armed officers were inside setting up a drug sting, authorities said. The man was shot by one of the officers as an accomplice took their wallets, authorities said. The officers were in two adjoining rooms of a Super 8 motel early Tuesday when Darnell Madison, 37, and Jacqueline Lynn Simmons, 21, came through the partly open door of one of the rooms, officers said. Madison, armed with a .38-caliber revolver, announced a robbery and quickly herded the seven officers together. The officers, part of the Jefferson County drug task force, carried several thousand dollars that they planned to use to buy drugs and film the deal. ``When he came in, I thought he was somebody connected with the drug deal coming early to rip us off,'' Officer Robert Knight said. ``We figured out pretty quickly, though, that he had no idea we were there to make a drug deal, much less that we were the police.'' The gunman told everyone to get on the floor and Simmons to collect the wallets, sheriff's Sgt. Billy James said. Madison repeatedly said he would kill the men if they tried anything, police said. ``We had guns in our holsters, guns on shelves, guns everywhere, but we couldn't get to them,'' Knight said. As the woman started collecting wallets, Madison was distracted by one officer and another eased his gun out of his holster and shot the robber five times, police said. ``A few seconds later, she would have seen a badge, and that would have been it,'' Knight said. ``The officer who did the shooting literally saved our lives. No doubt.'' Simmons was charged with robbery. She was being held Wednesday on $100,000 bond. Officials said Madison had a lengthy criminal record, and was on parole for a robbery conviction when he broke into the hotel room. Police refused to disclose the identity of the deputy who shot Madison. Lt. Linn Moore said the officer is not being accused of any wrongdoing. Chief Deputy Frank Rogers said he could not disclose who the undercover sting unit was targeting when it went to the motel. But he said the attempted robbery brought the sting plans to a close, and ``we don't know what happened'' to the drug suspects.

DOC.HEAD: No Puppy Blat in New Dictionary
DOC.TEXT: Planning to punt big bikkies on the pyjama game? It'll be ace-high if your team wins, but don't get tired and emotional if they're streeted. For those unfamiliar with speaking ``Strine,'' here's a translation, courtesy of ``The Macquarie Dictionary of New Words'': Planning to bet a lot of money on the one-day cricket match? It will be great if your team wins, but don't get drunk if they're beaten badly. ``Strine'' is the shorthand pronunciation for Australian English. The Dictionary Research Center at Sydney's Macquarie University has been keeping track of changes in the language since the school published the 2,049-page ``The Macquarie Dictionary'' in 1981. While it is not an official dictionary, the Australian Government Publishing Service used the Macquarie as the main reference for the government stylebook that is distributed nationwide. So many new words keep popping up that Macquarie has issued the 400-page ``New Words'' supplement to update the evolution in technology, finance, medicine and slang. Each entry is accompanied by a notation on the first time the word or phrase was known to have been used. ``We are moving into the force field of international English, which is very largely influenced by American English,'' said Susan Butler, the dictionary's editor. Hence, Australians now use seppo (American) phrases like ``touch base'' for making contact with people, ``worst-case scenarios'' and ``ballpark figures.'' Athletes ``tough it out,'' ``pump themselves up'' and ``lift their game.'' ``In Australia's history, we've shifted from being entirely British-dominated to being more independent of our colonial background,'' Ms. Butler said. The roots of some new words are fairly clear _ ``brain bucket'' for a helmet with a face mask, and ``shamateur'' for an athlete who is paid for playing but retains amateur status. Others are more murky, such as porky (a lie), frag (a little bit) and brick (falsify evidence). Science has yielded an entire lingo of computerese. To the outsider, it can be a bewildering jungle of PCs, ROM, RAM, hackers, bauds, microchips, megabytes and slaves. There's also the greenhouse effect, faxes, genetic fingerpinting, CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons) and VFTs (very fast trains). The world of finance has produced corporate cowboys, junk bonds, macro economy, insider trading and evoision (tax avoidance bordering on illegality). AIDS is a word in daily use now, along with other medical terms such as IVF (in vitro fertilization), SIDS (sudden infant death syndrome) and passive smoking. But slang and verbal shorthand are prime contributors to new words. Yuppie has proved to be a particularly fertile breeder, with whole generations of offspring: gruppies (environmentally conscious yuppies), scuppies (sensitive to social issues), puppies (pretentious), rumpies (rural) and zuppies (zestful). Most people know a pippie (someone who has inherited sudden wealth) who is also a Lombard (rich but lacking class). There are even yuffies (young urban failures), arpies (asset-rich parents) and Young Fogeys (young people whose attitudes and style are more in tune with the old). Politicians often spout blat (empty rhetoric) in the bearpit (place of fierce debate). If they go on for yonks (a long time), the party leader may send a toecutter (an enforcer) to bring them in line. While chauves (male chauvinists) are far from extinct, women's liberation has left its mark on language, with femocrat (a feminist bureaucrat), herstory (women's history), person Friday and sexual harassment all making their debuts in the dictionary supplement. Music always is changing, as the dictionary reflects, with thrash metal, salsa and rap spawning everything from slam dancing to dirty dancing, vogueing and headbanging. Go to a firestorm (a lively entertainment event) and get blown away (dazzled) watching the ragers (enthusiastic participants) go full on (act without reserve or restraint). Maybe the sound will be rad (wonderful), or it may make you spew (show extreme annoyance). Beam me up Scotty (get me out of here).

DOC.HEAD: Britain to Halve Troops in Germany and Reduce Its Armed Forces
DOC.TEXT: Britain said today that it plans by the mid-1990s to withdraw half of the more than 66,000 troops it has stationed in West Germany and to cut the nation's overall regular forces by 18 percent. Defense Secretary Tom King, announcing proposed wide-ranging conventional defense cutbacks to Parliament, also said the government planned to maintain some 40 Royal Navy warships. The current ceiling is about 50. King proposed that the Royal Air Force be cut from 89,000 personnel to 75,000, and the army from 160,000 to 120,000. Britain has 66,700 servicemen and women deployed in West Germany. They are the second biggest foreign military presence after the United States. The announcement followed a five-month review of defense expenditure by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and a committee of top Cabinet ministers in the light of a reduced Soviet threat. The government, long the most hawkish in NATO and one of the Western alliance's highest defense spenders, kept news of the review secret until word leaked several weeks after it began. King said Britain will make no reductions in its nuclear arsenal, retaining the present Polaris missiles and updating them with four new missile-carrying U.S. Trident submarines within the next few years. ``It is a time of opportunity and hope for change, yet without putting at risk the safe protection of our country,'' King told the House of Commons. ``Our aim is an orderly and planned transition to the new world unfolding.'' He said Britain will discuss the proposed cutbacks with its NATO allies. And he said implementation hinged on the signing of an East-West agreement on conventional arms cuts, final arrangements for German unification, and the pace of the withdrawal of Soviet troops from other East European countries. King said the proposals would mean reductions in British defense expenditure, but he gave no details. The figures would be announced in an autumn treasury statement, he added. In addition, King said there will be further immediate cutbacks to lop $1.1 billion off the $38.6 billion defense budget for this fiscal year, which ends in March. ``We shall be easing back on army recruiting and retiring early several ships and submarines,'' he said. Citing higher-than-expected inflation, the government announced last month the cancellation of orders for 33 Tornado jet fighters as a major saving on the current budget. Government officials said Mrs. Thatcher discussed the outcome of the review last week with service chiefs. The Cabinet committee's report was debated and accepted by the full 22-member Cabinet Thursday morning.

DOC.HEAD: John Denver Unveils Institute on Global Environment
DOC.TEXT: Singer John Denver said Wednesday he has helped establish an institute that will work to save the global environment. The Aspen Institute on Global Change, co-sponsored by the Amway Corp. of Ada, Mich., the United Nations Environment Program and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, will bring leading scientists together each summer in Aspen, Colo., to trade ideas. ``This is not just another think-tank,'' Denver said at a news conference, adding that saving the global environment is ``the most important task that faces the human race at this time.'' Denver said an education and outreach program would try to bridge the gap between researchers and people who want to be involved in local environmental action. William Nicholson, Amway's chief operating officer, said the direct marketing company has committed $500,000 to the institute over the next five years. Rick Chappell, associate director of science at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center, said NASA contributed $40,000. Chappell said that a possible project would enlist large numbers of students and others in simple environmental tests at points on Earth also being monitored from space as a way to check the accuracy of satellite measurements of Earth conditions. ``It would be the ultimate field trip for the kids,'' Chappell said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

July 20 The Register-Guard, Eugene, Ore., on balancing the budget: Once again, Congress has rejected the chimera of a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution. ... The simple, practical truth is that the problem was not created by a flaw in the rules governing the way budgets are put together. Nor can the trouble be eliminated by tinkering with those rules, whether constitutional or merely statutory. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law is an example of the latter. Rather, a continuing string of excessive deficits has resulted from political cowardice _ an unwillingness to either raise taxes to cover expenditures or cut spending to stay within revenues. Those are the only two ways to balance a federal budget. Spurred by Ronald Reagan's election and his crusade against taxes, the government in 1981 switched from a Democratic policy the new president derided as ``tax and spend, tax and spend'' to a new approach: borrow and spend. Borrowing to cover the gaps between annual expenditures and revenues more than doubled the national debt in less than a decade and made interest payments on the debt the third largest item in the budget, consuming 20 percent of current spending. ... The ballooning cost of the savings and loan rescue measures, among other things, has frightened George Bush into abandoning his dogmatic opposition to any tax increase. That breakthrough may create opportunities for the kinds of compromise that will be essential if current budget negotiations are to achieve success.

July 20 The Repository, Canton, Ohio, on the S&L bailout: Have you noticed that public anger over the cost of the S&L bailout has journeyed upward several notches? And there has been a corresponding reaction in Congress to take some steps to reassure the American people on these points: (1) That wrongdoers will be prosecuted; (2) that ill-gotten gains will be confiscated and some of the money paid back to the institutions from which it was stolen; (3) that legal barn doors are being closed to keep such a scandal from occurring again. There's another point that deserves attention, but is not getting it. You hear no debate about why it is that all the states have to share in the bailout regardless of how much (or how little) of the crookedness occurred within the borders of individual states. ... When the shape of new clean air legislation was being hammered out in meetings between the administration and Senate leaders, and then later in Senate debate, no one wanted to hear anything about the regionalism aspect of the legislation. Lawmakers from the West and New England were determined that the Midwest states would pay more than anyone else because of the region's reliance on coal-fired utilities. ... This is why states in the Midwest have a bigger beef about the S&L bailout than some others that are not happy about paying for out-of-control wheeling and dealing, particularly in Texas and California. It's also why Washington hasn't heard the last of this issue _ not by a long shot.

July 19 The Hudson Dispatch, Union City, N.J., on Neil Bush: So Neil Bush is angry. He says the Democrats are putting him in the political food processor because of his name. The president's 34-year-old son, former director of Silverado Savings and Loan Association in Denver, has been charged by thrift regulators with failing to mention his business relationship with two important Silverado borrowers. So if you think you're mad, Mr. Bush, you should talk to the American public, which is going to have to bail out all of the failed thrifts nationwide to the estimated tune of $500 billion. The tab for Silverado is estimated at $1 billion. Congressional Democrats are also up to their necks in the S&L scandal, and must be willing to take a certain amount of blame. Congress and the Justice Department must put aside partisan zeal and fervently seek culpability _ and remedy _ for what is becoming the nation's largest financial scandal. Even if Mr. Bush gets mad.

July 21 The Keene (N.H.) Sentinel on political undesirables: The United states may not have any political prisoners, but it does have a very long list of political undesirables. ... Until recently, the list was a state secret. Immigration lawyers guessed that as many as 40,000 people were on it. ... The names are not holdovers from the McCarthy era; more than two-thirds of them were put on it during the Reagan and Bush administrations. Some 4,399 were added during the first three months of this year alone. ... The widow of former Chilean President Salvador Allende was denied permission to give a speech to an American organization that had invited her. At various times, our government bureaucrats have also protected us from Nobel Laureates Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Pablo Neruda, from authors Graham Greene, Doris Lessing and Carlos Fuentes, and from French singer and actor Yves Montand. Too bad they can't do anything about Jesse Helms.

July 23 Chicago Sun-Times on radar detectors: Now that the trucking industry has called for a federal ban on radar detectors in interstate trucks, the radar detector lobby once again drags out its long-discredited constitutional argument against a ban. ``The government can't limit a citizen's use of a radar detector any more than it can limit the use of an AM-FM radio,'' said an industry flack. Sorry, friend, but the ``government'' can and it does. Radar detector bans, imposed by a few courageous states not just on trucks but on all vehicles, have been upheld by the courts. And not only can the government impose such bans, it clearly ought to do it. Radar detectors are used only for one purpose _ to break the law. And a survey found that between 33 percent and 52 percent of individual semitrailer drivers checked in a seven-state survey used the detectors. The next time you're being tailgated by one of those hotshot jockeys, you can rightly wonder about whose rights are being violated.

July 20 Green Bay (Wis.) Press-Gazette on Pete Rose: The Pete Rose story is both sad and instructive. It is sad because Rose's sentencing ... on two felony tax charges is further _ hope it is the final _ humiliation for a sports legend. Rose's major league baseball record earned him a long stint in the limelight. But now, banished from baseball and facing a five-month prison term, he stands in the harsher light of public scrutiny. It is instructive because the Rose case proves again that the law applies to the famous as well as to those whose names never graced a boxscore or a record book. By baseball standards, Rose is an oldtimer. But, at 49, he is young enough to pay his debt to society and get his life in order. Pete Rose's baseball records will last a long time. So will the image of a man who put himself above the law and now must pay the price.

DOC.HEAD: Three Lawyers Freed From Detention But Four Detainees Charged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with four men being charged, U.S. Embassy comment on releases, other details. Pickup 6th, `Rubia and...'
DOC.TEXT: The government today charged four people with plotting its overthrow. It also released three lawyers who had been detained without charge in a crackdown on proponents of multiparty politics. The U.S. Embassy welcomed the release of the three, but it expressed hopes that other detainees would also soon be released. ``We hope the cases of those remaining in custody can be resolved rapidly,'' said an embassy spokesman. Kenyan law permits detention without charge or trial of individuals the government considers a threat to state security. Those charged were former detainees George Anyona and Ngotho Kariuki, rural ruling party official Augustine Kathangu, and university lecturer Edward Oyugi. The government accused them of taking part in a meeting whose participants had ``seditious intentions of overthrowing the Kenyan government by unlawful means.'' Anyona, a former parliamentarian and an economist, and Kathangu, an official of the governing Kenya African National Union in Embu, were additionally charged with possessing seditious material. The four had been held without charge since July 12 when they were arrested together at a Nairobi-area pub. Those released were lawyers Gitobu Imanyara, John Khaminwa and Mohamed Ibrahim. They could not be immediately reached for comment. Their detentions preceded a rally planned for July 7 in favor of a multiparty system. Police tried to block the rally, which led to riots in Nairobi and four other cities. At least 28 people died and scores were injured. Human rights lawyer Gibson Kamau Kuria was threatened with arrest during the crackdown but was sheltered by the U.S. Embassy, which helped him safely leave Kenya. Still in detention are former Cabinet ministers Charles Rubia and Kenneth Matiba, and Raila Odinga, a businessman and the son of former Vice President Oginga Odinga. Rubia and Matiba were picked up by police July 4, and Odinga was detained July 5. They are leading advocates of multiparty politics in Kenya, which is by law a one-party state. Khaminwa represented Rubia and Matiba and was detained when he sought information about their whereabouts. Imanyara edited the Nairobi Law Monthly magazine, which served as a platform for the advocates of political pluralism in this East African nation. Ibrahim was a partner in a law firm that has represented individuals not in favor with the authorities. Rubia and Matiba had been denied a state license to convene the planned July 7 rally, but a crowd gathered anyway. Rioting began when police armed with wooden clubs and firing tear gas canisters dispersed the crowd. President Daniel arap Moi and other Kenyan leaders argue that more than one political party in the country would lead to tribal wars among the estimated 40 tribes. The government gave no reason for the lawyers' release. However, clergymen, lawyers and foreign governments, including the United States, had severely criticized the detentions. On Thursday, the International Bar Association switched the site of its biannual convention in September from Nairobi to New York City and cited the recent detentions as one reason.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: the prize.
DOC.TEXT: July 18 The Independent, Marshall, Minn., on Bart Simpson: Finally the uproar over poor little Bart Simpson has died down. Wonder if it had anything to do with school officials and politicians checking the TV listings and noticing the huge number of programs which share the airwaves with Bart Simpson? You know, the ones which glorify violence, make virtually any kind of promiscuous, deviant sex seem normal and acceptable; promote use of drugs ranging from nicotine and alcohol up to marijuana and cocaine; and make reckless driving seem like a good idea. Or perhaps it had to do with looking around at hundreds of kinds of T-shirts which do all the above and more. All of a sudden Bart Simpson doesn't seem nearly the threat he did to the younger generation. The Bible has some advice for folks who get all worked up over little things like Bart, but miss the bigger problems. It mentions something about straining at a gnat and swallowing a camel. It does not, we hasten to add, caution people about having a cow.

July 24 Greensboro (N.C.) News & Record on UNLV sanctions: The basketball players of UNLV _ the University of Nevada-Las Vegas _ have been barred from defending their 1990 national championship in next year's NCAA tournament because of recruiting violations in 1977, when most of them were about 7. ... The NCAA sanction ... writes an end to a painful episode in college sports, a story that spans a decade of great change and vigorous debate. One would like to think that the rules violations committed by UNLV coach Jerry Tarkanian 13 years ago are less likely today. But who can be sure? In fairness to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the long delay in this case is largely the fault of Tarkanian. After establishing his rules violations, the NCAA tried to suspend him from coaching for two years. Tarkanian sued in federal court to block the action and, in 1988, won in the U.S. Supreme Court. The court ruled that the NCAA contract with member schools empowered it to punish the schools, but only the schools had power to reprimand the coaches they employ. It took 11 years to get that far. Fairness also means apportioning some blame to UNLV, which should have punished Tarkanian _ should have done so years before he got to the Supreme Court _ but demurred. To that extent, the university is the cause of its own current troubles. Nevertheless, NCAA sanctions this late in the game smack of revenge: If Tarkanian is out of reach, then the NCAA will punish him by penalizing his players and his school, which of course stands to lose millions in tournament profits. We're all for high NCAA standards and vigorous enforcement. But by 1990, the UNLV case had become a loser and should have been written off to experience.

July 22 Los Angeles Times on Soviet coal miners: The miners' recent 24-hour strike (in the Soviet Union) prompted some startlingly candid reporting about their plight by state-run television. ... The average Soviet coal miner can gloomily anticipate being dead at the age of 48; Soviet men in less hazardous occupations can expect to live to 64 years. The retirement age for miners is 55. Only 5 percent of them survive to that age. It means standing a good chance of dying in a work-related accident. Each year, about 800 miners are killed on the job. Such appallingly high tolls are not, of course, unknown in American history. Happily, they are a thing of the past. In 1988, U.S. coal-mining accidents took 55 lives. ... Mikhail Shchadov, minister of the coal mining industry, concedes that hundreds of miners have died because of something as simple as a lack of timber to properly shore up mine shafts. This in a country rich in forests! ... The United States has offered technical help in a number of areas to the Soviets. ... American miners, mining unions and mining companies have learned the hard way what can be done to reduce hazards underground. A offer to apply that expertise to improve working conditions in Soviet mines would be a true humanitarian service.

July 22 Topeka (Kan.) Capital-Journal on Cambodia: The United States finally came to its senses ... and abandoned a policy on Cambodia that in essence supported the murderous Khmer Rouge. It is difficult to believe that the United States, with its professed interest in human rights, would ever side with the likes of the Khmer Rouge. Their reign of genocidal terror on Cambodia was the subject of the movie ``The Killing Fields.'' The communist Khmer Rouge are held responsible for more than 1 million deaths during their three-year rule that ended when Vietnam invaded the country in 1978. Since then, the U.S. position has been staunchly anti-Hanoi that American policy sided with the coalition that included the Khmer Rouge. ... Some of the things the United States has done in the interest of diplomacy are nothing to be proud of. Siding with the Khmer Rouge is one of the more unconscionable ones. The policy change was prompted by recent intelligence reports that the Khmer Rouge were making military gains in Cambodia. Faced with the possibility of their full return to power, the United States finally did the right thing.

July 20 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on Cambodia: Two cheers for the Bush administration's decision to change American policy towards Cambodia. And the fact that this was accomplished in consultation with Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze suggests that Asia might be one place where the United States and Soviet Union have more interests in common than either suspects. We shall see. In any case, it is refreshing to learn that U.S. policy in the region is now concentrated on preventing a recurrence of rule by the murderous Khmer Rouge, and not just based on hostility to Vietnam. ... There is no reason why the United States cannot provide aid to the Cambodian government, as well as the two non-communist guerrilla factions, in order to prevent the worst possible alternative. The real challenge for the Bush administration will be to persuade Congress to agree.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Rocks Western Iran
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake sharply jolted the city of Ahvaz in western Iran, but caused no loss of life or property, Tehran radio reported Wednesday. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said the quake struck Ahvaz, a city of 334,000, at 9:30 p.m. Tuesday and measured 5.5 on the Richter scale. A reading of 5 can cause considerable damage. Last month, an earthquake measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale hit northern Iran, leaving 40,000 people dead, injuring 60,000 and rendering half a million people homeless. More than 400 aftershocks have jolted the area since. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: to agree.
DOC.TEXT: July 23 Cumhuriyet, Istanbul, Turkey, on Cambodia: The first positive result in Asia from the ending of the cold war has been the U.S. withdrawal of its support of the guerrilla coalition in Cambodia, which also included the Khmer Rouge, and its decision to start talks with Vietnam aimed at putting an end to the crisis. The reasons the U.S. administration has taken this decision include the strong possibility of the Khmer Rouge, the country's most effective guerrilla force, coming to power again, and the increasing reaction in Congress against White House support of this ruthless horde of murderers. The tragedy of Cambodia is an example of what could befall small nations that happen to be located at the crossroads of big power interests. ... The Bush administration, even if belately, has finally realized the danger or has been forced to realize it as a result of pressures from within. ... The U.S. has committed the greatest crimes against Cambodia. At first the country has been bombed, then the legitimate ruler has been removed with a coup and the scene has been prepared for the Khmer Rouge to reappear. Even after their defeat by Vietnam, the horde of murders of Khmer Rouge ... has been supported by Washington. ... The people of Cambodia have suffered unbelievably since the coup d'etat the United States orchestrated in 1970. Maybe this nation, the sacrificial lamb of great power politics, deserves peace more than any other.

July 20 NRC Handelsblad, Rotterdam, Netherlands, on Cambodia: The battlefields on which the Cold War has raged are being cleared up. In Europe the first work has been done. The Americans are concentrating on areas where the burden of the past is still weighing heavily upon the population. One of these is Cambodia, once the side stage of the Vietnam war, then the bloody ideologic laboratory of Marxists gone berserk, now again threatened by the Khmer Rouge. It has taken (too) long, but the American government is currently willing to withdraw its indirect support of the gang of assassins and to talk with Vietnam _ the long-distance protector of the Hun Sen-regime _ about the future of Cambodia. If the American swerve will eliminate the Khmer Rouge as a factor on short term is the question. ... Initially the swerve will especially have diplomatic consequences. The coalition of three parties, in which the Khmer Rouge has the lead, may not count anymore on America's recognition. ... The swerve in the American policy also offers a wider perspective; normalization of the relations with Hanoi. Although (Secretary of State) James Baker wouldn't hear of that yet, that sort of development does seem to loom on the horizon. America's rather embarrassing stance in the Cambodian civil war had everything to do with the trauma of the Vietnam war. When Hanoi ended the terror of the Khmer Rouge in 1978, the world took a relieved breath. But the Washington of successively (Jimmy) Carter and (Ronald) Reagan could only see the validity of the so called domino-theory in the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia; if Saigon fell into communist hands, then all of Indo-China and subsequently all of Southeast Asia would be lost. ... The new American policy in regards to Cambodia means less subtlety in ... contact with China. The drastic changes in the European-Atlantic relations are starting to have an impact as far as the Far East. Beijing shall have to take this into account.

July 20 Business Times, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Cambodia: The decision by the U.S. government to open a dialogue with Vietnam to keep the Khmer Rouge from returning to power in Cambodia as well as withdraw its recognition of the U.N. seat held by the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea (CGDK) can be the harbinger of a fresh ploy to break the deadlock in the 11-year-old strife. ... The main reason, however, is that Washington's aid to the CGDK has been attacked at home and abroad for helping the Khmer Rouge, the strongest of the three component groups. ... But the question still is: Will the U.S. move really help hasten, and complete, the peace process? Asean, the European Community and so many other countries singly and collectively have tried over the past decade. They succeeded only in getting the Cambodian horses to the water, but none has managed to get them to drink. ... One reading of the U.S. decision is that it may force the CGDK deeper into the arms of China which has reportedly promised to double the U.S. assistance (amounting to about $13 million ... a year) should this be halted. ... Even if the dialogue leads to greater pressure by Vietnam on Hun Sen to make more concessions for the success of the U.N.'s efforts, it is difficult to see the Khmer Rouge agreeing to be a party to any settlement that ensues when it is frozen out of the process. The U.S. decision is clearly designed more to appease domestic opposition to its previous stand of full support for the CGDK, which also implied backing for the Khmer Rouge. The opening of the dialogue with Vietnam is only a maneuver to dilute the consequences of the about-turn in policy.

July 23 The Times, London, on the hostages in Lebanon: The taking of Western hostages in Lebanon is a game of cat and mouse. Part of the game is the regular perpetration of rumors of release. The groups which take hostages and political allies who hope to profit from this practice, have discovered how easy it is to manipulate the Western media in order to sustain pressure for ransom and thus maintain the price. ... A widely publicized report on July 7 led to speculation about the freeing of Brian Keenan, the Irish-born teacher kidnapped by Islamic extremists more than four years ago. There has never been any word from the kidnappers themselves. ... The truth is that nobody but those controling the lives of the captives knows anything about their whereabouts, state of health or prospects of freedom. The only reliable reports about them have come from former captives. The only way of countering this exploitation is for the West to do an uncharacteristic thing, to ignore any and every rumor unsubstantiated by some reasonably reliable source. ... The media should adopt a self-denying ordinance, not to report rumors, gossip and unfounded leaks about hostages, because to do so makes it the accomplice of the world's number one enemy.

July 23 Straits Times, Singapore, on India: While (India) has made impressive advance in science and technology over the past 43 years, that progress has not been translated into the social consciousness without which democracy is a vicious, mindless fraud perpetrated by every voter on every other. There is no simple answer. Not army rule, because the army soon starts taking after the corrupt politicians it replaces. Not revolution, for revolutions succeed only when they can return countries to year zero, which they cannot. Certainly not a resurrected religious state belonging to a mythical Golden Age, of the kind being offered by reactionary parties to a confused majority community. Inasmuch as there is an answer, it depends on a rebirth of nationalism, a remembrance of the romantic, but genuine national inclusiveness that marked independence, but which was gradually subverted by increasingly powerful vested interests. The problem with Indian politics is not democracy but its degeneration. The solution must then lie in putting meaning back into words, the spirit into tortured form. For Indians, that is no small challenge. For others, India is no small lesson.
End Editorial Rdp

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Widens Lead
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Karpov made short shrift of fellow Soviet Lev Polugaevsky to widen his lead in the International Grandmasters' Chess Tournament. Karpov, who will challenge World Champion Garry Kasparov in Lyons, France next October, secured the point in just 28 moves Tuesday night, playing white. The three other fifth round games all ended in draws, leaving the standings unchanged. Karpov led with five points. Tied for second place with three points were Ulf Andersson of Sweden and Matthias Wahls of West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Too Many Chinese Buried in Graves
DOC.TEXT: Almost three-quarters of all Chinese who die are buried in graveyards that often occupy valuable farmland, a newspaper reported Wednesday. Despite an official policy favoring cremations, about 4.5 million of the 6.5 million Chinese who die each year receive burials, the English-language China Daily quoted sources in the Ministry of Civil Affairs as saying. The Communist government has long urged the nation's estimated 1.1 billion people to abandon traditional elaborate funerals and burials. It says burials are an extravagance for a country with 23 percent of the world's population but only 5 percent of its arable land. Although most city dwellers are cremated, traditional rural areas have long resisted the practice. In recent years, newly affluent villagers have sought to honor the dead with large banquets, Buddhist ceremonies and ornate burial sites. The problem of disposing of the dead, even those who are cremated, has become so severe that one central Chinese city, the scenic lake city of Hangzhou, has urged its residents to scatter the ashes of the dead in a local river.

DOC.HEAD: House Sustains Bush Veto of Family Leave Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The House today sustained President Bush's veto of a bill that would require employers to provide up to 12 weeks off without pay to workers with new babies or family emergencies. The vote was 232-195 to override, 53 short of the two-thirds majority required to override. The action kept President Bush's veto record perfect. He has vetoed 13 bills, and Congress has not overriden any. Bush vetoed the bill last month after it passed the House with bipartisan support and passed the Senate on a voice vote. The president, who had voiced support for employee leave for new mothers during the 1988 presidential campaign, said in his veto message that the government should not require employers to offer a certain kind of benefit. Supporters had acknowledged beforehand they lacked the votes to override the veto. But sponsors pointed to polls showing widespread support for the concept, and Democrats hoped to use the issue against Republicans in the fall election campaigns. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said before the vote that similar bills would be before Congress in the future. He said Democrats would not try to pass weaker bills in a bid to win Bush's signature. ``We're going to have this kind of legislation enacted, if not this year in this session, next year or the year after. It's inevitable,'' Foley said. Republicans who supported the bill criticized Bush's veto during House debate. Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., said Bush had not opposed bills that placed other types of requirements on employers, such as are contained in clean-air, disabilities-rights and other bills. ``It's beyond my understanding why the president vetoed this,'' said Roukema, the chief GOP sponsor. ``What compelling national interest prompted this veto?'' ``Where's our heart?'' said Rep. Arthur Ravenel, R-S.C., who called the bill's requirement a minimum benefit and one that small businesses weren't covered by. But Rep. Steve Bartlett, R-Texas, praised Bush for his ``couragous veto.'' He and other opponents charged the bill would have imposed a ``one-size-fits-all benefit'' on all workers and employers, regardless of whether they might prefer differing benefits. Bartlett said the unpaid leave was a ``yuppie benefit, a benefit that can only be used by upper income workers,'' while effectively denying other potential benefits to workers because of its added expense. ``The mandate before us is cruel because it denies others a benefit that is not on the political agenda of those who sponsor this,'' he said. The bill would have required business and government employers to provide workers with up to 12 weeks of unpaid and job-protected medical leave or with leave for the care of a new child or an ill child, parent or spouse. Businesses with fewer than 50 workers, and workers who are among the highest-paid 10 percent within a company, would have been exempted. Employers would have been required to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave and restore returning employees to their previous jobs or equivalent positions.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Cancels TV Ads For Golf Tourney Because of No-Black Host Club
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th, `Supporting even...', to UPDATE with newspaper report that Toyota and Anheuser-Busch also canceling ads. Hall is cq in 3rd graf. A version moving on some sports circuits.
DOC.TEXT: IBM has canceled television commercials that were supposed to run during the Professional Golfers' Association championship because the host club has no black members, a company spokeswoman says. ``When we learned that this tournament was being played at a club that was exclusionary, we decided it was not an appropriate vehicle for our advertising,'' the spokeswoman, Gina Chew-Holman, said Tuesday. Officials of the private club, Shoal Creek, said it does not have a policy against blacks and some blacks have been guests. Hall Thompson, the club's founder, said in June the club has Jews, Lebanese, Italians and women among its members, but no blacks. ``Supporting even indirectly activities which are exclusionary is against IBM's practices and policies,'' Chew-Holman said. Toyota and Anheuser-Busch also are canceling their TV advertising with ESPN during the event, the Birmingham Post-Herald reported today. Officials with the corporations and ESPN were not immediately available to comment on the report. Everything was running smoothly for the Aug. 9-12 PGA championship, also held at Shoal Creek in 1984, until Thompson commented recently that the club would not be pressured into accepting black members. He later apologized and said he was quoted out of context. Thompson has refused to comment since his apology, as have other club members. Chew-Holman would not say how much money International Business Machines had planned to spend on television advertising during the tournament, which will be televised for two days by ESPN and carried by ABC for the final two days. Leaders of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and the NAACP have urged picketing of the tournament. Mayor Richard Arrington, who is black, says he hopes black leaders decide against demonstrations. ``I don't think they will be necessary to bring about the change being sought,'' he said. Publicity over Shoal Creek has ``started a process of assessment which will likely lead to the voluntary end of racial discrimination'' in Birmingham area country clubs in a year or so, Arrington said.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Flight From Miami Makes Emergency Landing at Heathrow
DOC.TEXT: A Pan Am jumbo jet flying from Miami to London made an emergency landing at Heathrow Airport Wednesday morning after the pilot reported hydraulic problems, officials said. Fire engines and ambulances lined the runway as the Boeing 747 touched down safely. It taxied to a terminal where passengers disembarked normally, said a spokeswoman for BAA Plc, which operates the airport. In New York, Pan Am spokesman Alan Loflin said the aircraft resumed its regular flights after a pump in the aircraft was changed. ``There was never any jeopardy to the airplane at any time,'' Loflin said. He said the plane, which carries a maximum of 412 passengers, was overbooked, but it was not immediately clear how many passengers were aboard.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Congressmen Still Unable To Agree On Pentagon Cuts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and top congressional experts on defense compared notes today on defense spending but could not agree how deeply the Pentagon budget should be cut in the year ahead. The meeting came as Bush mounts a major effort to hold the line on defense budget decreases in the wake of the reduced Soviet threat in Europe and pressures to reduce the overall budget deficit. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., the House Armed Services Committee chairman, has already said he wants to stop producing B-2 bombers, which cost $800 million each. The Air Force now has 15 of the so-called ``stealth'' aircraft. Congress previously agreed to build 75. Aspin said Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ``have in mind a much bigger defense budget than I think is going to come out of this process.'' He said it was impossible to ``come to grips'' with the defense budget without knowing how much budget summit participants will take out of defense. ``The process bogs down when we don't even have a defense number for one year, never mind five years,'' Aspin said. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the Senate Armed Services chairman, said, ``We didn't agree on anything,'' but he said the session was ``probably the best discussion we've had on defense.'' Nunn favors continued production of the B-2, which he said could revolutionize warfare and force the Soviets to scrap their air defense system if the radar-evading stealth technology proves itself. Bush said last Friday at a Strategic Air Command base in Cheyenne, Wyo., that he could live with the $18 billion the Senate Armed Services Committee has voted to cut from his $307 billion defense request for fiscal 1991. Nunn said, ``We can save some very substantial sums over five years and do it prudently,'' trimming $180 billion to $200 billion from defense. But he warned, ``If you do it over one year and you try to take one-fifth of the total five-year savings the first year in defense, you end up wrecking the personnel system (and) demoralizing not only those who will be forced out of the military ... but those who are left.'' Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House minority whip, told reporters that Aspin ``has the votes to pass a left-wing, destructive defense budget.''

DOC.HEAD: Meningitis Epidemic Kills 92 In Uganda
DOC.TEXT: An epidemic of meningitis has killed at least 92 people during the past month in northeastern Uganda, a newspaper reported Wednesday. New Vision newspaper said the outbreak in the arid Karamonja region had been aggravated by a lack of medication in the area, 248 miles from Uganda's capital, Kampala. The newspaper quoted an unidentified Catholic priest as saying that at least 42 victims, a majority of them children, were buried in his church's cemetery. ``Almost every day a person is brought for burial,'' the priest told the newspaper. Meningitis, a viral disease that attacks the brain and the spinal cord, is fatal if not treated early. People in Karamonja, which borders Kenya in the east and Sudan in the north, are also facing famine caused by a severe drought.

DOC.HEAD: Witness: FBI Pressured Him To Change His Story
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A Virgin Islands resident testified today that the FBI pressured him to change his story that he hadn't seen Marion Barry use any drugs on a 1986 boat ride. Defense witness Albert Benjamin also told the court on cross-examination that he became upset when he saw Barry ``make advances'' toward a female companion on the same boat trip. Benjamin, a former U.S. Army sergeant, testified that he felt pressured to tell investigators he had seen Barry and others use drugs. The officers and agents questioning him ``kind of kept driving home the point that I had to know, I had to see'' drug use, Benjamin said. ``I told (one), `Mister, you pushed your luck a little too far,''' Benjamin said he told one city police officer who had been hovering over him during a questioning session. Both city police and FBI agents participated in the session, Benjamin said. But Benjamin also said he felt disturbed seeing Barry make advances on his female companion, Rasheeda Moore, in plain view on a cabin atop the vessel. ``I was angry because I think adults should conduct themselves in an appropriate manner in public ... my wife was sitting there,'' Benjamin said. ``I really didn't appreciate what I saw ... I felt that was very out of place.'' When asked by Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts whether Barry had been ``fondling'' Moore, Benjamin answered, `Yes, and she accepted it.'' Moore later became a government witness against Barry, participating in the FBI sting operation that produced Barry's Jan. 18 arrest. Moore has testified that she and the mayor used drugs ``over 100 times.'' Barry's attorneys called Benjamin in an attempt to dispute the testimony of another government witness that the Benjamins could have seen Barry use drugs during the trip. Benjamin said he saw no drug use, but he testified that he did see Barry smoke a cigarette. Government witness Charles Lewis, who was on the trip, has testified that he and Barry smoked marijuana on the boat. Benjamin said he was unfamiliar with the smell of marijuana. On Tuesday, Barry's chauffeur says he doesn't recall any specific dates and details in 12 years of driving the mayor around _ except that he didn't take him to an alleged drug pickup site on Sept. 7, 1988. Testifying for the defense in Barry's drug and perjury trial, Walter Bracey said he vividly recalled driving Barry to the grand opening of a supermarket that morning, and then taking the mayor directly to a meeting with city fire department officials. A government witness, Lydia Reid Pearson, has testified that she handed Barry cocaine and a city job application at a municipal building shortly after 10 a.m. that day. Bracey testified that he drove Barry to the supermarket opening at about 9:40 a.m., stayed there with the mayor for 45 minutes, and then took him to the fire department meeting. Barry is charged with 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor charge of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Cargo Plane Crashes
DOC.TEXT: An Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 707 cargo jet was badly damaged Wednesday after it slammed into a culvert at the end of a runway while attempting to take off, a spokesman said. None of the three crewmembers was hurt after the crash at Addis Ababa's international airport, said a spokesman for the Civil Aviation Authority. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The plane was on a regular flight from Ethiopia's capital to Asmara, the besieged provincial capital of the northernmost province of Eritrea. Rebels of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front have virtually surrounded Asmara since last February and the government has had to rely on an airlift to supply its military forces and civilians in the city.

DOC.HEAD: Gephardt Says Nobody Wants to Raise Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 5-7, At the White House, to add White House views on budget session.
DOC.TEXT: Budget negotiators are looking at a new 1995 target for balancing the budget, but coming up with a plan is difficult because ``nobody wants to raise taxes,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt said today. Gephardt, D-Mo., told reporters at the White House that only ``incremental progress'' is being made in meetings with President Bush. However, he said negotiators generally had agreed to a framework under which $50 billion would be slashed from the deficit in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, and a total of $500 billion over the next five years. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-control law, which now calls for a balanced budget in 1993, would be eased to give two additional years to reach that goal, Gephardt said. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration and congressional Democrats had agreed to present ``packages'' later this week that will contain specifics. The proposals will be presented simultaneously at budget meetings either Thursday or Friday, Fitzwater said. That would resolve a controversy over which side would go first. The proposals will be the first specific plans proposed in the 11 weeks of bargaining. Speaking with reporters after the second Oval Office session this week on the budget, Gephardt said there has yet to be a single hard decision made in 11 weeks of budget-summit talks. However, he also said various packages will be presented later this week that will lay out specific options. Suggesting it now seems dubious that accord can be reached before Congress begins its August recess, Gephardt said: ``If we spend a lot of time worrying about when we'll get it done, we won't get it done.'' Today's White House session focused on cutting programs for the poor and elderly, he said. ``Both sides are troubled'' by the magnitude of cuts being discussed in these areas, he said. And, even though President Bush has lifted his pledge of no new taxes, when it comes down to specifics ``on the revenue side, nobody wants to raise taxes,'' he said. Consequently, ``It's very hard to put a final package together,'' he said. Gephardt, who is leader of the budget negotiators when Bush is not present, mildly chided the president for appearing to break his pledge to tone down partisan rhetoric. After agreeing to mute his political attacks against congressional Democrats on Tuesday morning, Bush went on to lash out at them in speeches in Philadelphia and New York City. Gephardt said Bush explained they had been ``pre-scheduled speeches'' and that the president had tried to separate his political attacks from the budget talks. ``All of us give political speeches,'' Gephardt said. ``(But) We have to decide if we want to make political points or solve this budget problem.'' Gephardt said if a deal can't be struck on the budget by the month-long August recess, negotiators may have to remain in Washington to continue working on one. Negotiators say they are not likely to decide precisely what the new taxes and spending slashes will be until September or later. Only then will the House and Senate have a chance to vote on the measure that emerges. ``The problem with putting together a detailed package now is that it's left out there dangling'' during the recess, said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. ``The members when they go home are subject to pressures from various groups'' and could end up agreeing to oppose the measure, he said. Some Republicans have offered to ignore the recess and keep working until a package is shaped, said Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas. But he agreed that what is most likely by the August break is ``the broad outlines of a package.'' Officials involved in the talks say White House budget chief Richard Darman remains hopeful that a detailed package can be completed _ and perhaps even enacted _ by early August. At the summit talks, now in their 11th week, bargainers failed Tuesday to agree to the precise amount of deficit-cutting they would seek. But Sasser confirmed that the ``general consensus'' of the negotiators remained a package of about $50 billion in savings for next year, divided about evenly between tax increases and spending cuts. The bargainers have informally been using those numbers for several weeks now. Bush complained at a GOP dinner in New York of the long ``Democratic dominance'' that he said has caused ``government by gridlock, with spending skyrocketing out of control, good legislation thrown aside for pork and a budget deficit looming over our children's children.'' He ended on a slightly kinder note, taking note of his daily meetings with congressional leaders. ``We all know that the Democrats have a long track record on spending,'' he said, ``but if the Berlin Wall could come down in the same year that America goes nuts over the Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles, who knows what could happen next? ... The leaders of Congress can work with me to break the impasse on reducing the budget deficit. And I think they are trying.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets to be Allowed to Spend Foreign Currency
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens with foreign currency they have been unable to use without explaining where it came from will be able to spend it freely at special shops and deposit it in banks starting Aug. 1. The change in rules was announced Tuesday by Deputy Prime Minister Stepan Sitarian, head of the government's foreign economic commission, the Tass news agency said. As well as easing banking problems for Soviets with legal access to foreign currency, the change will allow taxi drivers, prostitutes, black marketeers and others with illegally obtained cash to open foreign currency bank accounts and spend the money at special shops currently used by foreigners. It also will pump much-needed hard currency, such as U.S. dollars, into the Soviet economy. Hard currency refers to money that is convertible on the world market. The Soviet currency, the ruble, is not convertible. Sitarian said individual Soviets have $324 million in foreign currency they had acquired legally. However, they have been unable to spend the money in the Soviet Union except at special shops for foreigners known as beriozkas that have only a limited amount of goods. ``In accordance with the resolution, a network of trade houses and firm-owned stores will be set up in the Soviet Union, where Soviet enterprises and organizations, as well as citizens owning currency, will be able to buy imported and high-quality domestic goods,'' Tass said. It did not say when the new stores would open. Under the current law, a limited number of Soviets, such as those who have worked abroad or who work for foreign firms, may have foreign currency bank accounts. When they open the account, or when they spend their money in the special shops for foreigners, they must explain to the government how they obtained the funds. This will no longer be required, Tass said. ``This will enable many Soviet citizens owning foreign currency to legalize it and use it on Soviet territory,'' it said. Almost all Soviets are now barred from possessing foreign currency, but many flout the law. Dozens of Soviet shoppers are seen every weekend at joint-venture shops paying foreign currency for imported food and goods. Tass quoted Sitarian as saying, ``the Soviet government is aware of the weak sides of introducing the retail trade for currency on Soviet territory. This can evoke protests and discontent on the part of some layers of the Soviet population.'' But, he said: ``Still we found it necessary to take the step and enable state enterprises, cooperatives, collective farms and individuals owning currency to spend it in the Soviet Union.'' He said the currency deposits will provide a considerable sum of foreign currency reserves for the Soviet state, which the Soviet Union can use for its own purposes. The new system of stores and legalization of foreign currency accounts ``will give the state considerable income while curtailing foreign currency exports,'' Sitarian was quoted as saying. As an incentive to prospective depositers, Sitarian said the issue of interest on foreign currency accounts will be reviewed. Under the present rules, foreign cash accounts do not generate interest.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Toddler Remains In Critical Condition
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old Texas girl was awake and alert Wednesday, one day after receiving a liver and small intestine in a rare transplant operation. Tracey Kay Gonzales of Corpus Christi remained in critical condition in the intensive care unit at Children's Hospital here, said spokeswoman Sue Cardillo. The toddler was being weaned off a respirator that assists her breathing, said Ms. Cardillo. The child received the organs in a 14-hour operation that ended Tuesday morning. ``Doctors continue to be optimistic about Tracey's recovery,'' Ms. Cardillo said. ``At this point things are going as well as can be expected.'' The first 72 hours after the operation are the most critical, and it will be at least a week before doctors will be able to predict how she will fare, Ms. Cardillo said. Small intestine transplants have a poor success rate. Since 1983, one adult and three children have died within a year of their surgeries at Pittsburgh hospitals. One adult patient is still alive. No patients who have received small intestine transplants elsewhere have lived. Tracey needed the operation because she suffered from short gut syndrome, which left her small intestine unable to absorb nutrition. Her liver was damaged by a high-protein liquid she was fed intravenously since birth.

DOC.HEAD: Tens Of Thousands Mob Immigration Department As Deadline Nears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with final figures. Pickup 4th, ``If we...
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people mobbed Hong Kong's Immigration Department today, the last day to apply for permission to move to Britain and escape Communist rule when the British colony reverts to China in 1997. Laborers, doctors, clerks, housewives and teachers squeezed into a line that snaked more than half a mile over pedestrian walkways and along two main avenues in downtown Hong Kong. At least 50 people had spent the night, and several children fainted in the hot, humid weather. Immigration officials said that at least 45,000 people had waited in line. By the time police closed the gates shortly after midnight, about 18,000 heads of households had applied for the nationality package. This was in addition to an estimated 26,000 who submitted applications in previous days. ``If we don't apply, we'll lose out and become poor like all Communists,'' said John Lam, a 41-year-old office manager in a trading house, who had been waiting for six hours. ``I'm doing this for my son,'' he said, pointing to a baby sleeping in a pink stroller. The British government is offering about 225,000 Hong Kong residents the right to live in Britain. According to Hong Kong immigration officials, about 3.5 million of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people are eligible for consideration under the package. Already more than 1,000 people a week are emigrating, mainly to Australia and Canada, because they fear a loss of rights and opportunities when Hong Kong comes under Chinese rule in 1997. Mothers waiting in line today carried children strapped to their chests. Old ladies leaned on walkers and businessmen spoke into portable phones, cutting deals as they awaited their turn. C.B. Chan, assistant director of immigration, said the department would stay open until midnight to accommodate the crowd. Most of those eligible for the plan don't have to formally apply because they already can prove they are British subjects, either by possessing a British-Hong Kong passport or a Hong Kong birth certificate. Thus, thousands needlessly lined up today and the Immigration Department issued pleas to people with the necessary documents to go home. The confusion was another example that many Hong Kong residents are becoming increasingly desperate about their future. As part of a 1984 agreement, China promised to maintain Hong Kong's freewheeling economic and social system under a program it calls ``one country, two systems.'' But after the June 1989 crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in Beijing, many in the territory lost faith in China's promise. Hong Kong people also question British assurances of its support up until 1997, when Britain's 99-year lease on the colony runs out. In a sign interpreted by many as kowtowing to China, the colonial government is prosecuting five pro-democracy activists for breaking an obscure law banning the use of bullhorns. The government censored a film critical of Beijing and banned from its waters a radio ship that was intended to broadcast pro-democracy messages to China. A recent letter sent by a top official, William Ehrman, to Chinese authorities reaffirmed Britain's policy of forbidding Hong Kong from becoming a base for ``subversive activities,'' local media have said. A sudden job switch by Britain's foreign minister with special responsibility for Hong Kong, Francis Maude, also has caused concern. Maude has been appointed financial secretary to the treasury. ``This is a crucial stage of negotiations,'' said Martin Lee, a member of the Hong Kong's Legislative Council and a leading political activist. ``I hope the person replacing him will ... take Hong Kong matters to heart.'' Many of the people in line today said they had little hope of leaving. ``It's just a shot in the dark,'' said Leung Ling-yeung, a 33-year-old teacher who took the day off from school with her 8-year-old daughter. ``My English is not too good so I don't have much hope. But all of us will do anything to escape communism.'' To gain consideration under the British nationality package, applicants have to first become permanent residents of Hong Kong. That is achieved either by birth, marriage or by living and working in the territory for a certain number of years. Once they become permanent residents, they can apply for the right to live in Britain. The British government has issued guidelines which says it is looking for professionals in about 20 occupations, such as doctors and engineers. Fluency in English, rare among Hong Kong Chinese, is considered important.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Statehouse Scandals, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the three federal investigations involving state government and public officials in South Carolina:
DOC.HEAD: VOTE BUYING
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury has subpoenaed campaign spending records for all members of the state Legislature _ 124 lawmakers in the House, 46 in the Senate _ as part of an investigation into allegations they traded votes for cash. The probe apparently involves an FBI sting operation in which a lobbying working undercover offered legislators cash in exchange for votes on a bill establishing pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina.
DOC.HEAD: FBI AGENT
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Justice Department is looking into allegations that South Carolina's top FBI officer avoided arrest on a drunken-driving charge in March with the aid of the state's chief highway patrolman.
DOC.HEAD: HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities are investigating allegations two top state Highway Department officials each accepted $2,000 from a company that has received $114 million in road contracts during the past 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Gives Outlaw Groups 15 Days to Disband
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday threatened to use military force against armed outlaw groups unless they disband and surrender their weapons in 15 days, the Tass news agency reported. The ultimatum was Gorbachev's latest effort to crack down on increasing ethnic violence that has killed hundreds of people in the republics of Armenia, Azerbaijan and in Soviet Central Asia. It also was a tacit admission that Soviet Interior Ministry troops have been unable to stop militants from organizing _ at times with what Tass called ``the connivance of local authorities'' _ and obtaining caches of guns, ammunition, bombs and military hardware. The decree also comes at a time when Gorbachev is trying to negotiate a treaty with all 15 Soviet republics to transfer some of the powers from the central government to local authorities who want more autonomy from Moscow. The official news agency did not specify which regions Gorbachev's decree referred to, but it followed a week of detailed reports in the state-run press of rampages by ``terrorists'' in the southern republic of Armenia. On Friday, an Interior Ministry spokesman told Tass that armed groups in Armenia attacked at least eight government, Interior Ministry or police offices in recent days in unsuccessful attempts to seize weapons. The attackers used explosives in at least two of the incidents, Tass said. The unofficial Interfax news agency also reported at least two suspicious explosions last week _ one aboard a train that killed five people and another that damaged a water pipeline to Nagorno-Karabakh, a region disputed by Armenians and Azerbaijanis. Riots and attacks against KGB, government and party buildings have become part of a recurring pattern of anti-Soviet violence in various parts of the southern Soviet Union in the past year. Some attacks are aimed clearly at taking arms from police and KGB stocks, and others have been intended to force political change. In one of the biggest such attacks, Armenians bombarded the local KGB headquarters in the republic's capital of Yerevan on April 14 with stones, torches and flare-guns, Tass reported. One attacker was reported killed. On May 4, about 200 armed men who called themselves the Armenian National Army surrounded a Communist Party building in Yerevan for several hours and presented a list of political demands, including the withdrawal of all Soviet troops from Armenia, before dispersing. At least 200 people have died in two years of ethnic fighting between Armenians and residents of the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan, mostly over control of Nagorno-Karabakh, a predominantly Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan. In the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia, where another 212 people died in violence since June 4 between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks, Tass also reported last week that 26 firearms had been confiscated by police and 180 people were detained. Among the weapons seized was a grenade, Tass said. Gorbachev's decree authorized local police, officials of the republics, the Interior Ministry and the KGB to take action to ensure that all weapons were confiscated from the outlaw groups within 15 days. If the armed groups do not comply with the order, ``the Soviet Interior Ministry has the right to use Interior troops, and units of the Soviet Defense Ministry may become involved in some operations,'' Tass said. Interior Ministry and army troops have been sent to the Caucasus and Central Asia in the past, but only after violence has broken out. Some of these troops remain on patrol, especially along the border between Azerbaijan and Armenia, and in western Kirghizia. Tass said Gorbachev's decree was aimed at outlaw groups that threaten people's lives, seize arms, assault soldiers and police, and attack military and civilian facilities. ``They are connected with the commission of other grave crimes, and lead to casualties among innocent people,'' the agency said. ``Criminals, draft dodgers and deserters from the armed forces are often drawn into these groups.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi President Summons U.S. Ambassaor For Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Mubarak saying Kuwait and Iraq agree to direct talks to resolve the dispute. Pickup 3rd, `In a show...'
DOC.TEXT: The government said today that it will not be intimidated by U.S. pressure in its oil dispute with neighboring Kuwait, and President Saddam Hussein summoned the U.S. ambassador for talks. Although Iraq reportedly has massed troops along the Kuwaiti border, there were several signs today that Baghdad was prepared to resolve the dispute. Diplomatic sources in Kuwait said that Saddam has given assurances he will not use military force if Kuwait agrees to pay compensation for $2.4 billion worth of oil Iraq claims it has stolen since 1980. Later in the day, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said that Iraq and Kuwait have agreed to hold direct talks on Saturday or Sunday in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to try to solve their dispute peacefuly. Mubarak, who has actively tried to mediate the dispute, also told reporters in Cairo that Saddam had agreed to stop his verbal attacks on Kuwait. In a show of support for Kuwait, the Pentagon announced Tuesday that U.S. warships and aircraft would hold a ``short-notice exercise'' 600 miles to the south in the Persian Gulf with a second small state, the United Arab Emirates. Saddam moved troops to the Kuwaiti border after accusing Kuwait and the U.A.E. of exceeding their OPEC production quotas and driving down oil prices. He threatened to use military force if they did not adhere to OPEC guidelines. At the same time, he accused Kuwait of stealing oil from the Rumaila field, which is along the border and includes land both countries claim. The Iraqi newspaper Al-Jumhuriya said today the Kuwaiti foreign minister, Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, must ``know and his American masters in the White House know that Iraq will not succumb and will not let anyone encroach upon its rights.'' In apparent reference to the heightened U.S. military preparedness in the region, the paper accused Kuwait of ``implementing an American-Zionist plot to show that America is playing the role of protector in the gulf.'' The paper said Kuwait ``should be aware that those who are threatening the interests of the Arab nation and conspire against it will not be protected by foreigners.'' Official Iraqi radio said that Saddam summoned U.S. Ambassador April Glaspie for talks today. The report gave no details on what was discussed. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met with Kuwaiti and Iraqi leaders on Tuesday. Arab diplomats said Saddam told Mubarak he would not use force if Kuwait met Iraqi conditions on paying compensation. The diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Saddam also stressed that the dispute could only be solved through direct talks with Kuwait, not through Egypt's mediation. Kuwaiti Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah said today: ``Kuwait was and remains, with strong sincerity and enthusiasm, willing to meet with our brethren in Iraq to reach an understanding in a brotherly atmosphere on an acceptable formula in the interest of both parties.'' The disputed oil field extends two miles into Kuwait but Iraq claims it owns the entire field. Kuwait wants an Arab League committee to demarcate its borders and says Iraq has rejected the request. Saddam has spent an estimated $50 billion on sophisticated arms since coming to power in 1979 and appears to be trying to frighten Kuwait and the U.A.E. into ending oil overproduction. Iraq has the world's second-largest oil reserves but endured a costly war from 1980-88 with Iran and has a foreign debt of about $70 billion. Saddam claims his country lost $14 billion during the past year because of a world oil glut that has sent prices tumbling. Informed sources in Kuwait said the Iraqi troop buildup had increased over the last 48 hours to at least 30,000, and that more than 200 Soviet-made tanks were posted along Iraq's 100-mile-long southern border with Kuwait. The sources said Kuwait on Tuesday reinstated a state of alert it had declared July 16. Iraq has 17 million residents, including 1 million troops. Kuwait has 1.8 million residents, and 20,300 members of the armed forces. Pete Williams, a Defense Department spokesman, told reporters that the joint U.S.-Emirates exercise, codenamed ``Ivory Justice'' began Monday. In Abu Dhabi, a spokesman for the United Arab Emirates Foreign Ministry said that the Emirates holds routine military exercises this time of year. ``What the American official spokesman referred to is no more than part of a technical training program agreed upon previously and does not have any link with the latest developments in the region,'' the spokesman said in a statement reported by the official WAM news agency. The State Department announced at the beginning of the crisis that it backs Kuwait's territorial integrity. But Williams would not comment when asked if the United States would come to Kuwait's aid militarily if it were attacked by Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Tunnels to Help Endangered Toads Cross Road
DOC.TEXT: Why does the endangered Houston toad cross the road? For making whoopee. The 2- to 3-inch toads have been making the risky trip across Texas 21 for years, and many have been flattened en route. The state highway department said Wednesday it has a plan to get the toads to cross under the four-lane highway, not over it. For humans, the proposal is part of a roadway safety project. For toads, it's safer sex. On a 5{-mile stretch of Route 21 just east of Austin, state highway officials want to either build a series of tunnels or modify four drainage lines for the amphibians, which cross back and forth across the road looking for rain-swollen ponds where they breed. The toad was designated a federally endangered species in 1965. Several thousand of them live in Bastrop County, officials have estimated. The toad proposals will be reviewed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Department, which is responsible for protecting endangered species. The underground toad trail is part of safety improvements where there have been numerous instances of vehicles running into loblolly pines that line the scenic road. The highway department originally proposed cutting down about 1,000 of the trees but after residents protested, officials decided to line the stretch with guardrails and build paved shoulders. The state probably will choose to modify existing drainage lines for the toads, said Randall Dillard, a highway department spokesman.
