That would cost about $51,250 as opposed to $628,000 for fancy polymer concrete tunnels designed by a British firm. ``I don't know if a toad really knows the difference between a tunnel that's built for him or a modified drainage ditch,'' Dillard said.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Arthur Threatens Windwards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to UPDATE storm's path and strength
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Arthur, the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season's first storm to get a name, today pushed heavy rain across the Windward Islands with winds gusting to 60 mph in the Caribbean Sea. Government officials on the island nation of Trinidad and Tobago issued storm warnings for Trinidad, Tobago, Grenada and Grenada dependencies. The islands separate the southeastern Caribbean Sea from the Atlantic. At noon EDT, Arthur was centered about 425 miles southeast of Ponce, Puerto Rico. It was moving west-northwest at about 15 mph and was expected to remain on that course through Friday, said Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. Grenada reported 55 mph wind gusts early this morning and heavy rains were reported on Tobago and other islands in the area, Sheets said. The weather service reported top winds of 60 mph over open water. Tropical storms become hurricanes if their sustained winds top 74 mph. Arthur grew from a tropical depression, the second of the 1990 season, that formed Sunday in the open Atlantic. The hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Awesome Haircuts: Using Your Head to Make a Statement
LaserPhoto 26
DOC.TEXT: Nina Kaufman didn't have to leave California to get her nose pierced, her head shaved on one side and her black hair dyed purple. But to get a skull and sword etched on the back of her scalp, the 17-year-old San Rafael resident flew here for a session at Astor Place Hair Designers in Manhattan's East Village. ``She said she wanted a haircut that had something to do with death,'' said her friend, Janel Margaretta, 17, of Freehold, N.J., with whom she was staying. It was Janel's enthusiasm about Astor Place that led Nina to make the trip. ``It's awesome,'' Janel added. Fred Preda, the man with the electric razor, found nothing unusual about Nina's request, which the Terra Linda High School student sketched on a napkin before sitting in the barber's chair. ``I copy anything,'' Preda explained as he showed off photos of Union Jacks, Dick Tracy, Bart Simpson and other designs he has razored on scalps. Preda is one of 100 haircutters at Astor Place, a 10,000-square-foot, two-story salon that started out as a corner barber shop in 1965 and still has the rotating red, white and blue pole outside. The store almost went belly up in the late '60s when long hair came in and haircuts went out. But when punk rockers took over the East Village in the late '70s and began to demand head shaves, asymmetrical cuts, hair spiked like porcupine quills and locks dyed pink and blue, business at Astor Place started booming and never stopped. The walls are plastered with photos of famous customers, from John F. Kennedy Jr. to the New Kids on the Block. Right now the baddest 'dos are mops on top, bald on the sides. Popular among both sexes and all races, the fad was inspired by the fade, a thick-on-top, tapered-on-the-side cut that started among black teen-age boys. In his 1986 critically acclaimed film, ``She's Gotta Have It,'' Spike Lee as the character Mars Blackmon appears with a zig-zag carved in his hair. The carved cut _ which costs $25 and up, depending on how elaborate it is _ is easily individualized by leaving tufts of hair in a pattern to form initials or the design of your choice. Hector Craveiro, 26, a Catholic school teacher from Westchester, was having a map of Africa etched on his head. ``Everything's Africa now _ politics, fashion, music, names,'' he explained. ``Today was the last day of summer school at Sacred Heart, so I decided to come down and get it cut.'' Preda, the man with the razor, looked at a tiny plastic globe he keeps among his combs and gels as he etched the shape of the continent on the back of Craveiro's skull. Then he shaved away hair to form the letters UNITY, as per Craveiro's instructions, and colored the map in red, black and green using water-soluble markers. Not all Astor Place's customers are so avant garde. In one corner, a toddler getting a trim sucked on a lollipop while his mother looked on. Nearby, a businessman in a suit and tie read a newspaper while the barber snipped his hair short and plain. Then there was Hansen Williams, 25, a hospital orderly, having his head shaved clean except for a topknot of dreadlocks. ``I had it dyed blonde and I like to get it touched up every week,'' he explained. Enrico Vezza, 56, who started the store with his brother 25 years ago ``to make a living, that's all,'' shrugged. ``It's not just a barber shop,'' he said. ``It's theater.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested After Hiding AIDS Test
DOC.TEXT: A 23-year-old man has been arrested and charged with attempted first-degree assault because he allegedly planned to have sex with someone without telling the person he had tested positive for AIDS. Lt. Steve Imes said police were notified by an employee of a theater about a message written on a bathroom wall, giving a phone number and asking anyone interested in using drugs and having sex to call. A detective called the number and set up a rendezvous with the man at a hotel, Imes said. When they met and the man indicated he was interested in having sex, the undercover detective arrested him for vandalism for writing on the bathroom wall. Police then learned that the man believed he had tested positively for AIDS, Imes said. Despite that knowledge, he allegedly planned to go ahead with sex without telling the undercover detective he had tested positive, Imes said.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Study: Many Hospitals Should Offer AIDS Tests to All Patients
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Many hospitals should routinely offer AIDS tests to all patients, especially in poor city neighborhoods, because so many people are unknowingly infected with the AIDS virus, a government study recommends. The chief author of the report said AIDS screening should become as common a part of hospital care as testing for heart disease and glaucoma. ``There is a large number of infected persons who are unaware of their status,'' said Dr. Michael E. St. Louis. ``Hospitals may be an efficient place where they could potentially get plugged into an appropriate program of treatment or counseling.'' His report, based on a major study by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, found that AIDS infections are extremely common in some poor city areas, where one in five young and middle-age men carry the virus. But unsuspected AIDS infections occur virtually everywhere in the United States. By failing to spot these infections, the study said, hospitals are missing an important opportunity to provide early care to people who are likely to develop grave illnesses. While there is no cure for AIDS, treatment early in the infection can delay the start of AIDS-related health problems. St. Louis said that while ideally most hospitals would offer routine AIDS testing, the screening should be done only if they are prepared to keep the results confidential and to offer follow-up counseling and care to people who turn out to be infected. ``We are not saying that every hospital should be doing this,'' he said, ``but on the basis of our findings, many may need to consider it.'' While the CDC has not changed its estimate that 1 million Americans are infected with the AIDS virus, the latest study found a 70-fold difference in the infection rate across the United States. In most places, the virus is still rare. In several Midwest and Western states, well under 1 percent of patients screened carried the virus. By contrast, at two hospitals in New York City and Newark, N.J., more than 5 percent of all patients were infected. The numbers were especially high considering that the researchers did not test anyone who went to the hospital with any condition that might result from the AIDS virus or suggest a higher-than-usual risk of catching it. These included all people with cancer, infections, hemophilia, psychiatric problems and gunshot wounds. ``Our findings yield no support for the premise that the AIDS epidemic will soon abate, even in the areas that were the earliest infected, such as the New York metropolitan area,'' the doctors wrote. Their study, published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, was based on AIDS tests anonymously performed on 89,547 people. Their blood was drawn for other purposes at 26 hospitals during the past two years. Among the findings: _The overall AIDS infection rate ranged from less than one-tenth of 1 percent to nearly 8 percent, depending on the hospitals' location. The testing turned up at least one unsuspected infection in every hospital. _Men were seven times more likely than women to carry the virus, and blacks were almost twice as likely as whites to be infected. _At the two New York area hospitals with the highest infections, the virus was most common among men between ages 25 to 44. About 20 percent of them were infected. _At the eight hospitals with the lowest infection rates, none of the 5,002 women tested between ages 25 and 44 carried the virus. Dr. Deborah J. Cotton, clinical director for AIDS at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, cautioned that keeping test results confidential can be a serious problem, and often no counseling programs exist to advise people who find they are infected. ``It would be wrong to offer the test if there is no place to refer patients to if they turn out to be positive,'' she said. St. Louis said the CDC is revising its formal guidelines on hospital screening to recommend more aggressive testing for the AIDS virus.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Governor Vetoes Record Labeling Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `As a...', with three grafs to expand Roemer quote and add Tipper Gore comment. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Although the...' ^By GUY COATES
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer today vetoed a controversial bill that would have required warning labels on recordings that deal with potentially offensive topics such as drug abuse, sex and violence. Roemer said threatened economic boycotts against the state didn't sway him. He vetoed the bill, he said, because it was an infringement on constitutionally protected free speech. He said he hoped a voluntary labeling program being implemented by the recording industry would be successful and warned that the issue will return in Louisiana and other states if the industry's plan does not satisfy lawmakers. ``This issue will not go away,'' he said. ``As a parent, I wanted to sign the bill.'' Tipper Gore, president of the Parents' Music Resource Center, appeared with Roemer at a news conference. Her group was one of the first advocates of a voluntary labeling system. ``We all recognize the concern to protect children from violent and explicit messages but we don't want government to legislate that concern,'' said Mrs. Gore, wife of Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn. Although the bill passed both chambers with more than the two-thirds vote needed to override a veto, the Legislature is in recess and members would have to come back into session to override. No veto has been overridden this century. The bill, the first of its kind in the nation, would have required warning labels on recordings that promote deviant sex, violence, drug abuse, suicide or child abuse. It also would have prohibited sale of such recordings to people under 17. Under the bill, retailers, manufacturers and distributors would have been subject to jail terms and fines of up to $5,000 for violations. The aim was to protect children, but the bill didn't address the issue of having the same songs played on radio or television. Passage of the bill brought loud protests from the music industry, with threats of canceled performances and bans against groups touring in the state. The Neville Brothers, favorite sons in Louisiana, called the bill racist. Among performers who wrote the governor were Patti LaBelle, Tony Bennett, Ray Charles, Dick Clark, Dr. John, Elton John and Judas Priest. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences had threatened to end consideration of New Orleans as a site for the Grammy Hall of Fame if the bill had become law. Music industry organizations threatened to cancel planned conventions in the city. Radio stations had ``label day'' marathons to play nothing but records that disc jockeys thought would fall under the ban. Among them were such classics as ``Stagger Lee,'' ``House of the Rising Sun,'' ``Love For Sale,'' and ``Mack the Knife.'' In May, the recording industry unveiled a voluntary labeling system that it hoped would halt state campaigns for mandatory labeling. Industry spokesmen said every legislature except Louisiana's pulled back labeling bills while the voluntary program was tested. The legislation would not have taken effect until 1992. Haik had said that if the recording industry implemented its voluntary program, he would push for repeal of the law.

DOC.HEAD: Search For Elusive Wallaby Sputters
DOC.TEXT: A male Australian wallaby escaped from a zoo, leaving behind three females, and has led officials on a 10-mile chase, at speeds up to 30 mph. Animal keepers didn't bother to continue the chase Wednesday. Susan Stevens, a spokeswoman for the MetroParks Zoos, said rainy weather in the Boston area meant the 30-pound marsupial, named Aardu, probably would seek shelter. ``He's not likely to be visible in the rain, since he won't be moving around much,'' Stevens said. Aardu, a hardy vegetarian with a knack for survival, was probably in no danger, Stevens said. The chase began Monday when Aardu was reported missing from the Stone Zoo in Stoneham. He was spotted in a nearby forest, but bounded off when would-be captors approached. Stevens estimated that the wallaby had traveled 10 miles since his escape, reaching speeds up to 30 mph. She said Aardu apparently leaped to freedom from his cage, which is bounded by a moat and a high wall with a railing. He shared the enclosure with three female wallabies, and zoo keepers had hoped he would eventually father wallaby offspring. ``He can jump about 6 feet straight up, but we didn't think it was likely he'd get out of his cage,'' Stevens said. Until he's caught, Aardu shouldn't have much trouble surviving in the New England woods, Stevens said. ``The good news is that he's a hardy animal,'' Stevens said. ``He can adapt well to colder climates. And since he's a vegetarian, he has plenty of food and water. He could live out there indefinitely.'' The question was whether human search teams could do the same. Stevens was one of about 25 searchers who slogged through thick brush in the rain Tuesday. ``We sat there, soaking wet and tired, and we realized he's smarter than we are,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Reported Dead, Dozens Missing in Factory Collapse
DOC.TEXT: A factory on the outskirts of Bangkok collapsed Wednesday night, killing at least four people and injuring 10, police and news reports said. Up to 30 others were believed trapped and feared dead. A television report quoted the prime minister as saying the recently completed five-story plastics factory had not been built in line with government safety standards. Thai newspaper and television reporters quoted rescue officials at the scene as saying up to 30 people were still believed trapped. Television reports said the search for survivors would continue through the night. News reports said those caught in the collapse were working overtime. A district police officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the collapse occurred after regular working hours, at about 7 p.m. Reporters at the scene said three bodies had been pulled from the wreckage by midnight, and another person died in the hospital. Thailand's Channel 7 television said 10 people were taken to the hospital, three with serious injuries. Late-night television showed hundreds of rescue workers clearing rubble, using lights powered by generator because the electricity was cut off. Reporters at the scene said no sound could be heard from the collapsed building. Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan arrived shortly before midnight to view rescue efforts. He told a television interviewer that the factory's builders had failed to meet safety standards. Interior Minister Banharn Silpa Archa also said the building's construction failed to measure up to government standards. A factory worker told a television interviewer that the factory's second floor gave way and the rest of the structure then collapsed.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Paul Winfield did his homework for his role in ``Presumed Innocent,'' according to the judge who was his role model. ``He picked up that feeling of the courtroom, with lawyers going back and forth, trying to get in evidence they know they shouldn't get in, the exasperation you feel,'' District Judge Willie G. Lipscomb said at a screening of the new film. ``Presumed Innocent,'' about a deputy prosecutor accused of murdering a colleague, made its national debut Tuesday night at the Detroit Institute of Arts. The movie, starring Harrison Ford, was filmed partially in Detroit, although the book by Scott Turow was set in a mythical Illinois city. Winfield observed Lipscomb's court before playing the judge in the film. ``Presumed Innocent,'' which opens nationwide Friday, also stars Raul Julia and Greta Scacchi.

Actor Kevin Costner and FBI Director William Sessions are being honored by a national collegiate fraternity. Costner, the star of ``Field of Dreams'' and ``The Untouchables,'' is expected to be one of an estimated 500 delegates attending the special centennial conference of the nationwide collegiate fraternity in Syracuse Aug. 8 to 12. He and Sessions, who does not plan to attend, will be given ``Delta Chi of the Year'' awards. Costner ``was a marketing major at the University of California at Fullerton, but he hated it and went into acting,'' said Jeff Albright, Delta Chi national programming director. The film star has retained his allegiance to his fraternity and was the speaker at the 1988 convention, Albright said.

Country music singer Holly Dunn says her style of music has gotten a big boost from the White House. President Bush is a fan who has said he listens to country music on the radio and has country tapes in the Oval Office. Earlier this month, he invited Grand Ole Opry stars to perform at the economic summit in Houston. ``He's done us a real favor,'' Dunn said Tuesday in an interview. ``He's really into it. Jimmy Carter liked country, too.'' Dunn's hit records include ``Daddy's Hands,'' ``Are You Ever Gonna Love Me'' and ``Only When I Love.'' In 1987 she won the Country Music Association's Horizon Award as the most promising performer.

Country western singer Willie Nelson has decided to hang a ``for sale'' sign on his $3 million, 116-acre ranch in this mountain community west of Denver. ``It's a very nice estate, but very typically Willie. It's not ostentatious; it's more on the homey side,'' broker Brad Moss of Metro Brokers at Evergreen Inc. said Tuesday. Nelson is best known for his songs ``On the Road Again,'' ``My Heroes Have Always Been Cowboys and ``You Were Always On My Mind.'' The property, which includes a two-story, 4,700-square-foot main residence, has been a favorite hideaway for the singer, but neither he nor his estranged wife, Connie, has visited it for the past several months, he said. The Nelsons acquired the property in late 1980 for less than $1.5 million. The main house has nine rooms, Moss said. ``It has lots of character. It's not opulent, but it's big _ a big country boy's home,'' Moss said.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: Defense Management System Needs Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon must overhaul its management system, congressional investigators said Wednesday, likening the Defense Department's financial situation to the savings and loan crisis and other financial disasters that have required federal bailouts. The General Accounting Office said the Pentagon is planning to build weapons the nation can't afford, operates an inventory system with billions of dollars in excess parts and bases decisions on incomplete information. ``The lack of accurate financial data for decision makers was a critical problem in the New York City, Chrysler Corp., and savings and loan crises,'' Charles Bowsher, the nation's comptroller general and head of the GAO, told the House Armed Services Committee. ``A similar lack of financial data exists in the Defense Department today,'' Bowsher said. The federal government bailed out New York City in the mid-1970s and the Chrysler Corp. in 1980. Ways of handling the $100 billion savings and loan scandal are still being addressed. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., Armed Services chairman, asked Bowsher how far he would go in comparing Defense Department management to the nation's well-known financial disasters. ``In this case, you won't have the formal government bailout because you would have bailed out on an annual basis,'' Bowsher said referring to the nearly $300 billion defense budget Congress approves each year. He added, ``Any time you push too much money into the system, people are going to spend it. ... It's surprising in the Air Force that the accounting was as bad as New York City, it's really bad.'' Specifically, GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, said the proposed military budget for fiscal 1990 to fiscal 1994 totals $1.5 trillion but the Pentagon's planned spending for individual programs exceeds that amount by $100 billion. ``The department's five-year spending plan needs to reflect fiscal reality and recent world events,'' Bowsher said. The GAO also said the Defense Department has wasted tens of billions of dollars on weapons systems because they were not fully tested before they were purchases. GAO cited the B-1B bomber as an example and warned that the SSN-21 Seawolf attack submarine was following the same path. The GAO also noted that as of Sept. 30, 1989, the inventory of spare parts exceeded $109 billion of which $34 billion has been identified by the Pentagon as more than necessary for current requirements. Among its recommendations, the GAO said that in light of the diminishing Soviet threat, the Defense Department should fully test weapons before buying them. The agency stopped short of calling for slowing down various weapons systems, noting that would increase their cost. But said the department should review certain weapons. ``The Defense Department needs to decide which of the planned programs it can afford,'' Bowsher said. ``Over optimistic planning tends to obscure defense priorities and delay tough decisions and tradeoffs.''

DOC.HEAD: Weather Editors
Systems Editors
DOC.TEXT: On Wednesday, July 25, 1990, the National Weather Service will change ``Raleigh'' to ``Raleigh Durham'' in the temperature tables that have fixture numbers a9500, a9502, a9504, a9505, a9506, and a9507.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Hoax Played on Investigators of Crop Circles
DOC.TEXT: Someone equipped with Ouija boards, wooden crosses and a sense of humor played a practical joke on a team of investigators trying to determine the cause of mysterious circles that appear suddenly in farm fields. The team of engineers and photographers thought they had cracked the mystery when sophisticated cameras and monitoring equipment recorded flashing orange lights Tuesday night in a field they are watching in Wiltshire. When the international team found two large circles with parallel lines running through them on Wednesday morning, they were really intrigued. But upon closer examination they realized they had been had. Ouija boards and wooden crosses were found in the center of the circles, and the Operation Blackbird researchers were not amused. ``Somebody had a joke, but it has actually set our research back,'' said Colin Andrews, a team member and the author of ``Circular Findings.'' ``We have a serious job to do. It is only funny for 60 seconds,'' he said, adding that the recording of flashing lights were probably thermal images of people running around in circles. The investigators from the United States, Japan, West Germany and Britain had planned to spend three weeks monitoring the field in the Vale of Pewsey in the town of Wiltshire, 75 miles southwest of London. It was not immediately clear if the practical joke would cause them to change their plan. They are trying to determine the source of the mysterious circles, which have appeared suddenly among crops in England and elsewhere in Europe. The perfectly formed circles of flattened corn _ some with decorative patterns, some with concentric rings _ were first recorded in England in 1678. In other countries, the circles have been reported in sand, snow and rice paddies. The circles have been variously attributed to whirlwinds, witches, magnetic forces, animals, spaceships _ and hoaxers. Last year, 300 circles appeared and as many theories as to why. The most recent theory, published in the New Scientist magazine, suggested they were formed by weather conditions and electrical charges in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Pleads No Contest to Two Charges, Others Dismissed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Hazelwood attorney saying Hazelwood would agreed to 12 month suspension, new information on alcohol test. Picks up 6th graf, `Hazelwood entered...'. SUBS 15th graf, `The plea..', to DELETE now redundant first reference to Chalos.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard today dismissed charges of intoxication and misconduct against former Exxon Valdez Capt. Joseph Hazelwood, and the skipper pleaded no contest to two lesser charges. The plea agreement was revealed at the opening of a Coast Guard hearing to determine whether Hazelwood can keep his captain's license. The hearing continued before an administrative judge, who will decide any sanctions. Administrative Law Judge Harry Gardner could dismiss the charges, revoke Hazelwood's license or place him on probation, but no fine or prison term can be levied. Hazelwood's attorney, Michael Chalos, told the judge that Hazelwood agreed to accept a 12-month suspension of his license but wants to be given credit for three months because the Coast Guard has held his license for a year. ``This man has suffered enough,'' Chalos told the judge. ``He's a ship's captain. He wants to back to the sea, and he wants to go back as soon as possible.'' The Coast Guard dismissed a charge that Hazelwood was drunk by Coast Guard standards while he commanded the 987-foot tanker. The tanker hit a charted reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound, causing the nation's worst oil spill. It also dismissed a charge that Hazelwood was negligent in leaving a third mate who was not properly licensed in charge of the Exxon Valdez as it passed through the Valdez Narrows into Prince William Sound. The Coast Guard's action in dismissing the most serious charge related to alcohol was spurred by a recent defense discovery that Hazelwood's blood sample was mishandled and the test results may have been wrong. ``We now know that the alcohol test was invalid at best and bogus at worst,'' Chalos said at the hearing. ``This man should never have been put through this ordeal.'' Hazelwood entered no contest pleas to charges that he was negligent in leaving the bridge of the tanker and that he consumed alcohol within four hours of sailing. The Coast Guard changed the language of one charge, removing the allegation that Hazelwood's behavior contributed to the tanker's grounding. Hazelwood stood and faced the judge as he answered the remaining charges against him in a firm voice, saying, ``No contest.'' The alcohol charge that was dropped contended that Hazelwood had a blood alcohol level exceeding .04, the Coast Guard standard for intoxication, far lower than the Alaska state standard of .10. Hazelwood was acquitted by a Superior Court jury in Alaska of being drunk and reckless after extensive testimony about blood alcohol tests administered to him 10{ hours after the disaster. There was controversy over the accuracy of the tests because of the long delay. The tests showed Hazelwood had a blood alcohol reading of .06, according to testimony. Hazelwood came to the Coast Guard headquarters with two lawyers and four witnesses who had testified for him in his trial four months ago in Alaska. The witnesses were expected to testify during the hearing. Two of them are captains of ships who are expected to say that Hazelwood's departure from the bridge during an icy crossing was nothing unusual. Another witness, the tanker's radio engineer, was expected to recount the afternoon he spent with Hazelwood in the port city of Valdez, where Hazelwood was alleged to have drunk two or three vodkas before boarding his ship. The defense contends that the charge Hazelwood drank four hours before boarding is mitigated by the fact that the ship's sailing time had been moved up one hour earlier than scheduled. The plea agreement was apparently the result of months of negotiations between the Coast Guard and Hazelwood's lawyers, Chalos and Thomas Russo. The lawyers said earlier they hoped Hazelwood would be vindicated at the hearing and be able to resume his career as a captain. His master's license was issued in 1966 and has been in the possession of the Coast Guard since the Exxon Valdez accident. The Exxon Valdez was en route from the Alaskan port of Valdez to Long Beach on March 24, 1989, when it struck the reef. Gashed by jagged rocks, the tanker spilled 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into Prince William Sound. Hazelwood was acquitted at his trial in Alaska of being drunk and reckless, but was convicted of one misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. He was ordered to pay $50,000 restitution and spend 1,000 hours cleaning beaches at Prince William Sound. He is appealing. The 11th Coast Guard District, which includes Alaska, is headquartered in Long Beach.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Agrees Bomb Labs Should Be Kept Open
DOC.TEXT: Senators with jurisdiction over the Energy Department's national laboratories said Wednesday the government should keep the facilities open despite a decline in their bomb-making mission. Failing to support the laboratories as they make the transition to more civilian uses would be ``the biggest mistake in economic history,'' said Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., at a Senate subcommittee hearing on the future of the national laboratories. New Mexico is the home of the Los Alamos National Laboratory and the Sandia National Laboratories, two of three nuclear weapons research centers in the complex of nine department laboratories. The other center is the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. The department spends $5 billion a year on developing and testing nuclear weapons stockpiles. Witnesses, including Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, told the energy research and development subcommittee the laboratories can benefit private industry, math and science education and waste management. Energy Department laboratories employ more than 16,000 researchers with advanced degrees in science and technology, including more than 8,500 with doctorates. Fifteen Nobel prizes have been awarded for work performed at the laboratories, he said. More than 50 prizes have been awarded for work related to that performed at the national laboratories, he said. ``No single laboratory or group of laboratories anywhere in the country can compare with this resource or match its record of accomplishment,'' Watkins said. ``This country cannot afford to fritter away such a precious national asset.'' In the last week, he said, the department has signed two agreements with industry consortiums _ specialty metals and advanced manufacturing _ to provide them with technology developed in Energy Department defense programs. Watkins had no trouble converting the panelists, including Sens. Wendell H. Ford, D-Ky., chairman of the subcommittee, and J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., chairman of the full Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. ``It is essential that we continue to use these laboratories to their fullest potential,'' said Johnston.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Heir Allowed to Spend Own Money on Campaign
DOC.TEXT: A du Pont heir fighting a court declaration that he is incompetent to handle his financial affairs is being allowed to spend part of his $10 million inheritance on his campaign for Congress. Chester County Common Pleas Court Judge Lawrence E. Wood on Tuesday approved the transfer of $15,000 to the campaign fund of Lewis du Pont Smith, a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Smith's attorneys had sought the transfer from Wilmington (Del.) Trust Co. to enable Smith to buy radio and newspaper advertisements. Smith must gather 3,000 signatures on nominating petitions by July 31 to run as an independent candidate for the seat held by Rep. Richard Schulze, R-Pa. Wilmington Trust has monitored Smith's finances since 1985, when Wood declared him incompetent. Smith's family had sought the declaration after Smith gave $212,000 to LaRouche. Earlier this year, Smith ran ads touting his association with LaRouche, whom he called ``the world's leading physical economist.'' LaRouche is serving a 15-year federal sentence on conspiracy and mail- and tax-fraud convictions stemming from political fund-raising. The judge is still considering Smith's request to reverse the incompetency order.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth U.S. Nuclear Test of Year Conducted at Nevada Test Site
DOC.TEXT: The fourth announced U.S. nuclear weapons test of the year was detonated Wednesday deep beneath the surface of the Nevada Test Site. The Energy Department said the test, which was not announced in advance, was uneventful and was an apparent success. ``We had no problems with it,'' DOE spokesman Jim Boyer said. The weapon was listed as having a yield of less than 20 kilotons, and Boyer said it was in the smaller range of the underground detonations at the nation's nuclear proving grounds. The warhead was detonated at 8 a.m., 1,300 feet beneath the surface of Ranier Mesa. The site was about 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas. The test was the 703rd conducted at the site since weapons testing began there in 1951, and was the 498th test since the Limited Test Ban Treaty was signed in 1963. Last year, 12 warheads were detonated there.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Investigation Of Lawmakers Shakes Up Torpid Columbia Summer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `All three ..., and 10th graf, `And the ..., to CORRECT that highway investigation became public earlier; pick up 11th graf, `This is ...
DOC.TEXT: South Carolina's Statehouse, which still bears the scars of Sherman's cannons, is being shaken anew by a three-ring scandal that involves allegations of vote buying, drunken driving and construction payoffs. ``This has rocked the entire Statehouse,'' state Rep. David Beasley said of the scandals. He said he worried that the investigations would have ``long-term damaging effects'' on politics in the state. Gov. Carroll Campbell, a Republican heavily favored for re-election this year, also has said he worries about his state's image. ``We can't have South Carolina across the nation looking like the way we're being painted,'' the governor said. The allegations have called into question the state's relatively lax laws regulating lobbying and campaign contributions. ``The current laws are so permissive that people in South Carolina feel you can do anything,'' said John Crangle, head of the state's chapter of Common Cause, the government watchdog group. Two of the three investigations became public in the past week. First, federal officials confirmed they were looking into allegations of illegal conduct by state lawmakers. Lawmakers say a lobbyist, working as an undercover agent, offered legislators cash in exchange for votes. Then Tuesday, sources said the U.S. Justice Department was looking into allegations that the state's top FBI officer asked the chief highway patrolman to help him avoid a drunken-driving charge. The FBI already was investigating the Highway Department on allegations that top officials took money from a leading contractor. ``This is not good timing,'' Beasley said. The cash-for-votes investigation troubles lawmakers the most. At the heart of it is Ron L. Cobb, a flashy, cigar-smoking former legislator who is a well-known lobbyist. Cobb, some lawmakers said, offered them cash this spring when lobbying them about a bill that would have allowed pari-mutuel betting. A source has told The Associated Press that FBI agents videotaped the exchanges. Many lawmakers and lobbyists believe the investigation is a sting operation. Cobb's purported client, a Georgia-based organization called The Alpha Group, does not exist, according to Georgia or South Carolina records. However, neither U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel nor Fred Verinder, the FBI's top agent in South Carolina, will elaborate about the investigation. Cobb has not returned telephone calls to his office. No one has been charged with a crime. Critics blame the investigation on South Carolina's lax rules on lobbyists and campaign contributions. For example, South Carolina has no limit on corporate or individual campaign contributions, no limits on cash donations, little regulation on gifts from lobbyists and no pre-election campaign finance reports. Twenty-seven states limit individual campaign contributions, 35 states either ban or limit corporate contributions, 26 limit cash contributions and 15 ban or limit gifts from lobbyists. And South Carolina is among only three states that allow candidates to wait until after a general election to file their campaign finance reports. Furthermore, the finance reports are sent to committees in the state House and Senate, which Crangle said is ``like having the fox watch over the henhouse.'' Attempts at reform have died in recent years, including this year, when the General Assembly failed to complete work on a bill that would have required lobbyists to verify more details about their spending. State Sen. Sherry Martschink said news of the investigation actually pleases her. ``It should signal the end of the grim days, the end of shabby ethics legislation,'' she said. ``The revelations bring out into the open practices that should never have happened. Perhaps this is indeed the beginning of the end of the sad days.'' But it is not, apparently, the end of the scandals. Verinder, who is investigating the legislators, is himself at the center of allegations involving a drunken-driving cover-up. Government sources said on condition of anonymity that the Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility would look into allegations that Verinder was drunk when a trooper spotted his car weaving outside the city in late March. After Verinder was stopped, the sources said, he persuaded the trooper to let him call Col. J.H. ``Red'' Lanier, the state's chief highway patrolman. Lanier, who denies any wrongdoing, took Verinder home. Verinder, whose office said he would not comment, was cited only with a speeding ticket. ``He was drinking ... but he wasn't drunk,'' Lanier insisted. He also denied that his actions had anything to do with an investigation of the Highway Department by the FBI and two other agencies. The highway patrol is part of the Highway Department. ``That's ridiculous,'' Lanier said. He added that Verinder ``can't control an investigation that the state Law Enforcement Division, the IRS and the FBI, that three agencies are doing.'' The investigation is said to involve allegations that highway department employees took payoffs from contractors.

DOC.HEAD: Victoria Corderi New CBS Co-Anchor
DOC.TEXT: Victoria Corderi was named Wednesday as the permanent co-anchor with Charles Osgood of the ``CBS Morning News'' and the news segments of ``CBS This Morning.'' Corderi, who in January was transferred to New York from CBS' Miami bureau, joined CBS News in 1985. She succeeds Faith Daniels, who left CBS in March to join NBC as anchor of ``NBC News at Sunrise'' and the news segments of the revamped ``Today'' show.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Won't Challenge Sanction
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 9 grafs new with Durenberger, Heflin speeches. Picks up 4th graf pvs, ``There have been.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger today promised his colleagues to be ``a better man and, then, a better senator'' as they neared a vote on a resolution denouncing him for financial misconduct and ordering him to pay up to $123,000 in restitution. Ethics Committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala., said Durenberger ``knowingly and willfully'' violated ``the established norms of Senate behavior.'' ``The evidence of knowing and willful misconduct is clear and convincing, and far more troubling than Senator Durenberger's admitted negligence, lack of wisdom, or asserted misplaced reliance on others,'' Heflin told the Senate. Every senator was expected to vote for the sanction except for Durenberger and possibly his fellow Minnesota Republican, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, said Lois West, Durenberger's press secretary. Durenberger will vote ``present'' so as not to take a position, West said. Boschwitz may vote the same way, said his press secretary, Tim Droogsma. In prepared remarks scheduled for delivery on the floor after the vote, Durenberger called the Senate action ``an ending and a beginning.'' ``I ask your forgiveness,'' he said. ``For future challenges, I need your friendship.'' Durenberger called the experience a ``costly education'' and assured senators, ``I have reordered my personal and professional priorities to be, first, a better man and, then, a better senator.'' ``As for the future, I would ask only that I be judged ... not necessarily by what I say, but what I do. Financial restitution is only a beginning.'' ``There have been senators who said they would support him in whatever he wanted them to do,'' West said. ``Durenberger, if asked, has been saying that he would just as soon they accept it as he has done.'' Durenberger would be the seventh senator to be censured, condemned or denounced in the 20th Century, the Senate's most severe punishment for a member short of expulsion, according to Senate historians. The Senate action could take as little as an hour and a half, in contrast to what is expected to be a bitter floor fight in the House over disciplining Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass. The House ethics committee unanimously proposed reprimanding Frank for help he gave to a male prostitute, but some Republicans have called for censure, which would strip the congressman of a subcommittee chairmanship, or expulsion. The Frank matter is scheduled to go to the House floor on Thursday, but Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., could pre-empt that by introducing an expulsion resolution earlier. Spokesman Paul Mero said the conservative lawmaker was considering doing that. The Senate Ethics Committee last week unanimously recommended the full Senate denounce Durenberger for ``unequivocally unethical'' conduct in connection with a book-promotion scheme and Senate payments on his Minneapolis condominium. The committee's chairman, Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., and vice chairman, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., were expected to take a half-hour each to present the case against Durenberger this afternoon, said Heflin spokesman Tom McMahon. Afterward, two senators were to make statements in Durenberger's behalf and Durenberger was to make a short statement after the vote, West said. She characterized Durenberger's speech as ``an acceptance of the judgment, an apology.'' Durenberger wrote his two-page single-spaced speech Tuesday evening and had breakfast with a personal friend this morning before heading to a full schedule of meetings, West said. ``He's really holding steady almost as if he's doing it for everybody (staff members) around here. He's got a real positive attitude in that's he's looking forward to having this be over with,'' she said. She declined to name the senators who planned to speak in support of Durenberger. They would not be ``arguing against the sanction but in support of him as a senator and as a person,'' she said. Durenberger had appealed to the committee for a lighter penalty, saying denouncement was ``much too onerous.'' Boschwitz believes Durenberger has already been punished by the length of the 22-month-long ethics investigation and the $500,000 in legal fees he has incurred, said spokesman Droogsma. The resolution before the Senate said Durenberger ``brought the Senate into dishonor and disrepute'' and lists six violations of Senate rules: _A book contract that Durenberger used to collect $100,000 in speaking fees in 1985 and 1987 over the Senate's limits on speaking fees. _Real estate transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium that he used to obtain reimbursement for staying there during trips to Minnesota. _Failure to report the receipt of travel expenses in connection with the book-promotion appearances and trips to the Boston area to visit a marriage counselor. _Discussions about the condominium with the trustee of the blind trust in which the property was held. _Acceptance of free limousine service during the Boston trips in violation of Senate gift limits. _Conversion of a $5,000 campaign contribution to personal use. The ethics panel said Durenberger should reimburse the Senate $29,050 plus interest in condominium payments and give $95,000 to charity for exceeding speaking limits. The latter sum would be reduced by whatever taxes he has paid on the income.

DOC.HEAD: Early-Released Prisoner Convicted of Officers' Murders
DOC.TEXT: A man who was released from prison under the state's early release program was convicted Wednesday of first degree murder in the deaths of two police officers in November 1988. Charles Street, 36, showed no emotion as the verdicts _ including several convictions for armed robbery and possession of a firearm _ were read. Also in the courtroom were the families of slain Metro-Dade officers Richard Boles, of North Lauderdale, and David Strzalkowski, of Hollywood. After six weeks of testimony, the Dade County jury deliberated just a day, rejecting the defense's argument that Streetwas incapable of planning the murders because he was high on cocaine at the time of the shootings. The officers were slain with their own guns. Street of Boynton Beach had confessed to the shootings. He faces either life in prison without possibility of parole for 25 years or death in the electric chair. Circuit Judge Alfonso Sepe did not immediately set a date for sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Souter's Blank Slate on Major Issues Stymies Interest Groups
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter's Supreme Court nomination has escaped harsh criticism so far _ even from groups inclined to oppose any Bush nominee _ suggesting his lack of a record on divisive issues has insulated him from attack. As the nominee toured Capitol Hill to meet with senators Wednesday, liberal groups said they hope the Senate Judiciary Committee will closely question him during confirmation hearings in September. But almost no one had bad words for him now. On the right, the only thing conservatives could find to worry about was the possibility that Souter would prove to be other than one of their own. Richard A. Viguerie, chairman of the United Conservatives of America, said, ``Most conservatives today have nervous smiles. We think we can be happy, but we're a little apprehensive.'' Liberals, though hardly celebrating, were reluctant to attack the nomination. Ruth Pratt of the National Abortion Rights Action League in Souter's home state of New Hampshire said, ``The Senate needs to find out his position on issues of privacy and choice. We are somewhat encouraged by what we hear about his reluctance to overturn precedent.'' Marcus Hurn, spokesman for the New Hampshire Citizens Alliance for Gay and Lesbian Rights, said he would testify in favor of Souter if national gay rights groups oppose the nominee. ``I don't think the White House is getting a very political judge,'' Hurn said. ``I think he is a highly judicial person ...(with) a high regard for precedents.'' Sounding a warning _ though still not criticism _ Faye Wattleton of Planned Parenthood said if Souter refuses to answer questions on abortion when he testifies before the Senate Judiciary Committee, probably in September, ``I don't think he deserves to sit on the court.'' Rebecca Hagelin of the conservative Concerned Women for America, said ``We're going to see an effort by extremist feminist organizations to bring about an abortion inquisition.'' But she suggested that any group opposing his confirmation because he has not endorsed the high court's 1973 ruling legalizing abortion runs the risk of being branded extremist. Both liberal and conservative groups have acknowledged the president caught them off guard by picking a successor to William J. Brennan within three days of the Supreme Court justice's retirement announcement. By moving quickly and choosing someone apparently non-controversial, Bush has accomplished the dual purpose of short-circuiting a possible drive by opposing groups to influence the selection and enhancing confirmation prospects. The White House made no secret of its intentions. ``We saw that some of the special interests _ on abortion, civil rights _ were going to try to cook up a stew that this nomination would get dumped into,'' said presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Conservative activist Pat McGuigan said, ``Nobody knows anything about him. In terms of Senate confirmation, this is very helpful.'' But McGuigan said there could be political trouble down the road for Bush if Souter proves to be something other than a reliably conservative vote as a justice.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Apply for Plan to Live in Britain
LaserPhotos HK1,2
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents, worried about their future after China's takeover in 1997, flooded the Immigration Department Wednesday, the last day to apply for a special plan to emigrate to Britain. More than 18,000 heads of households submitted applications for the nationality package by 12:30 a.m. Thursday when police clanged shut a portable gate 30 minutes after the scheduled deadline. At least 45,000 people, including children and other dependents, waited in line throughout the day and no one appeared to have been turned away, immigration officials said. The British nationality package will grant full British citizenship to 50,000 families, or about 225,000 Hong Kong residents. Hong Kong is scheduled to return to Chinese control in 1997, ending 99 years of British colonial rule. More than 1,000 people a week are emigrating from Hong Kong, mainly to Australia and Canada. Emigration this year is expected to increase at least 30 percent over last year when more than 42,000 people left. According to Hong Kong immigration officials, about 3.5 million of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people are eligible for the British plan. But less than 10 percent will win the right of abode. Britain offered the plan in an attempt to stop Hong Kong's most skilled people from fleeing the territory as the date for the Chinese takeover draws near. China opposes the British emigration plan and has threatened not to acknowledge the British passports of Hong Kong residents. On Wednesday, people were packed 12 deep in some places outside the Immigration Department. The line snaked for almost a mile over walkways and along avenues from morning until late in the night. About 50 people spent Tuesday night sleeping on an overpass and dozens of people fainted in the humidity and heat. A woman wearing a sleeveless green T-shirt was the last applicant. ``I just want to be apply quietly,'' she pleaded in broken English as news photographers surrounded her. ``Apply quietly for Britain.'' As the clocked ticked toward midnight, women ran, clutching their babies, fathers sprinted with strollers and young toughs cut in line with an elbow in the face. ``If I don't get out of Hong Kong by 1997 I'm finished, I know it,'' said Li Qiang, a 42-year-old laborer who fled Communist China to Hong Kong during China's Cultural Revolution in the 1960s. ``I hate the Communists and I'm afraid they want to get me.'' Li was waiting with his wife and 11-year-old daughter who was dressed in ribbons and bows. ``I want to impress the officers,'' he said. ``Do you think it will work?'' During the day, thousands unfurled umbrellas to counter the withering sun. Businessmen whispered into portable phones, cutting deals as they awaited their turn. Most of those eligible don't have to formally apply, like people were doing Wednesday, because they already can prove they are British subjects, either by possessing a British-Hong Kong passport or a Hong Kong birth certificate. Immigration officials said thousands of people needlessly lined up. The confusion was a further indication of the growing fear Hong Kong residents have of the impending Chinese control. Charles Lai, a 45-year-old tax consultant, said he heard on the news that it was the last day to apply so ``we got the whole building to apply.' ``We figured first apply and then worry about our chances. It's like gambling,'' said Lai, who led a group of about 270 residents from an apartment house in Kowloon. Hong Kong residents also questioned Britain's support for the colony. Over the past few months, the Hong Kong government appears to have bowed to Chinese pressure to limit political discourse. It has prosecuted political activists, censored a film on China's democracy movement and started random identification checks during pro-democracy rallies. At the Immigration Department, many people said they had little hope of leaving the territory. ``I'm doing this for my son,'' said John Lam, a 41-year-old office manager at a trading house. Next to him a baby slept peacefully in a pink stroller.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon to Sell Naval Warfare Systems to Japan
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department said Wednesday it will sell Japan the Aegis state-of-the-art naval defense system and other weaponry for $825 million. The department said it had notified Congress that the Aegis combat system would be installed on a Japanese Self-Defense Force ship. The computer-and radar-driven system detects and defeats anti-ship missiles launched from the air or sea. Japan also is buying two E-2C early warning and command and control aircraft, plus 75 Harpoon anti-ship cruise missiles, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Aide Charged for Throwing Plate at Lawyer
DOC.TEXT: A longtime aide to Gov. Mario Cuomo was charged Wednesday with assault for allegedly throwing a plate at a lawyer during a weekend dinner party, police said. John Iaccio was charged with third-degree assault on a complaint filed by Jonathan Wehle, said Officer Jerry Yerbury of the police department of Guilderland, the suburb where the party took place at the home of another Cuomo aide. Wehle, a special counsel in the enforcement division of the New York Stock Exchange, was treated for a gash near his eye after the Saturday night episode. Iaccio did not report for work and no one at his home answered the phone. His lawyer, Stephen Coffey, refused to comment about the case. Wehle also did not answer telephone calls Wednesday. He told the Albany Times Union that Iaccio flipped the plate across a table at him. ``This guy did it in front of about 12, 13 people, and it was totally unprovoked,'' Wehle said. ``The words he said to me immediately afterwards and the words that I heard he said to the group when he left make me ... extremely angry.'' Neither police nor Wehle said what Iaccio was angry about. ``It was a misunderstanding, I believe, that set it off,'' Yerbury said. Iaccio surrendered Wednesday after being contacted by police, said Yerbury. He was released without bail. An arraignment was set for Aug. 9. Cuomo said Iaccio, a special assistant who frequently travels with the governor, had requested and was granted some time off. ``I don't know anything about the event. I know it was a dinner party,'' said Cuomo.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in Iraq-Kuwait Confrontation
With AM-Iran-Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are Wednesday's developments in the confrontation between Iraq and Kuwait over oil production and oil rich border land.

IRAQ UNINTIMIDATED: The Iraqi government in Baghdad said that it will not be intimidated by U.S. pressure in its oil dispute with neighboring Kuwait, and President Saddam Hussein summoned the U.S. ambassador for talks.

SEEKS KUWAITI CONCESSIONS: Kuwait diplomatic sources said Iraq's president gave assurances he would not use military force if Kuwait agreed to pay compensation for $2.4 billion worth of oil Iraq claims it has stolen since 1980 from a disputed border region and agrees to meet other conditions.
WEEKEND TALKS: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said that Iraq and Kuwait have agreed to hold direct talks on Saturday or Sunday in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to try to solve their dispute peacefuly.

KUWAIT STATEMENT: Kuwaiti Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah said: ``Kuwait was and remains, with strong sincerity and enthusiasm, willing to meet with our brethren in Iraq to reach an understanding in a brotherly atmosphere on an acceptable formula in the interest of both parties.''

U.S. EXERCISE: In a show of support for Kuwait, the Pentagon announced Tuesday that U.S. warships and aircraft would hold a ``short-notice exercise'' 600 miles to the south in the Persian Gulf with a second small state, the United Arab Emirates.

President Saddam Hussein of Iraq reportedly moved troops to the Kuwaiti border after accusing Kuwait and the U.A.E. of exceeding their OPEC production quotas and driving down oil prices. He threatened to use military force if they did not adhere to OPEC guidelines. Iraq denied that it was concentrating its forces on the border.

DOC.HEAD: Aerospace Executive To Head Independent NASA Committee
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration named a veteran aerospace executive Wednesday to head an independent committee that will review NASA's plans for the future of the nation's space program. The committee, under chairman Norman R. Augustine, will report its findings in four months. Its mandate is to look into all phases of the space program and make recommendations for alternate approaches when appropriate. Augustine has been chairman and chief executive officer of the Martin Marietta Corp., which builds the Titan series of rockets among its many space-related activities. Augustine was the only appointee named in an announcement by Vice President Dan Quayle, who is head of the National Space Council. The announcement said Augustine was recommended by Richard H. Truly, the administrator of National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The committee was formed because of a behind-the-scenes struggle between NASA and the National Space Council over control of the space program. Quayle and the council have sought to persuade NASA to seek alternate approaches to a number of major projects, including President Bush's plan to establish a manned base on the moon and send an expedition to Mars. ``Nothing is off the table, this is a top-to-bottom review of the space program,'' said a source from the vice president's side, who asked not to be identified. The announcement, however, sought to make clear that Truly was not relinquishing his responsibility to run the space agency. Reports in Washington were that Truly had threatened to resign if another authority was imposed on him. Truly is a former astronaut who was brought back from the Navy to run the manned space program after the fatal Challenger accident in January 1986. ``The committee will operate as an independent entity, reporting to the administrator of NASA, and will submit its findings to the administrator of NASA and, with the administrator, to the vice president,'' it said. The committee is to review the future of the civil space program, including both management issues and program content. Its members, according to the announcement, will review appropriateness of planned activities, organizational balance and structure, adequacy of skills, balance between roles of government and the private sector, possible contributions by other government agencies, the need to maintain a strong research and development capability, and assurance that missions can be carried out successfully. The committee members will be ``individuals selected for their knowledge of space activities and management expertise,'' the announcement said. Augustine's career includes both private and government posts, including under secretary of the Army. He received the distinguished service medal, the highest civilian decoration of the Defense Department, four times.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Kuwait Chronology
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Iraq and Kuwait have never agreed on the demarcation of their border since Kuwait gained its independence from Britain in 1961. Shortly after Kuwait gained its independendence, Iraq claimed sovereignty and the Kuwaitis asked Britain for assistance. Britain sent in paratroopers and they were replaced by an Arab force led by Egypt, which acted as a buffer between the two countries until tensions eased in 1963. Iraq reportedly has sent thousands of troops to its 100-mile-long southern border with Kuwait, although Iraq has denied building up troops along the border. Here is a brief chronology at the events of this dispute: July 17 _ Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accuses Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flooding the oil market and driving prices down, and that the move cost Iraq $14 billion in lost oil revenue. He further charges that Arab states in the Persian Gulf of conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq's economy and undermine its military buildup. July 18 _ Iraq acccuses Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells along the disputed border with Iraq and of seeking to wreck the country's economy by overproducing oil and thus pushing down prices. July 19 _ Kuwait cancels a state of alert it declared in an oil dispute with Iraq. July 20 _ Kuwaiti officials and diplomats suggest Iraq's sudden outburst of belligerence is aimed at getting its creditors _ including Kuwait _ to write off billions of dollars in debts from the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war. July 24 _ The U.S. Defense Department announces that U.S. Navy warships and aircraft were holding a ``short-notice exercise'' in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates, about 600 miles south of the Kuwait-Iraq dispute. July 24 _ Kuwait reinstates a state of alert it declared July 16 and canceled after three days of tension between the two oil-producing countries. July 25 _ The Iraqi government in Baghdad said that it will not be intimidated by U.S. pressure in its oil dispute with neighboring Kuwait, and Saddam summoned the U.S. ambassador for talks. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt says Iraq and Kuwait plan to meet in Saudi Arabia this weekend in an effort to resolve their dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Seated in Contra Mercenary Suit Against Secord, Southern Air
DOC.TEXT: A jury was selected Wednesday to decide a lawsuit that blames retired Air Force Major General Richard Secord and a CIA-linked airline for the 1986 plane crash in Nicaragua that helped unravel the Iran-Contra affair. Cargo handler Eugene Hasenfus and the family of the plane's co-pilot, Wallace Sawyer Jr., claim in the lawsuit that Secord and Miami-based Southern Air Transport used unsafe aircraft in the Nicaraguan Contra supply effort. The October 1986 downing of the C-123 by a Sandinista rocket helped trigger the Iran-Contra investigation. After the crash, the Reagan administration acknowledged that money was diverted from Iran arms sales to the Contras, despite a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebels. A six-member jury and two alternates were seated after questioning by senior U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins. Only a few of the 35 prospective jurors said they remembered reading or hearing about the crash. None showed any recognition when former White House aide Oliver North was mentioned as a possible witness. Secord sat at the defense table with Southern Air President William Langton and a team of lawyers. Hasenfus, of Marinette, Wis., sat across the room with his wife, Sally; Sawyer's widow, Kasanee Sawyer, of Magnolia, Ark.; and their attorneys. Secord pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to lying to the congressional committee investigating the Iran-Contra affair and has been placed on two years' probation. When the lawsuit was filed in 1988, attorneys had estimated damages at $135 million. However, on Wednesday the plaintiffs submitted new figures seeking actual damages of about $2 million for Sawyer's family and about $1 million for Hasenfus. Hasenfus, a cargo handler, or ``kicker,'' aboard a plane secretly supplying the Nicaraguan rebels, was captured and held for about three months after Nicaraguan troops shot down the plane. The lawsuit says Hasenfus was recruited in 1986 through the Pennsylvania airline Corporate Air Services and William Cooper, a pilot for Southern Air, which was once owned by the CIA and continues to do contract work for the U.S. government. Cooper, who also died in the crash, led Hasenfus to believe he was working on behalf of the U.S. government on a project being directed ``right out of the back door of the White House,'' the lawsuit said. Southern Air has denied any association with the Hasenfus flight. Secord's attorneys describe Hasenfus as a mercenary, paid about $3,000 a month, who knew the risks.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Attend New York Summit On Children
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will attend a 35-country United Nations ``world summit for children'' in New York on Sept. 30, the White House announced Wednesday. The following day, he will deliver his annual address to the U.N. General Assembly, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. Prime Ministers Brian Mulroney of Canada and Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan will chair the summit meeting. World leaders at the two-day event are expected to discuss ``making progress in the struggle to save young people vulnerable to hunger and disease,'' Fitzwater said. The event could turn into a major gathering of world leaders. Fitzwater said the White House has not ``received any word'' on whether Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will attend.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Offers $5 Million for Philippines Earthquake Relief
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos would donate about $5 million for earthquake relief in the Philippines if the Manila government and U.S. officials release funds frozen by the courts, her lawyer said Wednesday. James Linn, an Oklahoma City attorney representing the former Philippine first lady, said the offer was made several days ago and ``we're waiting for an answer from Manila.'' Tambi Wycoco, a spokesman for the Philippines Consulate here, said he'd heard ``rumors'' of the offer ``but we've seen nothing on it.'' ``Of course if she offered ... it would be accepted,'' he said. ``There are some in the community who say it would be her way of returning the money. Later she can say she gave back $5 million.'' Linn said Mrs. Marcos spoke by telephone with Vice President Salvador Laurel in Manila about the proposed donation. Laurel has split politically with President Corazon Aquino, with whom he rose to power in the February 1986 popular revolt that ousted Mrs. Marcos' husband, the late President Ferdinand Marcos. The proposed donation, of 100 million Philippine pesos, would require the approval of Mrs. Aquino's government and a U.S. court, which froze the Marcoses' assets after they were driven into Hawaiian exile. Philippines officials said on Wednesday that the toll now stands at more than 1,600 killed, 3,000 injured and 90,000 left homeless by the quake that struck the northern main island of Luzon a week ago. The disaster has created another financial crisis for the Aquino government, already burdened by a $26 billion foreign debt. Linn said Mrs. Marcos' offer was ``just a humanitarian gesture, with no strings attached.'' Some of the Marcos assets frozen by the 1986 court order are in Swiss banks and some in Hong Kong, said Linn. He would not estimate how much money was involved. He said the request for a court order releasing the funds would be put to U.S. officials later this week. Mrs. Marcos was acquitted here earlier this month of federal fraud, racketeering and obstruction charges in the alleged theft of more than $220 million from the Philippines treasury during Marcos' 20-year rule. Still pending are a series of civil lawsuits filed by the Aquino government, which is still trying to recover the money. In addition, the 61-year-old Mrs. Marcos has been subpoenaed to testify before a federal grand jury in Pittsburgh investigating dealings between the Westinghouse Electric Corp. and Marcos concerning a nuclear power plant the company built in the Philippines in the early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Aide Will Head Ag Department Public Affairs
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has named an aide, Kelly Shipp, as head of public affairs in the Agriculture Department. Shipp, 30, has been his press secretary since Yeutter joined USDA in early 1989. Before that, she was Yeutter's spokeswoman when he was U.S. trade representative in the Reagan administration. ``Kelly is extraordinarily capable,'' Yeutter said Wednesday in a statement. ``Her knowledge of (USDA), media relations and international trade issues will be a tremendous asset to our public affairs division.'' Yeutter said Shipp will continue to be his chief spokeswoman in her new job and will report directly to him. Shipp grew up on an Alexis, Ill., farm, which her parents still operate. She also worked at USDA and on Capitol Hill before joining Yeutter. The new assignment pays Shipp $71,200 a year, her office said. She succeeds Paul Kindinger, whose resignation was announced on Monday. He will teach agriculture at the Pentagon's war college here.

DOC.HEAD: Report Sets Timetable for Developing High-Speed Magnetic Train
DOC.TEXT: Federal agencies studying the feasibility of high-speed trains propelled by magnets should know by 1993 whether the United States can regain the lead in this transportation technology, said a report released Wednesday. The report _ a ``Preliminary Implementation Plan'' developed by the Army Corps of Engineers _ sets a timetable under which various federal agencies would evaluate and then oversee the development of magnetic levitation trains in the United States. ``We believe there is a golden opportunity for magnetic levitation in this country,'' said Dan Mauldin, deputy director of civil works for the Corps of Engineers. Magnetic levitation trains are propelled by magnets on a cushion of air over a rail. Such trains could travel up to 300 miles per hour, use less energy than conventional means of transportation and would be cheaper to ride than airplanes, according to the report. So far, only the Japanese and the Germans have developed prototype trains. Several projects are under discussion in the United States. In fiscal 1993, the federal agencies studying magnetic levitation _ which include the Transportation Department, the Federal Railroad Administration and the corps _ will choose from among three options, according to the report. The agencies may ask one or more industry teams to design an advanced magnetic levitation system. The ``winning'' team would then have the opportunity to build and operate a full-scale prototype. The agencies may encourage U.S. industry to team with state and local interests to build several different magnetic levitation systems at different sites. The market would then determine which system is superior based on operation, maintenance and costs. The agencies may encourage private-sector firms to adapt foreign magnetic levitation systems for U.S. transportation needs. The last option would require the smallest outlay of federal money, the report noted. Magnetic levitation was invented and pioneered in the 1960s and 1970s by Americans, including James Powell and Gordon Danby at Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York. But U.S. advances stopped around 1974, when the federal role in magnetic levitation development ended, Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan said at a news conference to release the report.

DOC.HEAD: Declared Dead, Man Startles Medical Team with Reaction to Pain
DOC.TEXT: A shooting victim declared dead for hours suddenly showed signs of life as medical technicians were preparing his body to remove organs for transplants. He died Wednesday, nearly 15 hours later. ``This is the first time I've seen one respond like this, and I've been at this for 30 some years,'' said Black Hawk County Medical Examiner Albert Dolan. He said a medical team that hoped to take organs for transplant from the body of James Albert Geiger of Waterloo stood aside Tuesday as doctors, who initially believed that Geiger had died eight hours before, worked to save his life. Geiger then died early Wednesday morning. Geiger, carrying a six-inch knife and threatening suicide, was shot late Monday, police said, when he lunged from beneath a table at his home in Waterloo toward a police officer. A .357-caliber bullet entered the top of his head and came to rest at the base of his brain, Dolan said. Geiger was declared brain dead early Tuesday. The medical examiner said a blood flow test was administered to determine if blood was reaching Geiger's brain. ``It's 90 percent accurate. When there's no flow, you consider the patient brain dead,'' Dolan said. ``That was what we found early on Tuesday, therefore he was given the diagnosis of brain dead. And you have to remember, there was severe trauma to the brain.'' Doctors got permission from Geiger's family to take the organs for transplants. But about 7{ hours after Geiger was pronounced brain dead, a cardiologist who was there to maintain Geiger's blood pressure was startled by an arm movement that would not happen if the patient were dead. ``We were all shocked. He indicated he had some response to pain, which normally a brain dead person would not,'' Dolan said. Another test showed the brain was marginally active, and Geiger was declared to be alive but very critical, Dolan said. In the next several hours, Geiger's blood pressure dropped, causing damage to his organs that made them unsuitable for transplant, Dolan said. Geiger died of heart failure early Wednesday morning. ``My own answer to this is that God just wasn't ready for him yet, that's the only explanation I can give. Unfortunately, medicine is not an exact science,'' Dolan said. The Waterloo Police Department is conducting an investigation and, at the chief's request, the Black Hawk County Sheriff's Department and Iowaservices committees to press ahead with production of the B-2 bomber and other major new weapons. The House is considering halting production of radar-evading jets, which cost $800 million apiece. The defense session came on the heels of another meeting between Bush and the five top leaders of Congress to push the budget summit talks along. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that at either Thursday's or Friday's meeting, both sides will ``simultaneously'' put proposals on the table for cutting $50 billion from the deficit next year and $500 billion over five years. But Democratic budget bargainers disputed that, saying no decision had been made on exchanging offers. ``That is so silly,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., told reporters the two sides have tentatively agreed to extend from 1993 to 1995 the Gramm-Rudman deadline for balancing the budget. Gephardt said major differences in defense levels is a major hang-up in reaching an overall budget compromise. Bush and the leaders discussed entitlement programs _ Social Security, Medicare and other programs for the poor and elderly _ and ``both sides are troubled'' by the magnitude of cuts that might be needed in those areas, Gephardt said. Despite Bush's earlier agreement that the government must pull in more tax revenues, ``nobody wants to raise taxes. ... It's very hard to put the final package together,'' the Democratic leader said. After the defense session, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., the House Armed Services Committee chairman, lamented that Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney still ``have in mind a much bigger defense budget than I think is going to come out of this process.'' Aspin announced Monday he favors halting production of the B-2 now that the first 15 bombers have been delivered to the Air Force. Bush wants to build the fleet of 75 that Congress agreed to several years ago. Aspin's Senate counterpart, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., who favors continued production, said afterwards, the B-2 ``has an uphill fight if it's going to survive.'' Aspin's committee is aiming to cut $24 billion from Bush's request for $307 billion for the Pentagon for fiscal 1991. Fitzwater said Bush called the meeting to express concern about ``inordinate cuts.'' Despite improved relations, the Soviet Union remains the United States' adversary, said Fitzwater. He quoted Bush as saying, ``There have been few changes in Soviet strategic forces. ... They are continuing to modernize their entire force, and will enter the START negotiations fully modernized.'' Cheney told the lawmakers that the House cuts would force the Pentagon to absorb personnel cuts of 250,000 in the first year, cutting back nearly four army divisions and 25 ships. ``We think that is unreasonable,'' Fitzwater said. Bush said at a Strategic Air Command base in Cheyenne, Wyo., last Friday that he wanted ``to hold the line at the already painful reduction of the defense budget set down by the Senate Armed Services Committee.'' That panel, chaired by Nunn, approved a $289 billion defense bill last week that would cut nearly $1 billion from Bush's $4 billion Strategic Defense Initiative request and remove 100,000 troops from active duty, including 50,000 from Europe. Nunn said after the meeting, ``We can save some very substantial sums over five years and do it prudently,'' trimming $180 billion to $200 billion from defense. ``The first year we can save about 20 percent responsibly. ...'' Nunn said. ``Over five years we can save about 35 percent of that total of $500 billion.'' But if too much is cut the first year, ``you end up wrecking the personnel system (and) demoralizing not only those who will be forced out of the military ... but those who are left,'' Nunn warned. Nunn said it will take strenuous efforts by Bush, Cheney and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft to save the B-2. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House minority whip, told reporters afterwards that Aspin ``has the votes to pass a left wing, destructive defense budget.'' ``That bill will either be fixed in conference or it will be vetoed,'' Gingrich said. ``What they're going to do in their markup is going to be a massacre, not a markup.''

DOC.HEAD: ASEAN Rejects Change in Cambodia's U.N. Seat
DOC.TEXT: A change in Cambodia's representation in the United Nations would hurt the search for peace in Indochina, the Association of Southeast Asian nations said in a statement Wednesday. Last week, the United States withdrew its support for the tripartite guerrilla coalition that holds Cambodia's U.N. General Assembly seat.
