In a communique, ASEAN foreign ministers said any change ``would set back the search for a comprehensive political solution to the Cambodian problem.'' The communique was mild in tone and did not mention the United States by name. Washington also announced last week it would open talks with Vietnam on a settlement in Cambodian and would no longer support the right of the guerrilla coalition to represent Phnom Penh in the world body. Those steps could open the way to a broader rapprochement between the United States and Hanoi, shifting the balance of power in Southeast Asia. Hanoi supports the Cambodian govenment. The abrupt U.S. policy change underlined the failure of years of ASEAN-led diplomacy to negotiate a settlement. ASEAN helped form the Cambodian resistance group in 1982. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the shift was designed to prevent the Khmer Rouge, the strongest of the three guerrilla groups, from gaining power in Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge took power in 1975 and slaughtered hundreds of thousands of civilians before it was ousted by Vietnam in 1978. ASEAN officials plan to meet Baker and foreign policy specialists from Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and the European Community later in the week. The communique also called for the resumption of the inconclusive Cambodian peace talks. It ``noted with regret that the conflicting parties themselves so far have not sufficiently shown the necessary political will for a negotiated settlement.'' The statement said ASEAN hopes that a ``Supreme National Council'' representing the three guerrilla factions and the Cambodian government will administer Cambodia. The guerrilla coalition is comprised of the communist Khmer Rouge, the non-communist forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann's Khmer People's National Liberation Front. ASEAN diplomats also said the U.S. switch could lower the incentive for the Khme271 million in the first three months of this year, a worse showing than in the same period a year ago but a sharp improvement over the previous quarter. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision said the red ink compared with a $3.1 billion loss in the fourth quarter of 1989 and a $10 million profit in the first quarter of 1989. The figures do not include 350 thrifts which were still open at the end of March but were controlled by the Resolution Trust Corp., a new agency charged with closing and selling failed S&Ls. The corporation is expected to release those figures next week. Analysts complained that reporting profit results separately for private and government-controlled thrifts amounts to sugar-coating bad news and interferes with their ability to analyze the entire industry. The thrift office collects information from both sets of S&Ls and in the past had always released both groups of figures. ``It's hogwash,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. The thrift office ``wants to be the good-news boys.'' However, thrift office director Timothy Ryan declared, ``I'm not ... Mr Rosy Scenario. ``Putting the two together presents an inaccurate picture of the industry,'' he said. The agency also is drawing criticism from Congress. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House Banking task force that monitors the S&L bailout, said in a letter to Ryan that there is ``no rational basis'' for separating the statistics. ``The American people are skeptical of the good faith of the regulators and of the savings and loan industry, and frankly this change in reporting ... looks bad,'' Vento wrote. In Wednesday's report, the thrift office did not say how much the losses were reduced by government subsidies to S&Ls bailed out in 1988. Ely estimated the subsidy at between $1 billion and $1.5 billion per quarter. The 1988 deals are coming under increasing criticism from Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, and others in Congress who say they provided acquirers with virtually guaranteed profits for very little investment. The agency said deposits at thrifts privately run at the end of March increased to $798 billion from $789 billion a year earlier. However, the figure includes interest paid on the deposits, which would have been about six times the $9 billion gain. Normally, economists subtract the interest to get an idea of whether S&L customers are withdrawing more than they are depositing. Also, the figures excluded deposits lost at S&Ls that were turned over the the RTC at some point during the year. Ryan, in a press release issued by his agency, had greeted the first quarter results as a sign of progress. He was quoted as saying, ``It appears that deposits and profits are returning to the strong part of the industry.'' However, at a news conference, he told reporters it was too soon to draw conclusions from the data. He said he would not know if the industry is capable of surviving until sometime early next year. ``Should we jump up and down and declare victory?'' he asked. ``No. This is still a very tough situation, in my view.'' The agency divided the S&L industry into four parts: 310 institutions expected to fail, 311 struggling thrifts that may fail, 620 S&Ls that are somewhat weak but are expected to survive and 1,264 institutions in good shape. Only the institutions in the last group earned what investors consider an acceptable return, $692 million. The next best group earned a subpar $192 million. The struggling S&Ls lost $281 million and the expected failures lost $874 million. ``You have an enormous segment of the industry that isn't making it,'' Ely said. Wednesday's report was about a month late. Ryan said the agency had changed its data collection process and hoped to release the reports on time in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Boesak Quits Church Posts, to Maintain Extramarital Relationship
DOC.TEXT: Anti-apartheid leader Allan Boesak, tainted by a scandal over his extramarital affair, said Wednesday he was resigning all his church posts to seek a political career. The mixed-race Protestant minister also said he would continue his relationship with Elna Botha, a married, white producer for government-run television. Boesak, the father of four children, said his wife, Dorothy, had initiated divorce proceedings. He and Ms. Botha issued simultaneous statements through their attorneys, saying their marriages had begun to fail before they met each other and that they intended to maintain their contact. Church officials had pleaded with Boesak to reconsider when he announced July 8 he would resign from his religious posts. He said Wednesday he would not change his mind and had stepped down as a minister of the Dutch Reformed Mission Church and president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, an international council of Protestant churches. ``I have ... decided to offer my services to the people of this country to bring about a united, non-racial and democratic South Africa. I am prepared to play any role which I may be called upon to play in this regard,'' he said in a statement released by his lawyer. Boesak has played a major role in the opposition to apartheid, leading demonstrations and touring the world to denounce South Africa's system of racial segregation. Long thought to be interested in a political career, Boesak models himself after the late Martin Luther King Jr. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who often marched with Boesak at the head of protests against apartheid, said Wednesday ``the sky is the limit'' for Boesak's future political career. ``People recognize his gifts, the sacrifices that he has made for the struggle, and I think thay they will follow him. ``He has fought a very great deal and his family has,'' Tutu said. ``Perhaps part of the cost is what has happened to his marriage.'' The revelations about Boesak and Ms. Botha were seen as a moral scandal in South Africa because both were married and Boesak was an ordained minister. Apartheid laws on inter-racial relationships were dropped in 1985. Boesak came under fire in the mid-1980s following press reports of his involvement with a white female church worker. A church inquiry later cleared him of any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Crash Kills Two, Injures Three
DOC.TEXT: An Army helicopter on which the crew had been using night-vision goggles crashed during a night exercise at Fort Campbell, killing two soldiers and injuring three, officials said Wednesday. The CH-47D Chinook medium-lift helicopter, which can carry loads suspended in slings, was on a training mission when it crashed late Tuesday. The soldiers were training with a load of two concrete blocks slung beneath the copter when it crashed, said Sgt. Steven Sanderson, a post spokesman. He did not know how much the blocks weighed. All that remained of the Chinook on Wednesday was charred wreckage. It was not known if the helicopter caught fire in flight or burned after crashing, said Bill Harralson, a deputy post public relations officer. Night-vision goggles, which enhance available light, were used on the flight, said Harralson. He did not know if they were used by the pilot, the co-pilot or both. The goggles came into controversy in 1988 after 17 soldiers were killed at Fort Campbell when two helicopters collided during a night flight on which the pilots were using the goggles. The goggles have since been updated. Harralson said it was not known if the goggles used on Tuesday's flight were of the early or latter version. The Chinook, the Army's mid-size helicopter, is used as a troop carrier or to slingload items such as artillery and fighting vehicles in battle areas. Safety officials from the Army Safety Center at Fort Rucker, Ala., arrived at the fort Wednesday to begin an investigation. Harralson said there were witnesses to the crash. That, coupled with survivors' testimony, should speed the investigation, he said. The survivors included the pilot and co-pilot, but the pilot was in critical condition at Vanderbilt University hospital in Nashville, officials said. Everyone aboard was from the post's 7th Battalion, 101st Aviation Regiment, said Harralson. The names of those killed were withheld until relatives could be notified, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nuns, Families Grieve Bomb Deaths, IRA Conveys Its Regrets
DOC.TEXT: A small, aging band of nuns grieved as a family Wednesday for a sister killed by chance by an IRA bomb along with three police officers. The Royal Ulster Constabulary in Armagh said it had detained two men for questioning but gave no other information about the investigation. Detectives told Britain's domestic news agency, Press Association, they were searching for seven men thought to be behind the Tuesday afternoon attack. Sister Fiona Fullham, regional superior of the Sisters of St. Louis, said Wednesday, ``I would pray that all those in Northern Ireland who have been involved in violence would try to think of the human face of the people who have died and who are dying, and of the families who are suffering needlessly all these years.. ``I would say, please stop. Please stop.'' The explosion killed Sister Catherine Dunne, 37; Constable William James Hanson, 37, and reserve officers Joshua Cyril Willis, 35, and David Sterritt, 34. Nearly 2,800 people have died in political and sectarian violence in the British province since 1969, including 273 police officers. Sister Catherine was the first nun. The Irish Republican Army said it set off the half-ton bomb hidden beneath a rural road near Armagh, but left it to its Sinn Fein political wing to express regret. ``Our sorrow at these deaths is genuine and profound, but will be abused by our political opponents who will cynically exploit yesterday's events for their own political purpose,'' Martin McGuinness, a Sinn Fein leader in Londonderry, said. The officiers, in one car, were killed outright. Sister Catherine was in an oncoming car and died of injuries at a hospital. A passenger in her car, social worker Cathy McCann, 25, was reported in satisfactory condition Wednesday, but still unaware her friend had died. Wednesday's statement of regret, similar to one issued when the IRA killed a 20-year-old Catholic girl in Warrenpoint in April 1989, was rejected in advance by Irish and British politicians and Protestant and Catholic leaders. Killing Catholics is particularly embarrassing for the IRA. Although condemned by the church, the IRA claims to be protector of the 600,000 Catholics in the Protestant-dominated province. ``If I hear one more deeply regrets statement from the IRA I think I shall take to the streets with a gun myself,'' said British lawmaker Anthony Beaumont-Dark of the governing Conervative Party. The IRA unit in North Armagh took responsiblity for the blast. It sent a message to news media saying the nun was the victim of ``unforeseen and fluke circumstances.'' Funeral services for Hanson and Willis were set for Thursday. Sterritt and Sister Catherine will be buried Friday. Sister Corina Muldoon, director of St. Joseph's School, remembered Sister Catherine as a lively woman, an enthusiastic swimmer and jogger. ``At this time when vocations are less and less, and our communities are getting older and older, a young sister is quite a treasure,'' she told reporters. The community, in Middletown since 1875, has 16 members. ``It's only when it comes home to your own door that you appreciate what death by violence is like,'' Sister Fiona said. `` ... When it's one of your own, you really realize what it must be like for the families of each one who has died by violence in Northern Ireland.'' In Dublin, Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins on Wednesday expressed revulsion at the killings and said, ``I hope that the overwhelming reaction to this outrage will cause those who support the IRA and their actions to stop doing so, once and for all.'' Des O'Malley, leader of the Progressive Democrats, the junior partner in Ireland's government, said Sister Catherine's death would have a special impact. ``It shouldn't have to, but this brings home the daily sufferings of people in Northern Ireland more forcibly than would otherwise be the case,'' he said. After Wednesday's news conference, the sisters at St. Louis Convent served sandwiches and tea, and Sister Corina apologized because they could not be more hospitable. Eight miles away in Caledon, a grave was being dug outside St. John's Anglican Church for Willis. He and his fellow officers ``will be forgotten next week, but not by their families,'' said the Rev. Frank Beamish, who had known Willis for 29 years. He prepared Willis for confirmation, officiated at his marriage, baptized his sons David, 4, and Andrew, 1, and worked with him as a church warden and member of the choir. ``It's shattering,'' Beamish said.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Sentenced To Prison For Beating Adopted Son To Death
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A couple was sentenced Wednesday to up to seven years in prison for beating their adopted son to death just eight weeks after he came to live with them. Bernice and Gerald Kittelberger were sentenced to two and one-third to seven years in prison for the death last August of 2-year-old Maurice West. ``Maurice was not treated like a child, he was treated like a piece of property,'' said Monroe County Judge Donald J. Wisner. ``This was a brutal crime.'' Bernice Kittelberger, 32, was convicted in a non-jury trial in May of manslaughter and second-degree assault. Gerald Kittelberger, 30, was convicted of second-degree assault. Even though Mrs. Kittelberger was convicted on two charges and her husband on one, the judge said he saw no reason to give her a longer sentence than her husband. Before sentencing, the Kittelbergers told Wisner they didn't intend to hurt the child. ``I loved my child very much,'' Mrs. Kittelberger said in a tearful, barely audible voice. ``If my loving him is wrong, then I'm sorry. What I have done may not have been right, but I loved my baby.'' ``I can only ask God for forgiveness,'' Gerald Kittelberger said. ``It's just something I have to live with for the rest of my life.'' The sentencing hearing was attended by Dale and Janice May, Maurice's foster parents in Cincinnati until he was adopted by the Kittelbergers. The Mays had wanted to adopt Maurice but were turned down because they were white and the child was black. The Kittelbergers are black. Dale May said he would have liked to see a stiffer sentence. ``Nothing's too much for them,'' he said. Mrs. Kittelberger faced a maximum possible prison sentence of 15 years and her husband a maximum sentence of seven years. Assistant Monroe County District Attorney Richard A. Keenan asked Wisner to impose the maximum sentence to ``send a message to the community that child abuse will not be tolerated ... that Maurice's death was not in vain.'' During the trial, Monroe County Medical Examiner Dr. Nicholas T. Forbes testified that Maurice died as a direct result of repeated and severe beatings. Witnesses said Maurice's face, legs, buttocks and genitals were severely bruised and swollen and there were partially healed burns on his palms and the backs of his hands. Mrs. Kittelberger told police that Maurice had died after choking on oatmeal. Both Kittelbergers admitted beating the toddler with a belt, a paddle and a stick wrapped in tape to punish him for resisting toilet training. Since Maurice's death, the Mays have won a civil suit against adoption officials in Hamilton County, Ohio, requiring that more consideration be given to interracial adoptions. The adoption hadn't been made final before the child's death.

DOC.HEAD: DDT Linked To Pancreatic Cancer in Chemical Plant Employees
DOC.TEXT: A chemical company warned former and current employees Wednesday that a study shows for the first time a possible direct link between pancreatic cancer and the insecticide DDT. The study by the University of Michigan focused on 28 cases of pancreatic cancer among Rohm & Haas employees who worked at its Philadelphia plant from 1948 to 1971, when DDT and related chemicals were produced there. Other researchers expressed caution at the preliminary results, saying too little was known to definitively draw a link between the chemical and pancreatic cancer, the fifth-leading cancer killer. DDT is known to cause liver cancer at high doses in mice, but is not known to cause cancer in humans, said Albert Heier, a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency spokesman. The pesticide was banned in 1972 over concerns about its adverse effect on the environment and wildlife and its persistence in the food chain. Rohm & Haas spokesman George Bochanski said the company received a draft of the study from Dr. David Garabrant about two weeks ago and decided to release the results to its employees. Bochanski said the company held meetings with current employees Wednesday and had sent letters to former employees. ``We felt it was appropriate to let our workers know now,'' Bochanski said. Garabrant and Rohm & Haas officials did not release a copy of the study, saying it was only a draft. Garabrant and company officials said that, based on the study, DDT could neither be identified nor ruled out as the cause of the pancreatic cancer. But they said the study was the first link between DDT, which is known to cause cancer in laboratory animals, and pancreatic cancer in humans. Garabrant ruled out other chemicals or lifestyle risks, such as smoking. ``We really have to look at this further'' before drawing conclusions about DDT's link with pancreatic cancer, the EPA's Heier said. The study was prompted by a 1987 report by Rohm & Haas that found 16 cases of pancreatic cancer among the 6,000 employees at its Philadelphia plant from 1948-71. Only about nine cases of the cancer would normally be expected, according to Bochanski. The national rate of pancreatic cancer is about 9 cases per 100,000 people, resulting in about 28,100 new cases and about 25,000 deaths a year, according to the American Cancer Society. About 3 percent survive five years or longer. The current study, commissioned by Rohm & Haas, used the same employee population but researchers discovered 12 additional known cases of the cancer. Garabrant said the study examined the medical records of all 28 employees diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and compared them to 112 other employees _ matched for age, sex and race _ who did not work with DDT, and questioned them or surviving relatives about lifestyles, such as smoking or diet. Rohm & Haas manufactured DDT until 1971. The company did not know the amount of DDT to which the employees had been exposed nor the length of their exposure. An epidemiologist at Fox Chase Cancer Center, Thomas Mason, cautioned against reading too much into Rohm & Haas' early results. DDT is stored in the body's fat, so a diet high in fat could affect the study's results, he said. He suggested that further research on the plant's rate of pancreatic cancer and DDT examine the connection to diet. Bochanski said it was uncertain what the company's next step would be.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says Cocaine Influenced Former Prosecutor Who Jumped Bond
DOC.TEXT: Cocaine and the influence of a female capital murder defendant led a former Dallas County prosecutor to jump bond on a federal drug charge, a doctor testified. ``He was heavily addicted to cocaine _ to the point where he was losing weight. It was ruining his health,'' said Dr. Robert John Powitzky, a clinical psychologist who examined Mike Wilson. ``He also was very caught up with a charismatic, probably psychotic woman. ``It was something willpower would not stop.'' Wilson himself said Tuesday at a detention hearing that cocaine was the reason he fled with Joy Davis Aylor, who's still on the loose. ``I left because I was scared. I didn't see any way out,'' Wilson testified during the hearing before U.S. Magistrate John B. Tolle. ``The whole thing was a nightmare to me.'' Tolle, who had released Wilson on personal recognizance before he fled, denied a request to free him again, on bail, so he could enter a drug treatment program. Wilson had pleaded innocent to charges of accepting 46 pounds of cocaine in exchange for his legal services. He was arrested March 21 by U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents in Dallas. He left town May 5 with Mrs. Aylor, who is accused of hiring a hit man to kill her husband's girlfriend in 1983. Wilson and Mrs. Aylor were involved romantically. Wilson, a former Dallas County assistant district attorney, said he considered suicide before he was captured June 11 in British Columbia, but had planned to surrender. ``Mr. Wilson was trying to come back when he was arrested,'' said his attorney, Gary Noble. ``He knows running away is not the answer.'' Wilson said he has not used cocaine since his initial arrest in March but that his mind was still affected by the drug when he ran off with Mrs. Aylor. Mrs. Aylor had been scheduled to go on trial May 14. She was free on $140,000 bond when she fled.

DOC.HEAD: President Declares Support For Baltic Republics
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised support Wednesday for the people of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in their quest for freedom from the Soviet Union. Bush held a ceremony in the Rose Garden marking ``Captive Nations Week,'' an event that the presidents have observed annually since the Eisenhower era. Bush brought with him both a piece of the Berlin Wall and a swatch of barbed wire that came from a now dismantled barrier on the Austria-Hungary border. ``These two symbols of tyranny should never be forgotten,'' Bush told his 100 guests, many of them refugees from communist lands. The audience also included a group of young interns from Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. ``They are here learning how a free society works and will return to build a free Poland, a free Hungary, a free Czechoslovakia,'' the president said. ``But while we celebrate for those who are now free, we must also remember those who are not,'' said Bush. He recalled the scene from China's Tiananmen Square last year ``where iron tanks were met by the iron will of a courageous lone man.'' ``Today I also want to remember especially the people of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia and renew our unflagging support for their long quest for national self-determination,'' he said. ``The road ahead is going to be difficult. But we can now join them in looking forward with hope to the day when their long, cherished dreams will become reality,'' he said. He asked the audience to pray ``that the next Captive Nations Week will be the last.'' The United States has never recognized the forcible incorporation of the three Baltic states into the Soviet Union in 1940 under pressure from Stalinist troops. Lithuania declared its independence from Moscow this spring, prompting Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to impose an economic embargo on the republic. Bush has urged restraint on both sides, while repeatedly affirming U.S. support for the Baltic states' right of self-determination. The Soviet leader recently eased the economic blockade after the Lithuanian parliament in Vilnius suspended its declaration of independence. The Kremlin is expected to start negotiations soon with the Lithuanians. Gorbachev has said it might take several years for the situation to be worked out. The Lithuanian parliament has also demanded independence, voting again last week to nullify the 50-year-old Soviet declaration of power.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Announces Big Defense Cuts, Halving Troops in Germany
DOC.TEXT: Britain, NATO's most hawkish member, said Wednesday it plans to pull half its troops from West Germany and cut its overall regular forces by 18 percent in response to a reduced Soviet threat. The United States announced defense reductions after last year's democratic revolutions in Eastern Europe. But British officials had cautioned against any quick decisions to slash forces. In Wednesday's announcement to the House of Commons, however, Defense Secretary Tom King acknowledged the lowering of global tensions. ``Our aim is an orderly and planned transition to the new world unfolding,'' said King. ``It is a time of opportunity and hope for change, yet without putting at risk the safe protection of our country.'' The moves, which also call for eliminating 19 warships and submarines by 1995, will produce substantial savings, King said. But he gave no immediate indication of the size of the Conservative Party government's ``peace dividend.'' King said Britain will make no reductions in its nuclear arsenal. Britain still plans to modernized its submarine-borne Polaris nuclear missiles by the mid-1990s with a more powerful Trident system bought from the United States. Wednesday's announcement followed a five-month review of defense spending by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and a committee of top Cabinet ministers. Mrs. Thatcher has been among the highest defense spenders in the Western countries' North Atlantic Treaty Organization. In the most dramatic proposal, King said the government envisaged that by 1995, Britain will have two rather than four divisions assigned to defend West Germany. It will also halve the number of air bases there. Britain has about 66,700 servicemen deployed in West Germany, including the 55,000-member British Army of the Rhine. They are the second biggest foreign military presence after the United States. In other deep conventional arms cuts proposed by the mid-1990s, King said the Royal Navy's submarine fleet will be reduced from 27 to 16 _ three-fourths of them nuclear-powered. The British naval fleet of frigates and destroyers will be cut from 48 to 40, King said. That move reverses a Conservative Party pledge to maintain a fleet of about 50 warships. The number of Royal Air Force squadrons will drop from 15 to about nine. King said the reductions hinge on several factors: the signing of an East-West accord on conventional arms cuts, final arrangements for German unification and the pace of withdrawal of Soviet troops from other East European countries. King said that by the mid-1990s, he envisages a British army of 120,000, down from 160,000; and the Royal Air Force with 75,000 personnel, down from 89,000. The Royal Navy and Royal Marines would be cut by only 3,000 personnel to 60,000. In addition, King said there will be further immediate savings of $1.1 billion from Britain's $38.6 billion defense budget for the fiscal year ending in March. He said the army would ease back on recruiting, and officials would retire several ships and submarines early. Despite his other comments, King said the Soviet Union remained the mightiest military force in Europe. He warned that if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev lost power, Britain could not ``suddenly try to recall'' its forces.

DOC.HEAD: Tainted Raccoons May be Source of Mercury for Some Panthers
DOC.TEXT: Endangered Florida panthers may get a lethal dose of mercury when they dine on raccoons that apparently pick up the poison by eating Everglades fish, scientists say. Recent laboratory analyses found significant amounts of mercury in the livers of raccoons captured in the eastern Everglades, said Melody Roelke, a veterinarian for the Panther Recovery Project. ``Those cats who eat these mercury-laden raccoons will pick up mercury, but it may not be the only source,'' Roelke said Tuesday in presenting her findings to officials from four state and federal agencies. The tainted raccoons were found in the same Shark River Slough area where a 4-year-old female panther known as No. 27 died of mercury poisoning last year. Panther No. 17, one of the largest and oldest known panthers at 154 pounds and 8 to 10 years old, was found dead Monday. Its remains were so decomposed biologists don't think they'll be able to find out what killed it. It's believed only 30 to 50 panthers remain in South Florida, and they face threats ranging from habitat loss to cars on the roads they sometimes cross. Roelke estimated that a 75-pound panther eating a 6-pound raccoon daily from the Shark River Slough would accumulate a toxic dose of mercury in 14 weeks. ``What that means is everything from uncoordination, visual problems to seizures and death,'' Roelke said. In the case of panther No. 27, ``there's a good probability that she moved into that slough about four months prior to her death. This is compatible with the time course for an animal eating nothing but raccoons every day.'' Officials cautioned that the data, while cause for concern, was preliminary, and they said raccoons make up a main part of the panther's diet in only a few areas. Raccoons eat fish. State health officials have warned against eating fish from several areas of the Everglades because of the mercury.

DOC.HEAD: Ads Tell Teens Drugs Or Alcohol Can Lead To AIDS
DOC.TEXT: A new advertising campaign unveiled Wednesday will try to persuade teen-agers that drugs and alcohol can lead to careless sex, which can lead to AIDS. ``AIDS. Another way drugs can kill you,'' the public service ads say. The $3 million, three-year campaign launched by the National Institute on Drug Abuse and the Advertising Council is the first targeted at teen-agers, the age group that has one of the fastest growing rates of AIDS cases. Among teen-agers 15-19, about 57 percent are sexually active, public health experts said. According to last year's Annual High School Survey conducted by the institute, 51 percent of seniors have used an illegal drug. Intravenous drug use is often associated with AIDS because the virus, transmitted through blood and other bodily fluids, can be spread by sharing needles with an infected user. But the new ads are aimed at use of alcohol and drugs not normally injected, like crack, cocaine and marijuana. ``If you become influenced by alcohol or drugs and then whether you decided ahead of time to abstain from sex or use a condom, you're so wiped out that you forget ... protection goes out the window,'' said Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary of health in the Department of Health and Human Services. Studies have shown that people are more likely to have sex and less likely to use condoms when they are under the influence of drugs or alcohol, he said. ``We're trying to get out front and discourage kids _ or adults _ from using drugs in the first place,'' he said. Mason said public health officials are concerned about the rising rate of AIDS among teens _ up by 35 percent between January 1989 and May 1990, from 342 cases to 530. He also noted that one-fifth of all people with AIDS are in their 20s _ about 27,500 people. Because the average time from infection with the AIDS virus until onset of the disease is believed to be nine years, many of these people probably were infected during their teens. The campaign features radio, television and print ads in which teen-agers are in sexual situations. In the TV ads, directed by Martin Scorsese and narrated by Spike Lee, the teens are at a house party, on the beach or in a car. Lee also narrates the radio spots. In the print campaign, one ad shows a picture of a wrecked car and below it a teen-age couple kissing in a car. Copy under the first photo reads: ``This fatal accident was caused by teen-agers getting stoned and going too fast.'' The caption under the second picture reads: ``So was this one. AIDS. Another way drugs can kill.'' Mason said that ``some may be offended by the forthright nature of these messages. But if we are to save lives, we must speak to teens in a language that will get their attention, make them listen and understand.'' As of the end of May, 136,204 people in the United States had been diagnosed with AIDS, and 83,145 of them had died. As many as 1.5 million Americans are believed to have been infected with the virus, with 40,000 to 80,000 new infections each year, Mason said.

DOC.HEAD: Foley Says Frank Will Overcome Expulsion, Censure Moves
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley on Wednesday predicted that Rep. Barney Frank will withstand Republican attempts Thursday to expel or censure the Massachusetts Democrat for his actions on behalf of a male prostitute. With Frank saying he would likely take to the House floor in his own defense, Foley, of Washington, said Wednesday that most Democrats and some Republicans would accept a House ethics committee recommendation that Frank merely be reprimanded _ the mildest sanction available. The matter is expected to come before the full House Thursday. ``In this case, a unanimous vote of the ethics committee should be accepted by both party leaderships and supported on the House floor, and it's what I believe the House will do,'' Foley said in a Capitol Hill news conference. Frank, one of two acknowledged homosexuals in Congress, already has publicly apologized for his actions on behalf of male prostitute Stephen Gobie and has said he may apologize to the House. In a brief interview Wednesday, Frank said he would ``probably'' participate in the debate. ``It does seem to me that I have an obligation to speak to my colleagues on this issue,'' Frank said. Some House members are seeking a tougher penalty against Frank. House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia is supporting a bid to censure Frank, a penalty that would cost the fifth-term congressman his Judiciary subcommittee chairmanship. And Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., said Wednesday that he was rounding up support for a move to expel Frank from the House, an action seen as unlikely. The 12-member ethics committee, split evenly between Democrats and Republicans, ``has come up with what I consider less than what the incident deserves,'' Dannemeyer said. He rejected the committee's conclusion that Frank was telling the truth when he said he immediately kicked Gobie out of his Capitol Hill apartment in 1987 when he learned that Gobie was operating a prostitution business from there. Dannemeyer said Frank had to have known of and countenanced the prostitution all along. ``If there's one thing any of us should be responsible for is to be responsible for what's going on in his own home,'' Dannemeyer said. The ethics committee dismissed charges that Frank was aware of the prostitution. Instead, the committee cited Frank for writing a misleading memo that was sent to a Virginia prosecutor overseeing Gobie's probation on a sex and drug felony conviction. The committee said the 1986 memo could be interpreted as an attempt to convince authorities to be lenient toward Gobie. The committee said also that Frank improperly used his congressional authority to avoid paying 33 parking tickets, some of them received by Gobie while on personal business. Thursday's debate was expected to be the first item on the House agenda. Foley set aside one hour of debate on the expulsion proposal followed by a vote, and another hour on whether the reprimand recommendation should be increased to a censure. There would likely be separate votes on the censure and reprimand issues.

DOC.HEAD: Jews Protest West German President's Visit with Waldheim
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Jewish activists donned concentration camp uniforms Wednesday to protest what they called West German President Richard von Weizsaecker's ``obscene'' plan to meet with Austrian President Kurt Waldheim. Four activists led by New York rabbi Avi Weiss stood outside the main gate of Weizsaecker's sprawling West Berlin palace, holding a large photo of Waldheim in a Nazi uniform. ``Weizsaecker's decision to be the first German leader to embrace Waldheim, who has a Nazi past, is obscene,'' said Weiss, who has led similiar protests against Waldheim in recent years. He said the group planned a large protest Thursday in Salzburg, Austria, where Weizsaecker and Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel are to pay a private visit to the Austrian leader. The visit represents a thaw in an informal boycott of meetings with Waldheim by Western leaders since Waldheim's election in 1986 to a six-year presidential term. Waldheim served in the German army in Yugoslavia during World War II and a U.N.-commissioned panel of experts has concluded he was in a position to know about Nazi atrocities. Havel, the highly regarded playwright who led the democratic revolt against Czechoslovakia's Communist government last year, has come under the most criticism for the planned meeting. There has been little criticism in Germany of Weizsaecker's trip. Weizsaecker spokesman Gernot Fritz said ``it is a private visit. He is meeting with Waldheim not in his capacity as president, but as a private person.'' Fritz, speaking in Bonn, West Germany, on Wednesday, said no official talks were planned. He said the visit is in conjunction with the opening of the Salzburg Festival of music and drama on Thursday. Havel was quoted as saying that the boycott of Waldheim by foreign statesmen has become ``a certain way stereotyped, and a game.'' In an interview with the Salzburger Nachrichten on Tuesday, he said ``by its ritualization, it effectively becomes a cliche. ``And there is not a bit of moral courage in this, but a cold-blooded calculation: if one won't go, nor will the other. They are simply afraid of each other,'' he was quoted as saying. Weizsaecker was in his Bonn office when the protesters gathered outside his West Berlin office, the Castle Bellevue, an 18th century residence of Hohenzollern princes. Guards kept the protesters, clad in the black-and-white striped shirts of concentration camp inmates, from entering the gate on the stately grounds, where Weiss tried to deliver a personal letter for Weizsaecker. Several police officers were called, and they allowed the group to recite Hebrew prayers outside the gate. ``Please don't let a German officer arrest a Jewish rabbi,'' Weiss told a police officer who ordered the group to disperse. Weiss said the protest in Salzburg would be bolder and larger. He said the group came to Berlin even though they knew Weizsaecker would not be there because it was the old Nazi capital. ``We felt we should come to Berlin on the way to Salzburg because this is a time of Germany's unification, when many people are asking whether Germany is going to be different from its past,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Says Better Ties With North Korea Possible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 5th graf pvs, If all, with current trade figure
DOC.TEXT: Prospects for better relations between North Korea and South Korea, and for possible expanded U.S. trade with North Korea, have improved in the past two months, a senior State Department official said Wednesday. At 11 meetings between U.S. and North Korean officials held in Beijing since last year, the United States has spelled out steps that could lead to closer ties between the two countries, said DeSaix Anderson, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. ``The moment is clearly propitious,'' Anderson told the House Foreign Affairs Asia subcommittee, saying the United States is looking for progress in North Korea's dialogue with South Korea, an agreement on nuclear safeguards, assurance that the North eschews terrorism and a process for returning remains of U.S. Korean War dead. The United States does not expect all of those actions at once, he said, but for each positive move by North Korea, the United States will respond in kind. If all of the steps are taken, ``the stage would certainly be set for a major improvement in our relations,'' Anderson said, adding that there are a range of possible U.S. responses, ``on the trade front, and so forth.'' U.S. trade with North Korea now is minimal. In 1989, the government issued export licenses for $8.4 million worth of goods that meet ``basic human needs,'' the standard set when limited exports began in 1988. Anderson cited the May 28 return of five sets of remains at the North Korean capital of Panmunjom, and said the United States regards that as ``an indication that North Korea wants to improve its ties with the United States.'' He also noted an agreement between the North and South for a meeting of their prime ministers in September and October, the highest-level such session since 1945. ``These talks may mark a turning point in inter-Korea relations,'' Anderson said. How the United States responds to North Korea will depend in part on the quality of that dialogue and any subsequent exchanges, he said. Anderson said the United States had received no word of terrorist acts sponsored by North Korea in the past 18 months. North Korea was put on the official U.S. list of terrorist countries after the bombing of a South Korean airliner in 1987. Adding to pressure for North Korea to emerge from its isolation is the comparative economic wealth of South Korea, whose economy has been booming for years, and a diminution of support from the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries, Anderson said.

DOC.HEAD: Anchorage Times Gets New Editor
DOC.TEXT: A former Chicago Tribune news editor on Wednesday was appointed editor of The Anchorage Times. J. Randolph Murray, 44, replaced Hugh Cunningham, who was hired as interim editor shortly after Veco International, an oil-field services company, bought the newspaper in December, said Publisher Bill Allen. Murray was news editor of the Tribune's Washington bureau from 1986 until last year. Before that, he was an assistant managing editor at the Chicago daily and had worked for the Tribune-owned Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel. Murray, a graduate of Georgia State University, joined the Times as a consultant in January to help redesign the newspaper. Cunningham, 69, is a former University of Florida journalism professor with more than 50 years in the newspaper business.

DOC.HEAD: Bishop of Bath and Wells Named New Archbishop of Canterbury
DOC.TEXT: George Carey, the Bishop of Bath and Wells and a supporter of the ordination of women, was named the 103rd Archbishop of Canterbury on Wednesday. Carey was a surprise choice to succeed Robert Runcie as spiritual leader of the state Church of England and 70 million Anglicans worldwide, including 2.5 million Episcopalians in the United States. ``To be nominated as the 103rd Archbishop of Canterbury is a sacred trust and I feel dazed and unworthy,'' said Carey, the 54-year-old son of a hospital porter who has remained close to his Cockney roots. ``Because I have a strong sense of history I am keenly aware of entering into a rich heritage of faith, learning and spirituality.'' His appointment was announced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who chose him from two names submitted by the 16-member Crown Appointments Commission, a church-elected body. The other name remains a secret. Runcie, who must retire by his 70th birthday on Oct. 2, 1991, has said he will retire at the end of January. As archbishop, Carey will be appointed to the Privy Council, which advises the queen, and become a member of the House of Lords, the unelected upper chamber of Parliament. Carey was not on any list of those considered main contenders to lead the church. But the speed of the announcement, which had not been expected until fall, indicated the nominating commission was unanimous. The 16-member commission forwarded the two names to Mrs. Thatcher two weeks ago. She met Carey on Monday and decided to recommend him, government sources said. An evangelical Christian, Carey is know for his orthodox views. However, he also favors the ordination of women and close relations with Roman Catholics and other Protestant churches, and is an avowed environmentalist. ``I want to be a pastoral archbishop,'' he told a news conference. Carey holds a doctorate from King's College London. He was principal of Trinity Theological College in Bristol between 1982 and 1987 and honorary canon of Bristol Cathedral before being named Bishop of Bath and Wells in 1987. The two frontrunners for the archbishop's post, Archbishop of York John Habgood and Bishop of Liverpool David Sheppard, are liberals and were opposed by the conservative wing of the church. Sheppard called Carey ``a gifted and able man who will serve the church and the nation faithfully with strength.'' Habgood, 63, said: ``There is a little human bit in anybody that likes the top job'' but he said that in his ``heart of hearts'' he thought he was too old for it. Runcie welcomed the ``imaginative appointment,'' a sentiment echoed by the Rt. Rev. Robert Williamson, Bishop of Bradford, who called it ``exciting.'' Carey served in the Royal Air Force as a radio operator before being ordained in 1962. He is married, has two sons and two daughters and, in a Who's Who entry, lists his recreation as jogging. He said he would encourage signs of ``new life and vigor'' in the church and hoped to bring in people like those he grew up with in London's East End. For them, he said, ``all too often the church seems light-years away.'' The Rt. Rev. Michael Baughen, the Bishop of Chester, said Carey ``has the Church of England very much in his heart, is a man of mission, is extremely well-grounded theologically, and has a warm and delightful personality with a real understanding of life.'' But Tony Benn, a left-wing lawmaker from the opposition Labor Party, criticized Mrs. Thatcher's role in the appointment and repeated his call for the separation of church and state in Britain. Christianity was introduced into England within 300 years of the death of Christ, probably by Roman soldiers then occupying the country. In 597, Pope Gregory the Great sent 40 missionaries to England headed by a monk, Augustine, to preach the Gospel to the nation. They landed in Kent, where Augustine was made the first archbishop of Canterbury that year.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan's Daughter Criticizes Tuna Fishing Regulation
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan's daughter Patti Davis on Wednesday blasted Reagan administration policies that she said contributed to the killing of more than 20,000 dolphins annually. Acknowledging that this figure represented a substantial reduction in dolphin deaths associated with U.S. tuna fleet fishing, Davis said she was ``not inured to hearing the tuna industry ... congratulating themselves on bringing the numbers down from over 100,000 to 20,000.'' ``During the Reagan administration, implementation of the Marine Mammal Protection Act was stalled at 20,500 dolphins per year,'' said Davis in testimony before the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee. ``That's 20,500 too many,'' added Davis, who was backing a bill to require labeling of tuna caught by setting nets on dolphins. She spoke on behalf of the Earth Island Institute, a California-based environmental group. Environmentalists have long sought to protect dolphins from being snared in nets cast to catch tuna. In the eastern Pacific Ocean where dolphins swim with tuna, purse seine nets are intentionally dropped below schools of dolphins to capture the tuna underneath when a drawstring is pulled to close the net. Davis, 37, blamed tuna industry lobbying and ``the anti-regulatory stance of the Reagan administration'' for weakened regulations concerning dolphin protection techniques. Davis argued that the Marine Mammal Protection Act aims at a zero rate of dolphin kill by tuna fisherman and that the nation should follow the example set by U.S. tuna canners. In April, the three largest U.S. tuna canners _ companies selling StarKist, Bumblebee and Chicken of the Sea brands _ said they would no longer buy or sell tuna captured along with dolphins. Last month they began labeling such products ``dolphin safe.'' The bill, S-2044, would require seafood and tuna distributors to label their products to disclose whether the contents were caught using dolphin-safe methods. Additionally, the labeling measure provides for penalties based upon volume of canned product and citizen suits against members of the tuna industry in the event of intentional or unintentional violations. The Bush administration and U.S. fisherman oppose the legislation, saying it would destroy the U.S. tuna fleet, reduce tuna stock and do little to help save dolphins.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives Deny Stepfather Intended to Kill Boy
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of a man charged with fatally plunging his 2-year-old stepson headfirst into a toilet testified Wednesday that he was a good father and may have been coerced into confessing. Thomas Coe's defense in his first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse trial began after more than a week of state testimony that he routinely abused stepson Bradley McGee and confessed on tape to the boy's dunking death. Prosecutors are seeking the electric chair for Coe, 23, if he's convicted. ``I don't think it's true at all,'' brother Jerry Coe testified. ``I know that he put it on a tape. But I also know he was probably exhausted and coaxed on by the state and the sheriff's department.'' Only a day before, jurors listened to Coe on tape admitting to investigators that he was irate, out of control and having a ``bad day'' when he dunked the toddler into the toilet as punishment for soiling his pants. Bradley died of head injuries July 28, 1989, two months after he was ordered returned from state foster care to his mother, Sheryl Coe, and stepfather Coe. Mrs. Coe, 21, has testified for the prosecution that during those two months her husband carried out a bizarre pattern of abuse against Bradley, often forcing the child to use his mouth to pick feces off the floor, and grinding his fist and cayenne pepper into the boy's genitals. Mrs. Coe has pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse and is serving a 30-year prison term. Defense attorneys have acknowledged Coe dunked the child into the toilet, but say he should be convicted of a lesser crime because it was merely a one-time form of punishment and there was never any intent to harm the child. Coe's sister-in-law, Melinda, testified that Coe was kind and caring to Bradley and his own infant daughter, Rebecca. ``Do you think he killed Bradley?'' prosecutor John Aguero asked. ``No I do not,'' she said. ``He's a good father. And the way he treated Bradley in his trailer and the way he treated my son and the way he treated his daughter _ there's no way in hell.''

DOC.HEAD: Spain, Cuba Seek End to Havana Embassy Dispute
DOC.TEXT: After almost a week of hostility, Spanish and Cuban officials said Wednesday they were intent on finding a solution to the forced entry of 18 Cubans at the Spanish Embassy. As negotiations were proceeding in Madrid, Spain's top diplomat here told reporters there had been a ``notable'' improvement in the climate with Cuba since some harsh exchanges last week. Embassy Charge Ignacio Ruperes meanwhile said Spanish authorities are still not sure whether nine of the Cubans were police agents sent to thwart the asylum bids of the others, who had arrived earlier. ``If they are police or not police, I cannot tell you,'' Ruperes told a small group of reporters outside the embassy. Reports persist that several of the would-be asylum-seekers are government provocateurs. Last week, relations between the two governments hit a low point. Spain withdrew its ambassador and suspended a $2.5 million aid program. Cuba said Spain should not have allowed the 18 to remain because they were not suffering political persecution. Cuba has called for the ``voluntary and unconditional'' departure of the Cubans at the embassy. Spain has said it will not expel the asylum-seekers. The crisis atmosphere seemed to be receding Wednesday. Cuban officials echoed the conciliatory remarks of Ruperes and the nine Cubans suspected of being police agents dropped plans for a hunger strike. And, aside from the more civil relationship between Havana and Madrid, three Cubans who had sought asylum in the Swiss Embassy last weekend left the compound voluntarily Wednesday morning. Their subsequent fate was not disclosed. Four Cubans remain at the Italian ambassador's residence. The wave of entries at foreign embassies began July 9, after thousands of Albanians who had sought refuge at foreign embassies in Tirana were allowed to leave by boat to Italy. Since then, more than 40 Cubans have sought refuge at a variety of embassies here. According to some estimates, perhaps half were government saboteurs on a mission to force out bona fide asylum-seekers. When the break-ins began, many analysts recalled the period 10 years ago when 10,000 crowded the Peruvian Embassy, setting in motion what became the Mariel boatlift. Over a five-month period, 125,000 Cubans left for Florida. At the time, there seemed little possibility that President Fidel Castro would be toppled from power. But among some Western diplomats here, there is serious question as to whether Castro could survive a similar mass exodus now. He is more isolated than before, has far fewer allies because of the reforms in the Soviet bloc countries and the economic situation has weakened. Marxism is almost universally discredited and food shortages, among other problems, have led to a rise in discontent. So Castro, anxious to keep the problem within manageable limits, has taken steps to discourage additional Cubans from seeking asylum. Police have been deployed in large numbers at Western embassies. In addition, Castro has taken a hard line toward those who have entered embassies, warning that none will be permitted to leave Cuba in a way that circumvents normal immigrations procedures. To some diplomats, one possible solution lies in a deal under which the Cuban asylum-seekers would leave the embassies after receiving promises from the Cuban government that no action will be taken against them. They then would apply to leave the country through normal means. Ruperes suggested both sides are eager for a settlement. ``On the Spanish side, there is serious will and I am almost sure there is the same on the Cuban side to resolve the problem,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Say FBI Tried to Get Them to Change Barry Story
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 23rd graf, Mundy also, with Mundy comment.
DOC.TEXT: A Virgin Islands couple testified Wednesday that they had felt pressure from the FBI to change their stories and tell investigators they had seen Mayor Marion Barry use illegal drugs on a 1986 boat trip. Albert Benjamin and his wife, Carmen, testified that they saw no drugs on the trip, although Benjamin said he did see Barry smoke a cigarette. He also testified he was unfamiliar with the smell of marijuana smoke. Benjamin said he became suspicious when passengers on the boat made repeated trips below decks, but said he could not see what they were doing and ``was not interested in trying to find out.'' ``I had suspicions that there was something out of the ordinary going on on that boat,'' Benjamin said. ``I saw all of them going below decks quite repeatedly.'' Other witnesses have testified that drugs were used below decks and that Barry took part in that activity. Barry's defense attorneys called the couple to dispute the testimony of a prosecution witness who said the former Army sergeant and his wife could have seen Barry use drugs during the trip to the islands. Benjamin said that in several interviews law enforcement officers ``kind of kept driving home the point that I had to know, I had to see'' drug use by Barry and others on the trip. ``I got a little tired and angry,'' Mrs. Benjamin said in describing her interrogation at FBI headquarters in Washington last fall. ``I felt a little pressure.'' On another subject concerning the boat trip, Benjamin told jurors at Barry's cocaine and perjury trial that he became angry when he saw Barry make sexual advances to Rasheeda Moore, the woman who later figured in Barry's January arrest and has been the prosecution's star witness. ``I was angry because I think adults should conduct themselves in an appropriate manner in public ... my wife was sitting there,'' Benjamin said. ``I really didn't appreciate what I saw ... I felt that was very out of place.'' When asked by Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts whether Barry had been ``fondling'' Moore, Benjamin answered, `Yes, and she accepted it.'' Mrs. Benjamin said she did not see Barry and Moore together atop the boat, but said she and her husband discussed it afterward. ``He was still quite angry,'' Mrs. Benjamin said. Moore, who took part in the videotaped FBI sting operation that led to Barry's arrest, testified earlier in the trial that she and the mayor used drugs ``over 100 times.'' Charles Lewis has testified that he and Barry smoked marijuana on the boat trip that Benjamin testified about. Benjamin said he agreed to go on the boat ride because of his long association with Lewis' family. ``It was a spur of the moment thing,'' said Benjamin. Earlier Wednesday, Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy raised questions about FBI involvement with cocaine-laden business cards alleged to have been found with Barry's belongings when the mayor was arrested at a Washington hotel. Mundy showed the court that mixed in with the cards were two business cards of an FBI agent. Frank Steele, a different FBI agent who seized the mayor's belongings when he was arrested, said he couldn't explain how the cards got there, but speculated they merely indicated who later conducted tests on Barry's cards. Mundy also said that Steele's own notes from the arrest indicated he took possession of Barry's belongings at 8:41 p.m., while the videotape showed Steele gathering the business cards at 8:56. Steele explained that he took Barry's suit jacket at 8:41 and the business cards at an unspecified later time. Tests conducted on the cards have shown traces of cocaine. Numerous government witnesses have testified that the mayor snorted powder cocaine by placing the drug on a business card and inhaling the drug. Mundy said after court ended for the day that ``a decision has been made'' on whether or not Barry will testify, but he declined to say if the mayor will take the stand. Barry is being coached by other attorneys in the event that he testifies, Mundy added. Barry's lawyers also want to attack the prosecution's witnesses by introducing medical testimony that cocaine hinders the user's ability to recall events accurately. All of the major witnesses against Barry testified that they had used cocaine. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said he would rule Thursday on whether to allow expert testimony on the subject from doctors.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls Across Much of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Violent summer weather including heavy thunderstorms and tornadoes hit problems in Florida, Arizona, Texas, Nebraska and Minnesota. Three tornadoes were reported at New Port Richey, Fla., but there were no reports of injuries or serious damage from the storms. Thunderstorms continued Wednesday in the Southwest, with locally heavy rain causing some floods. Flooding was forecast for the Santa Cruz River north of Tucson, Ariz., and, a flood warning was posted until Thursday along the Rio Grande River from Presidio, Texas, through the Big Bend National Park. The Rio Grande River at Castolon, Texas, was 2{ feet above flood stage at 11 a.m. Wednesday, and rising. More than four inches of rain fell near Sutton, Neb. Up to 3 inches of rain fell over east-central Nebraska, causing urban flooding at Fremont, Valley and Blair. Rainfall from morning thunderstorms caused flooding at Pipestone, Minn., where storms also brought strong, gusty winds and small hail. Hail an inch in diameter also fell at Scribner, Neb. during the early morning. Rain and thunderstorms continued into Wednesday afternoon from eastern Georgia and Florida though South Carolina, and across eastern New England. Charleston, S.C., received 1\ inch of rain in a half an hour. Showers and storms also extended from central Mississippi through Arkansas, southwest Missouri, southeast Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas and south central Colorado into northeast New Mexico. Rain and thunderstorms reached from central and eastern Nebraska across parts of South Dakota, North Dakota, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Iowa. Rainshowers and thunderstorms were scattered over Montana, the Idaho panhandle, parts of Washington, Oregon, and Nevada. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states Wednesday was 33 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 54 at Spokane, Wash., to 100 at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Last Detainee in Zimbabwe Freed, Deported
DOC.TEXT: A black South African businessman held without trial for three years for alleged sabotage was freed Wednesday, hours before the government was scheduled to lift a 25-year-old state of emergency. Immigration officials then briefly detained Leslie Lesia, 53, anew before deporting him to neighboring South Africa. Lawyers for Lesia said senior immigration officials waited for Lesia outside Chikurubi maximum security prison near Harare, questioned him in downtown Harare, and then saw he was driven to the main airport and put aboard a Johannesburg-bound flight without a passport or travel documents. He was not allowed to speak with reporters. Lesia was arrested in May 1987 under sweeping emergency powers that allowed for indefinite detention without trial. He was accused of importing a booby-trapped TV set into Zimbabwe from Mozambique earlier in 1987. The set exploded in a Harare apartment, killing the wife of an official of the South African guerrilla organization, the African National Congress. Lesia accused Zimbabwean authorities of torturing him after his arrest. He said interrogators broke both his legs with ax handles. He also said Zimbabwean agents abducted him in Mozambique and brought to Zimbabwe against his will. State prosecutors in Harare admitted they did not have enough evidence to convict him in court, but security authorities opposed releasing him because of his suspected contacts with South African agents. In announcing last week that the emergency was being lifted, Home Affairs Minister Moven Mahachi said Lesia was the only detainee held in Zimbabwe without trial. Mahachi cited reforms in South Africa, easing of regional tensions and political harmony at home as reasons for ending the emergency at midnight Wednesday. The white minority government of former Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith introduced the state of emergency in 1965 to crack down on black nationalists, now in power. Since Rhodesia became black-governed Zimbabwe in 1980, the emergency has been renewed every six months by a parliamentary vote.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Team Holds Hearings on Hubble Amid Report of 1981 Flaw in Mirror
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: A NASA team investigating the flawed mirror that crippled the Hubble Space Telescope started hearings Wednesday at the plant where the mirror was made amid reports that tests showed a problem in 1981. The seven-member team, led by Lew Allen, director of NASA's jet propulsion laboratory, took testimony in secret Wednesday at Hughes-Danbury Optical Systems Inc., formerly a division of Perkin-Elmer Corp. Interviews with employees and a review of data pertaining to the Hubble mirrors' testing and manufacturing were to continue Thursday. Thomas Arconti, spokesman for Hughes-Danbury, said no information relating to the investigation would be released while the probe was under way. NASA scientists have said the flaw in the $1.5 billion telescope will cut the Hubble's abilities in half and can only be partly corrected through a space mission scheduled for 1993. The Hubble has two mirrors, a main mirror and a secondary mirror. NASA scientists have said the problem appeared to be a spherical aberration, a problem in the shape of the primary mirror. The Hartford Courant reported Wednesday that scientists may have discovered that flaw in May 1981, but dismissed the evidence because they believed it was the result of a faulty testing apparatus. One source, a retired Perkin-Elmer scientist, told the Courant that the 1981 test showed a possible spherical aberration in the main mirror, a 94-inch structure that NASA had called the smoothest large mirror in the world. But the scientist, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the test results were assumed to be incorrect at the time because they contradicted tests done with an instrument thought to be more accurate. ``It's the smoking gun,'' the scientist said. Perkin-Elmer built the mirrors between 1979 and 1982. Hundreds of employees put in more than four million hours of work on the project. The company also built part of the telescope's guidance system. The retired scientist said that despite the 1981 test results, additional testing did not appear necessary at the time. Those working on the mirror were under pressure to finish because of delays and cost overruns, he added. ``Time and money was always a factor at that point in the program,'' he said. ``They were rushing to shut us down as fast as possible.'' The company had originally been awarded a $63 million contract, but cost overruns left NASA with a total bill of $451 million. Abe Offner, another retired Perkin-Elmer scientist who designed some of the mirrors' test equipment, told The Courant he didn't know of the test results and didn't think the tests were the problem. ``Why did they not do something about it?'' Offner said Tuesday. ``I don't know why it was not brought to my attention. I would have said, `Let's check it out and see what the problem is.''' Jeffrey Clayton, NASA's deputy program scientist for the Hubble project, told the newspaper Tuesday that NASA inspectors in Danbury at the time probably were aware of the test results. Allen, the leader of the NASA probe, said: ``I'm confident we have the ability to find the error. And the results will be embarrassing to someone or some group. But in order to get that answer, we need people to be as candid as possible.'' A statement on the team's progress would be issued from Washington on Thursday, said NASA spokeswoman Sarah Keegan. The Perkin-Elmer division that built the mirrors was purchased last year by Hughes Aircraft Co. of California.

DOC.HEAD: Zambian President Announces Prisoner Release, Other Concessions
DOC.TEXT: Yielding to demands of pro-democracy activists, President Kenneth Kaunda announced Wednesday he will release more than 1,000 prisoners and delay a referendum on ending one-party rule. The opposition had demanded the postponement to allow for voter registration. Pro-democracy campaigners welcomed Kaunda's announcement but said he should go further. In another step, the president said a monthlong, overnight curfew around the capital, Lusaka, was being lifted immediately, but he warned that ``if anyone misbehaves it will be slapped back on.'' Kaunda said the prisoners would be freed by the end of August, but he gave no exact number for those to be released. They include a lieutenant arrested after an abortive coup attempt last month and the alleged leaders of two other coup attempts. Others to be released are 34 student leaders held since five days of violent anti-government riots in June. The president said he would put off the Oct. 17 referendum on whether to end one-party rule to Aug. 21, 1991. Kaunda, whose United National Independence Party has ruled for two decades, led Zambia to independence from British colonial rule in 1964. He declared the southern African nation a one-party state in 1973. In the face of burgeoning political opposition, Kaunda agreed in April to hold a referendum on whether to return this nation of 7.5 million to Western-style multiparty democracy. Pro-democracy reformers have founded an alliance to campaign for the referendum, but they say the voter-registry rolls must be thoroughly updated. About 2.6 million people were registered as voters in 1987, but the reformers say many of their supporters deliberately refrained from registering then because they were disillusioned with Kaunda's government. Arthur Wina, a former finance minister who is chairman of the newly-founded National Interim Committee For Multiparty Democracy Referendum, welcomed the prisoner release, but he said all political prisoners should be freed. He also said that although the opposition had wanted a postponement of the referendum, the 10-month delay was too long and would encourage ``fraudulent activities.'' At a news conference in Lusaka, Wina also repeated the committee's demand for the repeal of state of emergency laws giving the government sweeping powers of arrest. In his announcement, Kaunda said he had no plans to step down unless voters demanded it, and he criticized pro-reform activists as ``the maximum forces of hatred.'' ``I will not abdicate my responsibility to this nation because of thuggery,'' he said. The Zambian leader has been fighting a wave of unrest, but he insisted he was not pressured into making the concessions. ``What I have announced today does not come from extreme weakness but extreme strength _ morally, politically and materially,'' Kaunda told reporters and ruling-party colleagues at his official residence in Lsuaka. Anti-government riots broke out in June after a 120 percent increase in the price of cornmeal, a staple. At least 26 people died in the unrest, the worst since independence. The food protests quickly escalated into political opposition to Kaunda.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Mass Grave Believed to Contain 26 Bodies of Leftists
DOC.TEXT:
The government announced Wednesday it has found another mass grave in the Atacama desert where victims of Chile's former military regime are believed buried. Officials said the latest grave is thought to contain the remains of 26 suspected leftists. Belisario Velasco, undersecretary of the Interior Ministry, said the bodies were apparently destroyed with dynamite. It was not clear why dynamite was used, but the victims may have been blown up after they were shot to death to make identification more difficult. The exact number of bodies in the grave has not been determined, but several skulls and other bones as well as pieces of decomposed clothing were found, Velasco said. Officials on Wednesday sent a team of doctors and anthropologists to investigate the grave in the desert near Calama, a mining city 960 miles north of Santiago. It was found by relatives of dissidents executed in the region shortly after the 1973 military coup that ousted the elected Marxist government of Salvador Allende and propelled Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power. His 16-year authoritarian rule was stained by charges of widespread rights abuses. While in power, Pinochet decreed an amnesty for all rights abuse that occurred before March 1978.
Pinochet was succeeded on March 11 by Patricio Aylwin, an elected civilian. The general remains commander-in-chief of the army. Military authorities had reported shortly after Pinochet's coup that 26 leftists were sentenced by a special military tribunal and executed on Oct. 23, 1973, in Calama. Relatives were notified, but the bodies were never delivered. Rosa Silva, president of an association of relatives of the victims, said Wednesday that the group believes the bodies in the latest grave may be those of the leftists executed in Calama. ``However, we are not sure, and we have to be very careful and make an investigation in depth, because we must respect the pain and the feelings of the relatives,'' she said. Officials announced June 5 that another mass grave had been found in the same desert outside the Pacific fishing village of Pisagua, 1,185 miles north of Santiago. That grave contained 20 bodies identified as those of leftists taken prisoner after the 1973 coup. It was the third grave found since the country restored democratic rule. A total of 23 bodies have been unearthed. Several of them have been identified, including that of a former Communist congressman. However, about 700 leftists who disappeared under military rule remain missing. Authorities say they are also nvestigating reports of other mass graves around the country. After meeting with army commanders, Aylwin said on June 21 that military chiefs deny knowing where any missing victims of anti-leftist repression may be buried.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Team to Repatriate Six Sets of Remains from Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military officials said Wednesday they are returning to the United States with six sets of human remains collected by Cambodians that are believed to be of American MIAs from the Vietnam War. It marks the first time since the end of the war in 1975 that Communist Cambodia has allowed the repatriation of suspected remains of Americans missing in action. A 14-member U.S. repatriation team was scheduled to arrive in Phnom Penh early Thursday by an Air Force C-141 cargo plane. A military honors ceremony was planned for Thursday at the Phnom Penh airport, and immediately afterward, the remains will be flown to the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii, agencies that account for America's wartime missing. Since Tuesday, a six U.S. military experts have been in Phnom Penh to examine sets of remains collected by Cambodians in recent years _ the first such MIA mission to Cambodia since the 1975 Communist takeover. ``We came and did our work and the cooperation was everything we asked for,'' Lt. Col. Joe Harvey, the U.S. team leader, told reporters after meeting with Dith Munty, first deputy foreign minister of the Vietnamese-backed government. Eighty-three Americans are listed as missing in action in Cambodia from the war. A military spokesman earlier said 82 were missing in Cambodia, but later raised the number to 83. The confusion apparently concerned an aircraft that crashed near the Cambodian border, leaving a GI missing. At least eight American civilians are also listed as missing in Cambodia, according to U.S. officials. On Tuesday and Wednesday, the U.S. team examined 28 sets of remains in a tiny laboratory at Cambodia's only medical college. The teak caskets contained bones, skulls and at least two sets of military identification ``dog tags.'' A Cambodian Foreign Ministry spokesman said his government paid $2,000 for the return of some remains from remote provinces. Harvey said six sets of remains warranted further analysis at the military laboratories in Hawaii to reach a positive identification. Four were found in outlying provinces and two were from an area southwest of Phnom Penh known as Choeung Ek, which was used as a mass execution ground by the fanatical Communist Khmer Rouge when they ruled the country from 1975 to 1978. The Khmer Rouge were ousted after Vietnamese forces invaded the country in late 1978. However, it was unclear if the remains found in Choeung Ek dated from the period when the Khmer Rouge held power. The U.S. mission broke a long political stalemate between Washington and successive Communist governments in Phnom Penh over the MIA issue. Lt. Col. Thomas Boyd, a team spokesman, said past U.S. efforts to examine remains in Cambodia had been ``either ignored or politicized.'' He said Washington would consider sending another such team to examine more remains, but added that this was not discussed during his group's visit to Phnom Penh. The United States does not recognize the Phnom Penh government. But a week ago, Washington announced it was withdrawing recognition of the Khmer Rouge-dominated guerrilla coalition that is fighting the Phnom Penh government, and would open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian civil war. Cambodia's Deputy Interior Minister Khim Ponn, head of a newly formed MIA commission, said he wanted to discuss normalization of diplomatic relations, but the Americans limited talks to the issue of missing Americans. Most of the Americans missing in Cambodia are airmen whose planes were downed during bombing raids from 1969 to 1973 on the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the major supply route for the North Vietnamese into South Vietnam that wound through the mountains of eastern Cambodia. A total of 2,299 Americans are officially listed as missing in action in Indochina. Aside from those in Cambodia, 1,678 are missing in Vietnam, 533 in Laos and six in China's coastal waters.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops to Pull Back at Dawn from Kuwaiti Border: Sources
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Iraqi border troops to withdraw, Kuwait seen winner in confrontation. Picks up 5th graf, `The oil...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BAG1
With AM-OPEC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops will begin pulling back from the border with Kuwait at dawn Thursday prior to direct talks to try to solve the two nations' dispute over land and oil production, diplomatic sources said. The sources, based in the Persian Gulf, said Wednesday that the development was viewed as a victory for the small sultanate of Kuwait in their propaganda campaign. Kuwait insisted that Iraq withdraw what it said were massed forces at their common 100-mile border before Kuwait would sit down for negotiations this weekend with Baghdad, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The sultanate wanted Iraq, with more than eight times the population of Kuwait, to move away from its muscle-flexing, they said. The sources credited intensive mediation by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia on Tuesday night for lightening the crisis atmosphere. Mubarak kept in contact with the Iraqis and Kuwaitis into early Wednesday, they reported. The announcement of direct Iraqi-Kuwaiti talks was made by Mubarak on Wednesday in Cairo amid an escalating anti-American campaign in the Iraqi media. The state-run newspaper said Iraq would not bow to U.S. pressure in the dispute. In Baghdad, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein summoned U.S. Ambassador April Glaspie for talks. Government radio gave no details of the meeting.
