In Kuwait, diplomatic sources said Saddam assured Mubarak that he would not use military force as long as Kuwait agreed to the following conditions: paying compensation for $2.4 billion in oil Iraq claims Kuwait stole, and holding direct talks on a border dispute. The oil allegedly stolen was from the Rumaila oil field, which includes land claimed by both Iraq and Kuwait. In addition, Iraq wants Kuwait to write off billions of dollars in loans it granted Iraq during the Iran-Iraq war, and it wants the reopening of a border air corridor. The dispute flared last week when Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing the oil and alleged that Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates were causing a slump in oil prices by exceeding their OPEC production quotas. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries price-monitoring committee began meeting in Geneva on Wednesday to set prices for the rest of the year. Iraq wants a cut in production to force a $7 increase per barrel. Mubarak met with leaders from Kuwait and Iraq on Tuesday. He told reporters in Cairo on Wednesday that direct talks would probably begin Saturday or Sunday in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia. ``Two delegations from both sides will sit and discuss the problem. Of course it will take several meetings,'' he said. ``Only the two delegations with each other,'' he said when asked who would sponsor the meeting. Mubarak also said Saddam had denied sending troops to the Kuwaiti border, despite reports to the contrary. ``What is present there was present before. I can tell you there is no intention from President Saddam to move any troops toward Kuwait,'' Mubarak said when asked when Iraqi troops would be withdrawn from the border. Diplomats in Iraq and Persian Gulf states said that soon after the dispute erupted last week, travelers saw battlefield missiles, armored personnel carriers and tanks prominently displayed along the road from Iraq to Kuwait. Diplomatic sources in Bahrain said Tuesday that a Washington Post report of 30,000 Iraqi troops at the border appeared to be correct. In a show of support for Kuwait, the Pentagon announced Tuesday that U.S. warships and aircraft would hold a ``short-notice exercise'' 600 miles to the south in the Persian Gulf with a second small state, the United Arab Emirates. In apparent reference to this, the Iraqi newspaper Al-Jumhuriya on Wednesday accused Kuwait of ``implementing an American-Zionist plot to show that America is playing the role of protector in the gulf.'' The paper said Kuwait ``should be aware that those who are threatening the interests of the Arab nation and conspire against it will not be protected by foreigners.''

DOC.HEAD: Airline Charged in Criminal Indictment Citing Maintenance Record Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-9, bgng `An Eastern ...' with 8 grafs with Eastern and FAA comment, moving up details on charges; picks up 10th graf, `Maloney said....; A version moving on business wire. ^LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines and several of its top maintenance managers were charged Wednesday with conspiring to falsify safety and maintenance records to avoid costly flight delays and cancellations. ``This indictment is about failure to maintain aircraft _ both regular maintenance and parts that are faulty,'' U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney said in announcing the charges. ``The motivation was to get the airplanes into the air. An airline only makes money with planes in the air.'' The federal grand jury indictment is unprecedented in the airline industry and adds to Eastern's woes as it seeks to regain passengers, build service and reorganize under federal bankruptcy protection after a bitter strike. None of the alleged violations caused accidents or injuries, authorities said. The 60-count indictment charges conspiracy to defraud the government, wire fraud, falsification of documents and obstruction of justice. It names the airline and nine high-level managers, including Edward Upton, the former vice president of maintenance and engineering. Until a few days ago, five of the defendants were still employed as maintenance supervisors by the airline, Maloney said. A 10th employee would be named in a separate document, he said. In a statement, the Miami-based airline said that during the last two years it had taken ``full corrective action under the scrutiny of the Federal Aviation Administration.'' ``Today there is no question that Eastern is safe. Eastern has its share of problems _ operating a safe airline is not one of them,'' the statement said. FAA Administrator James B. Bussey said the airline now meets the agency's safety standards. ``We are carefully studying the indictment and if we find anything that gives us cause for concern ... we will take whatever action is necessary to protect the traveling public,'' he said. At a news conference Tuesday, Martin Shugrue, appointed by a federal bankruptcy judge to run the airline, said Eastern would admit fraudulent maintenance and record-keeping practices, but not conspiracy. He termed the purported violations ``ancient history,'' said the problems had been corrected and insisted the airline was safe. Maloney said the violations took place from July 1985 to October 1989 at Kennedy and La Guardia airports in New York, Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta and Eastern headquarters in Miami. The investigation began after an Eastern maintenance supervisor voluntarily went to Maloney's office and told him about alleged irregularities. During the 10-month investigation, a federal grand jury uncovered a pattern of top airline managers ordering that maintenance not be performed on aircraft but that records be made to falsely show that it was, Maloney said. By tampering with log books, work cards and computerized maintenance records Eastern ``did cause aircraft that were not properly maintained or repaired to fly and carry unsuspecting passengers,'' the indictment said. The charges involved critical items including radar, landing gear, automatic pilots and fuel systems, Maloney said. Upton and other managers pressured ``supervisors and mechanics to sign off on airplanes that had not had their regular maintenance or corrective maintenance in order to get the plane in the air, or perhaps risk their jobs,'' Maloney said. Among the irregularities cited by Maloney were a failure to properly remove accumulated water from fuel tanks. The water can freeze at high altitudes and clog fuel lines and makes fuel gauges read high. In Atlanta, he said, workers installed defective or untested cockpit instruments to make it appear that corrective repairs had been made. If convicted on all counts, Eastern faces a maximum fine of $30 million. Each individual defendant faces up to five years in prison and fines up to $250,000 for each count. ``This case is not about money or fines, this case is about deterrence and a very important area of public safety,'' Maloney said. ``This is one of those indictments that is trying to send a message to the entire airlines industry.'' Eastern's employees went on strike March 4, 1989, and the company filed for bankruptcy protection five days later. Pilots and flight attendants quit the strike several months later but the mechanics remain on strike. Shugrue said Eastern expected to turn a profit in 1991. It is projected to lose about $500 million this year after an $852 million loss in 1989. Maloney said prosecutors had no evidence of improprieties at the airline since Shugrue assumed control.

DOC.HEAD: Leak Detected During Testing of Atlantis; Mission Further Delayed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 26 grafs to ADD comment on Atlas launch; move up references to other NASA troubles; minor editing. Pick up 23rd graf pvs, `Investigators, who...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: NASA's last-ditch effort to fix Atlantis' hydrogen leak on the launch pad failed Wednesday, forcing the trouble-plagued agency to postpone the space shuttle's flight until later this year. NASA engineers, who had hoped to avoid a long launch delay by quickly repairing the leak on the pad, said the shuttle must be returned to the hangar for more work. It had been scheduled for a secret military mission this month. Shuttle Columbia, still under repairs because of a different sort of hydrogen leak which scrubbed a May launch, will be the next shuttle to fly. It is scheduled for an astronomy mission in early September, and NASA says it expects the leak to be fixed in time. The developments came as a space agency team began probing the cause of NASA's highest-profile problem: the flawed mirror on the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. The seven-member team, led by Lew Allen, director of NASA's jet propulsion laboratory, took testimony in secret Wednesday at Hughes-Danbury Optical Systems Inc., the maker of the mirror. The flaw has halved the effectiveness of the telescope, which was put in orbit on an April shuttle mission. NASA, facing mounting criticism in Congress because of the string of setbacks, got one piece of good news Wednesday: A thrice-delayed Atlas rocket launch finally went off without a flaw. The rocket carried a government device designed to study electric fields in space and the Van Allen radiation fields. ``It's good to have something positive happen,'' said NASA spokesman Jim Cast. ``It's a definite boost to NASA morale.'' The Atlas launch had been delayed three times, because of a power problem, bad weather and a helium leak. On the shuttle, experts had hoped Atlantis' problem could be solved by simple launch pad repairs. But the leak reappeared during a test Wednesday and, after analyzing the data, engineers concluded they still didn't fully understand the problem. ``We were not able to fix it. We have learned more so we will roll back smarter,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. NASA will try to launch Atlantis on its classified Pentagon flight in November. The latest leak, detected when liquid hydrogen was pumped into Atlantis' external fuel tank, was about the size of the leak detected in two previous tests and was in the same area, a flange in a pipe that carries liquid hydrogen from the tank to the main engines. Workers tightened bolts around the flange and checked the welds, even though engineers doubted that would be enough to correct the problem. Had the spot been leak-free Wednesday, NASA would have tried to launch Atlantis in mid-August and Columbia in September. Now officials intend to get Columbia ready to move to the launch pad in early August, said shuttle director Robert Crippen. NASA officials want to get at least one shuttle up before Discovery's October mission with Ulysses, a satellite that will explore the sun's poles. Discovery has a 19-day ``window'' in which it must lift off or the mission will be delayed 13 months. That would be the next time Earth is in proper alignment again with the sun and Jupiter. If NASA hadn't tried to fix Atlantis at the launch pad, ``we would have forever wondered if we could have gotten two off before Ulysses,'' Lenoir said. The delay in launching Atlantis means NASA must bump yet another mission into next year. The space agency originally had planned nine shuttle flights for 1990, but now is down to seven. So far, only three have been flown. Columbia had been due to lift off May 30 with the $150 million Astro observatory for study of ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted by stars and other celestial objects. Columbia's leak was detected during fueling, six hours before liftoff. The space agency has since replaced Columbia's leaky plumbing with components from the unfinished shuttle Endeavour. Columbia's leak is believed to be larger than the one plaguing Atlantis and in a different place. Crippen said it's too soon to say how Atlantis' leaky fuel line will be repaired. One option is to attach a new external tank. The discovery of Atlantis' first leak, on June 29, prompted NASA to temporarily ground its three-shuttle fleet. The leak reappeared during a more elaborate test two weeks later. The Hubble telescope isn't expected to fulfill its potential until space-walking astronauts make repairs in 1993. Allen of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said the Hubble probers hoped to find what Allen called a ``smoking gun and a fingerprint on the trigger.'' Investigators, who expected to stay through Thursday, also planned to examine reams of data pertaining to the manufacturing and testing of the mirror, and equipment used to test the accuracy of the mirror. NASA's proposed space station Freedom also is under attack. Studies show the station will require more maintenance than is feasible unless major design changes are made.

DOC.HEAD: Three Lawyers Freed in Kenya, But Four Detainees Charged
DOC.TEXT: The government Wednesday freed from jail three pro-democracy lawyers but charged four other people with plotting its overthrow. The U.S. Embassy and human rights activists who had demanded the lawyers' release hailed the decision to free them. But they said other detainees should also be freed. President Daniel arap Moi and other Kenyan leaders have been struggling to put down a popular pro-democracy movement. They argue that more than one political party in this East African country of about 21 million residents would lead to wars among the estimated 40 tribes. The lawyers released Wednesday were Gitobu Imanyara, John Khaminwa and Mohamed Ibrahim. They could not be immediately reached for comment. They had been rounded up before a rally planned for July 7 to demand a multiparty political system. Police tried to block the rally, which led to riots in Nairobi and four other cities. At least 28 people died and scores were injured. The government gave no reason for freeing the three lawyers. Kenyan law permits detention without charge or trial of individuals the government considers a threat to state security. In New York, the Africa Watch rights group attributed the release to international pressure. Executive Director Rakiya Omaar, in a statement faxed to The Associated Press, said international press coverage ``has estroyed the myth of Kenya as a haven of peace and political stability.'' The U.S. Embassy welcomed the release, but it expressed hopes that other detainees would also soon be released. ``We hope the cases of those remaining in custody can be resolved rapidly,'' said an embassy spokesman. The new charges were against former parliament deputy George Anyona, former university dean Ngotho Kariuki, rural ruling party official Augustine Kathangu, and university lecturer Edward Oyugi. The government accused them of taking part in a meeting whose participants had ``seditious intentions of overthrowing the Kenyan government by unlawful means.'' The four had been held without charge since July 12, when they were arrested together at a Nairobi-area pub. Still in detention are former Cabinet ministers Charles Rubia and Kenneth Matiba, as well as Raila Odinga, a businessman and the son of former Vice President Oginga Odinga. They are all leading advocates of multiparty politics.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed, Seven Injured in Helicopter Crash Near North Sea Oil Facility
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter crashed Wednesday in the North Sea as it was approaching an offshore tanker loading facility, killing six people and injuring seven others, the Shell oil company said. The accident involving a Sikorsky helicopter raised new concerns about safety in the North Sea oil fields, where there have been at least four aircraft crashes the past four years. In July 1988, 167 men were killed in an oil platform fire. About 60 North Sea oil workers refused to fly out to the oilfields on Sikorsky helicopters until the cause of the crash has been determined. A Shell spokesman said half the men were staying in hotels on the Shetland Islands at company expense and the rest had returned to Aberdeen, Scotland, by plane. British Transport Secretary Cecil Parkinson told the House of Commons that the cause of the crash was not known. He said visibility was about two miles at the time and ``doesn't seem to have been a factor'' in the accident. John Prescott, the opposition Labor Party spokesman on transport, told the House of Commons that a door had fallen off another Sikorsky helicopter on Tuesday. He did not elaborate. The crash occurred at 10:55 a.m. as the helicopter was approaching the Brent Spar, an offshore tanker loading facility serving the four platforms in the Brent oil field operated by Shell U.K. Exploration and Production. The helicopter, carrying 13 passengers and crew, plummeted into the water about 100 yards from the facility, Ian Henderson, Shell U.K.'s deputy managing director, told BBC Television. The helicopter was operated by British International Helicopters, Ltd., a company chaired by British publisher Robert Maxwell, a statement from Maxwell's office said. Rescuers in helicopters and boats, including a special diving vessel, immediately converged on the crash site, about 115 miles northeast of Lerwick, in the Shetland Islands. Shell chairman Bob Reid told reporters at a news conference that the seven injured survivors were pulled from the water within 20 minutes after the crash. Shell said the survivors were first ferried to a nearby company facility for treatment. One of the rescued men suffered a broken leg, Henderson said. Parkinson said the injured were then taken to an Aberdeen hospital. He said four of the survivors were seriously hurt. The bodies of the six victims were discovered in the wreckage by a remote-controlled mini-submarine, a Shell spokesman said. He said the earliest the wreckage could be lifted and the bodies recovered would be Thursday. Two of those on board were pilots, five worked for Shell and six were employed by Shell contractors, she said. Britain's Department of Transport said it sent two inspectors to the scene to investigate.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Semitism Defendant Fails to Appear at Trial
DOC.TEXT: The defendant in a highly publicized anti-Semitism trial failed to appear in court for the second day of proceedings Wednesday, and the judge ordered police to find him. Svetlana Birulina, lawyer for 64-year-old Muscovite Konstantin Smirnov-Ostashvili, said he had not told her his plans, and she did not know where he was. ``We don't have contact with each other,'' said the lawyer, who was appointed by the court to represent Smirnov-Ostashvili because his regular attorney is on vacation. Judge A.I. Muratov's order means Smirnov-Ostashvili can be brought in forcibly by police, she said. On Tuesday, the opening day of the trial in Moscow's City Court building, Smirnov-Ostashvili declared his distrust of the entire Moscow Collegium of Lawyers to which Ms. Birulina belongs, and sought her dismissal. Muratov refused his bid, but postponed the trial a day because he could not maintain order in the crowded courtroom. On Wednesday, uniformed police with truncheons limited the number of reporters and onlookers allowed into the courtroom. Smirnov-Ostashvili was arrested for allegedly being an organizer of a Jan. 18 protest that broke up a meeting of writers as Moscow's Central House of Literature and roughed up some participants. The case was widely publicized here and heightened Jewish fears of anti-Semitic attacks. Speaking to reporters in the courtroom Tuesday, Smirnov-Ostashvili denied being anti-Semitic, but charged that Jews hold a disproportionate share of power in the Soviet Union. More than 71,000 Jews left the Soviet Union last year, and thousands more are leaving this year. Jewish leaders cite ``an unprecedented panic among the Jewish population'' in the face of threats from extreme Russian nationalist groups such as the Pamyat society. If found guilty, Smirnov-Ostashvili could be sentenced to up to five years in prison under a new law that toughens punishment for insulting people because of their ethnic background, or inciting ethnic intolerance.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Eastern Fit To Operate Despite Indictment
With AM-Eastern-Indictments
DOC.TEXT: Federal Aviation Administration officials said Wednesday they would closely study the criminal indictment against Eastern Airlines but believe the carrier is now fit to fly. ``Eastern Airlines today meets the FAA's safety standards for operating an airline,'' said FAA administrator James B. Busey after a federal prosecutor in New York announced the grand jury charges against the airline and several managers alleging a conspiracy to falsify maintenance records. ``We are carefully studying the indictments issued today, and if we find anything that gives us concern regarding the current safety disposition of Eastern, we will take whatever action is necessary to protect the traveling public,'' Busey said. The FAA has the power to suspend a carrier's license to operate. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar said FAA officials uncovered some of the problems in the first place and turned over the findings to the U.S. attorney's office in New York. The agency last year fined Eastern $839,000 for some of the safety violations cited in the indictment _ a fine that has not been paid because the airline filed for court protection from creditors under the federal bankruptcy laws in March 1989. ``We're waiting in line with all the other creditors,'' said Farrar. The FAA also revoked the licenses of several mechanics and was prepared to shut down the airline's maintenance base at John F. Kennedy Airport in New York, Farrar said, after it investigated allegations of records falsification. But Eastern closed the installation when confronted with the evidence, he said. ``The FAA intends to continue with the intense surveillance now in place at Eastern Airlines and will continue to cooperate fully with the U.S. attorney's ongoing investigation,'' Farrar said. Asked if the indictment would affect the way the FAA oversees maintenance work at other airlines, the spokesman said, ``We think it's pretty good, and we've been looking at Eastern awfully hard ever since'' the violations were found. Meanwhile, the Washington-based Air Line Pilots Association said the indictment is further vindication of its stand against Texas Air Corp. owner Frank Lorenzo, who formerly controlled the airline. Eastern is now run a court-chosen bankruptcy trustee, Martin Shugrue. ``We take great comfort in knowing that when a panel of ordinary citizens finally was presented with just a few of the safety violations in a proper legal forum, they found sufficient cause to act against Eastern,'' the pilots' union said. ``We hope that the irony of this development is not lost on those in Washington who abdicated their responsibility to protect Eastern's customers,'' the union's statement said. Pilots cited Eastern's alleged maintenance shortcuts as one reason for joining a strike by the Machinists union that forced the airline into filing for bankruptcy. The 60-count indictment against the airline and nine high-level managers charges conspiracy to defraud the government, wire fraud, falsification of documents and obstruction of justice.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Senate Denounces Durenberger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Moves higher reference to committee results being referred to FEC and Justice Department. Minor editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate formally denounced Sen. Dave Durenberger on Wednesday for ``knowingly and willfully'' violating its rules and ordered him to make restitution of up to $123,000 for money he received improperly. Durenberger, R-Minn., made no attempt to fight the vote to denounce him. Speaking in a quiet voice, he pledged to strive to become ``first a better man and then a better senator.'' The somber judgment marked the 24th time in 201 years that the Senate disciplined one of its own. The vote was 96-0, and after rendering their verdict many senators lined up to shake Durenberger's hand, some embracing him. Durenberger and fellow Minnesota Republican Rudy Boschwitz voted present. Durenberger was disciplined for violating Senate speaking fee and gift limits, misleading the Senate on real estate transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium and converting a campaign contribution to personal use. Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee, set the stage for the dramatic vote when he solemnly accused Durenberger, who watched from a front-row desk, of violating his public trust. ``The evidence of knowing and willful misconduct is clear and convincing and far more troubling than Sen. Durenberger's admitted negligence, lack of wisdom or asserted misplaced reliance on others,'' Heflin said. The committee findings will be referred to the Federal Election Commission and Justice Department for further investigation, but there have been no allegations of criminal wrongdoing. A tense calm hung over the crowded Senate gallery as tourists and other passers-by listened as senator after senator stood to praise Durenberger for his legislative accomplishments even as they were condemning him for his ethical lapses. ``No one in this chamber is approaching this vote lightly,'' said Sen. Orrin G. Hatch, R-Utah. ``The stones of denouncement are easier to cast than they are to retrieve.'' Heflin, a former Alabama Supreme Court justice, said there was ``convincing evidence that Sen. Durenberger knowingly and willfully engaged in a pattern of unethical misconduct which violated statutes, rules and standards of conduct.'' The ethics committee said Durenberger should reimburse the Senate $29,050, plus interest, for improper reimbursements he received while staying in his Minneapolis condominium during official trips from 1983-89. It also said he should pay $93,730, less state and federal taxes previously paid, for speaking fees he improperly kept during 1985 and 1986. The fees were for 113 speeches Durenberger said were promotions for his books on health care and defense issues. The committee concluded they were normal honoraria speeches subject to Senate limits. Durenberger, whose political fortunes have suffered at home, told the Senate just before Heflin spoke that he would not contest the committee's recommendation and earlier agreed to make restitution. Durenberger sat at a desk at the front of the Senate chamber, listening to the proceedings with his hand on his chin. ``I ask your forgiveness,'' Durenberger told his colleagues after the vote. ``For future challenges, I need your friendship.'' He called the experience a ``costly education.'' ``As for the future, I would ask only that I be judged ... not necessarily by what I say, but what I do,'' he said. ``Financial restitution is only a beginning.'' At a news conference after the Senate vote, Durenberger reiterated his pledge to become a better senator. Durenberger, a 12-year Senate veteran, was elected to fill the unexpired term of the late Sen. Hubert Humphrey. He does not face re-election until 1994. The end of the Durenberger case will allow the ethics committee to concentrate on pending investigations of six senators, including five who received donations from savings and loan figure Charles Keating _ and interceded with regulators on his behalf. In a case involving another lawmaker, the House ethics committee has proposed that Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., be reprimanded for improperly using his office to help a male prostitute. Action on that recommendation is expected this week. Several Republican colleagues said they believed Durenberger's judgment had been impaired by tragedies, problems he discussed during a June ethics committee hearing. The senator's first wife died of breast cancer 20 years ago and Durenberger said he was seeing a marriage counselor because his second marriage was in trouble. The couple remains married. He also said he was affected by severe financial problems, caused in part by educational expenses for his four sons. The chairman of the Senate Republican Caucus said Durenberger's committee assignments and other duties would not be affected by the Senate action. The major impact on Durenberger is the political fallout in Minnesota, where some newspapers have called on him to resign. Seven members of the Senate have been censured since the first recorded case in 1811. One, Democratic Sen. Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia, was denounced in 1979. Fifteen have been expelled, the most serious punishment. The last major ethics case involved New Jersey Democrat Harrison A. Williams Jr., who resigned in 1982 as his colleagues were about to oust him. In addition to the excess speaking fees, the committee found that Durenberger: _Violated Senate rules and the Ethics In Government Act when he failed to disclose, on public forms, travel reimbursements he received from 43 organizations in 1985 and 1986. _Broke the rules by converting a campaign contribution of $5,000 to his personal use. _Exceeded a rule limiting the value of gifts to $100 annually when he accepted free limousine service during 1985 and 1986 from people or groups interested in legislation. He used the limousines to see his marriage counselor in Concord, Mass. _Conceived a partnership arrangement for his condominium solely to enable him to claim reimbursement for overnight stays. _Structured a purported sale of the condominium to a friend's company and knowingly participated in back dating the transaction to justify claims for reimbursement. Not voting Wednesday were Republican Sens. Larry Pressler of South Dakota and Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming.

DOC.HEAD: First the Slaps, Then Hugs
With AM-Durenberger-Ethics
DOC.TEXT: No sooner had they slapped him down than his colleagues in the Senate lined up to shake Dave Durenberger's hand. ``He could have withered and fallen into self-pity and bitterness,'' said Republican Whip Alan Simpson as the Senate voted 96-0 Wednesday to do what it likes to do least _ punish one of its own. Instead of pitying himself, said Simpson, ``I have seen my friend soften and mature and grow in this terrible process.'' The debate was unusually personal. Several senators referred to Durenberger by his first name. Many spoke of his personal problems _ the death of his first wife, a troubled remarriage, four sons undergoing difficult adolescences, tremendous financial strains _ what Simpson called ``truly hellish experiences.'' Yet there was no flinching from the facts _ that he had violated the Senate's rules by taking money not properly his and trying to conceal his transgressions. Thus, hugs and praise alternated with descriptions of cold-blooded wrongdoing as the Senate struggled with the paradox of the popular Minnesota Republican. His judgment was impaired, his moral compass improperly calibrated when he engaged in questionable condominium and book promotion arrangements, said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., vice chairman of the ethics committee that spent months investigating him. ``I believe him and I sympathize with him.'' Durenberger, 55, sat nearly impassively as his transgressions were aired for three hours. He heard himself accused of willfully evading rules and casting a pall on the institution, and in the next breath labeled creative, decent, effective and influential. When it was all over, he said he was a better man and a better senator; he would work even harder, shoulder more responsibility. ``I ask your forgiveness,'' he said. ``I need your friendship.'' There seemed little doubt he would get both. ``Everybody who has spoken has made it so clear that they like and admire Dave Durenberger,'' said Sen. Bill Armstrong, R-Colo. ``After this is all over and we denounce him, we still want him to be our friend.'' The Senate was unusually full, with all committee business suspended for the proceeding. The many who spoke said they did not relish their task. ``I feel a special sense of discomfort,'' said Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell, noting he has worked closely with Durenberger for years on health care and environmental issues. But Rudman added that Durenberger's conduct could not be excused on that basis. And Durenberger, staring intently at him from across the aisle, nodded in agreement. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said Durenberger had ``approached this ordeal with just about as much grace and resolve to reform as I have witnessed in anybody in my life.'' He said Durenberger's predecessor _ Hubert Humphrey _ ``would be hugging Dave and I intend to after this ordeal is over.'' He did, as did Simpson. Others patted Durenberger on the shoulder as they engaged in long, intense handshakes. Some senators said they thought the trauma _ both Durenberger's and their own in having to sit in judgment of him _ would produce positive results. ``Sometimes hard times bring people together,'' said Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., a member of the ethics panel. He said the Senate has not always been congenial lately but ``today I sense a sense of feeling together, a sense of closeness and a sense of brotherhood.'' And Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., predicted the stressful events would deepen ``the personal relationships which Dave Durenberger has forged with so many of us.'' He summed up the paradox this way: ``As senators we must unflinchingly exercise the judgment which is required. ... As a human being I remain a steadfast friend of Dave Durenberger's and an admirer of the legislative work he has accomplished.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Ethiopian Rebels Subjecting Millions To Possible Starvation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``The ship,'' ship at Djibouti; U.N. statement
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Wednesday accused Eritrean rebels of recklessly exposing about 2 million of their own people to possible starvation by refusing to reopen an Ethiopian port to relief food. ``Their behavior is as reckless as it is inexplicable,'' the department said in a statement read by deputy spokesman Richard Boucher at the daily press briefing. On Tuesday, the United Nations abandoned efforts to reopen the port of Massawa through which it hoped to ferry food for about 4 million people. On Monday, after four weeks of negotiations, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLP) denied permission to a U.N. vessel to enter the harbor to conduct a survey. ``This action was taken despite repeated public pronouncements by the insurgents that they would welcome and facilitate a reopening of the port under U.N. auspices,'' the State Department said. The statement said the rebels were endangering the lives of some 2 million Eritreans they claim to represent. ``We hope that the EPLF will re-evaluate its decision to turn back the U.N. vessel and restate unambiguously its unconditional willingness to facilitate an international effort to reopen Massawa for relief shipments.'' The ship arrived Wednesday in Djibouti about 350 miles to the southeast at the entrance to the Red Sea, said a U.N. spokesman in New York, Paul Mitchell. It will remain there for a few days, said the U.S. Agency for International Development. Another U.N. spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said the ``suspension of the mission means that the famine-stricken and war-affected population of Eritrea will be deprived of essential humanitarian assistance vital for their survival.'' On Capitol Hill, meanwhile, Rep. Tony P. Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, called the rebels' refusal ``a betrayal.'' Hall said, ``Sadly, starvation is still being used as a weapon in Ethiopia. The EPLF lied not only to us but to their own people.'' Last Spring, forces of President Haile Mengistu Mariam blocked relief by bombing the Red Sea port to strike against the insurgents who were holding it. The Eritrean rebels, seeking independence from Ethiopia, are locked in a civil war with the central government. In May, President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, acting on a pledge by Mengistu to stop attacking the port, agreed to cooperate in helping the hungry in Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Group Calls for NIKE to Provide More Minority Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Operation PUSH announced Wednesday the civil rights organization would pressure Nike Inc. and other athletic shoe companies to provide more jobs for minorities and women. PUSH founder Jesse Jackson says organization officials hope to meet in 10 days with representatives of Nike of Beaverton, Ore., to discuss the company's hiring and promotion practices and to prod the company to use more advertising agencies and banks owned by minorities. ``We are the margin of profit for the athletic shoe industry and we want our fair share of jobs and investments in banks,'' said Jackson. ``We seek to meet to redefine our relationship. Right now, its unbalanced and unfair.'' PUSH director Tyrone Crider said that from 30 percent to 40 percent of all basketball shoes sold in the United States are bought by blacks. He said Nike was selected as the first shoe company to negotiate with because it was the biggest, commanding 54 percent of the basketball shoe market. Liz Dolan, spokeswoman for Nike said her company is ``well within federal guidelines'' for minority hiring. ``No company has done more to promote positive black role models to the public than we have,'' she said. The company's ads feature filmmaker Spike Lee, basketball star Michael Jordan, football and baseball star Bo Jackson and other black celebrities. Dolan said she had no figures on black representation in the company. Jackson and Crider did not say what percentage of minorities they thought the company should be hiring. Speaking to reporters at the end of PUSH's four-day national convention in Chicago, Jackson the issue of inner-city youths killing each other over tennis shoes and other athletic wear would not be brought up in the negotiations with the companies. ``That's another question,'' he said. ``They are being shot with bullets. Nobody has ever been shot with a gym shoe.'' Some critics have attacked Lee, Jordan and others for doing the shoe ads, saying they promote an obsession with the expensive products in poor minority communities. Shoe company manufacturers say the inner-city is not where most of the shoes are bought. Crider said a letter was sent by fax machine Wednesday to Philip H. Knight, Nike founder and chief executive officer, asking for a meeting and suggesting it take place next week in Chicago when the athletic shoe industry holds its national trade show. But Dolan said, ``PUSH hasn't contacted us at all.'' In the past, PUSH _ People United to Service Humanity _ has pressed the automobile, beverage and fast-food industries to hire more minorities. Jackson said PUSH would call for demonstrations and, possibly, boycotts if the athletic shoe industry did not respond to demands during negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Durenberger-Ethics a0752
DOC.TEXT: The vote Wednesday to denounce Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., was one of three levels of punishment senators can receive. The most serious sanction is expulsion. Durenberger received the next highest punishment, passage of a resolution condemning a senator's behavior. The Senate can write such a resolution as it pleases, using such words as ``condemn,'' ``denounce'' or ``censure,'' and they all amount to pretty much the same thing. The mildest form of punishment is a letter of criticism sent to the senator by the Ethics Committee. Such a case does not involve action by the full Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Stays Execution; Cites Chair Malfunction
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court issued a temporary stay late Wednesday just 12 hours before condemned killer Anthony Bertolotti was to be executed. A federal judge earlier had rejected arguments that Florida's electric chair is malfunctioning and denied his appeal. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta ordered the stay until 7 p.m. Friday. The three-judge panel, which has held up the execution of five other Florida inmates based on arguments of a malfunctioning electric chair, said it would hear oral arguments Friday. Bertolotti had been scheduled to die at 7 a.m. Thursday, but after the stay was issued state officials rescheduled his execution for 7:01 p.m. Friday. Earlier Wednesday, U.S. District Judge G. Kendall Sharp agreed with arguments from the state that a special test conducted on the chair Monday ``show that at least 2,000 volts can be conducted through the system ... and 2,000 volts are sufficient to cause painless termination of life.'' The judge ruled after a one-day hearing on the single issue of whether the chair could carry out an execution without causing ``cruel and unusual punishment'' to the condemned man. Sharp said the chair had operated successfully since the John Spenkelink execution in 1979 except for the May 4 electrocution of Jesse Tafero. When Tafero was executed, flames and smoke were seen rising from his head. Attorneys for other condemned killers have claimed that a broken electrode in the headpiece had tortured the inmate to death. Sharp, the District Court judge, agreed with state findings that an artificial sponge placed under the head electrode for the first time had caused the botched execution of Tafero. He added that ``it is unlikely that the circumstances of Jesse Tafero will happen again.'' Michael S. Morse, a biological engineer and teacher at Auburn University who conducted tests of the chair on Monday, said there was no indication of any flaw in the Florida State Prison execution system. A videotape of the public test conducted Monday was shown in court and in it, Morse says: ``I would say it is safe to conclude that the electric chair works as it is supposed to ... there is no question that this system is as lethal as any out there.'' But Fred Leuchter, who designs and builds execution systems for many states, disagreed sharply with Morse's testimony. ``The test was absolutely useless,'' Leuchter said. Noting that Morse had used a colander and a metal pipe for the test, Leuchter said: ``If the state of Florida gets an executee in the chair with a colander for a head and metal pipe for a leg, they would have an execution.'' Later, Leuchter said, ``the state of Florida is going to produce a living vegetable if it is allowed to continue executions.'' Leuchter and attorneys for other inmates contend that a broken electrode caused the problems with the Tafero execution and that the chair has not been fixed or modified since. Bertolotti's death warrant _ his third _ is good until Monday. The 38-year-old Bertolotti was sentenced to death for the fatal stabbing of Carol Ward in her home in Orange County in September 1983. His execution originally was scheduled for 7 a.m. Tuesday, but he got a 48-hour stay from the state Supreme Court Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: No Leak of Unemployment Figures Found
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department said Wednesday it could find no evidence of a leak of unemployment statistics earlier this month. The department's investigation was triggered by a report that about a minute and a half before release of the June figures by its Bureau of Labor Statistics on July 6, one trader sold bond futures heavily on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``We looked into it. We have no evidence that there was a leak,'' said spokesman Bob Zachariasiewicz. The department gives its monthly unemployment data to news organizations at 8 a.m. on condition that it not be made public until 8:30 a.m. This practice, called an embargo, gives reporters a chance to digest the material before they must write their stories. Some other departments, such as Commerce and Agriculture, release sensitive economic statistics to reporters in a locked room and then let them out all at the same time _ a ``lockup'' release. Zachariasiewicz said the department receives allegations of premature release from time to time, and ``we're continuously reviewing our procedures, but as far as this incident is concerned this appears to be the end of it.'' He said the department could not even pin down how the report of a leak originated, but: ``It appears some broker or analyst was speculating to explain a market fluctuation.'' The department has discussed ``possible changes in procedures with different physical facilities,'' in other words, a lockup of its own, ``but I don't foresee that we'll ever have the facilities.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Lawmakers: Hold Line On Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush pleaded with lawmakers Wednesday to spare the defense budget from cuts even deeper than the $18 billion already targeted by the Senate Armed Services Committee. Bush urged key lawmakers on both congressional armed services committees to press ahead with production of the B-2 bomber and other major new weapons. The House is considering halting production of radar-evading jets, which cost more than $800 million apiece. The defense session came as Bush administration officials and Republican congressional leaders agreed to a deficit-cutting proposal they plan to present to Democrats at budget negotiations. The package consists of slightly more than $50 billion in savings, split roughly evenly between new taxes and spending cuts, according to Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., and others. It would save more than $500 billion over five years, relying heavily on cuts in benefit programs such as Medicare, said one participant who asked to not be identified. But it was unclear when the offer would be made. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that at either Thursday's or Friday's meeting, both sides will ``simultaneously'' put proposals on the table for cutting $50 billion from the deficit next year and $500 billion over five years. But Democratic budget bargainers disputed that, saying no decision had been made on exchanging offers. ``That is so silly,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., told reporters the two sides have tentatively agreed to extend from 1993 to 1995 the Gramm-Rudman deadline for balancing the budget. Gephardt said major differences in defense levels is a major hang-up in reaching an overall budget compromise. Bush and the leaders discussed entitlement programs _ Social Security, Medicare and other programs for the poor and elderly _ and ``both sides are troubled'' by the magnitude of cuts that might be needed in those areas, Gephardt said. Despite Bush's earlier agreement that the government must pull in more tax revenues, ``nobody wants to raise taxes. ... It's very hard to put the final package together,'' the Democratic leader said. After the defense session, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., the House Armed Services Committee chairman, lamented that Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney still ``have in mind a much bigger defense budget than I think is going to come out of this process.'' Aspin announced Monday he favors halting production of the B-2 now that the first 15 bombers in development. Bush wants to build the fleet of 75. Aspin's Senate counterpart, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., who favors continued production, said afterwards, the B-2 ``has an uphill fight if it's going to survive.'' Aspin's committee is aimng to cut $24 billion from Bush's request for $307 billion for the Pentagon for fiscal 1991. Fitzwater said Bush called the meeting to express concern about ``inordinate cuts.'' Despite improved relations, the Soviet Union remains the United States' adversary, said Fitzwater. He quoted Bush as saying, ``There have been few changes in Soviet strategic forces. ... They are continuing to modernize their entire force, and will enter the START negotiations fully modernized.'' Cheney told the lawmakers that the House cuts would force the Pentagon to absorb personnel cuts of 250,000 in the first year, cutting back nearly four army divisions and 25 ships. ``We think that is unreasonable,'' Fitzwater said. Bush said at a Strategic Air Command base in Cheyenne, Wyo., last Friday that he wanted ``to hold the line at the already painful reduction of the defense budget set down by the Senate Armed Services Committee.'' That panel, chaired by Nunn, approved a $289 billion defense bill last week that would cut nearly $1 billion from Bush's $4 billion Strategic Defense Initiative request and remove 100,000 troops from active duty, including 50,000 from Europe. Nunn said after the meeting, ``We can save some very substantial sums over five years and do it prudently,'' trimming $180 billion to $200 billion from defense. ``The first year we can save about 20 percent responsibly. ...'' Nunn said. ``Over five years we can save about 35 percent of that total of $500 billion.'' But if too much is cut the first year, ``you end up wrecking the personnel system (and) demoralizing not only those who will be forced out of the military ... but those who are left,'' Nunn warned.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Peace Negotiators Try for Human Rights Accord
DOC.TEXT: Government and rebel leaders of El Salvador struggled to reach agreement on human rights issues on Wednesday in an overtime session of their peace talks in this Costa Rican capital. Talks began Friday and were to end Tuesday. When the two sides got nowhere on the issue of reforming the military, however, negotiators decided to move on to human rights in an attempt to make some tangible progress. The main objective of the talks is to reach a cease-fire in the decade-long civil war that has killed 72,000 people in the small Central American country. Oscar Santamaria, the justice minister and chief of the government delegation, said both sides are agreeable to U.N. human rights monitoring. ``The position of the government is that there will be a state institution that supervises human rights and that it will be monitored by the United Nations,'' Santamaria told The Associated Press. However, the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front wants the human rights commission to be run by the United Nations. ``Our position is that it should be a U.N. mission that oversees human rights, because if it's the government's, that will take away its effectiveness,'' rebel negotiator Schafik Handal, the senior guerrilla commander, told the AP. In El Salvador, rebels took over a small, rural community to explain to residents the status of the talks in Costa Rica. ``A man who looked like a peasant, with his M-16 on his shoulder, told us that if there are no concrete agreements they will launch another offensive on the capital, which could be worse than the one on Nov. 11,'' said Jaime Tejada, a resident of San Francisco Morazan, 45 miles north of the capital, San Salvador. The guerrillas talked of such an offensive before the discussions began to pressure the government to negotiate changes in the military. The November offensive was the largest in the history of the war, claiming 2,000 lives. This is the third round of talks this year aimed at ending the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Juan Corona Will Talk About Grisly Murders of 20 Years Ago, Lawyers Says
DOC.TEXT: Convicted mass murderer Juan Corona has decided to admit at a parole board hearing that he hacked 25 migrant workers to death in 1971, his lawyer said Wednesday. ``He indicated that he is going to be willing to talk about it,'' said Don Condren, who will represent Corona at his Aug. 1 parole hearing. ``At least he was when I spoke with him three weeks ago.'' Corona, 56, has spoken a little bit more openly about the crime recently, Condren said in an interview from his home at Carmel Valley, south of San Francisco. He refused to elaborate. Corona, a native of Mexico and a former farm labor contractor, was convicted of mass murder in 1973. The remains of 25 people, many of them immigrants, were unearthed from farm land near Yuba City, 120 miles northeast of San Francisco. Most of the bodies showed signs of mutilation and torture. Corona's first conviction was overturned in 1982 by an appeals court, which ruled his defense had been inadequate. At his second trial that year, he was again convicted of murder and sentenced to 25 years for each count. Mexican consular official Jesus Rodriguez Navarro testified at Corona's second trial that in 1978 Corona had confessed to him, saying ``I'm a sick man, and a sick man cannot be judged as the rest of them.'' An appeals court later ruled the reported confession should not have been accepted as evidence. Corona has never admitted to the killings in a public proceeding. He has been denied parole twice, in 1984 and 1987. Officials based their last refusal on what the called ongoing mental instability and the horrible nature of his crimes. Corona works in the cafeteria at Soledad prison and has attended weekly meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous for five years, said prison spokesman Jerry Smith. But he rarely speaks during the meetings and has lost interest in hobbies and reading, Condren said. ``Right now I don't think he's doing very much. A lot of people down there, they vegetate,'' Condren said. Condren described his client as ``very, very polite,'' and someone who no longer is a threat to society. Corona had hoped eventually to go to his mother's farm in Mexico, but she died in April, Condren said. ``Now he has no real ambitions. No training. All he can do is agricultural work. He feels like that's all he knows.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: Won't Open Dialogue on Disputed Kuril Islands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third graf pvs `Parliament speaker' to UPDATE with him being a political power in lower house of parliament. Picks up 4th pvs, `Gorbachev replied ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail Gorbachev refused to open a dialogue on the disputed Kuril islands during a meeting Wednesday with the speaker of Japan's parliament, Tass reported. The group of islands, stretching north from the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido, were seized by Soviet troops in the final days of World War II, and the dispute has kept Japan and the Soviet Union from signing a peace treaty to formally end the war. Yoshio Sakurauchi, speaker of the powerful lower house of parliament, or Diet, said at the meeting Wednesday in the Kremlin that it was his duty to raise the issue of the Kurils, Tass reported. Gorbachev replied that no one in the Soviet Union would say it holds the territory of other nations, according to Tass. ``All this is confirmed by postwar documents. It was a severe war for all countries. International decisions were made on the basis of the postwar realities and we abide by them,'' the official news agency quoted him as saying. ``I do not want to launch a discussion today on the issue that was repeatedly discussed with representatives of Japan,'' Gorbachev said, according to Tass. ``I can repeat today: We do not have a territorial issue.'' Sakurauchi, who was leading a parliamentary delegation on a visit to Moscow, said there was a ``new age'' in the Pacific region, Tass reported, and he added: ``We are prepared to pay heed to the Soviet public's view on all issues, but I think you, too, should take into account the Japanese public's opinion.'' The issue was raised during the June summit between Gorbachev and President Bush, but the Soviet leader reportedly would not budge. Bush has been quoted as saying he will continue to support Japan's position in the dispute. Gorbachev told Sakurauchi he hoped for constructive dialogue on other issues, Tass said. ``We favor good relations but, regrettably, they are not notable for dynamics today,'' it quoted Gorbachev as saying. ``Possibly, we will understand each other better with time.''

DOC.HEAD: AWOL Intelligence Analysts Face Discipline
DOC.TEXT: Six soldiers charged with going AWOL from their intelligence unit for what a friend described as a rendezvous with UFOs could lose pay and rank under disciplinary terms offered Wednesday by the Army. The six were reported missing from their units in Augsberg, West Germany, on July 9 and arrested in Gulf Breeze, Fla., four days later. They were offered the ``non-judicial punishment'' after an investigation failed to find evidence of espionage, said Major Ron Mazzia, a spokesman for Fort Knox, where they were being held. The soldiers were given three days to consider the proposed disciplinary action and could later be discharged, Mazzia said. It was still unclear why the six, all from the 701st Military Intelligence Brigade in Augsberg, traveled to Florida. Stan Johnson of Bybee, Tenn., said the oldest member of the group, Specialist Kenneth G. Beason, 26, told him they had been ``chosen by ... divine intervention to help prepare for the end of the world, which was supposed to occur in about eight years from now. ... ``They were going to Florida to kick off preparations,'' said Johnson, a friend of Beason's for several years who picked him up at the Knoxville, Tenn., airport on arrival from Germany. ``The real interesting part of this,'' Johnson said, ``was that when the second coming of Christ occurred, Jesus Christ was going to arrive in a spaceship.'' Gulf Breeze, a beach town near Pensacola where Beason and others in the group received training, has been the site of many reported UFO sightings. Besides Beason, those charged were identified as Pfc. Michael Hueckstaedt, 19, of Farson, Wyo.; Pfc. Kris Perlock, 20, of Osceola, Wis.; Pfc. William Setterberg, 20, of Pittsburgh; Specialist Vance Davis, 25, of Valley Center, Kan.; and Sgt. Annette Eccleston, 22, of Hartford, Conn. Capt. Kenneth Hicks of the Gulf Breeze police said that when he questioned Hueckstaedt and Eccleston, neither spoke of religion or UFOs. ``Really the only thing they said is they were heading out West and they were just going to kind of live out in the woods _ kind of like a survivalist group,'' Hicks said. They mentioned Santa Fe, N.M., and Texas, he said. Mazzia said the soldiers were AWOL for varying amounts of time, but the longest was seven days. The specific terms of the punishment, if they accept i, will be determined by an officer acting almost as a sentencing judge. The soldiers could lose pay or rank or both, and could be fined or given extra duty, Mazzia said. As they have lost their top-security clearances, the soldiers would have to be retrained for other Army assignments, Mazzia said. Instead, they could be discharged from the Army. But no discharge recommendation could be made until after the disciplinary action over the AWOL charges is complete, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Southeast Farmers Look to More Rain to Help Drought-Stricken Crops
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks of rain helped save some of the Southeast's parched soybean, cotton and peanut crops, but farm experts warned that without more rain soon, disastrous losses are still likely. The National Weather Service said significant rainfall for the region is unlikely in the next two weeks, although spotty afternoon and evening thundershowers will continue. Six weeks of hot, dry weather, with temperatures hovering around 100 degrees, destroyed corn in Georgia and North Carolina and threatened peanuts and soybeans throughout the region. Soybeans are vital to farmers in Tennessee, and about half the nation's peanuts are grown in Alabama and in Georgia, where they are the main crop. Larry Snipes of the Georgia Agricultural Statistics Service said crop conditions are improving after storms over the last two weeks raised the month's rainfall totals to almost normal _ 4.08 inches. In July, officials said parts of the state were 6 inches below normal for the year. ``We're a lot more optimistic now than we were two weeks ago,'' said Carl Cross, a statistician for the North Carolina Department of Agriculture. ``If we get normal precipitation for the remainder of the season, we could still have some good crops before the end of the season.'' In North Carolina, June rainfall averaged about 3 inches below normal, South Carolina was 2 to 5 inches below, and Tennessee had accumulated a 9.14-inch shortage since Jan. 1. The rain came too late for corn. The Georgia Farm Bureau said 100 percent of the state's dry land corn crop was lost, and irrigated production _ a tiny portion of the crop _ would be reduced because of poor pollination and heat stress. Cross said that in North Carolina, corn also was in the early stages of pollination when hot, dry weather arrived, causing reduced yields and, in some areas, the loss of the entire crop. But in Tennessee, the wet spring may have saved corn from the dry summer. Soggy conditions in April and May delayed the planting period, meaning corn hadn't reached critical growth stages when the dry spell began, said USDA statistician Ron Brantner. ``Had it been on schedule, we would have lost some corn yield,'' Brantner said. ``As it turned out, we did get some rains in time, so the corn crop is looking about normal right now.'' Much cotton and tobacco survived the baking temperatures, with tobacco markets recording good opening prices. North Carolina is predicting a record $1 billion crop. Peanuts _ Georgia's top crop at $500 million _ and soybeans were helped by the rain, but they need more to survive critical blooming and pegging stages. ``This is a critical state,'' Georgia Agricultural Commissioner Tommy Irvin said. ``When the soil gets so hot, the peg comes out of the vine and burns off instead of setting in the soil and (forming) the nut.'' In South Carolina, climatologist John Purvis said soybeans ``were suffering badly.'' ``Hay is in bad shape, but the rain has helped prospects for second or third crops,'' he added. Alabama crops have fared better than surrounding states, said Joel Moore, a federal agriculture statistician in Montgomery. Although a dry spell earlier this month threatened the state's corn, with recent rain the crop now is classified as 52 percent fair, 33 percent good and 12 percent excellent.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Supported Obscenity Case, Voted to Allow Hospital Abortions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS antepenultimate graf, which is 3rd bullet graf: ``_Successful defense,'' to CORRECT ``with parole'' to ``without parole''
DOC.TEXT: As New Hampshire's attorney general, Supreme Court nominee David Souter supported obscenity cases against Penthouse magazine, its local distributor and a pharmacy that sold its July 1976 ``Bisextennial'' issue. Court records show Souter's office successfully fought an attempt by Penthouse and other defendants to quash the indictments on jurisdictional grounds and also defended a state law that included any touching of a person's buttocks in its definition of sexual conduct. The Penthouse case was one of dozens the state argued before New Hampshire's supreme court during Souter's two years as attorney general. The records, reviewed Wednesday, show that Souter's office supported a tough law-and-order approach and positions on evidence rulings favorable to prosecutors. On another subject Wednesday, Concord Hospital said that in February 1973 Souter was a member of the board of trustees that voted to allow the hospital to perform abortions. The subject of abortion, perhaps the most emotional and divisive the Supreme Court addresses each year, is expected to figure prominently in senators' questioning of Souter at confirmation hearings in September. Concord Hospital President Richard Warner had said Tuesday that abortion never came before the board when Souter was a member and later its president. But on Wednesday, Warner said through a spokeswoman that while reviewing minutes of meetings held before he came to the hospital in 1975 he came across the minutes of the 1973 meeting. Doctors had requested adoption of the policy statement because of the month-old Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, Roe vs. Wade. Included in the statement, and still in effect, was a stipulation that hospital employees could refuse to assist with abortions. Dean Williamson, who was among the 45 trustees at the time, said Wednesday he recalls only a brief discussion of the issue and said he believed it was adopted on a voice vote without dissent. ``I don't recall any emotional debate,'' he said. Williamson said he had no recollection of Souter speaking on the issue. Another trustee, Marily Wilson, also said she could not recall Souter speaking. ``This was a medical procedure vote, not a social issues vote,'' she said. ``It was not over he rights or wrongs of abortion but rather about our responsibility as a medical facility in light of the law.'' On another issue Wednesday, The Union Leader in Manchester reported that in a 1976 college commencement speech, Souter, then state attorney general, attacked rigid federal affirmative action guidelines as ``affirmative discrimination'' and added, ``There are some things government cannot do.'' As for the Penthouse issue, the obscenity case was brought by a county prosecutor against Penthouse International, its New Hampshire distributor and a Manchester pharmacy. Penthouse and the pharmacy challenged the indictment on grounds the state had no jurisdiction to charge them because their parent corporations were not based in New Hampshire. The distributor, Manchester News, mounted a separate challenge on grounds the state's obscenity law was unconstitutional. The trial judge rejected those challenges and his rulings were appealed to the state supreme court where, by law, the attorney general represents county prosecutors in all appeals. Souter was listed on the state briefs in the high court cases. He did not personally argue the cases but approved the positions taken by his office. The court refused to throw out charges against Manchester News but did declare unconstitutional the portion of the state obscenity law that included ``any touching of the genitals, pubic areas or buttocks of the male or female or the breasts of the female'' in its definition of sexual conduct. Souter's office had filed a legal brief supporting that law. In the end, charges were brought to trial only against Penthouse, and the trial ended in a deadlocked jury. A quick review of the cases Souter's office argued before the New Hampshire Supreme Court turned up none that he argued personally. But the positions taken by the office were endorsed by him and often mirrored approaches he took later as a judge on the state's Superior and Supreme Court. Among the cases were: _Successful opposition by Souter's office to an appeal of an assault conviction by a man who argued that graphic slides showing the 16-month-old victim's injuries were too prejudicial to be allowed as evidence. _A successful argument by Souter's office that a murder conviction should not be overturned on grounds prosecutors failed to tell the defense the state had promised the key prosecution witness a new name after the trial. _Successful defense of state laws setting mandatory sentences of life without parole. In one 1978 case, two convicts had challenged the laws on grounds that he state Legislature lacked the authority to pass them and that such penalties amounted to cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the U.S. Constitution. _An unsuccessful attempt to bring state charges to trial against a man who had been acquitted of federal bank robbery charges after two hung juries. The high court said the state attempt amounted to double jeopardy. _A lost appeal in a case in which two men committed to psychiatric facilities after being charged with sex offenses challenged judges' orders extending their commitments. Souter's office argued such findings were sufficient to keep the men in the institutions, but the court ruled the state needed to prove the men posed a danger to society.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Pleads No Contest; Two Other Charges Dismissed, Coverup Alleged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD detail on dispute over blood test, Hazelwood comment.
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard dismissed charges of drunkenness and misconduct against Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood on Wednesday, but suspended his license as a ship's master. At an administrative hearing, Hazelwood pleaded no contest to two allegations stemming from the wreck of the tanker, which unleashed the nation's worst oil spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound. The plea that resulted in a nine-month license suspension covered two allegations: that he violated Coast Guard policy by drinking liquor less than four hours before taking command of the Exxon Valdez, and that he improperly leaft the vessel's bridge while it was headed for jagged Bligh Reef. The Coast Guard dismissed a charge that Hazelwood was intoxicated, with a blood alcohol level over 0.04 percent, the Coast Guard standard for operating a vessel. Also dismissed was a charge that he left an improperly licensed third mate in control of the ship. The Coast Guard proceeding was administrative rather than criminal; the only penalty that could be imposed involved Hazelwood's license. During arguments, Hazelwood's attorney, Michael Chalos, disclosed that the defense recently obtained documents indicating that the blood alcohol test taken 10{ hours after the spill was mishandled and unreliable. ``We now know that the alcohol test was invalid at best and bogus at worst,'' Chalos told the judge. ``This man should never have been put through this ordeal.'' The 987-foot tanker's hull was ripped open when it plowed into the reef the night of March 24, 1989, spilling nearly 11 millions of Alaska crude into Prince William Sound in the nation's worst oil spill. Hazelwood, of Huntington, N.Y., was previously acquitted of intoxication charges by the Alaska jury, which also found him innocent of recklessness but convicted him on a misdemeanor of negligently discharging oil. He was ordered to pay $50,000 restitution and spend 1,000 hours cleaning beaches at Prince William Sound. He is appealing. At the time of the accident, the Exxon Valdez was en route from the Alaskan port of Valdez to Long Beach when it struck the charted reef. Long Beach also is headquarters of the 11th Coast Guard District, which includes Alaska. At the Coast Guard hearing, Administrative Law Judge Harry Gardner suspended Hazelwood's master's license for 12 months, but reduced that by three months because the license, issued in 1966, has been held by the Coast Guard since the accident. Gardner told Hazelwood it was his duty to remain on the bridge of the Exxon Valdez until it had finished a crossing into Prince William Sound. ``It is difficult to understand why you were not on the bridge until you executed the turn,'' the judge said. ``I'm sure you have agonized over this during the last 16 months and I agree with your counsel that you have been through quite an ordeal. Hopefully this will make you an even better master in the future.'' Gardner said he concluded the grounding of the Exxon Valdez was the result of human error, citing the actions of the third mate and the helmsman who were on the bridge when the accident occurred. They have not been charged with violations. Hazelwood, 43, left the Coast Guard headquarters looking solemn. He said, ``I'm just glad this portion is over.'' He was engulfed in a crowd of reporters and camera crews as he left. His attorneys contended the newly found blood-test documents raised doubts that the blood tested was Hazelwood's. The documents showed that the Sacramento laboratory which tested the blood received three 10-millimeter tubes of blood with red stoppers. This report conflicted with testimony in National Transportation Safety Board hearings by the Coast Guard officer who took the blood. The officer said it was placed in three tubes, but only one had a red stopper _ the others were gray. To complicate matters, the defense got the laboratory's own copy of the document three days ago, and found it had been altered to conform to the NTSB hearing testimony. Another Hazelwood lawyer, Thomas Russo, said gray-stoppered tubes ones held blood with a chemical preservative to prevent it from fermenting and producing its own alcohol. The red-stoppered tubes hold blood without the preservative and are used for tests of drugs, but not alcohol. ``It's what we said all along and nobody would listen to us,'' Hazelwood said after the hearing. ``The possible skullduggery that goes along with it is enough to make anybody angry. A receptionist at ChemWest Analytical Laboratories in Sacramento, where the sample was analyzed, said Wednesday she was told to tell reporters her company would have no comment and referred all questions to the Coast Guard. Chalos and and Russo, said they believed the tardy disclosure of the alcohol records constituted misconduct by both the Coast Guard and the National Transportation Safety Board, which had access to the documents. Chalos and Russo said the papers were wrongly withheld from them before Hazelwood's criminal trial in Alaska. ``We had no actual physical control of any of the toxicological specimens,'' the NTSB said in a statement released Wednesday. It said the two laboratories which tested the blood were certified under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and the results provided the NTSB ``were identified as those of Capt. Joseph Hazelwood.'' At a news conference, Cmdr. Chris Desmond insisted that the Coast Guard did not drop the alcohol charge against Hazelwood because of the conflict over blood evidence. ``I want you to understand that the Coast Guard was above-board in these proceedings,'' he said. The agency was not aware of the conflicting documents until their agreement with Hazelwood had already been finalized, he said. But Russo followed Desmond and said, ``The Coast Guard position regarding Capt. Hazelwood was rather stern until this information was disclosed. I think the Coast Guard dropped the intoxication charge because they knew they could not prove the intoxication charge.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Calls Off Search for Missing Plane
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Navy has called off an unsuccessful, 12-hour search for an attack bomber and its crew who crashed in the South China Sea, a military spokesman said Thursday. The pilot and navigator were presumed dead. The Grumman A-6E Intruder from the aircraft carrier Independence crashed Tuesday almost 400 miles southwest of Subic Bay naval base while on a night flying operation, said spokesman Lt. Lee Saunders of the 7th Fleet. Subic lies about 50 miles west of Manila. Planes and helicopters from the Independence, the destroyer Goldsborough and the frigate Reasoner joined in the search. Howard Thomas, a spokesman for Whidbey Island Naval Air Station in Washington state, identified the missing pilot as Lt. Cmdr. Jeffrey Mines, 35, of North Bend, Neb.; and the navigator as Lt. Cmdr. Arthur Braun, 37, of Georgetown, Texas. The plane was based at the air station north of Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Passport Stalls Release of Marlon Brando's Son
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's son apparently lost his passport, which must be surrendered to authorities before his release from jail on $10 million bail, his lawyer said Wednesday. Judge Larry Fidler on Tuesday ordered the 32-year-old Brando to stand trial for murder in the shooting of his half-sister's boyfriend. The judge also set bail at $10 million, believed the highest in county history, and said the passport must be surrendered. ``We have been unable to locate the passport of Christian Brando and without it he cannot be released,'' defense attorney Robert Shapiro said. ``Attempts are still being made to locate it.'' Shapiro declined comment on whether the elder Brando had made the $10 million bail. But a bondsman for Bert Potter Bail Bonds said the bail was ready, once the passport turned up. Christian Brando faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted of the murder of Dag Drollet, 26, who was shot with a .45-caliber pistol on May 16 at the elder Brando's home. Arraignment was set for Aug. 7. Police allege Christian Brando shot Drollet during an argument about Brando's accusation Drollet had beaten his sister. The younger Brando also is charged with illegal possession of a machine gun, found when police searched the home.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Acquits New Orleans District Attorney
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, `However, Connick ...' with 2 grafs to include quote from Cole denying bias involved, picks up 19th graf pvs, `Fanning once...; moves up reference to Connick's son; SUBS 7th graf, ```There were ..' to show Burke starred in TV show
DOC.TEXT: District Attorney Harry Connick was acquitted Wednesday of gambling and racketeering charges arising from his return of gambling records to a convicted bookmaker. Actor Paul Burke, former assistant U.S. Attorney Patrick Fanning and New Orleans businessman Wilson Abraham also were acquitted of all charges. All three were charged with racketeering by conducting an illegal gambling enterprise and aiding and abetting a gambling operation. Burke also was charged with perjury. The accused bookmaker, Walton Aucoin, and two of his employees, Steve Bertolino and William Condon, were convicted on two counts each of gambling and racketeering. Connick, the father of Grammy-winning jazz musician Harry Connick Jr, sat quietly, rubbed his teary eyes and folded his hands after the verdict was announced. Several supporters cried, as did one juror. ``I feel fine,'' Connick told reporters outside the courthouse. ``There were no thoughts going through my mind, just feelings,'' said Burke, star of TV's ``The Naked City.'' ``It was like Roman candles going off...I just thank God we have a court system.'' Even before the federal jury returned its innocent verdict, Connick confidently filed qualifying papers Wednesday for a fall election. ``I'm ready to campaign,'' Connick said. ``We've been at this a long time and I'm ready for this to be over.'' The U.S. District Court trial lasted six weeks. The indictment alleged that Connick responded to the urgings of Burke, Fanning and Abraham and illegally returned seized records to Aucoin so the admitted bookie could pay off and collect gambling debts. Aucoin, Bertolino and Condon were accused of running an illegal gambling operation. Connick maintained that Aucoin was entitled to have his gambling records returned under state law. Aucoin said he needed them to pay federal income taxes. Prosecutors said those were merely excuses cooked up by Fanning, Burke and Abraham to help Connick justify the return of the records. The perjury charge against Burke stemmed from testimony he gave before a grand jury. James Cole, of the Justice Department in Washington, said the timing of the return _ just five days after Aucoin was arrested on Dec. 4, 1988 _ was the key to the case. Prosecutors said it would ordinarily take four to six weeks for the records to be returned. The indictment was handed up in December after a year-long investigation begun by U.S. Attorney John Volz. Connick and Volz had sparred for years over various issues and Volz later turned the case over to the Justice Department to avoid any appearance of bias. However, Connick always characterized the charges as part of a political vendetta, which Cole denied. ``I think the evidence that we had warranted the bringing of the case,'' Cole said. ``The decision to bring this case was made by the public integrity section of the Department of Justice .. The U.S. Attorney's office had no part in the decision of whether or not to prosecute this case.'' Fanning, once an assistant to Volz, was Aucoin's lawyer at the time of the 1988 arrest. Burke was an acquaintance of Connick and Aucoin, as was Abraham, a contributor to Connick's political campaigns. Connick, 63, has been district attorney since 1974. The investigation also involved former Gov. Edwin Edwards and a suburban sheriff, Harry Lee of Jefferson Parish, although neither man was indicted. Lee testified in the trial that he once returned gambling records to Aucoin after an arrest and Edwards was widely reported to have called Lee on Aucoin's behalf to urge return of those records.

DOC.HEAD: Murder on the Mystery Train: The Maid Did It
DOC.TEXT: The most frequent of suspects in murder mysteries, the butler, didn't do it this time.
