For release Sunday, July 29
DOC.HEAD: PERSONAL FILE: Flamboyant Frenchman Aims High
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Don't liken him to Donald Trump. Bernard Tapie is indeed wealthy, publicity-hungry and unashamedly ambitious. Yes, he is eying a run for the presidency and has just engineered the biggest deal of an extraordinary career by acquiring an 80 percent stake in Adidas AG, the giant sporting goods company. But Trump, said Tapie in a magazine interview earlier this month, ``is everything I loathed most ... the embodiment of cynicism and bad taste. The things he puts foremost are those that make me the most uneasy.'' Trump-like or not, Tapie has developed the highest public profile of any businessman in France. He owns the country's best soccer team, serves in Parliament, has hosted a television show, and wrote a book about himself titled, ``Gagner'' (``To Win''). Four years ago, women surveyed in a national poll picked Tapie over movie stars and singers as the man they would most like to accompany on a vacation. But Tapie, 47, says he's not content to make money and live the good life. He wants Adidas to expand non-profit sports development programs in Africa. He wants the French public to be more hospitable to immigrants. He wants to command a crusade against Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of France's far-right Nationa Front. It's a desire to be different from Trump, the ego-driven New York developer who made headlines with personal and financial excesses, that compelled Tapie to take on the mission of stopping Le Pen, Tapie told Paris Match magazine. Might he carry this fight all the way to the presidency, the interviewer asked. ``If necessary, yes,'' Tapie replied. ``If you have a chance to take a position of power, to affect the course of events, why not do it?'' Polls show Tapie to be broadly popular across France, and he fine-tunes his image by depicting himself as a populist scorned by the political and business elite. He grew up in a blue-collar Paris suburb and tried an assortment of jobs _ including pop singer _ before establishing himself in the 1970s as one of France's first world-class takeover specialists. He refined a technique of buying up bankrupt or failing companies at nominal prices, improving their efficiency, then selling them for a quick and often substantial gain. He has promised he won't repeat this pattern with Adidas, locked in a battle with Nike Inc. of the United States for the title of world's No. 1 sporting goods maker. The $290 million acquisition followed nine months of secret negotiations, but Tapie made sure the news was spread when the secrecy ended. He announced the purchase in Rome, on the eve of the World Cup soccer championship, to scores of reporters gathered from around the world. It was one of the biggest purchases ever of a West German firm by a Frenchman, and earned nationalistic praise for Tapie even from commentators skeptical about his financial base. Tapie silenced some doubters by listing eight major banks as his backers _ four from France, two from West Germany, two from Japan. An Adidas subsidiary, the Swiss-based firm ISL, serves as marketing consultant for international soccer's governing body, and Tapie has stated openly that he hopes his acquisition will help ensure France's selection as host of the 1998 World Cup. Although it lost money last year, Adidas remains one of the best-known brand names in the world, with products sold in 160 countries. It has 10,000 employees, and its sales and licensing revenues last year totaled about $2.8 billion. It dwarfs the total size of Tapie's industrial empire in France _ a constantly changing assortment of companies involved in such products ranging from weighing machines to health foods. One of his most prized possessions is Olympic Marseille, a soccer team that was foundering before Tapie began spending millions on world-class players. This year, the team reached the semifinals of the European Cup, which determines the continent's best pro team. He previously sponsored teams in the Tour de France, and was the executive force behind Greg LeMond in 1986 when he became the first American to win the world's premier bicycle race. A yachtsman and pilot, Tapie describes sports as one of his three passions, along with business and politics. In December, he took on Le Pen in a nationally televised debate, and was a consensus winner. A subsequent poll indicated 46 percent of French voters would support him for president. He serves in Parliament as an independent, but votes with the governing Socialist Party and is believed to be well-liked by President Francois Mitterrand. Despite his connections, he describes himself as an outsider. ``The class war still exists,'' he told Paris Match, ``I have the whole establishment against me.'' He said Le Pen, who favors the deportation of immigrants, ``capitalizes on the negligence of others.'' ``Me, I've shown I know how to beat him,'' Tapie said. ``The political establishment either doesn't know or doesn't want to.'' Last month, Tapie went on television to announce his latest anti-Le Pen strategy _ a ``Citizens Forum'' which will stage rallies in 400 communities considered strongholds for the far right. He vowed to reduce the National Front's support in the polls from 15 percent to 10 percent. Four years ago, an interviewer asked Tapie what his weak point was. ``I'm always in a state of insecurity,'' he replied. ``When everything is going well, I'm afraid it won't last.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 29

DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan sought to reassure financial markets that the central bank has not abandoned its battle against inflation under some deal to support budget deficit-cutting efforts. Greenspan said Tuesday that the Fed remained intent on acheiving ``within a few years'' its goal of pushing inflationary pressures close to zero. Private analysts saw Greenspan's comments before a House Banking subcommittee as an attempt to remove doubts in the financial markets that the central bank was wavering in its commitment to fighting inflation.

Chicago Mercantile Exchange officials told a Senate panel the system of market ``circuit-breakers'' aimed at curbing steep stock drops functioned well during Monday's plunge. One day after the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 100 points in 90 minutes, leaders of the nation's largest futures exchanges reported favorably Tuesday to the Senate Banking Committee on safeguards set up after the 1987 stock market crash.

Car and light truck sales by the nation's major automakers dropped 13 percent in mid-July compared with last year, when buyers flocked to showrooms to take advantage of incentives, the automakers said. The sales rate during the July 11-20 period last year was among the highest of 1989. Incentives that drew customers into showrooms during the year-ago period were trimmed back by automakers this year. The 10 major U.S. vehicle manufacturers said Tuesday that car sales fell 13.3 percent and truck sales dropped 12.6 percent in the period.

Eastern Airlines and some executives will be indicted on conspiracy and other criminal charges for safety maintenance violations at airports in early 1989, the company said. Martin R. Shugrue, the bankruptcy-court appointed trustee running Eastern, said Tuesday the airline was prepared to admit fraudulent maintenance and record-keeping but not conspiracy. The refusal led to the collapse of plea bargain talks with the U.S. Attorney's Office in Brooklyn.

Americans' wages, salaries and other benefits shot up 5.2 percent over the past year, the government said in a report analysts saw as another sign that inflation is failing to retreat. Much of the increase in employment costs was due to higher benefit expenses, such as rising health-care costs, the Labor Department said Tuesday. Benefit costs alone jumped a sharp 6.9 percent for the 12-month period ending in June, well above the 5.6 percent increase of a year ago.

OPEC ministers began gathering for a critical strategy session that has been overshadowed by Iraqi threats to punish cartel members that exceed their oil production limits. The meeting Wednesday is taking place as oil prices continue a rebound from lows of earlier this year that served to aggravate the political tensions raised by Iraq, especially against neighboring cartel member Kuwait.

A judge ordered Amoco Corp. to pay about $155 million for damages from a massive oil spill by the Amoco Cadiz tanker off northern France in 1978. Amoco officials said Tuesday they would appeal the order, promising to prolong a case that has dragged through the courts for years.

Attorney General Dick Thornburgh complained of the ``unwillingness'' of federal courts to punish savings and loan fraud with long jail terms, but said punishment was becoming tougher. Thornburgh responded Tuesday to criticism from the panel's chairman, Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., who cited FBI statistics showing the average S&L offender in 1989 received a sentence of 1.9 years while the average bank robber was sentenced to 9.4 years.

Congress voted to preserve U.S. sugar policy despite criticism that it is bad for agriculture, consumers, foreign relations and the war on drugs. Both the House and Senate on Tuesday defeated amendments to the 1990 farm bill that would have reduced from 18 cents to 16 cents a pound the price guaranteed to growers. That reduction, said the amendments' sponsors, would have brought the support for sugar more in line with other government farm programs, stopping unfair competition that is leading Midwest wheat producers to fight off buy-out efforts by better-rewarded sugar beet producers.

The stock market steadied Tuesday with the help of a rally in oil issues ignited by speculation about higher petroleum prices. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.82 points to 2,922.52. The dollar weakened against key foreign currencies. Bond prices fell. Soybean futures prices resumed a slide; most corn futures retreated; wheat futures advanced; crude oil futures rose; livestock and meat futures were mostly higher; and precious metals fell.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Regulator Brings First Charges in New York Probe
DOC.TEXT: More than a year after revealing a probe of the New York commodities pits, federal futures regulators have charged four brokers with fraud in handling customer orders. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission accused the four, and a firm owned by one of them, of non-competitively executing crude oil futures trades for customers on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange in lower Manhattan. The four, all registered with the CFTC as floor brokers, were identified as Douglas M. Friedman, of Forest Hills, Queens, N.Y; Michael S. Pomerantz, Scarsdale N.Y.; Lawrence A. Beck, Fort Lee, N.J.; John J. King, Old Bridge, N.J. Also named in the nine-count administrative complaint disclosed Tuesday was MSP Trading Inc. a firm owned by Pomerantz. Pomerantz, King and Beck were accused of deceiving and defrauding customers by taking their orders to buy or sell and then taking the opposite position _ at the customer's expense _ allegedly with Friedman's help. The moves would violate CFTC rules that require a trader to submit customer orders to the general marketplace. ``The investigation is continuing,'' said Dennis Klejna, director of the CFTC's Enforcement Division. He said further charges were ``certainly possible.'' Pomerantz's lawyer, Barry Mandel, and King's lawyer, Ira Lee Sorkin, both in New York said they had not seen the CFTC complaint and therefore could not comment. Lawyers for the other defendants were not in their offices when called for comment Tuesday night. The investigation came to light in May 1989 when the government revealed it was conducting criminal and civil investigations of alleged illegal trading at four New York commodities exchanges. The CFTC complaint alleged that the other three used Friedman, who trades primarily for his own account, to circumvent CFTC rules between July and December 1988. If an administrative law judge rules in favor of the CFTC, the defendants could be subject to penalties ranging from suspension of trading privileges to fines up to $100,000 per violation. The investigations are unrelated to a longstanding probe of Chicago's commodity markets that yielded indictments against 48 people. Sixteen have pleaded guilty to lesser charges. Earlier this month, a federal jury convicted two Swiss franc traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange of relatively minor trading violations and acquitted a third. The jury could not reach verdicts on scores of more serious charges, including a racketeering count against one defendant and mail and wire fraud charges against all three. Federal prosecutors have said they plan to refile the remaining charges against the men, whose sentencings were tentatively scheduled for November.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Exchange: Market `Circuit-Breakers' Worked
DOC.TEXT: Futures trading representatives testifying before a Congressional panel praised so-called circuit breakers for stopping Monday's plunge in the Dow Jones average of industrial stocks. One day after the Dow fell more than 100 points in 90 minutes, leaders of the nation's largest futures exchanges reported favorably to the Senate Banking Committee on safeguards set up after the 1987 stock market crash. ``Yesterday was a very good example of just how well the circuit-breaker functions,'' Leo Melamed, chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, said Tuesday. The Dow drop helped cause a similar decline in the stock-index futures market, where traders bet on the direction of stock prices by buying and selling contracts based on market indexes. The price tumble tripped ``circuit-breakers'' on the Chicago Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, prompting brief trading halts that are designed as safeguards against a market crash. Merc officials, through an automated conference call, stayed in touch with the other future exchanges on Monday, as they have done in previous market drops, an official said before the hearing. Merc President William J. Brodsky said officials had several conversations with New York Stock Exchange President Richard Grasso. Brodsky said the Chicago exchanges also were in touch with federal regulators at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which in turn passed along pertinent information to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees the stock market. ``Yesterday was about as normal as you can expect for something that's not normal,'' said Brodsky. The circuit breakers were put in place to forestall a collapse like that of Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow Jones plummeted more than 500 points. The Dow average of 30 industrial stocks, the most widely watched measure of the stock market's activity, dropped more than 100 points early Monday before regaining about half the loss to close down 56 points. The New York Stock Exchange has asked its member firms for voluntary compliance with a proposed temporary ban on computerized selling tactics when the market rises or falls 50 points. An NYSE request for SEC approval of the voluntary program trading halt proposal during volatile markets is to be taken up by the commission in Washington on Wednesday. Sen. Donald Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, noted the futures markets can be more attractive to traders during a sudden downturn in the market. He said the circuit breakers appeared to be effective Monday, and added: ``It seems to me that in effect that's also an implicit argument that if there were no circuit breakers who knows what kind of races we were off to yesterday.'' Melamed said the circuit-breakers ``allowed the orders to reaccumulate and rethink the situation and, in fact, stoppped the market.'' ``As you know, at the NYSE the market continued to go down long afterward so that it took a while to effect the NYSE cash market, eventually both markets steadied,'' he said. On the Big Board, trading would be suspended for one hour if the Dow falls more than 250 points and two hours after another 150-point drop. The Chicago halts call for a 30-minute stoppage if the Standard & Poor's 500-stock futures contract drops 12 points, the equivalent of about 96 points in the Dow. The contract is not allowed to trade at a lower price during that time period. Melamed and other futures and agricultural group leaders were in Washington to oppose legislation that would strip the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of authority over stock index futures and give it to the SEC. The Bush administration has favored bills calling for such an action, which are pending in both the House and Senate. After the hearing, Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., chairman of the banking panel's securities subcommittee, said there are ``conversations on a compromise'' ongoing although he declined to say which senators were involved. ``I'm not sure it's going to bear any fruit; I'll be candid with you about that,'' Dodd added. He also said that he didn't think the issue of stock index futures was dead in this congressional session.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Panel Finds No Cause to Limit Camera Imports
DOC.TEXT: Keystone Camera Products Corp. cannot blame a flood of cheap foreign imports for its marketplace woes, a U.S. trade panel said as it ruled out tariffs and import quotas. Keystone, of Clifton, N.J., claimed it is the sole remaining American manufacturer of conventional 35mm fixed focus and point-and-shoot cameras, and 110 pocket cameras. On that basis, it asked for trade restraints on imports from Japan, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Mexico, South Korea, Thailand and Brazil. ``Imports of cameras were not a substantial cause of injury to the domestic camera industry,'' the four members of the U.S. International Trade Commission ruled Tuesday. ``Certainly, the quantity of imports as well as the price of the imports had negative effects on the operations of Keystone,'' wrote Commisioner David B. Rohr. ``I am forced to conclude however, that these effects are dwarfed by other factors which have had much more profound negative effects on Keystone.'' In particular, he cited failed marketing strategies and a failed videotape venture. The firm, which produced 2.5 million cameras last year, said the competition could jeopardize the future of 500 manufacturing and distribution jobs in the depressed Clifton-Paterson area of New Jersey. The company said that imports of the types of cameras it produces, increased from 11 million in 1985 to 27.5 million in 1987 _ an increase of 150 percent. Its petition excludes imported disc, single-lens reflex, instant print and imported 110 cameras that are not fixed focus. Myron J. Berman, chairman of Keystone, did not respond to repeated phone calls. Berman had said earlier that without import restrictions, Keystone would be forced to move its production facilities overseas, as other camera makers have done. He said the company already had cut costs to the bone. Keystone still could seek relief by charging that foreign cameras have been dumped in the American marketplace at less than fair-market value, said Betsy Godley, a spokesman for the trade panel. Keystone received support from one member of New Jersey's congressional delegation _ Sen. Bill Bradley _ after it petitioned the International Trade Commission for help on March 29. It received an extra boost from House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and House Majority Whip William H. Gray III of Pennsylvania. Bradley, a Democrat and an opponent of protectionist trade measures, had declined to sign the lawmakers' letter. He sent his own to U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, spokesman Michael Jones had said. Giant camera maker Eastman Kodak Co. of Rochester, N.Y., which said it was not being hurt by imports, had asked the trade commission to uphold free trade and deny relief to Keystone. Kodak argued that Keystone was responsible for its own market troubles. It also had disputed Keystone's claim to be the last bona fide American camera maker.

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Car and Truck Sales Down
With PM-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Car and truck sales fell 13 percent in mid-July compared with a strong results last year, marking a contrast with the gains posted in each of the past two 10-day sales periods. ``I think what you're seeing in these June and July numbers is some buying to take advantage of the incentives before they expire,'' said analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. of New York. Incentives in mid-July of last year pushed up the sales rate. This year, incentives still are in effect, but automakers have been trimming them back as their unsold new-vehicle inventories shrink. The 10 major U.S. vehicle manufacturers said they sold cars and trucks at a combined average daily rate of 34,549 during the July 11-20 period this year compared with a daily average of 39,726 during the same time last year. Car sales fell 13.3 percent and truck sales dropped 12.6 percent. Counted separately, General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said their car sales during the period fell 17.8 percent while sales of cars made by Japanese companies in the United States rose 23 percent. The Big Three held 84.5 percent of the car market during the period while the transplants had the rest. Auto industry observers are looking closely at the sales rates in July after the pace of vehicle sales began picking up in late June. Analysts have said it's too soon to tell if the industry is beginning a rebound as some of them predicted for the second half of 1990. ``I think the market is pointed in that direction,'' said Herb Adcox, owner of Adcox Chevrolet in Chattanooga, Tenn. ``Everyone seems to think that things turned at the last of June and the first week of July. ``The second week of July, it just slowed down. I don't know why,'' he said. So far this year, the car and truck sales pace was running 3.6 percent below last year's, with car sales down 4.8 percent and truck sales off 1.6 percent. During the past two 10-day sales periods, automakers and analysts have been mildly surprised at the strength in the market, given a generally sluggish economy. Analysts have said they want to see how the sales trend runs over a longer period before speculating on what may be driving the market. There have been some early theories that the glut of new cars and trucks bought in the mid-1980s are beginning to age, and owners may be trading them in. Ford said its car sales plunged 24.6 percent in mid-July this year and truck sales fell 10.4 percent. That combined for an 18.8 percent decline in vehicle sales in mid-July. So far this year, Ford's car and truck sales were running 8 percent behind last year's pace. Chrysler's North American-made cars and trucks were selling at a rate 17.2 percent behind last year's clip in mid-July as car sales dropped 17.9 percent and truck sales, which include the company's profitable Jeeps and minivans, fell 16.7 percent. For the year, car and truck sales for Chrysler were running 13.4 percent behind last year's rate. GM said its mid-July vehicle sales were running 13.3 percent behind last year, with car sales dropping 13.4 percent and truck sales falling 13.2 percent. For the year, GM's cars and trucks were selling at a rate 3.6 percent behind last year.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers At Critical Oil Talks; Comment Focuses On Prices, Not Politics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Kuwait, Iranian minister comments. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `The troop ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers today sought a way to boost oil prices and defuse tensions in the Persian Gulf, where Iraq has threatened military action against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for exceeding production quotas. Members declined to discuss Iraq's threats in advance of a meeting of the cartel's eight-member monitoring committee later today. The 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries formally begins its mid-year conference Thursday. Kuwait's new oil minister, Rasheed Salem al-Ameeri, declined to comment on reports that Iraq has massed tens of thousands of troops on its border with Kuwait, or on earlier Iraqi threats. Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh expressed confidence the cartel would agree to increase its target price, now at $18 a barrel, to $20 or more. ``I am in favor of any price that is higher than what we have now,'' Indonesian Oil Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita said upon arrival this morning. Asked about the effect of the Persian Gulf tensions on the meeting, OPEC Secretary-General Subroto said Tuesday, ``We are an economics organization. We talk about economics.'' Saudi Arabian Oil Minister Hisham Nazer said, ``We are here to solve oil problems.'' Even Iraq's oil chief, Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, confined his public remarks to oil prices. He pushed his proposal to lift the cartel's target price to $25 a barrel by cutting OPEC production. He refused to discuss the reports of Iraqi troop movements. The troop movements coincide with threats last week by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to take military action against countries producing oil in excess of their OPEC-set caps. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have stubbornly refused in the past to limit crude output to their quotas. A sharp fall in oil prices in the spring was largely blamed on too much oil on the world market. Saddam claimed Iraq, badly in need of money to repair damage from its 8-year war with Iran, has lost $14 billion in oil revenues during the last year because of falling prices. Iraqi officials also accused Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells in the border area that they claim are in Iraqi territory. Word of the Iraqi troops sent oil prices higher Tuesday. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 6 cents to settle at $20.56 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Chalabi, the Iraqi minister, called for agreement on a higher target price. Libyan Oil Minister Fawzi Shakshuki also said he would like prices to go up to $25 a barrel. But he said the cartel ``would have been there now'' had prices remained at the strong levels posted in January. The average price for seven crudes monitored by the cartel reached $20.46 in early January but plunged to $13.64 a barrel less than six months later. It has since rebounded to $16.25 a barrel. OPEC accounts for major portion of world oil output and a cartel price rise would affect the price at the pump in the United States, which imports about half the oil it consumes. Two OPEC price shocks in the 1970s sent the U.S. economy reeling. But recent OPEC accords _ and prices _ have been undermined by members' departures from their assigned quotas. A confidential report, prepared by OPEC's secretariat in Vienna, was understood to say the value of the cartel's target price has been sharply eroded by inflation and exchange rate fluctuations. According to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity the market report estimated the cartel's target price slipped from about $16 a barrel in January to about $11 last month. To try to pump up prices, the ministers were expected to agree to a proposal worked out by Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf producers to trim output so total production is limited to about 22.5 million barrels a day in the coming months. Nazer said he was confident that OPEC would strike such a deal. The OPEC market report, according to the sources, estimated the group's output at 23.5 million barrels a day in the April-June quarter of the year. Demand for the cartel's oil was estimated to run at 21.8 million barrels a day in the July-September quarter, climbing to 24.4 million barrels in the final three months of last year year, said the sources. Under the Persian Gulf proposal, Kuwait and the U.A.E. would pledge to hold output to 1.5 million barrels a day each. They have each been pumping as much as 2 million barrels a day. Kuwait's quota now stands at 1.5 million barrels a day and the U.A.E.'s at 1.1 million barrels. Under the proposed arrangement, only U.A.E. would see its supply target increase; the other producers would remain at current levels. OPEC's members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the U.A.E. and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were higher at midday Wednesday on London's Stock Exchange as investors worried about British corporate earnings. Shares rose strongly early in the session, but then weakened in thin trading, dealers said. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 10.1 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,371.0, near the morning low of 2,369.4 and off from the high of 2,382.5. Volume came to 270.5 million shares at midday, compared with 233 million shares at the same time Tuesday. Some institutions have been selective buyers of stocks such as food retailers and oil companies, dealers said. They said oil stocks were the most active, underpinned by expectations that the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries which starts Thursday would manage to cut back production and push up crude oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: British Government Clears British Airways Stake in Sabena
DOC.TEXT: The British government on Wednesday cleared British Airways PLC's planned linkup with the Belgian carrier Sabena World Airlines. The European Commission previously objected to the deal. The decision announced Wednesday by Britain's Department of Trade and Ministry follows a British Monopolies and Mergers Commission investigation which found that British Airways' intended 20 percent stake in Sabena wouldn't operate against the public interest. The Sabena deal also calls for KLM Royal Dutch Airways to take a 20 percent stake in the Belgian airline, which would be 60 percent-owned by the Belgian government-controlled parent company Sabena SA. British Airways and KLM were each to pay about $62 million for their stakes. The European Commission, which safeguard's competition in Europe, decided in June that the deal could hurt competition at the Brussels airport, and the original agreement now is to be renegotiated through talks with the EC. The Monopolies and Mergers Commission found in its investigation that British air travelers would benefit from a Brussels-based hub-and-spoke system the airlines want to set up. The joint venture would increase choices available on intercontinental flights, the department quoted the commission as saying. The monopolies commission also found that British Airways and Sabena, currently the only airlines serving Brussels from London's Heathrow airport, would be no more likely than before to raise prices on the route under the new agreement. Pricing on the route is governed by Britain's Civil Aviation Authority. The monopolies commission also found that the CAA would be in a position to restrain Sabena from gaining any future competitive advantage in serving London's other airports from Brussels. The monopolies commission's report made no comment about the EC's findings. However, the department noted that the British government's investigation recognized that the ``greater part of the effects of the arrangements lie outside'' Britain. British Airways, welcoming the department's decision, said it was confident that the EC also would ``respond positively to this pan-European inititiative.''

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose .75 to 2,923.27 in the first half hour of trading. Beyond that, brokers said hopes for lower interest rates were buttressed by a new statistical sign of weakness in business activity. The Commerce Department reported that new factory orders for durable goods fell 3.2 percent in June. DuPont climbed 1\ to 40[ in active trading. The company posted second-quarter profits of $1.02 a share, up from $1 a share in the corresponding period last year. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .12 to 194.57. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 181.92 million shares, down from 209.03 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Toledo, Chrysler Reach Agreement on Jeep Plants
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and local and state officials announced today an agreement to bring more Jeep production and possibly hundreds of jobs to Toledo. Company spokesman Michael Glusac said Chrysler will move production of the Wrangler YJ from Brampton, Ontario, to Toledo starting Jan. 1, 1993. The company also said that if it decides to build the new JJ model, it would be produced in Toledo by 1993. In return, the city and state will provide an incentive package that could total $22.5 million over the next 10 years. ``The agreement meets Chrysler's needs as well as the needs of the city and state for a framework for determining the future of Jeep in Toledo,'' Glusac said at a news conference. ``Market conditions must ultimately govern our decisions about what vehicles we make, where we make them and in what volume. However, the agreement being announced gives us assurances about what Chrysler can expect in the years ahead,'' he said. The company already makes the Jeep Cherokee and Grand Wagoneer in Toledo. Mayor John McHugh said he would ask the City Council to grant Chrysler a 10-year tax abatement on personal property taxes on an estimated $75 million worth of equipment the company expects to install at its two Toledo plants. The equipment would be for production of both vehicles. The city agreed to provide up to $500,000 a year for seven years starting in 1991 for improvements to the plants. The state agreed to provide up to $5 million for retraining workers. ``This is a major triumph for business, labor and government in northwest Ohio,'' Gov. Richard Celeste said. ``In a true partnership, we have worked to extend Chrysler's commitment to produce the Cherokee at the Toledo Jeep facilities. And returning the production of the Wrangler to Toledo will reassure that Chrysler Jeep will continue to play an important economic role in the community.'' The agreement is the final piece of a package that was needed to move Jeep Wrangler production to Toledo from Brampton and keep the two local plants operating beyond 1992. The two plants currently employ 5,300 people. The first part was reached last month when Chrysler reached a seven-year contract with United Auto Workers Local 12. The contract contained a number of work rule changes to make the plants more efficient. However, Chrysler said it would not move Wrangler production to the city until an agreement was reached on an incentive package. In April, several Toledo area officials, including U.S. Rep. Marcy Kaptur and Mayor John McHugh, said Chrysler would move the Wrangler and build a new Jeep line in Toledo, which would create between 1,200 and 1,600 jobs. While Chrysler officials told Local 12 the Wrangler would be coming to Toledo, the company said it was re-evaluating plans to build the ``JJ'' model, a small sport-utility vehicle made in a joint venture with the French automaker Renault. Chrysler also told the union that, in all likelihood, no new jobs would be created. The transfer of Wrangler to Toledo would offset the projected decline in sales of the Jeep Cherokees and Grand Wagoneers. However, union officials said despite Chrysler's projections, they felt Wrangler production would create 1,200 jobs in Toledo.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 443.33 up .77 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Bill on Track in Both Chambers of Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th graf. Opponents of ... to CORRECT by removing description of support system. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving steadily toward passing a five-year farm bill that generally maintains current law and preserves most of the government's farm support systems, including the hotly debated sugar program. During a marathon session that began Tuesday morning and lasted until nearly midnight, the Senate defeated one challenge after another to the bill worked out by its agriculture committee. The price support system protecting honey producers is the only program that has been eliminated so far. Opponents of the peanut program were mounting their offensive today. The House also was protecting the work of its committee as it defeated efforts to change the dairy and sugar programs. Opponents of the present sugar program wanted to change the support price from 18 cents a pound to 16 cents, a proposal also supported by the Bush administration. That reduction would have brought the support for sugar more in line with other government farm programs, easing the struggle between Midwestern grain farmers and the better-rewarded sugar beet producers threatening to buy them out, amendment supporters said. ``Wheat farmers and barley farmers support the sugar program,'' Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., said sarcastically. ``They would like to have one like it.'' Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., called sugar producers ``the most pampered farmers in America ... and the most profitable.'' Bradley also said the quota system used to control the amount of foreign sugar sold in the United States hurts poor Latin American countries receiving foreign aid. He said some of those countries are trying to find alternatives to coca, the raw material for cocaine, and would benefit from more open markets in the United States. ``The coca price is below the break-even point,'' said Bradley. ``This is an opportunity for us to begin to wean some of these countries from coca production into other crops, particularly sugar.'' Supporters said the program was needed to preserve American jobs and provide price stability. They said that even if the support price were reduced, consumers would not see any difference in the price of products containing sugar. ``To say this can be passed on to the American housewife is the wildest speculation,'' said Rep. Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn. ``All this will do is put more money in the hands of the manufacturer who is using sugar.'' An amendment by Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., to increase target prices on wheat and feed grains for smaller producers lost, 72-24. Daschle said it was needed to keep 500,000 family farms from going out of business during the five-year life of the bill. It would have put target prices on a two-tier system in an effort to get more money for small and medium-sized farms without going over budget. For example, instead of freezing the target price on wheat at $4 a bushel as called for in the bill, Daschle would have farmers receiving $4.10 a bushel for the first 12,500 bushels of wheat, and $3.40 for every subsequent bushel. Similar adjustments would be made for corn, oats, sorghum and barley, which also are frozen at current levels in the bill. Opponents of the amendment, including Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said it would destroy the compromise worked out by the panel, possibly preventing passage of the whole bill. In other action, the Senate: _Approved an amendment that prevents fruits, vegetables, potatoes and edible beans from being grown on acreage that is covered by the flexibility provisions of the bill's subsidy program. _Defeated a plan to allow foreign vessels to be used if no U.S.-flagged vessels are available for food aid shipments to foreign countries. The House, meanwhile: _Defeated an amendment that would have allowed the Agriculture Department to reduce the milk price support level if surpluses exceeded 5 billion pounds in any year. _Approved a provision to prevent states from imposing any surcharge for milk processing greater than the federal government's. _Voted to allow grazing on land that is set aside under the cotton acreage reduction program. _Approved disaster payments to cotton producers who are prevented from planting because of Indian water rights disputes.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise On Tight Soyoil Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices rose in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade in a rally led by the soybean complex following a government report showing unexpectedly low soybean oil stocks. The Census Bureau's weekly soybean crush report showed U.S. soyoil stocks at 1.4 billion pounds, which was about 100 million pounds below market expectations and 1.3 billion pounds below the year-ago level. William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc., said the report suggests the amount of soybean oil on hand Sept. 30, the end of the current marketing year, could be at the lowest year-end level in history. Soybeans were further supported by McDonald's Corp.'s announcement that it will switch to all vegetable oil from beef fat for making french fries, some analysts said. Soybean meal stocks also were below expectations at about 263,000 tons. Biedermann said new export demand for U.S. corn helped boost corn futures, although gains were kept in check by expectations for more beneficial crop weather in the Midwest. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in September at $3.04\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent higher with September at $2.61{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1 cent higher with September at $1.29 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 2{ cents higher with August at $5.86\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, paced by sharp gains in the pork-belly market on continued strength in the cash market. Live cattle were .07 cent to .45 cent higher with August at 77.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .50 cent higher with August at 88.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .03 cent to .95 cent higher with August at 60.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.7 cents to the limit 2 cents higher with August at 47.12 cents a pound. Most livestock and meat futures rose on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Blood Between Paper Mill and Workers Over Contract Fight
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Sunday has never been a day of leisure at the International Paper mill that dominates this historic Adirondack Mountain village. The workers liked it that way because they got paid double time. But the paper company, embroiled in a bitter labor dispute with the union representing nearly 700 of the mill's 850 employees, recently decreed it will only pay straight time for Sunday work. The workers are entering their third year without a contract. The United Paperworkers International Union says there is nothing it can do to reverse the company's decision to eliminate premium pay without a contract in place. The company says it needs wage and benefit concessions from workers to stay competitive. The company has already eliminated time-and-a-half pay for holidays. ``I've negotiated a lot of contracts over the years, and I've never seen the company negotiate in the style it does now, and its style is, `take it or leave it,''' said Robert Blaise Jr., a past president and current recording secretary of UPIU Local 497. Negotiations have deadlocked. Morale, the union claims, has slumped. ``It's deteriorated to the point where no one gives a damn,'' Blaise said. Dan Fitzgerald, a truck driver at the mill, said, ``it's rock-bottom. It's like Stalag 13.'' ``It's difficult for everybody in a period like this, but ... we continue doing our jobs and are committed to creating a good product in a safe environment,'' said Dale N. Sutherland, an International Paper spokesman. Company officials, union leaders and village authorities differ over what effect the contract dispute has had on the community. But all agree that International Paper means a great deal to Ticonderoga. ``I'd shudder at the thought if International Paper ever had massive layoffs,'' said Kitty J. Garrand, executive director of the Ticonderoga Area Chamber of Commerce. ``Without IP you might as well lock your doors,'' said a sales clerk in a retail clothing shop on Montcalm Street, Ticonderoga's main drag. International Paper has been Ticonderoga's chief employer since 1925. It is also one of the world's largest paper manufacturers with 67,000 employees worldwide, 55,000 of them in the United States. The Ticonderoga mill pumps millions of dollars into the local economy, including $22 million a year in wages for its 655 hourly employees, Sutherland said. Ticonderogans are sensitive to anything concerning the company. They watched uncomfortably as nearly 2,100 UPIU members lost their jobs to replacement workers in a 16-month strike at IP mills in Jay, Maine; De Pere, Wis.; and Lock Haven, Pa. Between 1,800 and 1,900 of them remain out of work, said Gordon Brehm, spokesman for the UPIU in Nashville, Tenn. Worries that replacement workers would be used locally peaked last winter when more than 1,000 non-union workers arrived to fill temporary maintenance and construction jobs at the mill during its annual shutdown. The non-union workers were employed by BE&K Construction Co., a Birmingham, Ala., contractor that supplied International Paper with replacement workers during the strike. Using BE&K workers in Ticonderoga was a humiliation for the union. ``We don't believe in the credo of using non-union help and we don't believe they should be working in this mill,'' said Blaise. BE&K workers rented every available apartment and motel room in Ticonderoga and surrounding towns, pumping money into an area desperate for extra dollars when the summer tourist season ends. But the workers _ dubbed ``beakers'' by the UPIU _ were blamed for what passes for a crime wave in this rural community near the Vermont line. Two BE&K employees were accused of sexually assaulting a female co-worker, while another was charged with stabbing to death his roommate, also a BE&K worker, in the nearby town of Schroon. It was the first murder there since the early 1950s, police said. At the union hall, a door is decorated with a mock wanted poster depicting a rat in a police lineup with the words ``BE&K worker'' underneath. The last of the BE&K workers left the area in late April and ``it's business as usual around the community,'' Garrand said. Contention is nothing new in Ticonderoga. Located on the southern reaches of Lake Champlain and the northern shore of Lake George, Ticonderoga's name comes from the Iroquois ``cheonderoga,'' or ``the place between two lakes.'' It became a strategic portage for generations of marauding Indians and later French, British and American explorers and soldiers who fought for control of Fort Ticonderoga, a 235-year-old stone fortress outside the village. The union, which last struck International Paper locally in the early 1970s to protest allegedly unsafe working conditions, said there is no justification for cutting pay or seeking wage concessions since the company is so profitable. In 1989 International Paper reported record earnings of $864 million. The company contends the paper industry is in a down trend and the pay concessions are necessary if the company wants to stay competitive in the world market. Of International Paper's 22 major paper manufacturing mills, four are operating without union contracts. The company negotiates each mill's contract separately, so if some are halted by strikes others keep running. ``When you've got 30, 40, 50 mills with no contracts ... you might have more bargaining power,'' said James W. De Zalia, president of Local 497. Union officials in Ticonderoga say profits have come at their expense, although mill wages are far above the average for the region. Ticonderoga mill workers average about $13.50 per hour and the average annual pay for hourly employees is approximately $35,000. But De Zalia said the workers hardly have an easy life. ``We work seven-days stretches, holidays, Sundays,'' De Zalia said. ``You work around chemicals and all the hazards'' of factory work, he said. Last January, union members voted 453 to 67 to reject the latest company offer. No negotiations have been held since. The company refuses to discuss specifics of the contract dispute. The cuts in premium pay and an increase in health insurance deductions have cost workers thousands of dollars a year, De Zalia said. That translates into fewer dollars spent at local businesses, he said. ``As for buying cars, building new homes, it has to have an effect,'' De Zalia said. ``After all these years, all of a sudden they take it right away from you.'' ``I didn't have a chance for college. But I want to make sure my kids have a chance to go,'' Fitzgerald said. ``It's going to be a burden.'' But the workers are apprehensive about challenging the company. ``Hopefully the company will say, `hey, let's settle before something happens,''' De Zalia said. ``Nobody wants to strike. Nobody wins. Everybody loses in a strike.''

DOC.HEAD: Australian Truck Plant Selects Site Near Toledo
DOC.TEXT: An Australian company will make an innovative pickup truck in the Toledo suburb of Northwood in a $225 million venture that will create 1,500 jobs, a company official announced today. Kelpie North America Corp. expects to build 60,000 hydraulic-lift pickup trucks a year for the U.S. market. The company is a subsidiary of Sydney, Australia-based Kelpie Industries Ltd. The company has developed more than 20 prototypes for the truck in the last three years. The truck features a bed and tailgate that lower to the ground. ``Our company is confident that we have chosen the best possible site to meet our production needs to launch our products in North America,'' Paul Cooper, president of Kelpie North America. Corp., said at a news conference with Wood County commissioners in Bowling Green, the county seat. A Canadian site also was under consideration. ``Major contributing factors were strong community support and an excellent local, skilled labor pool,'' Cooper said. The company expects to begin construction this summer at a 70-acre site. The truck will carry a price tag of $16,500 to $17,900, depending on options, the company said. The one-ton, front-wheel-drive truck has no rear axle; the wheels are mounted directly to the frame. The load tray, known as the bed, raises and lowers hydraulically, making it easy for people to place heavy objects in the truck. Most of the prototypes were built in Australia, but labor difficulties there and the potential size of the North American market led Kelpie to seek a site in the United States or Canada, the company said. In addition to the 1,500 jobs that would be created at the plant, another 4,500 related jobs could be created in the area, the company has said. The first vehicle could roll off the assembly line in about 12 to 14 months, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Norfolk Southern Earnings Drop 10.2 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Norfolk Southern Corp. said Wednesday its second-quarter earnings fell 10.2 percent from a year earlier, when the company had a one-time $13.6 million gain. The railroad and transportation company said it earned $155.9 million, or 95 cents per share, down from $173.7 million, or 99 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $1.18 billion, up from $1.17 billion in the comparable 1989 period. The drop in earnings was attributed in part to the $13.6 million after-tax gain that inflated Norfolk Southern's 1989 second-quarter earnings. The gain came from the sale of a portion of Norfolk Southern's trailer train holdings. The company also said some of its segments suffered a drop in revenue or had an increase in expenses, but the firm gave no other reasons for the income decline. Spokesman Bob Auman said earnings are affected by a number of factors including fuel costs. For the first half, Norfolk Southern said it earned $296.1 million, or $1.79 a share, down 3.7 percent from $307.5 million, or $1.74 a share, in the first six months of 1989. First-half revenue totaled $2.32 billion, up from $2.29 billion in 1989.

The parent of USAir said it lost $75 million in the most recent three-month period, attributing the drop to weakness in the nation's economy. America West Airlines said it registered second-quarter profits of more than $6 million, nearly double its earnings in the same period last year, as it dramatically increased its passenger miles.
DOC.HEAD: USAir
DOC.TEXT: USAir Group Inc., based in Arlington, Va., said its quarterly loss, equal to $1,86 a share, compared with profits of $101 million, of $2.29 a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue for the quarter ended June 30 was $1.71 billion, down slightly from $1.73 billion a year earlier. ``Revenue growth has been below expectations,'' USAir Group Chairman and President Edwin I. Colodny said in a statement. He said industry-wide domestic capacity was growing faster than traffic and widespread promotional fare cuts on both coasts had reduced per passenger yields. For the first half of 1990, USAir reported a net loss of $113 million, or $2.92 a share, on revenue of $3.3 billion, compared with net income of $116 million, or $2.65 a share, on revenue of $3.2 billion in the same time last year.

America West posted second-quarter earnings of $6.14 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $3.03 million, or 14 cents a share, during the second quarter of 1989. Revenue rose 37 percent to $326 million from $239 million a year earlier. The results reflect a major improvement over the first quarter of the year, when the airline reported a net loss of $2.6 million. Al Frei, senior vice president of finance, said much of the improvement was due to a substantial drop in the fuel costs. ``Fuel prices ... were more than 10 cents per gallon lower than during the first quarter of the year,'' he said. Phoeniz-based America West reported a 49.9 percent increase in passenger miles in the second quarter over the same quarter last year, Frei said. The airline increased its passenger capacity during the quarter by 33.4 percent, primarily by adding twice-daily Boeing 747 service between Phoenix and Honolulu. For the first half of 1990, America West reported net earnings of $3.6 million, or 18 cents a share, down from $13.1 million, or 64 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. Half-year revenue was $631 million, up from $472 million a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Rose
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with closing European quotes, midday New York prices. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed Wednesday in dealings in Europe, rising against the British pound and the Japanese yen but falling against other major currencies. Gold prices rose in Europe. The dollar was helped against the yen by jitters over rising tensions in the Persian Gulf which also has helped boost world oil prices. The situation has undermined some confidence in the oil-import dependent Japanese economy. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 149.13 Japanese yen from 148.70 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 148.75 yen. At midday in New Yor, the dollar was quoted at 149.25 yen. Dealers said the dollar still is under pressure aginst the mark and most other currencies because of concerns that U.S. interest rates will fall. The dollar was also pushed down by weaker-than-expected U.S. durable goods orders for June, which raised chances the Federal Reserve will encourage lower interest rates to stimulate the economy. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8125 from $1.8250 late Tuesday. In New York, the dollar traded for $1.81085 at midday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.6170 West German marks, down from 1.6185; 1.3715 Swiss francs, down from 1.3750; 5.4185 French francs, down from 5.4275; 1.8215 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8230; 1,183.62 Italian lire, down from 1,184.75, and 1.1518 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1557. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $373.25 a troy ounce, up from $368.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $372.50 an ounce, up from $368.35 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.42 to close at $367.83 an ounce. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $4.89 a troy ounce, up from $4.85 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Airlines Indicted on Criminal Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Andrew J. ... to UPDATE with U.S. attorney comment; INSERTS new 8th graf to ADD that none of charges caused accident; Edits to tighten; PICKS UP 15th graf, `In addition...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY20 of July 24
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines and several of its top managers were indicted today on criminal charges of falsifying aircraft maintenance records and other aircraft-safety documents. The 60-count indictment alleges a fraudulent scheme to try to minimize flight delays and cancellations that resulted in flights by improperly maintained or repaired airplanes. The violations allegedly took place from July 1985 to October 1989 at John F. Kennedy International and LaGuardia airports in New York, Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta and Eastern headquarters in Miami. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement that the alleged conspiracy ``strikes a raw nerve in anyone who has ever boarded an airplane.'' ``Thousands of innocent passengers may have been put at risk every day by the criminal actions of these defendants,'' Thornburgh said. Eastern faces a maximum fine of $30 million. Each individual defendant faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count. The indictment charges that by tampering with log books, work cards and maintenance records Eastern ``did cause aircraft that were not properly maintained or repaired to fly and carry unsuspecting passengers.'' None of the alleged violations caused any accidents or injuries, authorities said. The airline and nine employees were charged with conspiracy, fraud, keeping false records, concealing information from the Federal Aviation Administration and other charges. The charges follow a year-long federal investigation and the collapse of plea bargain talks in which Eastern refused to admit to conspiracy charges. Martin Shugrue, appointed to run Eastern by a bankruptcy judge, said Tuesday the airline was prepared to admit to fraudulent maintenance and record-keeping but not conspiracy. Andrew J. Maloney, the U.S. attorney in Brooklyn, said the charges involved ``critical items'' including radar, landing gear, automatic pilot instruments and fuel systems. The indictment alleges Eastern and several managers used ``intimidation and coercion'' to force the airline's maintenance personnel to avoid and minimize flight delays and cancellations. It accuses Eastern and the workers of falsifying aircraft maintenance records ``to make it fraudulently appear that scheduled maintenance and corrective repairs had been completed.'' In addition to the airline, named in the indictment were Edward Upton, Eastern's staff vice president of maintenance and engineering during the period; Thomas Lewis, Eastern's northern area director of maintenance; and seven other maintenance supervisors and foremen. A criminal indictment is unprecedented in the airline industry and could add to Eastern's woes as it seeks to regain passengers, build service and reorganize under federal bankruptcy protection after a bitter strike. ``I think the public will recognize these are historical events that don't bear on Eastern today,'' said Shugrue, who has run the airline for about three months. Shugrue said Eastern has undergone and passed a ``rigorous inspection'' by the FAA and the Defense Department. He called Eastern ``the most-inspected air carrier in the world.'' In refusing to acknowledge the conspiracy charge, Shugrue said, ``We cannot and will not plead guilty to violations of the law for which we find no evidence.'' The criminal investigation began last year after the FAA fined Eastern $839,000 for alleged maintenance violations, primarily at Kennedy. Eastern cooperated with that investigation and closed its maintenance facility at Kennedy last year. Shugrue said Eastern expected to turn a profit in 1991. The Miami-based airline is projected to lose about $500 million this year after a $852 million loss in 1989. Eastern's employees struck the airline March 4, 1989, and the company filed for bankruptcy protection five days later. Pilots and flight attendants quit the strike several months later but the mechanics remain on strike. A federal bankruptcy judge appointed Shugrue on April 18 to run the airline in place of Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Eastern's parent company, the former Texas Air Corp., now known as Continental Airlines Holdings Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Takeover Investors Apparently Win Key Votes in Battle For Control
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. said Wednesday an investor group trying to wrest control of the troubled former steel giant evidently had enough shareholder votes to fill three seats on the 10-member board of directors. ``Our tally shows that we don't have enough votes to elect our directors,'' Chief Executive Officer Howard M. Love told a news conference after the company's annual shareholders' meeting. The vote appeared to be a significant victory in a prolonged battle for control of the company by Centaur Partners, a New York investment concern and NII's largest stockholder with 16.5 percent of its shares. With three seats on the board, Centaur could wield enormous influence in convincing the other board members to follow its plan to sell what's left of NII and give the money to shareholders. Management has proposed a different future for NII, formerly a debt-ridden steel company that diversified then sold most assets to pay creditors. Under the management plan, NII would be restructured as a wholesale drug distributor. NII's owns FoxMeyer Drug, the nation's third-largest drug distributor. About 200 stockholders and proxies were present to select three new directors. Candidate slates were nominated by the company and Centaur. The results of voting won't be known until the shareholders' meeting reconvenes Aug. 9. But Centaur appeared confident it had won. ``This was an absolutely tremendous outpouring of support,'' said Centaur principal Abbey J. Butler. ``We do think that the shareholder vote is a mandate,'' said Centaur principal Melvyn J. Estrin. They declined to say how many votes they believed Centaur had. Love's seat on the board was one of those at stake. He had said he would retire once the company's restructuring was complete but said Wednesday he would step down March 1. Robert King, president of FoxMeyer, tried to persuade shareholders to back NII's restructuring plan. He said the wholesale drug distribution industry was a $25 billion a year business and growing by 15 percent annually. Eugene Cohen, one of a few shareholders who addressed Love during the meeting, said stockholders have not shared in profits from the sale of NII assets or received dividends. ``What incentive is there to buy stock in Intergroup?'' Cohen said. Walker Street Associates, which owns 8.4 percent of NII stock, objected to increases in NII management's severance, pension and stock option plans. ``Most shareholders have been looking for the company to tell them something other than `trust us,' '' said Steve Mizel, a Walker official. The dissidents' slate was Estrin; Robert J. Slater, former CEO of CF&I Steel Corp.; and William G. Tull, retired chief operating officer of American Security Bank in Maryland, where Estrin is a director. The seven remaining directors include five independents as well as NII President James S. Pasman Jr. and Richard S. Smith, director of The Permian Corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary of NII. The next directors' meeting is scheduled for Aug. 22.

DOC.HEAD: PacTel, Cellular Communications Combine into Huge Midwest Service Area
DOC.TEXT: Pacific Telesis Group and Cellular Communications Inc. said Wednesday they have agreed to combine cellular telephone operations in the Midwest, creating the third largest regional cellular system in the U.S. The joint venture must be approved by shareholders and regulators. The deal would combine Cellular One and PacTel Cellular, a subsidiary of San Francisco-based Pacific Telesis Group. Sam Ginn, chairman and chief executive officer of Pacific Telesis Group, said the company had been looking for a way to expand its cellular telephone operation for some time in the United States and abroad. ``The mega-system created by this joint venture will virtually double the number of customers we reach in the Midwest,'' Ginn said. The combined entity would cover a 27,000-square-mile area that includes Cincinnati, Cleveland, Columbus, Dayton, Detroit and Toledo, where 15 million people live. George Blumenthal, chairman of Cellular Communications, said the joint venture would make it easier to provide better cellular telephone service in Ohio and Michigan. ``We think we'll work well as a team,'' he said. The deal is expected to close by the second or third quarter of 1991 if approved by CCI shareholders and state and federal regulators. Under the deal, Pacific Telesis will purchase 5 percent of CCI stock for $39 per share. It will have the right to increase its percentage ownership for several years and then possibly acquire the rest of CCI's stock after 5{ years. PacTel Cellular, which has 443,000 subscribers, serves the greater Detroit-Toledo area under the name Cellular One and the company operates in Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Diego and Atlanta. CCI is the leading provider of cellular service in Ohio and operates in Puerto Rico. Before closing the deal, CCI plans to spin off to its shareholders two new public companies comprising CCI's international activities and its long distance-microwave business. After closing, CCI plans to spin off to shareholders a third public company with its Puerto Rican cellular interests.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 8.42 to 2,930.94. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 895 up, 583 down and 512 unchanged. Analysts said traders were encouraged by the market's steady showing since it ran into a barrage of sell orders in early trading on Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average, down more than 100 points at its low point Monday, later trimmed its loss for that session to 56.44 points. On Tuesday it rose 17.82 points. Beyond that, brokers said hopes for lower interest rates were buttressed by a new statistical sign of weakness in business activity. The Commerce Department reported that new factory orders for durable goods fell 3.2 percent in June. At the same time, however, the data did nothing to dispel recent worries over a sluggish, erratic pattern in corporate profits. Investors' ``bargain-hunting'' mood was evident in several of the depressed bank stocks, which have been battered by worries about loan risks and talk of a credit crunch. Chase Manhattan, the most active Big Board issue, rose | to 20]; Citicorp ] to 21; Chemical Banking \ to 24[; Manufacturers Hanover } to 31\, and J.P. Morgan ] to 37[.
