DOC.HEAD: RESENDING FOR ALL NEEDING
Gold Rally Resumes; Mideast Buying Rumored
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices rose substantially Wednesday on New York's Commodity Exchange, but although the market closed well below the day's highs analysts said the recent rally appeared likely to continue. On other commodity markets, other precious metals rose; copper futures advanced; energy futures fell; livestock and meat futures were higher; and grains and soybean retreated. Gold futures settled $3.80 to $4.10 higher with the contract for delivery in August at $372.40 a troy ounce and the spot July contract at $372, the highest settlement for spot gold since May 22. The rally erased Tuesday's moderate losses and pushed prices beyond the highs posted Monday, when August gold soared $7.70. August gold traded as high as $375.50 early in Wednesday's session, boosted by indications of Middle Eastern buying and by speculation that the simmering dispute between Iraq and Kuwait over crude oil could boil over into armed conflict. But buying interest faded when the August contract topped $375 an ounce. Speculators took profits, pushing prices down to near the middle of the day's trading range. ``The close was a little disappointing. I don't know how much immediate follow-through we'll get from this,'' said Anne Orton, vice president of the currency and precious metals dealer Deak International Inc. Still, Orton said, ``the gold market looks a lot more constructive than it has for quite some.'' Analyst John O'Connell of Refco Inc. in New York said gold's recent strength was only ``a blip'' so far. He said he didn't have great confidence that the rally would continue but said the chart signals remained bullish . Silver futures settled 1.5 cents to 1.8 cents higher with July at $4.828 a troy ounce. Copper futures rose strongly for the third time in the last four sessions on the Commodity Exchange amid expectations that workers at Peru's state-owned Mineroperu metals mining and refining company will go on strike Thursday. Copper settled .15 cent to 1.45 cents higher with July at $1.237 a pound. Most energy futures retreated on the New York Mercantile Exchange on modest profit-taking as traders awaited developments from an OPEC meeting in Geneva. Ministers from the 13-member cartel are expected to negotiate new production quotas in an effort to raise world oil prices. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. energy broker Brian Tagler said the lack of fresh news from the oil cartel's gathering gave traders an opportunity to sell and collect profits amassed during the oil market's recent advance. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 18 cents lower to 4 cents higher with September at $20.38 a barrel; heating oil was .56 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 56.76 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .24 cent to .45 cent lower with August at 63.04 cents a gallon. Pork belly futures soared the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit for the second straight day on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as the cash market continued to strengthen. Hog futures also rose sharply in line with higher cash prices for live hogs. Higher cash cattle prices boosted the cattle futures. Live cattle were .28 cent to .82 cent higher with August at 77.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent to .68 cent higher with August at 88.77 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent to 1.5 cents higher with August at 60.67 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.95 cents to 2 cents higher with August at 47.12 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures finished slightly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as late profit-taking erased modest gains posted earlier in the session. Wheat settled 2 cents to 2{ cents lower with September at $3.01{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1 cent lower with September at $2.60} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents higher with September at $1.29 a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 6 cents lower with August at $5.83} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Boon for Toledo: More Auto Jobs on the Way
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos TO1-TO3
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and an Australian truck maker announced separate plans Wednesday to bring auto production work to an area that has lost thousands of manufacturing jobs in recent years. Local officials said the projects would help boost a sagging economy. Chrysler announced an incentive package to move production of the Jeep Wrangler from Brampton, Ontario, starting Jan. 1, 1993. It also said if it decides to build the new ``JJ'' model, it would be produced in Toledo. The plan may create new jobs, but how many is unclear. Chrysler said the transfer of Wrangler to Toledo would offset the projected decline in sales of Jeep Cherokee and Grand Wagoneers, both made in Toledo. But the United Auto Workers union said it expected Wrangler production to create hundreds of jobs. ``We're looking at retaining thousands of good-paying jobs at Jeep plus untold thousands of other jobs held by Toledoans, which rely on Jeep,'' Mayor John McHugh said. While Chrysler was making its announcement, Kelpie North America Corp. said it would make a hydraulic-lift pickup truck in Northwood, about five miles east of Toledo. The $225 million venture is expected to create 1,500 production jobs and could result in 4,500 related jobs. ``Given the loss of manufacturing jobs in our area, it is especially good to see not just new jobs being added, but manufacturing jobs as well,'' Northwood Mayor John Hageman said. ``These are jobs that will provide a respectable standard of living for our families,'' Wood County Commissioner Thomas Warns said. Toledo has seen its manufacturing base erode. It has lost 3,000 manufacturing jobs in the last two years alone. The unemployment rate for the Toledo area in May was 7.0 percent. The latest word of a plant closing came in May, when Champion Spark Plug Co. said it would close its Toledo plant by the end of the year, idling 430 workers. Three small auto parts plants have closed since January 1989, putting 620 people out of work. Other companies have reduced their work force or moved operations to other cities with lower labor costs. Chrysler said the Brampton plant would be closed with the move of Wrangler production to Toledo, but some workers would be transferred to another Chrysler plant in Canada. In return, Toledo and the state will provide incentives that could total $22.3 million over the next 10 years. They include a possible 10-year tax abatement on personal property taxes for Chrysler, up to $500,000 a year for seven years for plant improvements, and up to $5 million to retrain workers. The agreement is the final piece of a package that was needed to move Wrangler production to Toledo and keep the two existing plants operating beyond 1992. The two plants employ 5,300 people. The first pickup truck made by Kelpie North America could roll off the Northwood assembly line by October of 1991. The company, a subsidiary of Sydney, Australia-based Kelpie Industries Ltd., expects to begin construction this summer on 70 acres. The truck features a bed and tailgate that lower to the ground. It will retail for $16,500 to $17,900. Kelpie expects to build 60,000 trucks a year for the U.S. market. A Canadian site also had been considered. ``Major contributing factors were strong community support and an excellent local, skilled labor pool,'' Paul Cooper, president of Kelpie North America, said at a news conference in Bowling Green. The one-ton, front-wheel drive truck has no rear axle; the wheels are mounted directly to the frame. The load tray, known as the bed, would be raised and lowered hydraulically, making it easy for people to place heavy objects in the truck.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange Reports Fraud
DOC.TEXT: The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange said Wednesday it was investigating fradulent trades made a day earlier in which someone misrepresented his identity. The exchange said the transactions in the cocoa market have been accepted for clearance by an exchange member and that the exchange would provide money to cover margin calls for any affected trasnactions. A margin is the amount of money required as a downpayment for the purchase of a block of securities or commodities. The exchange said in a statement that members who executed the transactions would reimburse the exchange for any losses. The statement did not elaborate on who was responsible for the trades or provide any further details. The exchange said the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the U.S. Attorney's Office had been notified about the alleged fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Computer Maker Announces First-Ever Quarterly Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT loss amount; SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT 4Q 1989 revenue. ^By LESLIE DREYFOUS
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. reported a $256.7 million fourth-quarter loss Wednesday, the computer giant's first ever quarterly loss and a reflection of a voluntary severance program under which 3,000 employees left over the last 12 months. Mark Steinkrauss, director of investor relations, said Digital's restructuring program included plans to cut another 5,000 to 6,000 people in the coming months through voluntary severance and attrition. The loss by one of New England's most important companies provided further evidence of economic trouble in the region, which grew quickly during the boom years of the 1980s but tumbled into recession because of the slumping high-technology, financial services and real estate industries. But some securities analysts who follow Digital saw the loss as a piece of good news because it showed the company was aggressively trying to cut expenses while remaining competitive. ``I'm encouraged that they decided to bite the bullet and do it,'' said Marc Schulman, an analyst with UBS Securities Inc. in New York. ``Things are as bad as they're going to get, and now they're going to get better.'' Added Steinkrauss: ``The company knew exactly what it was doing. ..in light of what it needs to do in terms of reducing its cost structure.'' Still, the news was not well received on Wall Street. Digital stock fell 62{ cents a share to $74.87{ in New York Stock Exchange trading. Employee retraining, separation incentives and other costs associated with the Maynard, Mass.-based company's restructuring program cost $400 million in the fourth quarter. Senior Vice President John F. Smith also attributed the computer maker's loss to ``the continuing economic slowdown that affects both U.S. and several other markets.'' For its fourth quarter ended June 30, the company said it lost $2.11 a share on revenue of $3.4 billion, compared with earnings of $313.2 million, or $2.51 a share, on revenue of $3.5 billion for the same quarter in 1989. Profits for the full fiscal year after absorbing pretax charges of $550 million fell to $74.4 million or 59 cents a share, from $1.1 billion or $8.45 a share in 1989. Digital's sales were up 2 percent to $12.9 billion, from $12.7 billion last year. ``Increasing profit is the most important challenge the company faces,'' Smith said in a statement. ``We are not satisfied with our operating results and will continue focusing on revenue growth and reducing our cost structure.'' He said the company was reducing costs by identifying positions that are no longer needed, either because of changes in technology or business practices. ``We expect to begin receiving ongoing cost savings from these actions in the current year, and the full impact will be realized by next fiscal year,'' Smith said in the statement. Schulman, who predicted Digital's turnaround would take about two years, said many of the bigger computer companies are scrambling to update product lines and keep up with overseas competitors. ``Given their size, it's going to take awhile,'' he said. ``The underlying problem is the shift in the structure of demand toward work stations and PCs (personal computers) _ areas which do not represent a high percentage of their revenue.'' Companies are also beginning to scale back from the explosive expansion of the early 1980s, when the industry boomed in California's Silicon Valley and along Massachusetts' Route 128. More recently layoffs and other job reductions have been widespread among industry giants like Digital, the world's second largest computer maker after International Business Machines Corp. In December, IBM announced it would eliminate 10,000 U.S. jobs. Other affected companies have included Unisys Corp., Control Data Corp., Amdahl Corp., Bull HN Information Systems Inc., Wang Laboratories Inc. and Prime Computer. ``The whole industry has been slumping and it looks like it's continuing,'' said David Wu, a stock analyst with S.G. Warburg & Co. in New York. ``Digital can recover but it's a matter of how much and how fast.''

DOC.HEAD: Home Sales Post Modest Gain
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede and 3rd graf to CORRECT previous last increase from Septemebr to November. FYI figures in Lasergraphic NY34 are correct
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Economy
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes posted their first increase in seven months in June, but analysts were divided Wednesday on whether the modest 1.2 percent gain offered at least the glimmer of rebound for the depressed housing sector. The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes edged up to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million units. The June advance was the first increase in sales since a 3.2 percent gain in November. Since then, existing home sales have either fallen or remained unchanged as the housing industry was battered by rising mortgage rates. Industry officials said they viewed the June advance as an encouraging sign that better days may be ahead, especially in light of the fact that mortgage rates have been declining in recent months. Fixed-rate mortgages fell to 9.99 percent last week, according to a national survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. It marked the first time rates have been below 10 percent in six months. ``People have been watching to see which way rates are headed. Now, they're out scouting the inventory. In general, it appears the market is building up steam,'' said Norman D. Flynn, president of the Realtors group. But David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill Inc., said he saw little reason to believe that the small June upturn in existing home sales would be followed by further gains. ``We may have found the floor for the slump in housing, but I don't think we will be coming off of it for awhile,'' Wyss said. ``People just aren't as excited about owning a home because the investment prospects don't look as good as they did in the 1990s.'' The median price of an existing home rose 2 percent in June, to $97,500. The median is the midpoint, with half the homes selling for more and half for less. The sales strength in June came from a sharp 9.1 percent jump in activity in the Midwest, where existing homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 960,000 units. Sales also were up in the West by a smaller 1.8 percent, to an annual rate of 580,000 units. The other two regions of the country posted sales declines. In the South, sales fell a slight 0.8 percent to an annual rate of 1.31 million units. Sales were off 5.8 percent in the Northeast, to an annual rate of 490,000 units as that section of the country continued to exhibit extremely weak sales activity. Flynn said that psychological barriers caused by a general economic slowdown were continuing to scare away buyers in the Northeast. ``Unfortunately, many people in the Northeast are of the mindset that it is a bad time to buy,'' Flynn said. ``That is bunk. Sellers are more than willing to negotiate. Buyers should be jumping into the market.''

DOC.HEAD: Factory Oders for Durable Goods Down In June
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 10th graf: ``The news,'' with pessimistic poll result; SUBS 11th graf: `A separate,'' which is pvs 10th graf, to CORRECT September to November
DOC.TEXT: Factory orders for ``big ticket'' durable goods plummeted 3.2 percent in June, the government said Wednesday in a report that raised new concerns that the United States could be flirting with a recession. The Commerce Department said that demand for durable goods, items ranging from bicycles to battleships, fell $4.14 billion to a seasonally adjusted $124.69 billion last month. The June decline came as a surprise to analysts who had counted on a further pickup in orders to signal that the fortunes of the nation's manufacturing sector were on a permanent upswing. Durable goods orders are considered a key barometer for the future since a drop in orders normally triggers cutbacks in production plans and job layoffs. Hopes for a rebound in manufacturing had been fueled by a 4.2 percent rise in orders in May and an even bigger 6.7 percent advance in March. But the June decline continues the saw-tooth pattern evident since January. Orders fell by 4.1 percent in April and dropped by a record of 10.5 percent in January. ``The durable goods report is a distinct yellow flag on how the economy might perform in the second half of the year,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``In two of the last three months, we have seen substantial declines in the orders numbers.'' Mark Zandi, senior economist at Regional Financial Associates in Chester, Pa., said the orders report was especially disappointing because many economists had looked for a rebound in manufacturing to help bolster growth in coming months. ``If manufacturing doesn't show signs of strength, there really is no sector of the economy to provide the impetus for growth,'' he said. ``The consumer sector is extremely weak, investment spending has been hurt by the slide in profits and housing is in a recession.'' The news came on a day when a new poll by ABC and Money magazine said a record proportion of respondents, 71 percent, believed it was not a good time to make a purchase, and the same proportion believed the economy was in not-so-good or poor shape. The poll did not give comparisons from the past. A separate report Wednesday showed that sales of existing single-family homes posted a small 1.2 percent advance in June, the first monthly gain since last November. The National Association of Realtors attributed the upturn to falling mortgage rates and said it offered the promise of further gains in the months ahead. But other economists said that a one-month upturn did not signal an end to the extended slump besetting the housing industry. In a sign of how sluggish the manufacturing sector has been, orders for durable goods totaled $744.7 billion during the first six months of this year, 1.5 percent below the same period in 1989. The June weakness was widespread across all industry groups. About half of the decline was attributed to a 20.7 percent drop in orders for military hardware, the biggest setback in the defense category since a 33.6 percent drop in January. The military sector tends to be extremely volatile, depending on the timing of government contracts. But analysts believe this year's weakness reflects the beginnings of an extended period of defense cutbacks. Even without the big defense decrease, durable goods orders would have been down 1.7 percent in June.

DOC.HEAD: Dominant Diamond Business De Beers In Deal For Soviet Output
DOC.TEXT: De Beers tightened its grip on the global diamond market Wednesday with an exclusive five-year deal to sell the Soviet Union's rough diamond output, which could total more than $5 billion. The financially strained Soviet Union, among the world's biggest gem diamond producers, will get a $1 billion advance against future diamond sales. De Beers' London-based marketing arm, the Central Selling Organization, will strengthen its position as the world's dominant diamond seller. It already markets 80 percent of global rough diamond production of some 100 million carats. The Soviets do not disclose their output. The nation reached the deal because it wanted to sell a huge stockpile of diamonds without disrupting the stable world diamond market, De Beers said. The Soviet Union had refused to deal directly with the South African-based company because of its home country's policies of racial separation, but now is willing to do business openly with De Beers' new Swiss arm, De Beers Centenary AG. De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. established the publicly-held Swiss company in May to head the non-South African businesses of De Beers, which is controlled by the wealthy Oppenheimer family of South Africa. De Beers Centenary said in a statement released in Lucerne, Switzerland and made available in London that it reached the agreement with Glavalmazzoloto of the Soviet Union for the exclusive export and sale of the USSR diamond production. Glavalmazzoloto is the main administration for precious metals and diamonds under the Soviet Union's council of ministers, De Beers said. De Beers' Luxembourg-based subsidiary, Centenary Holdings SA, has agreed to advance Glavalmazzoloto $1 billion against future diamond deliveries. Repayment would be made over five years beginning in November. The Soviet diamond stockpile will be held at De Beers' London-based marketing arm, the Central Selling Organization, as collateral for the advance, De Beers said. The organization, a 57-year-old cartel, has the financial resources to hold large stocks of diamonds, which is how it keeps the market stable. Although De Beers said it had had no direct contact with the Soviet Union since 1963, diamond experts say De Beers already sells most of the Soviet Union's West-bound diamonds. ``We have not had an official agreement with the Russians. In the past, obviously, being major distributors of rough (diamonds), Russian diamonds have found their way into the rough,'' said De Beers spokesman Roger Van Eeghen. ``It came through other sources, other channels.'' All the world's major diamond producers, including Botswana, Australia, Tanzania, Zaire and Namibia, have sales contracts with De Beers Centenary. The Central Selling Organization had sales of $4.09 billion last year. De Beers must renegotiate several key contracts this year, which experts have said might loosen its grip on the diamond market. The formal marketing of the Soviet diamonds, like those from elsewhere, will take place in London and Lucerne, De Beers said. Julian Ogilvie Thompson, De Beers chairman, said the deal would bring ``continued stability and prosperity of the international diamond industry.'' Nicholas Oppenheimer, deputy chairman of De Beers Centenary, said the Soviet Union, at a time of ``considerable financial strain,'' was able to raise a $1 billion loan while signing a contract assuring it of ``a steady flow of funds from diamonds'' over the next five years. Large-scale diamond mining began in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and is concentrated in the Yakutia region of North Eastern Siberia, De Beers said.

For Release Sunday, July 29
DOC.HEAD: Jury Still Out on Success of Media, Entertainment Combination
Graphic
With BC-Time Warner-Laws
DOC.TEXT: The court ruling that cleared the way for Time Inc. to buy Warner Communications Inc. is a year old, but Wall Street has doubts about the media and entertainment conglomerate's prospects. Worries about the company's big debt, its ability to handle possible interest rate hikes and absorb shocks in businesses such as moviemaking or records have depressed its stock price. So have uncertainties about possible changes in the regulatory environment for its cable television business. The acquisition costs have led to scary financial reports as well. Time Warner lost $376 million in the first half of the year after paying preferred dividends. ``How the mighty have fallen,'' said media analyst Dennis McAlpine of Oppenheimer & Co. in a recent analysis. The company that won Wall Street raves as ``the forerunner of the international media behemoth'' a few months ago, he wrote, is now viewed there ``with the disdain normally accorded a skunk walking into a church social.'' But he recommended buying the depressed stock, citing the company's ``eminent position in most of the industries in which it operates, its apparent ability to meet its debt obligations and its positive long-term prospects.'' Time Warner stock traded in the mid-$90s this past week, down from a peak of $182.75 a share last summer. The stock had soared in June 1989 after Paramount Communications Inc. offered $200 a share for Time, only days before shareholder votes were scheduled on Time's plan to merge with Warner. Time executives called Paramount's offer phony, reworked the Warner deal in a way that required no shareholder vote and got the Delaware Supreme Court's blessing in a ruling July 24, 1989. As a result, Paramount never got the chance to take its offer directly to Time's stockholders. Many still resent that. ``We would have preferred that they would have accepted Paramount's offer,'' said Kyle Krueger, portfolio manager for Eagle Asset Management in St. Petersburg, Fla., which now owns 1.63 percent of Time Warner's stock. But he doesn't blame Time Warner management for the company's current low price. ``We think they are doing fairly well,'' he said. Time Warner executives say the company's stock price reflects the market's distaste for companies with debt, and its disfavor for those in the cable and entertainment industries in particular. They argue Time Warner can handle its debt. Time Warner's magazine, music, film, book, TV production and cable television businesses are generating more than enough cash to meet debt payments over the next few years, they say. Securities analysts generally agree that the company will generate $2.1 billion to $2.5 billion in cash flow a year, while interest and preferred stock payments will require about $1.3 billion a year through 1992. But in 1993, the company is due to reduce its debt by $2 billion. McAlpine and others feel the company will have to either sell assets or take on partners in joint ventures to raise money by that date. McAlpine also said the company has $3 billion in investments that could be sold to reduce debt. These include shares of companies such as Hasbro, Atari and Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc., real estate in Burbank, Calif., and minority interests in assorted cable system operators. Time Warner's co-chief executives, Steven J. Ross and Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., told analysts in May that they are looking for partners who can give the company access to new makets or who will pay handsomely for a minority stake in various Time Warner operations. In the meantime, Ross and Nicholas appear determined to run the company as if there were no $10.8 billion debt. Peter Appert, media analyst for C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc., wrote after the May meeting that while the company was aware of Wall Street's concerns with its high debt level, ``management's focus appears to be on expanding the business first and lowering the debt levels second.'' Time Warner has made a number of strategic deals over the past few months. It bought Lane Publishing, a California magazine publisher, for about $180 million in cash and stock. Senior magazine executives hope to use Lane as a springboard for regional publishing ventures in the West and Far East. In April, the company paid $19.5 million for a 19.5 percent stake in Six Flags Corp., which runs seven amusement parks and may offer a wider outlet for the Warner Bros. cast of cartoon characters such as Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. Time Warner spent $13.3 million in March for a 25 percent stake in a cellular radio venture with Price Communications. It offers an opportunity to get a close look at a new line of business. It entered a joint venture for a Scandinavian pay TV service, and is helping build the first modern movie theaters in the Soviet Union. Both markets offer appealing growth potential. Its most controversial move to date was a tentative agreement to guarantee $650 million in loans for Pathe Communications Inc.'s $1.2 billion bid for MGM-UA Communications Inc. The deal alarmed some analysts who felt Time Warner could not afford the extra debt. But Time Warner executives said the risk was well worth it because its loan guarantee would have been secured by the United Artists film library that they said was worth much more than $650 million. The issue has evidently become moot as the pact between Pathe and Time fell apart amid an exchange of lawsuits before any loans were arranged. ``From an outsider's perspective, maybe it was better that they didn't get involved,'' said Edward Atorino, media analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc. Time Warner also is investing millions in its core businesses. It launched a magazine, Entertainment Weekly, which some analysts say could lose $60 million before turning profitable, and a cable network, The Comedy Channel. The company also has cut back since Time obtained control of Warner last July. It sold the textbook company Scott, Foresman and Co. for $448 million last December. Its Southern Progress Corp. suspended publication of money-losing Southpoint magazine, a regional magazine, in May. Nonetheless, the company says the diversity of its businesses, which run from Time and Fortune magazines and Book-of-the-Month Club to music from Pasula Abdul and movies like ``Batman'' and ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' insulate it against reversals in any one business. Gordon Crawford, senior vice president at the research arm of Capital Group Inc., the single largest Time Warner stockholder with an 8 percent stake, said company management is doing fine and the market will eventually realize it. ``Their actions illustrate they are going to continue running the company in an aggressive fashion with a longterm point of view,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Takeover Law Evolves After Time Warner Milestone
With BC-Time Warner
DOC.TEXT: When the multibillion-dollar fight for Time Inc. landed in the Delaware courts last year, everyone who followed the case knew there was more at stake than just the outcome of a takeover battle. They were right. The legal precedent that emerged strengthened the takeover defenses of some of the nation's biggest firms and became a model for laws in other states. When the Ohio Legislature passed a new anti-takeover bill in April, lawmakers included a provision that has become known as the Time Warner Amendment: ``The selection of a time frame for the achievement of corporate goals shall be the responsibility of the directors.'' The provision codifies the Delaware Supreme Court's ruling that boards of directors are not under a duty to put aside their long-term goals in favor of a takeover bid that would give stockholders more money for their shares now. Leigh Trevor, a member of the Ohio State Bar Association who lobbied for the amendment's passage, said he and other corporate lawyers wanted ``to remove debate over that subject in court'' should an Ohio company find itself in a situation similar to Time's. In March 1989, Time and Warner Communications Inc. announced plans to merge in a stock swap valued at $18 billion. Then, in June, three weeks before shareholders were to vote on the deal, Paramount Communications Inc. launched a hostile $10.7 billion bid for Time alone. Time responded by beginning its own $14 billion tender offer for Warner, Paramount raised its bid to $12.2 billion and the companies went to court in Delaware, where all three were incorporated. Paramount argued that the Time board should be forced to seriously consider its bid, which would give shareholders immediate cash instead of the future profits promised by Time and Warner. Meanwhile, the would-be merger partners contended that their plans _ which culminated two years of negotiations _ should not have to be shunted aside just because a third party had put a higher offer on the table. In July, Delaware Chancery Court Judge William T. Allen and then the state Supreme Court upheld the right of the Time board to proceed with the combination with Warner and the creation of Time Warner Inc. In a written decision issued in February, Supreme Court Justice Henry R. Horsey said, ``A board of directors ... is not under any per se duty to maximize shareholder value in the short-term even in the context of a takeover.'' Legal scholars viewed the ruling as strengthening the hand of directors in takeover battles. The decision automatically added protection to other companies incorporated in Delaware, home to many of the country's biggest firms, including about half the Fortune 500. Other states look to Delaware for guidance on corporate law issues, so Ohio included the Delaware ruling in its statutes. ``We wanted to make it crystal clear if it is not already clear enough ... the time frame for achieving corporate objectives is a board decision,'' said Trevor, a partner with the law firm Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Cleveland. Critics of anti-takeover statutes tend to view laws such as the new Ohio provision as a means for entrenching management. But its supporters say this was no knee-jerk reaction to the Delaware ruling. ``If we cannot have the opportunity for long-term planning in publicly held American companies, we put ourselves at a disadvantage with foreign competitors whose legal systems do provide adequate time for long-term planning and implementation of long-term plans,'' Trevor said. ``We have been handing to our international competitors an advantage because they can look out at the horizon and over the hill and we can't,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday July 29

DOC.HEAD: Yields Fall on Two-Year Notes
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes fell in Wednesday's auction to the lowest level in seven months. The average yield was 8.07 percent, down from 8.41 percent at the last auction on June 26. It was the lowest rate since two-year notes averaged 7.71 percent on Dec. 19, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8 percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,987.30 A total of $11.7 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $40.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: General Motors Subsidiaries Report Mixed Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Two of General Motors Corp.'s three primary subsidiaries reported higher second-quarter earnings this year over last year, while its main defense contractor had sharply lower profits, the companies said Wednesday. GM reports earnings for its automotive operations Thursday. GM-Hughes Electronics Corp., the automaker's electronics and defense industry company, said its earnings for the second three-month period of this year dropped to $189.5 million or 47 cents a share, 21.1 percent below profits of $240.3 million or 60 cents a share in the same period last year. General Motors Acceptance Corp. and Electronic Data Systems Corp. reported second-quarter profits rose 12.2 percent and 19.5 percent, respectively. GM-Hughes said its revenues during the period rose to $3 billion from $2.8 billion during the same period a year ago. The company said the profit decrease was caused mainly by tax credits recorded in the second quarter of last year and by costs associated with new spacecraft products. During the quarter, GM-Hughes said it won new Defense Department contracts that include a $210 million order for two Navy communications satellites and a $155 million order from the Brazilian government for a telecommunications system. For the first six months of the year, when U.S. government orders decreased, GM-Hughes said it earned $372.3 million or 93 cents a share, compared with $450.4 million or $1.11 a share, a decline of 17.3 percent. The news was different at GM's financing and computer systems subsidiaries. GMAC said it earned $301.6 million during the second quarter, compared with $268.8 million during the same quarter a year ago. Lower short-term borrowing costs helped boost income from financing operations to $267 million during the quarter from $224 million in the year-ago period. For the first half of 1990, GMAC's profits rose slightly to $638 million compared with $625 million during the first six months of last year. EDS earnings continued their upward trend during the second quarter by increasing to $125.3 million or 52 cents a share, compared with $104.9 or 44 cents a share during the second quarter of last year. Revenues rose to $1.4 billion from $1.3 billion last year. During the quarter, EDS signed contracts with Westmoreland Coal Co. of Philadelphia and Westar Transmission Co., a subsidiary of American Oil and Gas Corp. In the first half of the year, EDS earned $235.1 million, or 98 cents a share, compared with $204.9 million, or 85 cents a share, during the first six months of 1989. Revenues for the January-June period this year were $2.8 billion compared with $2.6 billion during the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem, Allegheny Ludlum Profits Decline in 2nd Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem Steel Corp. on Wednesday reported a 74 percent slump in second-quarter earnings while Allegheny Ludlum Corp. posted a 38 percent plunge in its quarterly income. Both steelmakers blamed lower steel prices for part of the deterioration. Bethlehem Steel said it earned $21.9 million, or 21 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30, down from $84.1 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. Sales dropped about 10 percent to $1.28 billion from $1.43 billion during the second quarter of 1989. Allegheny Ludlum, the nation's largest specialty steel maker, said for the three months ended July 1 profits were $22.6 million, or 68 cents a share, down from $36.7 million, or $1.08 per share, in the same period of 1989. Sales fell 11 percent to $295.99 million from $333.81 million a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem Steel
DOC.TEXT: Lower steel prices and shipments and higher operating costs at Bethlehem Steel's Sparrows Point plant near Baltimore caused the decline, chairman Walter F. Williams said in a news release. Steel shipments were reported down about 13 percent, primarily in semifinished steel shipments to other steel producers. The company said shipments are not expected to slip further during the third quarter because of recent strong orders from the automotive market and declining steel imports. Costs rose at Sparrows Point because of planned outages of the large blast furnace and the hot strip mill for maintenance and modernization, the company said. A scheduled 25-day outage at the hot strip mill during August and continued coke oven repairs at Sparrows Point will dampen third-quarter results, but ultimately enhance overall performance, Williams said. For the first six months, Bethlehem Steel netted $43.2 million, or 41 cents a share, on sales of $2.49 billion. In the first half of 1989, Bethlehem Steel reported income of $148.8 million, or $1.81 a share, on sales of $2.84 billion. During the second quarter of 1989, results included $50 million of unusual charges for restructuring the company's BethForge Division. Net income also was reduced in the first half of 1989 by $55 million of restructuring charges related to the Baltimore Marine Division. Operating results at both divisions improved during the second quarter this year, the company said. The company warned against approval of legislation pending in Congress that would stiffen controls under the Clean Air Act. ``We believe that certain features of the bill concerning air toxics are not based on sound scientific data and available technology and, if enacted, could impose significant, unwarranted costs on domestic steelmakers in the future,'' Williams said.
DOC.HEAD: Allegheny Ludlum
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny Ludlum said its profit drop reflected lower prices, which were pushed down by competition and increased exports of semi-finished electrical steel. In the first half of 1990, profits fell 35 percent to $45.9 million, or $1.37 per share, compared with $71 million, or $2.10 per share, in the same period of 1989. Sales fell nearly 18 percent in the first half to $575.4 million from $697.7 million, the company said. ``While the future overall direction of the economy is unclear, so far, market demand for our specialty materials this year has surpassed our expectations and new market applications continue to be developed,'' President Robert P. Bozzone said. He said the cost of a new four-year labor agreement, effective April 1, also contributed to the decline in second-quarter earnings.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday, with investors worried about British corporate earnings and a drop in the pound. The day began on a positive note, with prices charging to session peaks. But the advance couldn't be sustained, dealers said, because of worries about corporate profits. Investors also were agitated by a sharp drop in sterling which was pressured by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major's failure Tuesday, during an economic debate in the House of Commons, to mention plans for the pound's entry into Europe's exchange rate mechanism. Instead, the chancellor commented that inflation could go yet higher. ``The market is realizing that (entry) will take longer than anticipated,'' one market maker said. ``Some of the euphoria is evaporating.'' At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 3.8 points, or 0.2 percent, at 2,364.7, above the session low of 2,363.1 but off the day's high of 2,382.5. The Financial Times 30-share index was off 1.0 point at 1,865.7. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 2.14 points to close at 1,275.36. Volume came to 427.5 million shares compared with 385.7 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Throws Out Some Claims, Allows Others Against Cigarette Company
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts' highest court threw out parts of a lawsuit Wednesday against a tobacco company whose cigarettes were bought by minors, but allowed some claims to continue. The Supreme Judicial Court granted summary judgment in favor of Philip Morris Cos. Inc., dismissing claims that the company should be held liable for the fact that convenience stores sold cigarettes to the two plaintiffs, Theresa Kyte and Sean Cann. But the court said the plaintiffs could pursue their claims that the company engaged in a deceptive act in violation of state consumer protection laws. The court also declined to dismiss a claim that the company breached an implied warranty that its products were safe. A Middlesex County Superior Court judge had denied the company's motions for summary judgment. ``You only need one (claim) to win,'' said Edward Greer, an attorney representing the plaintiffs. But Hadrian Katz, an attorney for Philip Morris, said the court's decision effectively wiped out the plaintiffs' case. ``There's nothing left,'' he said. Tobacco liability cases have been brought against cigarette companies in the past, but rarely have met success. In 1988, a federal jury in New Jersey awarded the first damages against a cigarette company, giving $400,000 to a man whose wife died of lung cancer. But an appeals court overturned the award this year and ordered a new trial. In Boston this year, a federal jury found American Tobacco Co. should not be held liable for the cancer death of a Cambridge man. Greer said unlike the previous cases, his case focuses on minors who do not have the same ability as adults to gather information and make decisions. Kyte, of Waltham, started smoking at age 12, and Cann, of Brookline, at age 15. Each smoked Marlboro and Parliament cigarettes, made by Philip Morris. They claim they repeatedly bought the cigarettes at convenience stores, even though state law prohibits selling tobacco to minors. In their suit, they said the company conspired to sell the cigarettes to minors through the convenience stores. But the high court rejected the argument. ``We have accepted the principle that, in particular circumstances, a supplier may be liable for harm caused after the supplier knowingly placed property in the hands of an incompetent person,'' the court said. ``Our cases have not, however, held a manufacturer of a product liable in negligence simply because some third party unlawfully placed that product in the hands of a minor and, as a result, the minor or some other person was harmed,'' the decision said. In a dissenting opinion, Chief Justice Paul Liacos said the plaintiffs raised legitimate issues and should have been allowed to present more evidence to support their claims. The court allowed two other claims to proceed. One is that Philip Morris violated state consumer protection laws through a ``pattern and practice of sales to minors,'' Greer said. He said he would show that Philip Morris profits from sales to minors and targets its advertising toward young consumers. The second claim accuses the company of breaching an implied warranty that its products are ``fit for intended use, free from defect, safe to consume and non-carcinogenic and non-addictive.'' To make this case, the plaintiffs claim a design defect specifically with Marlboro and Parliament cigarettes, rather than claiming all cigarettes are inherently defective. Philip Morris' Katz said the claims of unique design defects were ``nonsense.''

DOC.HEAD: British Aerospace Decides To Appeal EC's Rover Decision
DOC.TEXT: British Aerospace PLC said Wednesday it would appeal a European Commission decision ordering the British company to repay illegal government subsidies it received when it bought the formerly state-owned Rover car maker. British Aerospace said it would appeal to the European Court of Justice the order to repay 44.4 million pounds, or about $80 million, of hidden sweeteners. The company said that following ``a careful review'' and in light of independent professional advice, it would file an appeal to protect shareholders' interests and test its rights before the court. The company said it has informed the government and shareholders of its decision. The government has said it accepted the EC's June decision but was disputing the amount of sweeteners to be returned. British Aerospace bought Rover from the government for 150 million pounds, or $272 million, in July 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Rohr Gets $1 Billion Contract from Airbus
DOC.TEXT: Airbus Industrie will pay Rohr Industries Inc. $1 billion to supply another 800 jetliners with engine nacelle systems, the aerodynamic structures that surround jet engines, Rohr said Wednesday. Rohr made a deal in 1984 with the European plane-building consortium to provide nacelle systems for 200 Airbus A320 jetliners. Under Wednesday's follow-on agreement it will also supply nacelle systems for 800 A321 planes beginning in early 1992. The A321 is a stretch version of the A320, and Rohr said the systems will have many similarities. It was the second $1 billion agreement announced this year by Rohr, an aerospace component supplier based in Chula Vista, near San Diego. Rohr said in March it had been awarded a $1 billion contract to provide the engine nacelle system for McDonnell Douglas' MD-90 airliner.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting Likely to End Early, Hard Work Remains
DOC.TEXT: A meeting of senior trade negotiators is expected to end Thursday with agreement on the need for intense efforts to overcome barriers in crucial talks aimed at a more open global economy. But the outcome of the four-day meeting leaves rifts between the United States and the European Community, and between industrialized countries and the Third World. David Woods, spokesman for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said Wednesday that the meeting would likely endorse a package of proposals aimed at liberalizing trade in 15 key areas. However, he said a number of high-level officials attending the 105-nation Trade Negotiations Committee meeting had voiced disappointment that more progress had not been made on narrowing differences. The proposals are described as ``profile'' accords. Full agreements are meant to be finalized at the start of December when the Uruguay Round of trade talks concludes. The aim of the negotiations, launched in 1986, is to reduce barriers to trade and set new standards in important areas such as banking services. Many countries have warned that failure of the talks will lead to a dangerous surge of protectionism. But the ``profiles'' demonstrate how much work remains, little more than four months before the deadline. The proposal on liberalizing trade in textiles, for example, includes conflicting policy options backed by the United States, the EC and Third World textile exporters. The text on intellectual property rights such as patents also reflects the same three-way split. A compromise document on agriculture lays out clear proposals for cutting domestic farm supports and import barriers, and says export subsidies should be reduced most of all. But the United States and agricultural exporters like Australia still insist on the elimination of export subsidies, while the EC has made it plain it will defend their use. Woods said the meeting had met the end-of-July target for profile accords, even though some countries ``may not agree that what we have achieved are satisfactory final profiles.'' He said the final session Thursday was expected to agree on a way to intensify the negotiations. The meeting, comprised mainly of officials just below ministerial rank, was originally scheduled to last until Friday. It had been widely billed as a chance to boost progress in the most contentious areas. Chief EC negotiator Hugo Paemen told a press conference that senior officials were likely to travel to Geneva for another meeting Oct. 8 and then be on ``permanent standby'' until the December ministerial gathering in Brussels. He described the package of proposals as a ``strong basis to start from.'' Paemen's optimism contrasted with formal statements from developing countries. Brazil, Colombia, Mexico and China were among those criticizing lack of headway in efforts to reduce import duties and open markets. The United States, Australia and Canada all voiced concern in speeches Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Competition Expected for U.S. Rice Farmers
DOC.TEXT: U.S. rice farmers can expect competition for world markets to heat up in the coming year, an Agriculture Department report said Wednesday. Vietnam, the report said, has cut into Thailand's markets by selling at ``prices substantially below'' those offered by Thai exporters. Thailand is the world's largest rice exporter. ``Recently, Thailand announced an export subsidy scheme in an effort to increase exports, but the response has been weak,'' the report said. Thailand's market share dropped from 40 percent in 1989 to 31 forecast for 1990. ``It is expected that Thailand will aggressively compete with Vietnam to regain market share in 1991,'' the report said. The U.S. global market share is forecast to fall to about 18 percent in 1991 from 20 percent the past two years. Analysts said tight supplies and relatively high prices ``may hinder U.S. competitiveness'' in some foreign markets.

DOC.HEAD: Gleacher, Morgan Stanley Forming New Firm
DOC.TEXT: Eric Gleacher, who left Morgan Stanley & Co. to form his own mergers and acquisitions firm, is combining his business with that of Morgan Grenfell Group PLC, the London-based merchant banking company, it was announced Wednesday. The new firm, Gleacher Morgan Grenfell Inc. will handle U.S. mergers and acquisitions and what are called cross-border transactions, those involving U.S. and foreign parties. Gleacher Morgan Grenfell will operate as the U.S. arm of Morgan Grenfell, which is a subsidiary of the Deutsche Bank Group. Gleacher said his firm will be a partner to Morgan Grenfell but independent of the merchant banker. ``It's not like me going back to work for Morgan Stanley,'' he said. After opening his own firm earlier this year, Gleacher advised ConAgra Inc. on its $3.8 billion purchase of Beatrice Co. and expected to expand his business overseas to take advantage of the growing number of cross-border transactions. He said in a telephone interview Wednesday that it had become ``clear to me that we could never accomplish on our own what we could accomplish as partners with Morgan Grenfell and Deutsche Bank.'' While at Morgan Stanley, which is not connected with Morgan Grenfell, Gleacher advised Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. on its $24.53 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES name of beer to ``Bud Dry'' in 8th graf
DOC.HEAD: Brewer Reports Record Profits And Sales For Quarter, First Half
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Cos. reported record profits and sales for the second quarter and the first half of the year Wednesday as new brands pumped up growth for the world's largest brewer. In the three months ended June 30, profits were $257.5 million, or 90 cents a share, up 10.2 percent from $233.7 million, or 82 cents a share, in the corresponding 1989 quarter. Sales of $3 billion were 11.5 percent higher than the $2.69 billion in last year's second quarter. Two beers introduced this year _ Bud Dry and Busch Light _ led the way for the big increases in the quarter, along with the strong performance of the company's four other light beers. ``We are extremely pleased with our beer company's performance,'' said Auust A. Busch III, chairman and president of the company. The company sold 22.3 million barrels of beer to wholesalers in the quarter, compared with 21.4 million in the same period a year ago. Beer sales in the first half were 42.4 million, up from 41 million in the same period a year earlier. Busch has said that he wants the company to achieve a 50 percent market share over the next few years and one way to do that is to introduce new products. Since January, the company has rolled out Bud Dry and Busch Light nationally along with a non-alcoholic beer called O'Douls. The company is also testing another new beer, Busch Draft. The company also was helped by higher profits in several other subsidiaries including Campbell Taggart, Inc., a wholesale bakery and food products company, and the Metal Container Corp., which make aluminum cans. For the first six months of the year, Anheuser-Busch had profits of $440 million, or $1.54 a share, a 9.8 percent increase over the $400.8 million, or $1.40 a share, in the first half of 1989. Sales of $5.59 billion were up 9.9 percent from $5.09 percent in the first two quarters of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Finish Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy prices pulled back Wednesday amid some modest profit-taking as traders awaited developments at an OPEC meeting. Crude prices opened firmly on the New York Mercantile Exchange in anticipation of what might be accomplished at the meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Ministers from the 13-member cartel are expected to negotiate new production quotas in an effort to raise world oil prices. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. energy broker Brian Tagler said the lack of fresh news from the oil cartel's gathering gave traders an opportunity to sell and collect profits amassed during the oil market's recent advance. He said after a preliminary session adjourned Wednesday without any major announcements, crude prices weakened. The contract for September delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, fell 18 cents to $20.38 a 42-gallon barrel after rising 6 cents on Tuesday. The contract had spurted 44 cents on Monday to the highest level for a near-month contract since April. Contracts for delivery during October through December also declined. Prices for refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc followed crude prices down. Unleaded regular gasoline for August delivery, which edged 0.07 cent lower on Tuesday, lost 0.24 cent on Wednesday and settled at 63.04 a gallon. Later contract months gained. The August contract for home heating oil, which advanced 0.82 cent on Tuesday, tumbled 0.56 cent to settle at 56.76 cents a gallon. Subsequent contracts posted similar losses. In natural gas trading, the September contract settled at $1.440 per 1,000 cubic feet compared with $1.450 Wednesday. Contracts for later delivery were mixed.
